passage_content: ולדרכינונבין דברי המכילתא הנ"ל (קושיא ג') לא הביאן הקב"ה דרך פשוטה לארץ ישראל אלא דרך המדבר, אמר הקב"ה אם אני מביא עכשיו ישראל לארץ, מיד מחזיקים אדם בשדהו וכו' והןבטלים מן התורה, אלא אקיפם במדבר מ' שנה שיהיו אוכלין מן וכו' והתורה נבללת בגופן וכו' ולכאורה אין זה טעם המבואר בכתוב פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה ושבו מצרימה, אמנם לדרכנו הוא ענין אחד עם טעם המבואר בכתוב, ואפשר דמ"ש פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה וגו' סובב על מלחמת ל"א מלכים כקושיתנו לעיל (קושיא א') ואלמלי נכנסו לארץ ישראל בדרך פשוטה לא יהי' התורה נבללת בגופן, ואיתא להאי חששא פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה וירצו לשוב למצרים, ע"כ הקיפן הקב"ה דרך המדבר, וע"י שיתעצמו בעצם התוה"ק ישיגו רצון הבוי"ת ולא ירצו לשוב עוד מצרימה.
translation: And according to our way of understanding the words of the aforementioned Mechilta (question 3), the Holy One, blessed be He, did not bring Israel to the Land of Israel through a straightforward path, but rather through the desert. The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "If I bring Israel to the Land now, immediately a person will hold onto his field, etc., and they will be distracted from the Torah. Rather, I will encircle them in the desert for forty years so that they will eat from, etc., and the Torah will be absorbed within them, etc." And seemingly, this is not the reason explained in the verse, "lest the people regret when they see war and return to Egypt." However, according to our way, it is one matter with the reason explained in the verse. It is possible that what is said, "lest the people regret when they see war," refers to the war of the thirty-one kings, as our question above (question 1) indicates. And had they entered the Land of Israel through a straightforward path, the Torah would not have been absorbed within them. And this concern is stated: "lest the people regret when they see war and wish to return to Egypt." Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, encircled them through the desert, and by strengthening themselves in the essence of the Holy Torah, they will achieve the will of the Creator, blessed be He, and will not wish to return to Egypt anymore.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the divine strategy of leading the Israelites through the desert rather than directly to the Promised Land. This approach was intended to prevent the people from becoming preoccupied with their possessions and neglecting the Torah. By enduring the hardships of the desert for forty years, the Israelites would internalize the teachings of the Torah, strengthening their commitment to God and reducing the likelihood of returning to Egypt out of fear of conflict. Ultimately, this process was designed to ensure that their connection to the Torah would be deeply embedded within them.

passage_content: באופןאחר יתבארו הדקדוקים ודברי המדרשים הנ"ל, בהקדם לפרש מאמה"כ ולא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים כי קרוב הוא כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה ושבו מצרימה, פרש"י ז"ל פן ינחם יחשבו מחשבה על שיצאו ויתנו לב לשוב עכ"ל, וכתב הרא"ם ז"ל שכל לשון ניחום שבמקרא לשון מחשבה אחרת כמו שפירשו בפסוק (בראשית ו') וינחם ד' כי עשה את האדם, אף כאן יתהפכו ממחשבתן הראשונה שהיתה לצאת ממצרים ויתנו לב לשוב עכ"ל הרא"ם ז"ל, אמנם מלת ינחם סובל ג' משמעות שונות, והפסוק שהביא הרא"ם לראי' וינחם ד' כי עשה את האדם, גם שם פרש"י ז"ל ב' פירושים נחמה היתה לפניו וכו', דבר אחר נהפכה מחשבתו של מקום ממדת רחמים למדת הדין, עוד ישמש הכתוב במלת ינחם על לשון הנהגה כמ"ש וינחם אל מחוז חפצם, ואף כאן ולא נחם אלקים פרש"י ולא נהגם כמו לך נחה את העם וכו'
translation: In another way, the nuances and words of the aforementioned Midrashim will be clarified, by first explaining the verse, "And God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, for it was near; for God said, 'Lest the people regret when they see war and return to Egypt.'" Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that "lest they regret" means they might think of returning. Thus, the Ra'ahm, of blessed memory, wrote that every expression of regret in the Scriptures implies a different thought, as they explained in the verse, "And the Lord regretted that He had made man." Here too, they would turn from their initial thought of leaving Egypt and would consider returning, as the Ra'ahm, of blessed memory, stated. However, the word "regret" carries three different meanings, and the verse that the Ra'ahm brought as a proof, "And the Lord regretted that He had made man," Rashi, of blessed memory, also explained in two ways: "It was a regret before Him," etc. Another explanation is that the thought of the Holy One, blessed be He, changed from the attribute of mercy to the attribute of judgment. The term "regret" can also be used in the sense of guidance, as it is written, "And He guided them to their desired destination." And here too, "And God did not lead them" means, as Rashi explains, "He did not guide them," like "You shall guide the people," etc.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine guidance and the potential for human thought to shift in response to challenges, as illustrated by the biblical verse regarding God's decision not to lead the Israelites through the land of the Philistines. It highlights the idea that "נחם" (to comfort or to change one's mind) can signify a change in divine intention or guidance, reflecting a deeper theological understanding of God's relationship with humanity. The text emphasizes that God's concern is for the people's spiritual state, fearing they might reconsider their escape from Egypt upon encountering war. Ultimately, it illustrates the dynamic interplay between divine providence and human perception in the context of faith and redemption.

passage_content: והנהכתב האוהחה"ק להלן עה"פ ותן שמה מלא העומר מן והנח אותו לפני ד' למשמרת וגו' כי פירוש למשמרת סובלת ב' דרכים, ומדרכי התורה כל שהתיבה תסבול ב' דברים, שקולים במשמעותה תכוין אל הב' כי איזה מהם תוציא וכו' עיי"ש לענינו, וכמו"כ לעניננו שמלת נחם סובלת ג' משמעות שונים, יתכן שנתכוין הכתוב על שלשתן, כי איזה מהם תוציא, ועד"ז יתיישבו כל דברי רז"ל והדקדוקים שבענין שנפרטו לעיל, דהנה תועלת וטובה גדולה נצמח לכל דורות ישראל, ממה שהקיפם הקב"ה לישראל דרך המדבר, כמשה"כ (ירמי' ב') הלוך וקראת באזני ירושלים לאמר זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך אהבת כלולותיך לכתך אחרי במדבר בארץ לא זרועה, ובגמ' סנהדרין (ק"י ע"ב) דרשו רז"ל דאף אחרים באים בזכותם לעוה"ב והזכות הזה עומדת לישראל בכל הדורות וכמ"ש רש"י ז"ל בירמי' שם וז"ל תאוותי לרחם עליכם כי זכרתי חסד נעוריך וכו', ומה הוא חסד נעוריך לכתך אחר שלוחי משה ואהרן מארץ נושבת יצאתם למדבר ואין צדה לדרך כי האמנתם בי, וסיים הכתוב כי בזכות זאת קדש ישראל לד' ראשית תבואתה כל אוכליו יאשמו רעה תבוא אליהם נאם ד', וזהו טעם מספיק שהוצרכו ישראל לסבב דרך המדבר, כי אלמלי הלכו דרך ארץ פלשתים בארץ נושבת, הי' נשלל מהם הנסיון הגדול, וראתה חכמתו ית' שבזכות הנסיון הזה יתקיימו ישראל בגלותם ויבואו לעוה"ב, לכך הקיפם דרך המדבר ועי"ז זכו לעצמם ולדורות הבאים.
translation: And behold, the holy writing below, on the verse "And place there the full measure of the omer and set it before the Lord for safekeeping," etc., for the interpretation of "for safekeeping" bears two meanings, and according to the ways of the Torah, whenever a term can bear two meanings, it should be understood in both ways, as to which one will be taken out, etc. See there for its relevance. Likewise, concerning our matter, the word "nacham" bears three different meanings; it is possible that the writing refers to all three, as to which one will be taken out. And similarly, all the words of our Sages and the nuances in the matter that were detailed above will be clarified. Behold, a great benefit and goodness arise for all generations of Israel from the fact that the Holy One, blessed be He, surrounded Israel with a path through the desert, as it is written (Jeremiah 2): "Go and proclaim in the ears of Jerusalem, saying: I remember for you the kindness of your youth, the love of your betrothals, when you went after Me in the wilderness, in a land not sown." And in the Gemara, Sanhedrin (K.Y. 72b), our Sages expounded that even others come in their merit to the World to Come, and this merit stands for Israel in all generations, as Rashi, blessed be his memory, wrote there in Jeremiah: "My desire is to have mercy on you, for I remembered the kindness of your youth," etc. And what is the kindness of your youth? "When you went after the messengers of Moses and Aaron, from a settled land you went out to the desert, and there was no provision for the way, for you believed in Me." And the writing concludes: "And because of this merit, Israel was sanctified to the Lord, the first of His harvest; all who eat of it will be guilty of evil coming upon them, says the Lord." And this is a sufficient reason why Israel needed to be surrounded by a path through the desert, for had they gone through the land of the Philistines, in a settled land, they would have been deprived of the great trial, and the wisdom of the Blessed One saw that through the merit of this trial, Israel would endure in their exile and come to the World to Come. Therefore, He surrounded them with a path through the desert, and through this, they merited for themselves and for future generations.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' journey through the desert, emphasizing that this experience was divinely orchestrated to instill faith and resilience in future generations. It highlights the multifaceted meanings of the term "נחם" (to comfort) and suggests that the trials faced in the wilderness were essential for the spiritual development of the Jewish people. This journey not only solidified their relationship with God but also ensured that the merit of their faith would benefit them and their descendants throughout history. Ultimately, the text underscores the idea that challenges can lead to greater spiritual rewards and continuity for the Jewish people.

passage_content: ואפ"לכי הטעם הנ"ל נרמז ג"כ בכתוב פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה ושבו מצרימה, ובטעם המובא במכילתא הנ"ל שהסיבן הקב"ה דרך המדבר, כדי שיהי' התורה נבללת בגופן. וכל אלה הטעמים יתאחדו לאחדים ועל קוטב א' יסובבו, ויתבאר בהקדם דברי המכילתא פ' בשלח כי ד' נלחם להם במצרים, ולא במצרים לבד אלא בכל המצירין להם לישראל לדורות וכו', לכך נאמר כי ד' נלחם להם במצרים, הרי דמצרים שם הכולל לכל האומות המצירים לישראל, וכן דרשו רז"ל בפסיקתא זוטא (פ' בא סי"ב) למה נקרא שמה מצרים על שם שהצירו את ישראל בה,ולפי"ז כל המצירים נקראים בשם זה, והוא שם הכולל לכולן ע"ש תכונתם ופעולתם, אלא שקראם הכתוב בשמם הפרטי להגדרת סימניהם.
translation: And although the aforementioned reason is also hinted at in the verse "lest the people regret when they see war and return to Egypt," and in the reason brought in the aforementioned Mechilta that the Holy One, blessed be He, led them through the desert so that the Torah would be absorbed in their essence. All these reasons will unite into one and revolve around a single pole, and it will be clarified in advance by the words of the Mechilta in Parashat Beshalach that the Holy One, blessed be He, fought for them in Egypt, and not only in Egypt but in all the oppressors of Israel throughout the generations, etc. Therefore, it is said that the Holy One, blessed be He, fought for them in Egypt, which indicates that Egypt is the term that encompasses all the nations that oppress Israel, and thus our Sages of blessed memory expounded in Pesikta Zutah (Parashat Bo, section 12) why it is called Egypt, because they oppressed Israel there. According to this, all the oppressors are called by this name, which is a term that includes all of them according to their nature and actions, except that the scripture calls them by their specific names to define their characteristics.
summary: The passage discusses the divine orchestration of events to prevent the Israelites from returning to Egypt out of fear during warfare, emphasizing that God leads them through the desert to integrate the Torah into their essence. It highlights that God's intervention in Egypt symbolizes His ongoing protection against all nations that oppress Israel throughout history. The term "Egypt" serves as a collective representation of all oppressors, reflecting their shared characteristics and actions against the Jewish people. This theological insight underscores the unity of divine providence and the enduring struggle of Israel against its adversaries.

passage_content: ופירשתיבזה מ"ד בתנחומא (פ' תצא ס"ה) זכור את אשר עשה לך עמלק וגו', ר' תנחומא פתח זכרוניכם משלי אפר לגבי חומר גביכם (איוב י"ג) אמר הקב"ה לישראל אותן ב' זכירות שכתבתילכם בתורה הוו זהירין בהן, תמחה את זכר עמלק זכור את אשר עשה לך עמלק וכו', אם זכיתם אתם בניו של אברהם אבינו וכו', ואם לאו לגבי חומר גביכם, התקינו עצמכם לשעבודה של מצרים עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה צ"ב דהרי הבטיח הבוי"ת לישראל לא תוסיפון לראותם עוד עד עולם, והבטחה לטובה לא יתבטל בשום פנים, ואיך אמר התקינו עצמכם לשיעבודה של מצרים, וכבר ביארנוהו באופנים שונים (עיין בדרושים לפ' זכור) ולדרכנו יתבאר עפ"י פשוטו דהכוונה על גלויות בין האומות, דמצרים הוא שם הכולל לכל המצירים לישראל, ועד"ז יתפרש לעניננו במאמה"כ פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה ושבו מצרימה, שזו הי' תקנה לדורות, ולא בשביל חשש של אותו הדור הסיבן הקב"ה דרך המדבר, כדי למנוע חזרתן לארץ מצרים, דא"א שישובו למצרים נגד רצונו ית', והקב"ה הזהירם מלשוב בדרך הזה לעולם, אולם טעם הסיבן דרך המדבר הי' בשביל תקנת דורות העתידים חלושי כח. שלא יכלו לעמוד בקשרי המלחמה נגד נסיונות העצומים שיעמדו ויתגברו לעומתם, ע"כ הכין הבוי"ת לפניהם זכותם של דור המדבר, וכח האמונה החזקה של לכתך אחרי במדבר, הושתל על ידיהם גם בדורות העתידים.
translation:
And this is explained in the Midrash Tanchuma (Parashat Tetzaveh, §65): "Remember what Amalek did to you," etc. Rabbi Tanchuma opened, "Your memories are like the ashes of your back" (Job 13). The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Israel: "Those two remembrances that I have written for you in the Torah, be careful with them: 'You shall obliterate the memory of Amalek' and 'Remember what Amalek did to you,' etc. If you merit, you are the children of Abraham our forefather, etc. But if not, you are like the ashes of your back. Prepare yourselves for the servitude of Egypt." Thus concludes the Midrash. 

At first glance, this is difficult to understand, for the Blessed Creator has promised Israel, "You shall no longer see them again forever," and a promise for good cannot be nullified in any way. How then can it say, "Prepare yourselves for the servitude of Egypt"? We have already explained this in various ways (see the discourses on Parashat Zachor), and according to our path, it can be understood simply that the intention is regarding exiles among the nations, for Egypt is a term that encompasses all those who oppress Israel. Similarly, it can be interpreted in our context regarding the verse, "Lest the people regret when they see war and return to Egypt," for this was a provision for future generations, and not because of the concern of that generation. The Holy One, Blessed be He, led them through the desert to prevent their return to the land of Egypt, for it is impossible for them to return to Egypt against His will. The Holy One, Blessed be He, warned them never to return by that way. However, the reason for leading them through the desert was for the rectification of future generations who would be weak in strength, who would not be able to withstand the ties of war against the immense trials that would arise and overpower them. Therefore, the Blessed Creator prepared for them the merit of the generation of the desert, and the strong faith of "I led you through the desert" was instilled in them for future generations as well.
summary: The passage discusses the dual commandments of remembering and erasing the memory of Amalek, emphasizing their significance for the Jewish people. It addresses the apparent contradiction between God's promise that Israel would never see Egypt again and the warning to prepare for potential enslavement, interpreting Egypt as a metaphor for all nations that oppress Israel. The text highlights that the journey through the desert was divinely orchestrated to instill a strong faith and resilience in future generations, ensuring they would have the spiritual strength to face trials and tribulations. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of maintaining faith and the legacy of the ancestors in overcoming challenges.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבאר הפסוק פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה וגו', פרש"י ז"ל כגון מלחמת וירד העמלקי והכנעני, ובמכילתא דר' ישמעאל בראותם מלחמה זו מלחמת עמלק שנא' וירד העמלקי וגו' (במדבר י"ד), דבר אחר זו מלחמת בני אפרים וכו', דכתיב בני אפרים נושקי רומי קשת הפכו ביום קרב וגו' (תהלים ע"ח) מפני שלא שמרו ברית האלקים וגו' עברו על הקץ ועל השבועה עכ"ד המכילתא, וכבר הבאנו לעיל (בדרוש הקדום), קושית המפרשים ז"ל מדוע לא נקטו רז"ל ויבא עמלק וילחם עם ישראל ברפידים, שהי' סמוך ליציאתם ממצרים, ועמלק בא מארצו להלחם עמהם, משא"כ שם הזהירם הקב"ה אל תעלו כי אין ד' בקרבכם ולא תנגפו לפני אויביכם, וא"כ הי' מקום להנצל מן המלחמה, ואין כ"כ האי חששא של פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה גם במלחמת בני אפרים היתה גרמת המלחמה על ידיהם ע"י שיצאו שלא ברשות, ואין נפק"מ בזה בין דרך רחוק לקרוב, וכמו"כ יזדמן גם אם יסבו דרך המדבר, ולדרכינו ירמוז כל זה לדורות העתידים והבוי"ת מגיד מראשית אחרית שיזדמן להם נסיונות כאלו, בראותם מלחמה כגון וירד העמלקי והכנעני וגו', וכגון מלחמת בני אפרים, שגרמת המלחמה הי' ע"י שעברו על הקץ ועל השבועה והתגרות באומות לפני הזמן, ובעוה"ר חטא הזה מצוי גם בדורנו וזה גורם לאריכת הגלות, וז"ש כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה, וכפרש"י והרא"ם ז"ל שיחשבו מחשבה אחרת ויתהפכו ממחשבתן הראשונה, היינו כח האמונה הגדולה שהי"ל ביציאתם ממצרים, ושבו מצרימה שזה יגרום אריכת הגלות ויתוסף כח לשונאי ישראל להיות מצירים לישראל כמ"ש רז"ל שעל חטא זה של דחיקת הקץ אמר הקב"ה הריני מתיר את בשרכם וכו', ולטעם זה הסיבן הקב"ה דרך המדבר והיקיפם מ' שנה טרם נכנסו לארץ, ודור המדבר דור דיעה שמרו את הברית והשבועה ולא דחקו את הקץ (חוץ מהערב רב שהם היו המעפילים) וכח האמונה זו הושתל על ידיהם לדורות העתידים, גם זכותם יעמוד להגן על כל דורות ישראל כאמרז"ל, וזהו טעם הסיבן דרך המדבר.
translation: And similarly, the verse is explained: "Lest the people regret when they see war," Rashi, of blessed memory, interprets it as referring to the war of Amalek and the Canaanite. And in the Mekilta of Rabbi Ishmael, it states that this war refers to the war of Amalek, as it is written, "And Amalek came down" (Numbers 14). Another interpretation is that this refers to the war of the children of Ephraim, as it is written, "The children of Ephraim, armed with bows, turned back in the day of battle" (Psalms 78) because they did not keep the covenant of God, etc. They transgressed the appointed time and the oath, thus concludes the Mekilta. We have already brought above (in the ancient discourse) the question of the commentators, of blessed memory, why our sages did not mention that Amalek came and fought with Israel at Rephidim, which was close to their departure from Egypt, and Amalek came from his land to fight with them. In contrast, there God warned them, "Do not ascend, for the Lord is not among you, and you will fall before your enemies." Therefore, there was room to be saved from the war, and the concern of "Lest the people regret when they see war" is not so significant, as even in the war of the children of Ephraim, the cause of the war was by their own doing, as they went out without permission. There is no difference in this between a long way and a short way, and similarly, it could happen even if they took a route through the desert. And all this hints to future generations, and the blessed Creator reveals from the beginning the end, that they will encounter such trials when they see war, such as "And Amalek came down" and the war of the children of Ephraim, where the cause of the war was due to their transgressing the appointed time and the oath and provoking the nations before the time. And, woe to us, this sin is also prevalent in our generation, and this causes the prolongation of the exile. Therefore, it is said, "For God said, 'Lest the people regret when they see war,'" and as Rashi and the Ra'ah of blessed memory explain, they will think another thought and turn away from their original thought, which is the great power of faith that they had at their departure from Egypt, and they will return to Egypt, which will cause the prolongation of the exile and will give strength to the enemies of Israel to oppress Israel, as our sages of blessed memory said that for this sin of pushing the end, God said, "Behold, I permit your flesh," etc. For this reason, God led them through the desert and surrounded them for forty years before they entered the land. The generation of the desert was a generation of knowledge; they kept the covenant and the oath and did not push the end (except for the mixed multitude, who were the ones who caused the ascent). This power of faith was implanted by them for future generations, and their merit will stand to protect all generations of Israel, as our sages of blessed memory said. This is the reason for their being led through the desert.
summary: The passage discusses the concern that the Israelites might lose faith and return to Egypt upon witnessing war, referencing the battles with Amalek and the Ephraimites as examples of the consequences of not adhering to God's covenant. It emphasizes the importance of maintaining strong faith and not hastening the redemption, as doing so can lead to prolonged exile and suffering. The text highlights that the generation of the desert upheld their covenant with God, which serves as a protective merit for future generations. Ultimately, it underscores the significance of faith and patience in the face of trials, as well as the dangers of acting prematurely against divine timing.

passage_content: אואפשר שירמוז הכתוב על מלחמת היצר, ועפימ"ש האלשיך הק' (סו"פ בשלח) כי כל שרי עם ועם קל לפניו ית' להפילם כמו רגע, ומיד נופלים אומותם, אך שר עמלק אין מפלתו כי אם ביד ישראל וכו', הוא השטן הוא הס"מ הוא יצה"ר, ובכל חטא ועון אשר נחטא אנו מחזיקים ומאשרים אותו כנודע, באופן שא"א להפילו ארצה, אם לא שזכינו מכל עונותינו וכו', כי אז יכנע וימחה מן העולם, וז"א כי מחה אתה את השר על השמים, ואח"כ אמחה את זכר עמלק מתחת השמים, הפך יתר האומות שהוא ית' מפיל השר משמים תחלה וכו', וע"כ צריך זכירה זו בלב כל איש ישראל, למען ידעו כי בדבר הזה תלוי' גאולתם וטובתם לעולם עכ"ד ז"ל, ובזה יל"פ דברי התנחומא הנ"ל, זכור את אשר עשה לך עמלק וגו', אמר הקב"ה לישראל אותן ב' זכירות, תמחה את זכר עמלק זכור את אשר עשה לך עמלק הוו זהירין בהן, אם זכיתם אתם בניו של א"א וכו', היינו שתהיו ראויים להתייחס אחריו שלחםביצרו ועם כל העולם עוע"ז, ואם לאו התקינו עצמכם לשעבודה של מצרים, היינו שעבוד הנפש של כוחות הטומאה ותועבת מצרים, וז"א פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה, היינו מלחמת עמלק כפרש"י והמכילתא, ופן יחשבו מחשבה אחרת לנטות מדרך האמת ולא יוכלו להתגבר נגד מלחמת היצר שהוא שרו של עמלק, ועי"ז ושבו מצרימה, יחזרו לבחי' מעשה ארץ מצרים, וע"כ הכין הקב"ה כח וזכות של דור המדבר להיות זכותן וכח קדושתם מגינא ומצלת לכל דורות ישראל, וז"ש הכתוב ולא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים כי קרוב הוא, והי' נשלל מהם הזכות הגדול של לכתך אחרי במדבר, כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה לדורות, ויחשבו מחשבה אחרת כנ"ל ע"כ הכין הבוי"ת מראש הנסיון הגדול של לכתך אחרי במדבר. ובכח זה יתקיימו ישראל לדורות.
translation:
And it is possible that the text hints at the war of the yetzer (evil inclination), and according to what the holy Alshich says (in the portion of Beshalach) that all the princes of each nation are light before Him, blessed be He, to bring them down in an instant, and immediately their nations fall. However, the prince of Amalek cannot be brought down except by the hand of Israel, etc. He is the Satan, he is the S"M (the evil inclination), and in every sin and transgression that we commit, we hold and affirm him, as is known, in a way that it is impossible to bring him down to the ground unless we merit from all our sins, etc., for then he will be subdued and erased from the world. And this is what is meant by "And I will erase the memory of Amalek from under the heavens," in contrast to the other nations, whom He, blessed be He, brings down the prince from the heavens first, etc. Therefore, this remembrance is necessary in the heart of every Jew, so that they know that in this matter their redemption and goodness in the world depend. Thus far, his words, may his memory be a blessing. 

And with this, we can explain the words of the Tanchuma mentioned above, "Remember what Amalek did to you," etc. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel those two remembrances: "You shall erase the memory of Amalek" and "Remember what Amalek did to you," be careful with them. If you merit, you are the children of Abraham, etc., meaning that you will be worthy to be related to him who fought against his yetzer and with the whole world of idol worship. And if not, prepare yourselves for the servitude of Egypt, meaning the servitude of the soul to the forces of impurity and the abomination of Egypt. And this is what is meant by "Lest the people regret when they see war," meaning the war of Amalek, as Rashi and the Mechilta explain, and "Lest they think another thought to stray from the path of truth and will not be able to overcome the war of the yetzer, which is the prince of Amalek." And through this, they will return to Egypt, returning to the state of the deeds of the land of Egypt. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, prepared the merit and strength of the generation of the wilderness to be their merit and the strength of their holiness, a shield and protection for all generations of Israel. This is what the verse means, "And God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, for it was near," for they would have been stripped of the great merit of "You followed Me in the wilderness," for God said, "Lest the people regret when they see war for generations," and they would think another thought as mentioned above. Therefore, He prepared the beginning of the great trial of "You followed Me in the wilderness." And with this strength, Israel will endure for generations.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual battle against the yetzer hara (evil inclination), equating it with the force of Amalek, which can only be defeated by the merit of the Jewish people. It emphasizes the importance of remembering Amalek's actions as a means to strengthen one's resolve against temptation and to maintain a connection to the holiness of past generations. The text highlights that divine assistance is contingent upon the people's awareness and remembrance of their struggles, ensuring their spiritual survival and redemption throughout generations. Ultimately, it underscores the necessity of vigilance in the face of spiritual warfare to avoid regression into the spiritual bondage reminiscent of Egypt.

passage_content: ולפי"זאפשר לפרש במלת פן ינחם ג' משמעות, כי איזה מהם תוציא, ויתכן שנתכוין הכתוב לכולם, ועפ"י פשוטו יכוין הכתוב על אותו הדור יוצאי מצרים, דהנה השגחה סיבת הדביקות כמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל, ואם זוכין לבטחון ואמונה אמיתית נמשך הישועה בניקל יותר, ומעתה אלמלי הלכו ישראל בדרך קרוב דרך ארץ פלשתים, יש מקום לחשוש שמא בראותם מלחמה יחשבו מחשבה להנצל מן הסכנה בדרך הטבע ע"י שישובו למצרים, ואף שא"א שישובו נגד רצונו ית', אבל המחשבה בלבד פוגמת ולא יהי' ראויים לנס, דהשגחה סיבת הדביקות, וז"ש ולא נחםאלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים כי קרוב הוא וכפרש"י ז"ל נוח לשוב באותו הדרך למצרים, וע"כ יש לחשוש שיעלה על לבם מחשבה זו, גם יל"פ פן ינחם מלשון נחמה שיתנחמו בזה בראותם מלחמה ושבו מצרימה, אף שסבלו שם עבדות ועינוי, אבל מיראת סכנת המות יבחרו יותר לחזור ליד לוחציהם ואם ככה יחשבו לא יהיו ראויים אל הנס, ומה"ט הסיבן הקב"ה דרך המדבר ים סוף, וכאשר יהיו רחוקים ממצרים לא יהי' בחזרה מנוס ומפלט מן המלחמה, ויתלו עיניהם בישועת ד' ועי"ז יהיו נושעים
translation: According to this, it is possible to interpret the word "lest" (פן) in three ways, as any of them could be taken, and it is possible that the text intends all of them. According to its simple meaning, the text refers to that generation, the children of Israel who left Egypt. Behold, Divine Providence is the cause of attachment, as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, states. If they merit true faith and trust, salvation will come to them more easily. Therefore, had the Israelites taken the closer route through the land of the Philistines, there is reason to fear that upon seeing war, they might think of escaping the danger through natural means by returning to Egypt. And although it is impossible for them to return against His will, the mere thought itself is damaging, and they would not be worthy of a miracle, for Divine Providence is the cause of attachment. This is why it says, "And God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, for it was near," and as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains, it would be easy to return that way to Egypt. Therefore, there is concern that this thought might arise in their hearts. Additionally, "lest" (פן) can be understood in the sense of comfort, that they might find comfort in this by seeing war and returning to Egypt, even though they suffered there from slavery and affliction. But out of fear of the danger of death, they would prefer to return to their oppressors. If they think this way, they will not be worthy of the miracle. For this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, led them through the wilderness to the Sea of Reeds, and when they are far from Egypt, there will be no escape or refuge from the war, and they will lift their eyes to the salvation of God, and through this, they will be saved.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine providence and the importance of faith and trust in God for the Israelites during their exodus from Egypt. It suggests that had they taken a shorter route through the land of the Philistines, their fear of war might have led them to consider returning to Egypt, which would have disqualified them from receiving divine miracles. By leading them through the wilderness, God ensured that they would rely solely on His salvation, reinforcing the idea that true faith is essential for experiencing divine intervention.

passage_content: ולדרכנוהנ"ל שהי' טעם הסיבן דרך המדבר בשביל תועלת דורות העתידים, יתפרש ג"כ מלת ינחם מלשון נחמה, דהנה באמת ספיקא קמי שמיא ליכא, וראתה חכמתו ית' שלכובד נסיונות הגלות ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה, זו מלחמת עמלק ומלחמת היצר, ויחשבו מחשבה אחרת, אלא שלא אמרו ית' במאמר מוחלט, כי דבורו ית' מכריח ויתבטל הבחירה, ולז"א כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם, והנה המחשבה בלבד פוגמת כמ"ש לעיל, אולם בכ"ז אפשר לחזור בו ולהתגבר עליו, ומחשבה מוציא מידי מחשבה, וכל עוד שהאדם מצטער ומתחרט על המחשבה רעה, הבוי"ת עוזרו ומצילו מידי מעשה, אבל אם ח"ו ימצא מרגוע לנפשו ויקבל תנחומין על התהפכות המחשבה, אז עלול ח"ו ליפול לתועבת מצרים, וז"פ פן ינחם העם ר"ל יחשבו מחשבה אחרת ויתנחמו בזה, ושבו מצרימה שאז יפלו לתועבת מצרים ח"ו.
translation: And to explain the aforementioned, that the reason for the suffering in the wilderness was for the benefit of future generations, the word " ינחם" (to comfort) can also be understood from the root of "נחמה" (comfort). For indeed, there is no doubt before Heaven, and His wisdom, blessed be He, saw that due to the heaviness of the trials of exile, the people would be comforted by witnessing war, this being the war of Amalek and the war of the yetzer (evil inclination), and they would think a different thought. However, He did not say it in an absolute statement, for His word compels and nullifies free choice. Therefore, it is said that God said, "Lest the people will be comforted," meaning that they might think a different thought and find comfort in it, and return to Egypt, for then they would fall into the abomination of Egypt, Heaven forbid.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine guidance and the trials faced by the Jewish people, emphasizing that the challenges of exile serve a purpose for future generations. It highlights the idea that while God is aware of the struggles, He allows for human choice, warning against the dangers of succumbing to despair or false comfort. The text suggests that negative thoughts can lead to spiritual downfall, but through genuine remorse and effort, one can overcome these challenges. Ultimately, it cautions against complacency, as it may lead to a return to the spiritual degradation of Egypt.

passage_content: גםיל"פ פן ינחם מלשון הנהגה כמ"ש וינחם אל מחוז חפצם, עפי"מ שפרשתי בפ' המרגלים עה"פ נתנה ראש ונשובה מצרימה, פרש"י כתרגומו נמני רישא, נשים עלינו מלך, ורבותינו פי' לשון ע"ז עכ"ל, והנה הרבה מפוה"ת ובכללם השלה"ק כתבו דמרגלים נתכוונו לש"ש אלא שטעו. והכתוב העיד עליהם שהיו מתחלה כשרים וצדיקים, גם ישראל שבאותו הדור היו דור דיעה נשמות גבוהות ולא יתכן לחשוב שרצו לעבוד ע"ז בפועל ח"ו, ואפ"ל עפ"י אמרם ז"ל (שבת דף ק"ה) א"ר אבין מאי קראה לא יהי' בך אל זר ולא תשתחו' לאל נכר. איזהו אל זר שיש בגופו של אדם, הוי אומר זה יצה"ר וכו' שכך אומנתו של יצה"ר היום אומר לו עשה כך, ולמחר אומר לו עשה כך, עד שאומר לו עבוד ע"ז והולך ועובד עכ"ד הגמ' ורש"י ז"ל (בפ' עקב) הביא מדברי הספרי וסרתם ועבדתם אלהים אחרים, וסרתם לפרוש מן התורה, ומתוך כך ועבדתם אלהים אחרים, שכיון שאדם פורש מן התורה הולך ומדבק בע"ז וכו' עיי"ש, ובזה יובן דנתנה ראש פירושו נמני רישא וכפרש"י והתרגום, ואין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו, אולם אם ממנין ראש שלא ברצון השי"ת ולא על דעתו של משרע"ה, סופו שיהי' המנהיג הזה מוליכם לעבוד ע"ז, ורבותינו ז"ל גילו לנו מדרשו כי ראש זה לשון ע"ז ע"ש סופו, היום אומר לו עשה כך עד שאומר לו לעבוד ע"ז, וגם בחי'זו נרמז כאן בכתוב, כי ראתה חכמתו ית' שבאחריות הימים יעמדו על ישראל מנהיגים רעים, ובסיבת ההנהגה ושבו מצרימה יפלו למעשה ארץ מצרים וע"ד שאמה"כ נתנה ראש ונשובה מצרימה, וז"ש פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה היינו מלחמת היצר, וכגון וירד העמלקי נסיונות של דחיקת הקץ ומרידה באומות, ומעתה יש חשש פן ינחם העם מלשון הנהגה, שכח הנהגה רעה יתעום ושבו מצרימה, וע"כ הכין הבוי"ת כח והזכות של דור המדבר שתהי' מגינא ומצלת להקל כובד הנסיונות לדורות, וזהו טעם הסיבן דרך המדבר.
translation: Also, it is possible that they will be comforted from the language of leadership, as it is written, "and He comforted Himself concerning His desire." According to what I explained in Parashat the Spies on the verse "Let us appoint a leader and return to Egypt," Rashi, as per his translation, interprets it as "let us appoint a head," and our Rabbis explained the language of idolatry. And behold, many of the commentators, including the Shelah HaKadosh, wrote that the spies intended for the sake of Heaven, but they erred. And the scripture testified about them that they were initially righteous and just, and also the Israelites of that generation were a generation of knowledge, lofty souls, and it is inconceivable to think that they wanted to serve idolatry in practice, Heaven forbid. And it can be said according to their statement, may their memory be blessed (Shabbat 105), Rabbi Avin said, "What is the verse 'There shall not be in you a foreign god, and you shall not bow down to a foreign god'? What is a foreign god that exists in a person's body? This is the evil inclination," etc. For thus is the nature of the evil inclination: today it tells him to do this, and tomorrow it tells him to do that, until it tells him to serve idolatry, and he goes and serves. Thus said the Gemara, and Rashi, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Eikev), brought from the Sifrei, "And you shall turn away and serve other gods," meaning you shall turn away from the Torah, and from this, "and you shall serve other gods," for when a person turns away from the Torah, he goes and cleaves to idolatry, etc. There, it can be understood that "Let us appoint a leader" means "let us appoint a head," as Rashi and the translation explain, and no verse departs from its simple meaning. However, if they appoint a head not with the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, and not with the consent of Moshe Rabbeinu, the end will be that this leader will lead them to serve idolatry. And our Rabbis, may their memory be blessed, revealed to us its midrash that this head is a term for idolatry because of its end. Today it tells him to do this until it tells him to serve idolatry, and also in this aspect, it is hinted here in the verse, for He saw that in the end of days, evil leaders would arise over Israel, and because of the leadership and their return to Egypt, they would fall into the practices of the land of Egypt, as it is written, "Let us appoint a leader and return to Egypt." And this is what is meant by "lest the people be comforted" when they see war, which is the war of the evil inclination, such as "and the Amalekite came down," trials of pressing the end and rebellion against the nations. And from now on, there is a concern that the people may be comforted from the language of leadership, for the power of bad leadership will deceive them, and they will return to Egypt. Therefore, the Blessed One prepared the merit and strength of the generation of the desert to be a shield and save to lighten the burden of trials for generations, and this is the reason for the path of the desert.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of leadership and its potential to lead people astray, particularly in the context of the spies sent to scout the land of Canaan. It emphasizes that the spies, initially righteous, ultimately succumbed to the influence of the evil inclination, which can lead to idolatry. The text warns that poor leadership can result in a regression to spiritual bondage, as seen in the phrase "נתנה ראש ונשובה מצרימה," indicating a return to Egypt. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of divine guidance and the merit of the generation in the wilderness as a protective force against future trials and tribulations.

passage_content: ואפשרלקשר טעם הכתוב עם טעם המובא במכילתא הנ"ל, אמר הקב"ה אם אני מביא עכשיו ישראל לארץ, מיד מחזיקים אדם בשדהו ואדם בכרמו והם בטלים מן התורה, אלא אקיפם במדבר מ' שנה שיהיו אוכלין מן ושותין מי הבאר והתורה נבללת בגופן וכו' עכ"ד המכילתא, ולכאורה הרי ר' ישמעאל ס"ל בגמ' ברכות (ל"ה ע"ב) ואספת דגנך מה ת"ל, לפי שנא' לא ימוש ס"ת הזה מפיך, יכול דברים ככתבן. ת"ל ואספת דגנך הנהג בהן מנהג דרך ארץ, ואמר אביי הרבה עשו כר' ישמעאל ועלתה בידן כרשב"י ולא עלתה בידן, ואיך אפ"ל דבשביל שיחזיקו איש בשדהו יתבטל התורה, ואם ככה יש לחשוש א"כ מה יהי' תקנתן של דורות אחריהם שלא יהיו אוכלי מן, אמנם משונה הדור ההוא מכל הדורות שבעולם, דלפי שכח זכותם מגין על כל דורות ישראל, ע"כ הי' צורך להם לשמירה יתירה ולשלימות מאוד נעלה, ומה"ט הסיבן הקב"ה במדבר ונתן להם המן כדי שתהא התורה נבללת בגופן, ולולא כח התוה"ק, גם זכות האמונה הגדולה של לכתך אחרי במדבר אין לה קיום נצחי לדורות, ולזה דייק הכתוב "לכתך אחרי" במדבר, ע"ד הכתוב אחרי ד' תלכו, והוא רק ע"י התוה"ק וכל דבר בעבדות השי"ת צריך שיהי' מקושר עם התוה"ק, וזולת זה אין לה קיום, גם מפני שהי' הדור ההוא שורש כל דורות ישראל והוכנו להגין בזכותם על כל הדורות ע"כ הוצרכו לשמירה יתירה ושיהיו דבוקים בעצם התוה"ק דיבוק עצמי, ואלמלי זה פונה לכרמו וזה פונה לשדהו הי' נחסר מהם שלימות האמיתי, משא"כ בדורות שאחריהם אין הכרח לזה והרבה עשו כר' ישמעאל ועלתה בידן, ולפי"ז טעם המכילתא ישתווה עם טעם המבואר בכתוב, כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם וגו' כדרכנו הנ"ל, ולטעם זה הוכן הנסיונות של דור המדבר, לכתך אחרי במדבר וגו' להגין על כל הדורות, ולזה הי' צורך להקיפם מ' שנה במדבר שיהא התורה נבללת בגופן.
translation:
And it is possible to connect the reason of the text with the reason brought in the aforementioned Mekilta. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: If I bring Israel to the land now, immediately a person will hold onto his field and a person to his vineyard, and they will be neglectful of the Torah. Rather, I will surround them in the desert for forty years so that they will eat from the manna and drink from the well, and the Torah will be absorbed within them, etc. Thus is the conclusion of the Mekilta. 

And seemingly, Rabbi Yishmael holds in the Gemara Berakhot (35b) regarding "And you shall gather your grain," what is it to teach? Since it is said, "This Torah shall not depart from your mouth," one might think that the words are to be taken literally. Therefore, it is stated, "And you shall gather your grain," conduct yourself with the ways of the land. And Abaye said: Many acted according to Rabbi Yishmael and it succeeded for them like Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai, and it did not succeed for them. 

And how can it be said that because a person will hold onto his field, the Torah will be neglected? If so, one must be concerned, what will be the remedy for the generations after them so that they will not eat from the manna? However, that generation is different from all generations in the world, for their merit protects all generations of Israel. Therefore, they needed extra protection and a very high level of completeness. For this reason, the Holy One, Blessed be He, surrounded them in the desert and gave them the manna so that the Torah would be absorbed within them. 

And were it not for the strength of the Torah, even the great merit of "following you in the desert" would not have eternal existence for the generations. And for this reason, the text emphasizes "following you in the desert," in accordance with the verse "After the Lord your God shall you walk," and this is only through the Torah. Every matter in the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, must be connected with the Torah, and without this, it has no permanence. 

Also, because that generation was the root of all generations of Israel and was prepared to protect all generations through their merit, they needed extra protection and to be attached to the essence of the Torah, a deep attachment. And were it not for this, one would turn to his vineyard and another to his field, and they would lack true completeness. However, in the generations that followed, there is no necessity for this, and many acted according to Rabbi Yishmael and it succeeded for them. 

According to this, the reason of the Mekilta aligns with the reason explained in the text, for God said, "Lest the people regret," etc., as we have explained above. And for this reason, the trials of the generation of the desert were prepared, "following you in the desert," etc., to protect all generations. Therefore, there was a need to surround them for forty years in the desert so that the Torah would be absorbed within them.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of the Israelites' prolonged stay in the desert, emphasizing that their unique spiritual status required them to be deeply connected to the Torah. It highlights that their sustenance from the manna and water from the well served to integrate the Torah into their very being, ensuring their spiritual integrity. This connection was essential for the protection and continuity of future generations, as the merit of that generation would safeguard all subsequent ones. Ultimately, the text illustrates the profound relationship between divine guidance, adherence to the Torah, and the spiritual legacy of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ועפי"זיתבאר דברי המד"ר ויהי בשלח פרעה, מי אמר ווי, משה אמר ווי וכו' אמר משה צועק אני שנתייגעתי להוציא את ישראל ממצרים ואיני נכנס עמהם לארץ עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב דאין לזה קישור עם מאמר הכתוב, והול"ל בפ' בא עה"פ יצאו כל צבאות ד' מארץ מצרים, גם מנין נתברר לו עכשיו שאין סופו ליכנס עמהם לארץ, ולדרכנו השיג משרע"ה שיהיו עוד גלויות, דלטעם זה יש חשש פן ינחם העם וגו' יחשבו מחשבה אחרת, גם פן ינחם העם מרעת המנהיגים, וכ"ז לא יצוייר אלמלי נכנס משרע"ה לא"י, כאמרז"ל דלא שלטו האויבים במעשה ידיו ולא הי' אחרי' חורבן עוד, אלא שלא היה עדיין הזמן לגאולה נצחית, ועכ"פ השיג משרע"ה ממה שהסיבם הקב"ה דרךהמדבר לטעם פן ינחם העם, ידע שלא יכנס לארץ וע"כ צווח ווי וא"ש הקישור, והבוכ"ע ינחנו בדרך האמת וננצל ממנהיגים לא טובים ונזכה לעשות תשובה שלימה, ובמהרה נקבל פני משיח צדקנו בנחת ובשמחה בקדושה ובטהרה, ונזכה לראות הישועה שלימה בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: And according to this, the words of the Midrash will be explained: "And it was when Pharaoh sent out," who said "woe," Moses said "woe," etc. Moses said, "I cry out, I have labored to bring Israel out of Egypt, and I will not enter with them into the land." Thus far the Midrash. And it is puzzling that there is no connection to the verse, and it should have been stated in Parashat Bo regarding the verse "All the hosts of the Lord went out from the land of Egypt." Also, how did it become clear to him now that he would not enter the land with them? And according to our way, Moses understood that there would be more exiles, for this reason there is a concern that the people might regret, etc., they might think other thoughts, also that the people might regret the evil of the leaders. And all this would not be conceivable had Moses entered the Land of Israel, as our Sages have said that the enemies did not have power over his handiwork and there would not have been further destruction, except that the time for eternal redemption had not yet arrived. And nevertheless, Moses understood from what the Holy One, Blessed be He, caused them to wander in the desert, for the reason that the people might regret, he knew that he would not enter the land, and therefore he cried "woe," and I understand the connection. May the Blessed One guide us on the path of truth and save us from bad leaders, and may we merit to make complete repentance, and may we soon greet our righteous Messiah with ease and joy, in holiness and purity, and may we merit to see complete salvation with the upliftment of the horn of the Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, may it be soon.
summary: The passage discusses the anguish of Moses as he realizes he will not enter the Promised Land after leading the Israelites out of Egypt, reflecting on the potential for the people to lose faith due to the hardships they will face. It emphasizes the divine plan that necessitated their journey through the wilderness to prevent the Israelites from regretting their liberation and to avoid the influence of unworthy leaders. The text expresses a longing for redemption and the hope for a complete and joyous salvation, culminating in the arrival of the Messiah and the revelation of divine glory. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of faith and repentance in the face of challenges.

passage_content: עודאפ"ל ושבו מצרימה עפימ"ש הרמב"ן הק' בחידושיו למס' עירובין דלמ"ד תחומין דאורייתא איך התירו חכמים ע"י תקנת עירוב דבר שנאסר מן התורה, ותירץ הרמב"ן דהאדם נמשך אחר סעודתו וע"י שמחשבתו שם נחשב כאילו הוא עצמו הי' שם וזהו סברא דאורייתא. ומן התורה הותר ע"י העירוב לילך עוד אלפים אמה ע"י סעודתו שהניח שם, כי מחשבתו של אדם נמשך אחר סעודתו, וכל מקום שמחשבתו הוא שמה נחשב כאילו הוא עצמוהי' שם, ועד"ז יובן הכתוב פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה ויכנס בלבם מחשבות כאלו שע"י מחשבתם יחשב להם כאלו שבו למצרים, ולא שיחזרו בפועל שמה, כי הרבה שלוחים למקום למנעם, רק בעודם בא"י אם יהרהרו לעשות כמעשה ארץ מצרים יחשב להם כאלו שבו בפועל וז"ש ושבו מצרימה, וז"ש במדרש כדי שלא יבואו לידי מחשבות כאלו לכן הוצרך להקיפן במדבר ארבעים שנה וכו' והתורה נבללת בגופן ואין עוד חשש זה שיחזרו למצרים ע"י גרמת המחשבות.
translation: Furthermore, it is said that they will return to Egypt, according to the words of the holy Ramban in his novelties on the tractate Eruvin, that according to the opinion that the boundaries (techumim) are of biblical origin, how did the sages permit through the enactment of an Eruv something that is forbidden by the Torah? The Ramban answered that a person is drawn after his meal, and by his thoughts being there, it is considered as if he himself was there. This is a reasoning of biblical origin. And by the Torah, it is permitted through the Eruv to walk another two thousand cubits because of the meal he left there, for a person's thoughts are drawn after his meal, and wherever his thoughts are, it is considered as if he himself was there. Similarly, one can understand the verse "lest the people regret when they see war" and thoughts like these enter their hearts, that through their thoughts it will be considered as if they returned to Egypt, and not that they would actually return there, for there are many messengers to prevent them from going there. Rather, while they are still in the Land of Israel, if they contemplate doing like the actions of the land of Egypt, it will be considered as if they returned in action. This is what is meant by "and they will return to Egypt." And this is what is stated in the Midrash, that in order not to come to such thoughts, they needed to be surrounded in the desert for forty years, etc., and the Torah is absorbed in their bodies, and there is no longer this concern that they will return to Egypt through the cause of thoughts.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that a person's thoughts can influence their spiritual state, as illustrated by the Ramban's interpretation of the Torah's laws regarding travel on Shabbat. It emphasizes that through one's thoughts, a person can be considered as if they have returned to Egypt, even if they are physically in the Land of Israel. To prevent such negative thoughts and potential regression, the Israelites were made to wander in the desert for forty years, ensuring that the Torah became internalized within them and eliminating the risk of returning to the mindset of Egypt. This highlights the Hasidic idea of the power of thought and its impact on one's spiritual journey.

passage_content: עודאפשר לפרש אומרו ושבו מצרימה עפימ"ש בספה"ק צמח ה' לצבי פ' ראה עה"כ אבד תאבדון (הובא לשונו בויואל משה מאמר ב' סי' קכ"ט) ותוכן דבריו שאדמת ארץ ישראל אינה סובלת כל טומאה, ובאותן המקומות שמטמאין את א"י מתקפלת הארץ תחתיהם ורצועה בישא מארץ העמים נמשך עלי' עיי"ש, ובערבי נחל פ' שלח פי' שעד"ז היה טעותם של המרגלים שלא מצאו בא"י קדושת הארץ כי הי' הכל במדבר במקום חנייתן של ישראל עיי"ש, וזהו אומרו פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה ושבו מצרימה, ר"ל אף כשהם בא"י יכולים להיות על אדמת מצרים ע"י שיתנהגו שלא כשורה, ומה"ט ויסב אלקים את העם דרך המדבר ים סוף כדי שיקבלו את התוה"ק, ואחר שיהי' התורה נבללת בגופן יכנסו לא"י ואין עוד חשש זה, ולפי"ז טעם המדרש וטעם המבואר בפסוק מתאימים ועל קוטב א' יסובבו.
translation: It is also possible to interpret the statement "and they will return to Egypt" according to what is said in the holy book Tzemach Hashem, in Parashat Re'eh, on the verse "You will surely perish" (as quoted in the language of Vayoeil Moshe, Maamar 2, Siman 129). The essence of his words is that the land of Eretz Yisrael cannot tolerate any impurity, and in those places that defile Eretz Yisrael, the land folds under them, and a strip of evil from the lands of the nations is drawn upon it, as stated there. And in the section of "Shlach," it is explained that similarly, the error of the spies was that they did not find the sanctity of the land in Eretz Yisrael because everything was in the desert, in the place of the encampment of Israel, as stated there. And this is the meaning of "lest the people will regret when they see war and return to Egypt," meaning that even when they are in Eretz Yisrael, they can be on the land of Egypt if they behave improperly. And for this reason, "God turned the people toward the desert, the Sea of Reeds," so that they would receive the Torah, and after the Torah would be absorbed within them, they would enter Eretz Yisrael, and there would be no more concern of this kind. According to this, the reason of the Midrash and the reason explained in the verse are aligned and will revolve around one pole.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the land of Israel cannot tolerate impurity, and when impurity is present, the land retracts, akin to a connection to Egypt. It highlights the error of the spies who failed to recognize the sanctity of the land due to their experiences in the wilderness. The text emphasizes that even in Israel, improper behavior can lead to a spiritual state akin to Egypt, which is why God guided the people through the desert to prepare them for receiving the Torah. Once the Torah is internalized, they can enter the land without fear of returning to a state of impurity.

passage_content: במסיבהאחר יתבאר דברי המכילתא והדקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם מ"ד במד"ר (פ' כ' סימן י"ח) ויסב אלקים את העם דרך המדבר וגו', מכאן אמרו רבותינו אפי' עני שבישראל לא יאכל עד שיסב, שכך עשה להם הקב"ה שנא' ויסב אלקים עכ"ד המדרש, והוא פליאה דויסב דקרא אינו ממשמעות הסיבה כ"א מלשון סיבוב, ואיך דרשו רז"ל מכאן על הסיבה בלילי פסחים ואינו מענינו כלל, והיפ"ת פי' זה רק דרך רמז מדכתיב ויסב ולא כתיב וינחם עיי"ש, ועדיין צ"ב קישור הרמז לכאן, דהסיבה בלילי פסחים מורה על החירות, והליכתם דרך המדבר מורה על ההיפוך כמשה"כ ויענך וירעיבך וגו' למען נסותך וגו'
translation: In the next section, the words of the Mechilta and the aforementioned nuances will be clarified, as it is stated in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 18), "And God turned the people toward the wilderness, etc." From here, our Sages said that even a poor person in Israel should not eat until he reclines, for thus did the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is said, "And God turned." Thus is the teaching of the Midrash. It is wondrous that the term "turned" in the verse does not imply the meaning of reclining, but rather from the language of turning. How did our Sages derive from here the concept of reclining on Passover nights, which is not related at all? And the explanation is that this is only a hint, as it is written "And He turned" and not "And He comforted," as you can see there. Yet, the connection of the hint to this matter remains to be clarified, for reclining on Passover nights indicates freedom, while their journey through the wilderness indicates the opposite, as it is written, "And He afflicted you and caused you to hunger, etc., to test you, etc."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the term "ויסב" in relation to the Jewish practice of reclining during the Passover Seder, drawing from the Midrash that emphasizes the importance of this act even for the poorest among Israel. It highlights the contrast between the notion of freedom symbolized by reclining and the hardships faced during the Israelites' journey through the desert, which served as a test of faith. The author questions the connection between the act of reclining and the journey through the wilderness, suggesting that the deeper meaning lies in the spiritual transformation and the experience of divine providence. Ultimately, the text reflects on the themes of freedom, humility, and the trials that lead to a greater understanding of God's guidance.

passage_content: ב)משה את עצמות יוסף עמו וגו', במס' סוטה (י"ג ע"א) בא וראה כמה חביבות מצות על משרע"ה, שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק במצות שנא' חכם לב יקח מצות וגו', עכ"ד הגמ', והמהרש"א ז"ל בח"א דקדק, מדוע תיארו אותו בשביל זה בתואר חכם, ומה ענין החכמה בזה יותר הול"ל תואר צדיק וחסיד, גם מהו האשמה שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה, הרי היו מצווין על ככה מפי הגבורה, ואם הי' אפשר לקיים שניהם, מדוע באמת נמנעו ממצוה רבה כזו, והיו מושבעין על זה מפי יוסף הצדיק, ומדוע שבקו לי' למשה לבדו, ובגמ' תירצו מפני שאמרו כבודו בגדולים יותר מבקטנים, וא"כ הרי לש"ש נתכוונו ומהו האשמה בדבר וצ"ב.
translation: B) "Moses took the bones of Joseph with him," as it is stated in Masechet Sotah (13a), "Come and see how beloved the commandments are to Moshe Rabbeinu, for all of Israel were occupied with the spoils, and he was engaged in the commandments, as it is said, 'A wise heart will acquire commandments,' etc." Thus concludes the Gemara. And the Maharsha, of blessed memory, in his first part, noted why he was described with the title "wise" for this, and what the connection of wisdom is here; it would have been more appropriate to say the title "righteous" or "pious." Also, what is the accusation that all of Israel were occupied with the spoils, when they were commanded to do so by the Holy One, Blessed be He? And if it were possible to fulfill both, why did they indeed refrain from such a great commandment, especially since they were sworn to this by Joseph the Righteous? And why did they leave it to Moses alone? The Gemara answers that they said his honor is greater among the great than among the small. If so, they intended for the sake of Heaven, and what is the accusation in this matter? This remains to be clarified.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses' dedication to the mitzvah of carrying Joseph's bones, contrasting it with the rest of Israel's focus on the spoils of Egypt. It highlights the idea that Moses is referred to as "wise" for prioritizing this commandment, raising questions about the nature of wisdom in fulfilling divine commandments. The text also explores the tension between collective obligation and individual responsibility, suggesting that while the people were commanded to take the spoils, Moses' actions reflect a higher spiritual calling. Ultimately, it emphasizes the value of mitzvot and the unique role of Moses in embodying a deeper commitment to divine will.

passage_content: ולבארהענין נקדים מ"ד במד"ר להלן (פכ"ה ס"י) ויותירו אנשים ממנו, אלו מחוסרי אמנה שבהם וכו' מיד ויקצוף עליהם משה, כיון שכעס שכח לומר להם שילקטו ביום הששי ב' עומרים לאחד כיון שהלכו ולקטו ביום הששי ומצאו כפלים, באו הנשיאים ואמרו למשה שנא' ויבואו כל נשיאי העדה ויגידו למשה, ומה אמר להם הוא אשר דבר ד' וגו', ואינו אומר הוא אשר דברתי, אלא אשר דבר ששכח עכ"ד המדרש, והקשה היפ"ת והלא הי' ראוי לומר להם דין זה תיכף ביום א' כמו שאמר להם כל הפרשה של מן, והכעס הי' אח"כ ביום ב' כשהותירו ומדוע תלו רז"ל סיבת השכחה ומניעת הציווי בקצף על המותירים, (וביארנו בזה בדברנו להלן עיי"ש).
translation: To clarify the matter, we will precede with M.D. in Midrash below (Perek 25, Siman Yud). "And the people left over some of it," these are the ones lacking faith among them, etc. Immediately, "And Moses was angry with them." Once he became angry, he forgot to tell them to gather on the sixth day two omers for each person. Since they went and gathered on the sixth day and found double, the leaders came and told Moses, as it is said, "And all the leaders of the congregation came and told Moses." And what did he say to them? "This is what the Lord has commanded," etc. He does not say, "This is what I commanded," but rather "what was forgotten," as the Midrash concludes. And the question arises: why was it appropriate to tell them this law immediately on the first day, just as he told them the entire section about the manna? The anger was afterwards on the second day when they left over, and why did our Sages attribute the reason for the forgetfulness and the withholding of the command to the anger over those who left over? (And we have explained this in our discussion below, see there.)
summary: The passage discusses the incident of the Israelites collecting manna, highlighting the tension between divine instruction and human forgetfulness. It emphasizes that Moses, in his anger, neglected to remind the people to gather a specific amount on the sixth day, leading to their confusion and excess collection. This reflects a deeper Hasidic concept of the interplay between divine providence and human action, illustrating how emotions can impact spiritual clarity and the transmission of divine commandments. The text suggests that the consequences of anger can obscure essential teachings, underscoring the importance of mindfulness in spiritual leadership.

passage_content: והנל"פלענינינו עפימ"ד במדרש ילקוט (ר"פ דברים רמז תשצ"ט) אחד עשר יום מחורב, אלו זכו ישראל לאחד עשר יום היו נכנסין לארץ, אלא מתוך שקלקלו מעשיהם גלגל עליהם המקום למ' יום ארבעים שנה וכו', ר' יהודה אומר אלו זכו ישראל לג' ימיםהיו נכנסין לארץ שנא' וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, והנה כתיב ובני ישראל אכלו את המן ארבעים שנה עד בואם אל ארץ נושבת את המן אכלו עד בואם אל קצה ארץ כנען, וטרם שעברו הירדן נפסק ירידת המן כמבואר בדרז"ל, ומעתהאפ"ל דע"כ לא אמר להם משרע"ה מצות והי' ביום הששי והכינו, ביום הראשון כשהתחיל ירידת המן ואמר להם כל הפרשה, כי הי' עדיין הי' משרע"ה מצפה שיזכו ישראל למעלת השלימות, ולג' ימים יהיו נכנסים לארץ ומיד יפסק ירידת המן, ולא יהי' צורך להם באזהרה זו והי' ביום הששי והכינו, אמנם כשראה ביום השני ולא שמעו אל משה ויותירו וגו', השיג מעכשיו שלא הגיעו ישראל עדיין לבחי' זכו, וע"כ אז הי' זמנו לומר להם מצות השבת, אלא מתוך שכעס ונצטער על מדריגתם של ישראל, שכח לומר שילקטו ביום הששי ב' עומרים לאחד, וא"ש דסיבת הכעס גרמה, וביום השני דייקא.
translation: And this is what we have learned in our teachings according to the Midrash Yalkut (Parashat Devarim, Remez 795): "Eleven days from Chorev, if Israel had merited eleven days, they would have entered the land, but because they spoiled their deeds, the Holy One, blessed be He, caused them to wander for forty years." Rabbi Yehuda says, "If Israel had merited three days, they would have entered the land, as it is stated..." Thus concludes the Midrash. And behold, it is written, "And the children of Israel ate the manna for forty years until they came to a settled land; they ate the manna until they came to the edge of the land of Canaan." And before they crossed the Jordan, the descent of the manna ceased, as explained in the teachings of our sages. Therefore, can we say that Moses did not tell them the commandment, "And it shall be on the sixth day, and they shall prepare," on the first day when the descent of the manna began, and he told them the entire section, because Moses was still hoping that Israel would merit the level of completeness, and they would enter the land in three days, and immediately the descent of the manna would cease, and there would be no need for this warning, "And it shall be on the sixth day, and they shall prepare." However, when he saw on the second day that they did not listen to Moses and left over, etc., he realized from that moment that Israel had not yet reached the level of merit. Therefore, it was then time to tell them the commandment of the Sabbath. But because he was angry and distressed about the level of Israel, he forgot to say that they should gather on the sixth day two omers for one, and it is understood that the cause of the anger brought this about, specifically on the second day.
summary: The passage discusses the potential for the Israelites to enter the Promised Land within eleven days had they merited it through righteous actions. However, due to their shortcomings, they were destined to wander for forty years. The text highlights the significance of the manna, which ceased before they crossed the Jordan, and reflects on Moses' initial hope that the Israelites would achieve a level of spiritual completeness. When they failed to heed his instructions, it prompted a shift in his message, emphasizing the connection between their spiritual state and the divine provision they received.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבאר דברי המכילתא (הובא לעיל בדרוש הקדום) אמר הקב"ה אקיפם במדבר מ' שנה שיהיו אוכלין מן ושותין מי הבאר והתורה נבללת בגופן וכו', ולכאורה הרי מפורש בכתוב טעם אחר, דסיבת הליכתם דרך המדבר הי' לטעם פן ינחם העם וגו' וכבר ביארנו בזה אופנים שונים, ולענינינו אפ"ל דאלמלי זכו ישראל היו נכנסין לא"י מיד, כי לא הי' מקום להך חששא פן ינחם העם וגו' שיחשבו מחשבה אחרת כפרש"י ז"ל, אבל מפני שידע הבוי"ת שלא הגיעו ישראל עדיין לשלימותם, ויחשבו מחשבות לסור ממצות ד' וכמו שאירע להם. ע"כ הקיפם הקב"ה מ' שנה במדבר, שיהי' התורה נבללת בגופן ולא יסורו ממנה, נמצא דטעם המכילתא מקושר עם טעם המבואר בפסוק, דלולי הטעם פן ינחם, לא הי' צורך להקיפם במדבר לטעם המכילתא.
translation: And similarly, the words of the Mechilta (brought above in the ancient discourse) explain that the Holy One, blessed be He, surrounded them in the desert for forty years so that they would eat from the manna and drink from the well, and the Torah would be absorbed within them, etc. And seemingly, it is explicitly stated in the verse that the reason for their journey through the desert was lest the people regret, etc. We have already explained this in various ways. In our context, it can be said that had Israel merited it, they would have entered the Land of Israel immediately, for there would have been no place for this concern of lest the people regret, etc., that they would think other thoughts, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explains. But because the Creator, blessed be He, knew that Israel had not yet reached their completeness, and they would think thoughts to turn away from the commandments of the Holy One, as happened to them, therefore the Holy One, blessed be He, surrounded them for forty years in the desert, so that the Torah would be absorbed within them and they would not turn away from it. Thus, the reason of the Mechilta is connected with the reason explained in the verse, for without the reason of lest they regret, there would have been no need to surround them in the desert for the reason of the Mechilta.
summary: The passage discusses the divine reasoning behind the Israelites' 40 years of wandering in the desert, emphasizing that this period was intended to ensure the Torah became internalized within them. It suggests that had the Israelites been spiritually ready, they would have entered the Promised Land immediately, without the concern of them regretting their journey. However, due to their incomplete spiritual state, God chose to keep them in the desert to prevent them from straying from the commandments. Thus, the reasons for their wandering are interconnected, highlighting the importance of spiritual readiness and the internalization of divine teachings.

passage_content: ובזהנבוא לבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל ויסב אלקים את העם דרך המדבר וגו', מכאן אמרו רבותינו אפי' עני שבישראל לא יאכל עד שיסב, דהנה התוס' (בר"פ ערבי פסחים) פירשו בטעם הרבותא דאפי' עני שבישראל וכו', דס"ד דהסיבת עני לא חשיבא הסיבה, דאין לו על מה להסב ואין זה דרך חירות, ויש מפרשים דאדלעיל קאי לא יאכל עד שתחשך, ואפי' עני שלא אכל כמה ימים לא יאכל עד שתחשך, ומ"ש לא יאכל עד שיסב הוא מילתא באפי נפשי' ולא מיירי בעני, אמנם בדברי המדרש כאן שלא נזכר הלכה זו דלא יאכל עד שתחשך, עכ"ח רבותא דאפי' עני קאי על חיוב הסיבה וכפי' הראשון של התוס'.
translation: And with this we come to explain the words of the aforementioned Midrash, "And God turned the people around through the wilderness," etc. From here our sages said that even a poor person in Israel should not eat until he reclines. Behold, the Tosafot (in the chapter of Arvei Pesachim) explained the reason for the emphasis that even a poor person in Israel, etc., for it might be thought that the reclining of a poor person is not considered reclining, as he has nothing to recline upon and this is not the way of freedom. And there are those who interpret that this refers to the earlier statement, "He should not eat until it gets dark," and even a poor person who has not eaten for several days should not eat until it gets dark. And what is meant by "He should not eat until he reclines" is a matter in and of itself and does not refer to the poor person. However, in the words of the Midrash here, where this law of not eating until it gets dark is not mentioned, it is indeed a novelty that even a poor person is included in the obligation of reclining, according to the first interpretation of the Tosafot.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "sitting" (הסיבה) during meals, emphasizing that even the poorest Jew is obligated to recline while eating, reflecting a deeper spiritual freedom. This obligation signifies that true liberation is not merely physical but also involves a dignified approach to sustenance. The text highlights the importance of intention and the sanctity of the act of eating, suggesting that every individual, regardless of their circumstances, should partake in this practice to elevate their spiritual state. Ultimately, it underscores the Hasidic belief in the inherent value and dignity of every person in their relationship with God and the mitzvot.

passage_content: ואפ"לעפ"י דרכם דס"ד דהסיבת עני לא חשיבא דרך חירות ולא מטעמם, וע"ד שפי' בספה"ק מעשה ד' ואילו לא הוציא הקב"ה את אבותינו ממצרים, הרי אנו ובנינו וכו' משועבדים היינו לפרעה במצרים, ר"ל דאלמלי לא הוציא הקב"ה את אבותינו ביד חזקה, אלא פרעה ברצונו הי' משלחם, הרי אנו ובנינו עד סוף כל הדורות היינו משועבדים אליו שעבוד נפשי והתחייבות הכרת תודה, וזה גרוע ומזיק לבחי' הנפש יותר משעבוד הגוף עיי"ש לדרכו, והנה כמו"כ העני שאין לו מה לאכול ומצטרך ליהנות מאחרים, מדרך הטבע שהוא נעשה משועבד ומשוחד אל המחזיקים בו, וקשה לו לגלות ולפרסם האמת אשר הוא בהתנגדות לרצון תומכיו ועוזריו, ובעוה"ר ככה הוא גם בהחזקת התורה, ישנם מנהיגים כשרים אשר לבם כואב על חילול שמו ית', ועל הפרת הדת והאמונה ר"ל, אבל מפני שמקבלים תמיכה להרבצת התורה מאינשי דלא מעלי המחזיקים בדעת המינות וברעיון המדינה הציונית, בע"כ נעשים משועבדים לדעת תומכיהן. וא"א להם לגלות האמת כפי מה שבלבם בדעת התוה"ק, ואף שכוונתם לש"ש להרבצת התורה, אבל זהו מתחבולות היצה"ר, כמ"ש בספה"ק זרע קודש לפרש הכתוב לא תקח שוחד כי היצה"ר אם רוצה למנוע אחד ממצוה גדולה ועיקרות, משחד עיניו במצוה אחרת, כדי למנעו ממצוה היותר גדולה.
translation: And according to their way of thinking, the reason for the poor person is not considered a way of freedom, nor is it for their sake. As explained in the holy book, the story of the four, if the Holy One, blessed be He, had not taken our forefathers out of Egypt, we and our children would have been enslaved to Pharaoh in Egypt, meaning that if the Holy One, blessed be He, had not taken our forefathers out with a strong hand, but rather Pharaoh had willingly sent them away, we and our children would have been enslaved to him for all generations, in a servitude of the soul and an obligation of gratitude. This is worse and more harmful to the aspect of the soul than the servitude of the body, as explained there in his way. Likewise, the poor person who has nothing to eat and must rely on others, by nature becomes enslaved and dependent on those who support him. It is difficult for him to reveal and publicize the truth, which is in opposition to the will of his supporters and helpers. Unfortunately, this is also the case in the support of the Torah; there are righteous leaders whose hearts ache over the desecration of His name and the violation of the faith, but because they receive support for the propagation of the Torah from those who do not elevate themselves, who hold beliefs of heresy and the idea of the Zionist state, they inevitably become enslaved to the opinions of their supporters. They cannot reveal the truth as it is in their hearts according to the holy Torah, and even though their intention is for the sake of Heaven in the propagation of the Torah, this is a trick of the evil inclination, as stated in the holy book, "Holy Seed," to explain the verse "You shall not take a bribe," for the evil inclination, if it wants to prevent someone from a great and fundamental commandment, blinds his eyes with another commandment, in order to prevent him from the greater commandment.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual bondage that arises from dependency on others, particularly in the context of poverty and the support of Torah institutions. It emphasizes that just as the Israelites would have remained enslaved to Pharaoh without divine intervention, the poor become spiritually enslaved to their benefactors, compromising their ability to express true beliefs. This dynamic is paralleled in the realm of Torah leadership, where even well-meaning leaders may become beholden to those who support them, leading to a distortion of their true convictions. Ultimately, the text warns against the subtle manipulations of the evil inclination, which can divert individuals from fulfilling their highest spiritual obligations.

passage_content: והנהכמו"כ העני שאין לו משלו ונהנה משל אחרים, ורוצה להראות בעצמו דרך חירות ולספר בנסי השי"ת בגאולה האמיתית, אבל ה"ה משועבד לדעת המחזיקים בו, וע"כ הי' ס"ד לומר דלא יתחייב בהסיבה דלא חשיבא דרך חירות, אמנם באמת צריך להתגבר בנסיון זה שלא לזוז מדעת התוה"ק ודרך האמת אף עבור כל הון דעלמא, וזהו החרותהאמיתי להיות מקושר ומשועבד לדרך התוה"ק, ולפרוק מעליו כל שעבוד אחר זולתו, והראי' ממה שהסיב הקב"ה את ישראל דרך המדבר, ועיכבם מ' שנה במדבר ונתאחרו מחרות של ישיבת הארץ איש תחת גפנו ואיש תחת תאנתו, והכל לטעם שתהי' התורה נבללת בגופן כמבואר בדברי המכילתא, וע"כ גם העני נתחייב בהסיבה ויכול להראות בעצמו דרך חירות, על אשר הוציא הקב"ה אותנו ממצרים וזכינו אל התוה"ק, אשר כל החירות שבעולם בטילים לגבי', ואין לך בן חורין אלא מי שעוסק בתורה, וז"פ דברי המדרש ויסב אלקים את העם דרך המדבר מכאן אמרו רבותינו אפי' עני שבישראל לא יאכל עד שיסב.
translation: And behold, just as the poor man who has nothing of his own and benefits from the possessions of others, he wishes to demonstrate a path of freedom and to recount the miracles of the Holy One, Blessed be He, in the true redemption, yet he is indeed enslaved to the opinions of those who support him. Therefore, one might think that he would not be obligated to recline, as it is not considered a path of freedom. However, in truth, he must strengthen himself in this trial not to deviate from the teachings of the Torah and the path of truth, even for all the wealth of the world. This is the true regret, to be connected and enslaved to the path of the Torah, and to cast off all other servitude besides it. The proof is from how the Holy One, Blessed be He, led Israel through the desert, and delayed them for forty years in the wilderness, causing them to miss the freedom of dwelling in the land, each under his vine and fig tree, and all this was for the reason that the Torah should be absorbed within them, as explained in the words of the Mechilta. Therefore, even the poor man is obligated to recline and can demonstrate a path of freedom, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, took us out of Egypt and we merited the Torah, which all the freedom in the world is nullified in comparison to it, and there is no free man except one who engages in Torah. Thus, as the Midrash states, "And God led the people around by the way of the wilderness," from here our sages said that even the poorest of Israel should not eat until he reclines.
summary: The passage emphasizes that true freedom is found in adherence to the Torah, even for the impoverished who rely on others. It highlights the necessity of overcoming external dependencies and remaining committed to the teachings of the Torah, as exemplified by the Israelites' journey through the desert. The text asserts that all worldly freedom pales in comparison to the spiritual liberation achieved through Torah study, reinforcing the idea that even the poorest among Israel must engage in this practice to attain true freedom.

passage_content: וכמו"כלענינינו להחזקת הישיבה ובתי ת"ת כאן ובא"י, מוכרחים אנו לקבל תמיכה להחזקת התורה כי המצב קשה מאוד כידוע, אבל ח"ו לסוג אחור מדעת התוה"ק אפי' זיז כ"ש, ואף בעד כל כסף וזהב שבעולם, ויותר אני מוותר על הכל, וכמו שפירשתי בנסיון של אאע"ה שהשליכו נמרוד לכבשן האש על שלא רצה להשתחוות לע"ז, ולכאורה מה נסיון הוא זה בערך רום קדושתו ומסנ"פ של אאע"ה אמנם אחד הי' אברהם שפירסם אלקותו ויחודו ית' בעולם, והודיע לכל באי עולם שיש אלקי הממציא כל המציאות והוא יחיד ואין זולתו, ועכשיו שרצה נמרוד להשליכו לכבשן האש, בא אליו הבע"ד בטענת הסתה, הלא אין בעולם זולתך המפרסם אמונת הבוית"ש, ואם תושלך לאש ותשרף הלא ישארו כל העולם תועים ונתעים אחרי הע"ז, מוטב לך לוותר עכשיו הפעם ולהשתחוות לע"ז ואח"כ תוכל להמשיך בדרכך להשריש האמונה בלבות בנ"א, רק זאת הפעם תשתחוה לע"ז בשביל תיקון העולם, אמנם אאע"ה השיב לו אין אני רוצה להשתחוות לצלם אף בשביל תקון העולם: ואף שהשתוקק מאוד להאיר דרך לתועים ולהמשיכם לאמונת הבוית"ש אבל להשתחוות לצלם בשביל זה לא אסכים בשום אופן שבעולם, ויותר אני מוותר על הכל והשי"ת יעשה את שלו ואני עשיתי כל מה שבאפשרותי, וזה הי' הנסיון היותר גדול שהשליך מנגד כל רצוןנפשו אף בעבודת השם מה שהי' משתוקק בכל לבו ונפשו לפרסם אמונתו ית' לכל באי עולם, ולא נעשה משוחד אל הרצון הזה, אבל ביטל רצונו מפני רצונו ית'.
translation: And as for our matter regarding the support of the yeshiva and the Torah schools here and in Eretz Yisrael, we are compelled to receive support for the sustenance of the Torah, for the situation is very difficult, as is known. However, Heaven forbid to deviate even slightly from the knowledge of the Holy Torah, and certainly not for any amount of money or gold in the world. I would rather forgo everything, as I explained in the trial of our forefather Avraham, who was thrown into the fiery furnace for not wanting to bow to an idol. And seemingly, what kind of trial is this in relation to the greatness of his holiness and the essence of our forefather Avraham? Nevertheless, one was Avraham, who publicized His divinity and His uniqueness in the world, and informed all the inhabitants of the world that there is a God who creates all existence, and He is One and there is none other. And now, when Nimrod wanted to throw him into the fiery furnace, the accuser came to him with the argument of incitement: "Is there anyone in the world besides you who publicizes the faith in the Blessed One? If you are thrown into the fire and burned, the whole world will remain lost and misled after the idol." It would be better for you to forgo this time and bow to the idol, and afterwards you can continue on your path to instill faith in the hearts of people. Just this time, bow to the idol for the sake of repairing the world. However, our forefather Avraham replied to him, "I do not want to bow to the idol even for the sake of repairing the world." And although he greatly desired to illuminate the way for the lost and to lead them to the faith in the Blessed One, to bow to the idol for this he would not agree in any way in the world. I would rather forgo everything, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, will do His part, and I have done all that is within my power. And this was the greatest trial, that he cast aside all the desires of his soul, even in the service of God, which he longed for with all his heart and soul to publicize His faith to all the inhabitants of the world, and he did not allow this desire to become a bribe to his will, but he nullified his will for the sake of His will.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of unwavering faith and commitment to God, even in the face of severe trials and temptations. It recounts the story of Abraham, who refused to bow to idolatry despite the potential for greater good in spreading belief in God, illustrating the principle that one must not compromise their faith for any worldly gain or to rectify the world. This reflects a core Hasidic belief in prioritizing divine will over personal desires, showcasing the profound dedication to maintaining the sanctity of faith above all else. Ultimately, it teaches that true devotion requires self-sacrifice and a steadfast rejection of idolatry, regardless of the circumstances.
