passage_content: ובדרךאגב נל"פ דברי הגמ' במסכת מגילה (ז' ע"א) דאיכא שם הרבה ילפיתות דאסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה, ר' יוסי בן דורמסקית אומר אסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה שנאמר ובביזה לא שלחו את ידם, פרש"י האיך ידעו מה עשו הרחוקים אי לאו דברוה"ק נאמרה, אמר שמואל אי הואי התם הוה אמינא מלתא דעדיפא מכולהו שנא' קימו וקבלו וכו', אמר רבא לכולהו אית להו פירכא לבר מדשמואל דלית ליה פירכא וכו' והא דר' יוסי בן דורמסקית דלמא פריסתקי שדור פרש"י שלוחים שלחו להם למרדכי ואסתר שלא נגענו בביזה שלא ירע למלך, וא"כ אין ראי' מזה דברוה"ק נאמרה עכ"ד הגמ', ויל"ד מאי הי' ס"ד דגמ' מעיקרא לילף מהכא דברוה"ק נאמרה, הלא המגילה לא נכתבה מיד כ"א אחר זמן, כאמרז"ל שלחה אסתר לחכמים קבעוני לדורות ולא רצו עד שדרשו כתוב זאת זכרון בספר וכו' עיי"ש, וא"כ במשך הזמן אפשר שחקרו כל פרטי פרטיים וגם שלחו הרחוקים שלוחים כקושית הגמ', ומנ"ל דברוה"ק נאמרה.
translation: And by the way, it seems that the words of the Gemara in Tractate Megillah (7a) should be noted, that there are many teachings there that Esther was said with divine inspiration. Rabbi Yossi ben Dromaskit says that Esther was said with divine inspiration, as it is stated, "And in the plunder they did not send their hand." Rashi explains how did they know what the distant ones did if it was not said with divine inspiration. Shmuel said, if I were there, I would have said something that is superior to all of them, as it is stated, "They established and accepted," etc. Rava said that for all of them there is a refutation except for Shmuel, who has no refutation, etc. And this of Rabbi Yossi ben Dromaskit, perhaps it is a question of the messengers who were sent to Mordechai and Esther, that we did not touch the plunder so that it would not be bad for the king. And if so, there is no proof from this that it was said with divine inspiration, thus far the Gemara. And it should be understood what was the initial thought of the Gemara to learn from here that it was said with divine inspiration, for the scroll was not written immediately but rather after some time, as our sages said, Esther sent to the sages to establish it for generations, and they did not want to until they required, "Write this as a memorial in a book," etc. Therefore, over time, it is possible that they investigated all the details, and also sent messengers from afar, as the Gemara questions, and from where do we know that it was said with divine inspiration.
summary: The passage discusses the Talmudic interpretation regarding the Book of Esther, particularly the assertion that it was divinely inspired (ברוה"ק). Rabbi Yossi ben Dromaskit argues that the phrase "and they did not send their hands to the plunder" indicates a divine revelation, as it suggests knowledge of distant events. The text highlights the complexity of understanding the divine nature of the Megillah, emphasizing that it was not written immediately but rather after a period of reflection and inquiry by Esther and the sages. This underscores the Hasidic concept of the interplay between divine inspiration and human understanding in the unfolding of sacred texts.

passage_content: וק"זהישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' ואתחנן) ביאר דברי הגמ' הנ"ל בדרך נעים ונחמד וז"ל יש להבין מה הי' הכוונה בזה שלא שללו וכו' והנ"ל דיש בו ענין נסתר לבד הפשוט, דהנה יש להבין מ"ד בגמ' (גיטין נ"ז) מבני בניו של המן למדו תורה ברבים וא"כ מזה מוכרח שלא כלו זרע המן. וע"ז יש לתמוה שמהסברא הי' ראוי לראשונה לכלות זרע הצורר, אבל הענין יובן עפימ"ש ז"ל (שמו"ר פ"א סכ"ט) ויפן כה וכה וירא כי אין איש עתיד לצאת ממנו שיתגייר, ולכך באלו שהי' בהן ניצוצות הקדושה לא נגעו בהן. או שנשפע רוה"ק על כל ישראל וכו', ואנשי הכנה"ג כתבו המגילה וידעו זה ברוה"ק, והנה איתא בספרים על פסוק ושבתי אני וראיתי דמעת העשוקים, שהכוונה על ניצוצות הקדושה שנשבו בתוך הטומאה, ועפי"ז מדוקדק מאוד הלשון ובביזה במקום שיש ביזה לא שלחו את ידם. אמנם לפי"ז צ"ב פירכת הגמ' דלמא פרסתקי שדור, והואז"ל תירץ דהפירכא רק לפי הפשטיות שהוא הלבוש, משא"כ להפנימות, ולכך לא אמר אית להו תיובתא עייש"ד כי נעמו ועוד נבאר בזה לדרכנו.
translation: And this is what Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parshat Va'etchanan), explained the words of the aforementioned Gemara in a pleasant and delightful manner. It is necessary to understand what the intention was in not completely eradicating the seed of Haman, etc. The aforementioned indicates that there is a hidden aspect beyond the simple meaning. Behold, we must understand the statement in the Gemara (Gittin 57) that from the descendants of Haman, they learned Torah in public, and therefore it is evident that not all of Haman's seed was destroyed. And on this, one might wonder that logically, it would have been appropriate to completely annihilate the seed of the oppressor. However, the matter can be understood according to what is stated in the Midrash (Shemot Rabbah 1:69) that he looked this way and that and saw that there was no one who would come forth from him to convert, and therefore, those who had within them sparks of holiness were not touched. Or perhaps the Holy Spirit was poured out upon all of Israel, etc. And the men of the Great Assembly wrote the Megillah and knew this through the Holy Spirit. And behold, it is stated in the books regarding the verse "And I returned and saw the tears of the oppressed," that the intention is regarding the sparks of holiness that were captured within the impurity. And according to this, the language is very precise, and in a place where there is plunder, they did not extend their hand. However, according to this, the question arises regarding the Gemara's challenge of perhaps they were from the descendants of the Persians, and the answer is that the challenge is only according to the superficial meaning, which is the garment, whereas in terms of the inner essence, therefore it was not said that they have a refutation, as it is pleasing, and we will further explain this in our way.
summary: The passage discusses the survival of certain descendants of Haman, emphasizing that not all of his lineage was eradicated due to the presence of divine sparks of holiness within them. It suggests that the spiritual insight of the sages, who recognized these sparks through divine inspiration, led to the decision not to harm those with potential for redemption. The text highlights the concept of hidden holiness within impurity and the importance of recognizing and preserving these divine elements, reflecting a deeper understanding of the relationship between good and evil in the world.

passage_content: ונל"פאף לפי פשוטו דהכוונה על ביזה של כסף וזהב וכלים נחמדים, דהנה בני ישראל היו עסוקים לכלות שונאיהם ושונאי ד' זרע עמלק נוסף לזה היו צריכים להזהר שלא להרוג אותן שיש בהן ניצוצות הקדושה, כמ"ש ק"ז זלל"ה שנשפע רוה"ק על כל ישראל וידעו להזהר בזה, אמנם הנותן דעתו אל הביזה, לא ימלט שלא ינטה מן תכליתו, כי נעשה משוחד אל הרצון הזה, וכל מטרתו רק להשיג מן הביזה כל מה שאפשר, לז"א הכתוב והרוג בשונאיהם חמשה ושבעים אלף, ואל תחשוב שלא כוונו אל המערה להרוג הראויים ליהרג, ולהניח הראויים להמלט, לז"א ובביזה לא שלחו את ידם, שלא נגעו בביזה כלל, ואם אין משוחדים אל הביזה אז מגיעים אל האמת.
translation: And it seems according to its simple meaning that the intention is regarding the plunder of silver, gold, and precious vessels. Behold, the children of Israel were occupied with destroying their enemies and the enemies of God, the seed of Amalek. In addition to this, they needed to be careful not to kill those who contained sparks of holiness, as it is written in Zohar that the Holy Spirit was poured out upon all of Israel, and they knew to be cautious about this. However, one who focuses on the plunder cannot help but stray from his purpose, for he becomes corrupted by this desire, and his entire aim is only to obtain from the plunder all that is possible. Therefore, the scripture says, "And they killed of their enemies five hundred seventy thousand," and do not think that they intended to the cave to kill those who were deserving of death and to spare those who were deserving of escape. Thus it is said, "And in the plunder they did not stretch out their hand," for they did not touch the plunder at all. If they are not corrupted by the plunder, then they reach the truth.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of intention and purity of purpose in the context of the Israelites' battles against their enemies, particularly Amalek. It highlights that while they were engaged in warfare, they needed to be mindful not to harm those who contained sparks of holiness. The text warns against being distracted by the allure of material gain from the spoils of war, suggesting that true spiritual clarity and connection to the divine can only be achieved by avoiding such distractions. Ultimately, it conveys that a focus on the divine purpose leads to a more profound understanding of justice and mercy in their actions.

passage_content: אמנםלא יספיק מה שלא לקחו מן הביזה בפועל, דאף אם רק נותנים דעתם להשיג מן הביזה, א"א לכוון אל האמת, וכמו שאירע להרבה בנ"א שתעו מדרך האמת, בשביל שהיו מצפים להנאה המדומה ונשתחדו אל הרצון הזה, אף שלא הגיע אליהם ונסתיים בהבל וריק, אולם כותבי המגילה ידעו ברוה"ק שלא כוונו שום א' מישראל אל הביזה, ולא שלחו את ידם להרוג בשונאיהם לכוונת הביזה, ומזה למדו ז"ל דאסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה, ול"ק דחיית הגמ' דלמא פריסתקי שדור, ששלחו שלוחים להודיע למרדכי ואסתר שלא נגעו בביזה, דא"א לברר דבר זה על ידי שליח ואין אדם יודע מה שבלב חבירו ועכ"ח דברוה"ק נאמרה, ומה דדחו בגמ' דברי ר"י דדלמא פריסתקי שדור, היינו אלמלי לא הי' לנו ילפותא דשמואל דאסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה, היינו מפרשים ובביזה לא שלחו את ידם שלא לקחו בפועל, וא"כ אין ראי' דברוה"ק נאמרה, דדבר זה אפשר שהודיעו ע"י שלוחים כדחיית הגמ' דלמא פריסתקי שדור, אבל לפי המסקנא דאסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה, נרמז בכתוב גם שלא נתכוונו אל הביזה וע"כ ע"י רוה"ק דאל"ה מנא ידעי, וכמו"כ אפ"ל לדרך ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה, דבאמת לפי המסקנא שכבר נתברר לנו ממקו"א דאסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה, מסתבר שנרמז ג"ז בפסוק ובביזה לא שלחו את ידם, שלא נגעו להרוג במקום שיש ניצה"ק, ומה דדחי בגמ' דלמא פריסתקי שדור, היינו אלמלי לא הי' לנו ילפותא ממקו"א אין הכרח מכאן דברוה"ק נאמרה, דדלמא פי' הכתוב כפשוטו, וע"ז איכא דחויא דלמא פריסתקי שדור והבן.
translation: Indeed, it is not sufficient what they did not take from the spoils in practice, for even if they only set their minds to obtain from the spoils, it is impossible to align with the truth. This is as happened to many people who strayed from the path of truth because they were expecting a false benefit and surrendered to this desire, even though it did not reach them and ended in vanity and emptiness. However, the authors of the scroll knew through the Holy Spirit that no one from Israel intended for the spoils, nor did they extend their hands to kill their enemies with the intention of the spoils. From this, our sages learned that Esther was said through the Holy Spirit, and it is not difficult to understand the rejection in the Gemara that perhaps they sent messengers to inform Mordechai and Esther that they did not touch the spoils, for it is impossible to clarify this matter through a messenger, and no one knows what is in the heart of another. And thus, it is said through the Holy Spirit. And what the Gemara rejected regarding the words of Rabbi Yochanan, that perhaps the messengers of the generation, is because if we did not have the teaching of Shmuel that Esther was said through the Holy Spirit, we would interpret that they did not send their hands to the spoils, that they did not take in practice. Therefore, there is no proof that it was said through the Holy Spirit, for this matter could have been communicated through messengers, as the Gemara rejected that perhaps the messengers of the generation. But according to the conclusion that Esther was said through the Holy Spirit, it is hinted in the verse that they also did not intend for the spoils, and therefore through the Holy Spirit, for otherwise, how would we know? Likewise, it can be said according to the way of the holy Rabbi Moshe, may his memory be blessed, that indeed, according to the conclusion that has already been clarified to us from other sources that Esther was said through the Holy Spirit, it is reasonable that this is also hinted in the verse that they did not send their hands to the spoils, that they did not touch to kill where there was a spark of holiness. And what the Gemara rejects regarding perhaps the messengers of the generation, is that if we did not have a teaching from other sources, there is no necessity from here that it was said through the Holy Spirit, for perhaps the verse means simply, and to this, there is a challenge that perhaps the messengers of the generation, and understand.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of intention in actions, particularly regarding the spoils of war. It argues that true alignment with divine will cannot be achieved if one is motivated by material gain, as seen in the case of the Purim story where the Jewish people did not seek the spoils from their enemies. The text highlights that the authors of the Megillah, through divine inspiration, understood that the Israelites did not intend to take the spoils, which is a key aspect of their righteousness. This understanding reinforces the notion that genuine spiritual intent is paramount in fulfilling God's commandments.

passage_content: היוצאלנו מזה דבמקום שיש עסק של ביזה צריך לסייעתא דשמיא מרובה שלא יכשל האדם וינטה מדרך האמת, כי השוחד יעוור עיני חכמים, וכבר פירשתי במאמר הנביא (ישעי' א') שמתאונן שם על מצב הדור בעת החורבן ואמר שריך סוררים וחברי גנבים כולו אוהב שוחד ורודף שלמונים וגו', דהנה ממ"ש כולו אוהב שוחד ולא אמר כולו לוקחי שוחד. משמע שלא הי' כללות הדור בזה הבחי' רעה לקבל שוחד: רק היו אוהבי שוחד, ולכאורה מאי גריעותא כ"כ אם רק אהבו את השוחד ונתגברו על יצרן ולא קבלו, ומדוע מונה אותו הנביא בין עבירות החמורות כ"כ, ויש מהקדמונים דס"ל דעדיף טפי מי שיש לו נטי' אל הרע ומתגבר עליו, שעושה לכבוד קונו, משא"כ מי שבטבעיותו מרוחק ממנה במה עובד את אדוניו, ומסייע להם מדברי רז"ל (תו"כ סו"פ קדושים) אל יאמר אדם אי אפשי בבשר חזיר וכו' והרמב"ם חולק עליהם, (עיין ישמח משה פ' ראה) אמנם שאני שוחד מכל עבירות שבתורה, דאם יש לאדם נטי' ח"ו אל א' מהעבירות ונתגבר על יצרו ולא עשאה, הרי עדיין לא פעל און ואדרבה עבודה גדולה הוא, משא"כ שוחד מעוור עיני האדם ומרחיקו מדרך האמת, וע"כ אף אם יש לו רק נטי' ואוהב את השוחד ומצפה לקבלו, אף אם לא יקבל כלום, הדמיון בלבד מעוור עיני שכלו, ואף שוחד דברים נמי אסור כאמרז"ל (כתובות ק"ה ע"ב) והביאו בגמ' שם מעשה בר' ישמעאל בר אלישע דאייתי לי' האי גברא ראשית הגז, וא"ל דינא אית לי, א"לפסילנא לך לדינא ולא קביל מיני', אותיב לי' זוגא דרבנן וקדייני לי', בהדי דקאזיל ואתי אמר אי בעי טעין הכי ואי בעי טעין הכא, (פרש"י בכל אשר הולך ובא הי' לבו לזכותו וכו', ואומר בלבוהלואי ויטעון כך וכך ויזכה בדין) אמר תיפח נפשם של מקבלי שוחד. ומה אני שלא נטלתי ואם נטלתי שלי נטלתי כך, מקבלי שוחד עאכו"כ, ולזה התאונן הנביא כולו אוהבי שוחד, אף שלא היו כולם מקבלי שוחד אבל מפני שהי' ענין השוחד אהוב אצלם כבר נתרחקו מאור האמת וצריך למאוס בזה בתכלית ההתרחקות.
translation: We must be aware that in a place where there is a business of plunder, one needs a great deal of divine assistance so that a person does not stumble and deviate from the path of truth, for bribery blinds the eyes of the wise. I have already explained in the words of the prophet (Isaiah 1) who laments the state of the generation at the time of the destruction, saying that the rulers are rebellious and companions of thieves, all of them love bribes and pursue rewards, etc. Behold, it is written "all of them love bribes" and it does not say "all of them take bribes." This implies that not the entirety of the generation was in this bad trait of accepting bribes; rather, they were lovers of bribes. And seemingly, what is so bad if they only loved the bribe and overcame their inclination and did not accept it? Why does the prophet count this among such serious transgressions? There are some of the ancients who hold that it is better for one who has an inclination towards evil and overcomes it, as he does so for the honor of his Creator, unlike one who is naturally distant from it; how does he serve his Master? And they support this from the words of our sages (Toras Kohanim, Parshas Kedoshim) that one should not say, "I do not desire to eat pork," etc. However, Rambam disagrees with them (see Yismach Moshe, Parshas Re'eh). Nevertheless, I differentiate bribery from all the transgressions in the Torah, for if a person has an inclination, Heaven forbid, towards one of the transgressions and overcomes his inclination and does not commit it, he has not yet acted wickedly, and on the contrary, it is a great service. However, bribery blinds a person's eyes and distances him from the path of truth. Therefore, even if he only has an inclination and loves the bribe and hopes to receive it, even if he does not receive anything, the mere thought blinds his intellect. And even verbal bribery is also forbidden, as our sages said (Ketubot 105b), and they brought there a story about Rabbi Yishmael ben Elisha who was presented with a certain man who was the first of the fleece, and he said to him, "I have a legal claim against you." He replied, "I will disqualify you from the legal claim and will not accept from you." He then presented him with a pair of rabbis and they judged him. As they were going and coming, he said, "If I want to claim this way and if I want to claim that way," (Rashi explains that wherever he went and came, his heart was to justify him, etc., and he said in his heart, "Would that he would claim thus and thus and be justified in the judgment"). He said, "Cursed be the souls of those who accept bribes." And as for me, who did not take, and if I took, I took what was mine, how much more so for those who accept bribes! And for this, the prophet lamented, "all of them love bribes," even though not all of them were acceptors of bribes, but because the matter of bribery was beloved to them, they have already distanced themselves from the light of truth, and one must utterly despise this.
summary: The passage emphasizes the danger of favoritism towards bribery, highlighting that even a mere inclination to love bribes can blind a person to the truth and lead them away from righteousness. It contrasts the severity of bribery with other sins, arguing that while one may resist other temptations, the love of bribes corrupts the mind and distorts moral judgment. The prophet's lamentation about the generation's love for bribes serves as a warning that such attitudes, even without actual acceptance of bribes, can distance individuals from divine truth and necessitate a complete rejection of this inclination. Ultimately, the text calls for a profound aversion to bribery to maintain one's connection to the path of truth.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דברי הגמ' (סוטה י"ג ע"א) שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה ומשרע"ה נתעסק בעצמות יוסף שנא' חכם לב יקח מצות, (עיין לעיל קושיא ב') דאה"נ שגם ישראל לש"ש נתכוונו ונצטוו על ככה מפי ד', ואמרז"ל בגמרא ברכות (דף ט' ע"א) שא"ל הקב"ה למשה בבקשה ממך לך ואמור לישראל בבקשה מכם שאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וכלי זהב וכו' ומה דשבקו העסק בעצמות יוסף על משרע"ה, היתה ג"כ כוונתם לש"ש כאמרז"ל שאמרו כבודו בגדולים יותר מבקטנים, אמנם מפני שהיו עסוקין בביזה נעשו משוחדין אלי' והשוחד יעוור עיני חכמים ואמרז"ל אם חכם חכמתו מסתלקת ממנו, משא"כ משרע"ה נתקיימה חכמתו. ולזה דרשו רז"ל חכם לב יקח מצות זה משה שעסק בעצמות יוסף ונסתלק מן הביזה, ולכך תיארוהו בזה בתואר חכם, וסיפי' דקרא ואויל שפתיים ילבט נדרש על ישראל דמפני שהרבו העסק בביזה נאבדה חכמתם, ואפשר דאילולי כן היו מכריעים לקיים שניהם.
translation: And in this, the words of the Gemara (Sotah 13a) are clarified, that all of Israel were engaged in plunder, while Moshe Rabbeinu was occupied with the bones of Yosef, as it is said, "A wise heart will acquire commandments" (Proverbs 10:8). (See above, question 2.) Indeed, it is true that Israel also intended for the sake of Heaven and were commanded thus from the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed be He. And our Sages said in the Gemara Berakhot (9a) that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moshe, "Please go and tell Israel, 'Please, from you, ask the Egyptians for silver and gold vessels,' etc." And the reason that they abandoned the task of the bones of Yosef for Moshe Rabbeinu was also for the sake of Heaven, as our Sages said, "His honor is greater in the great ones than in the small ones." However, because they were occupied with plunder, they became blinded to it, and bribery blinds the eyes of the wise. And our Sages said, "If a wise man, his wisdom departs from him," whereas in contrast, Moshe Rabbeinu's wisdom was sustained. Therefore, our Sages expounded, "A wise heart will acquire commandments" refers to Moshe, who was engaged with the bones of Yosef and withdrew from the plunder. And thus he is described here with the title of wise. And the end of the verse, "And a fool with his lips will be ruined," is interpreted regarding Israel, that because they increased their engagement in plunder, their wisdom was lost. And it is possible that had it not been for this, they would have been able to fulfill both.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the actions of the Israelites and Moses during the exodus from Egypt, highlighting that while the Israelites were preoccupied with plundering, Moses focused on the bones of Joseph, demonstrating a higher spiritual intent. This reflects the Hasidic concept that true wisdom and divine service come from selflessness and prioritizing sacred tasks over material gain. The text emphasizes that Moses's wisdom remained intact because he was not distracted by the allure of wealth, while the Israelites lost their insight due to their focus on plunder. Ultimately, it illustrates the importance of intention in one's actions and the potential spiritual blindness that can arise from material pursuits.

passage_content: ויהיבשלח פרעה את העם וגו', במד"ר (פרשה כ' סימן ז') מי צווח ווי פרעה משל למלך שהי' בנו הולך למדינה א' ושרה אצל עשיר אחד וכו', והיה המלך משלח אגרות אל אותו האיש וכו', עד שהלך והוציא את בנו בעצמו, התחיל אותו האיש צווח וכו', כך פרעה אמר כשהיו ישראל אצלי הי' הקב"ה משלח לי אגרת בכל שעה, כה אמר ה' שלח עמי וכו', כשהוציא הקב"ה את ישראל התחיל פרעה צועק ווי ששלחתי את ישראל עכ"ד, וצ"ב כי אין המשל דומה לנמשל כי האגרות שקבל פרעה היו התראות על המכות ולא של כבוד, ולמה הי' משתוקק אליהם עד שצווח עבורם ווי.
translation: And Pharaoh sent the people away, etc. In the Midrash (Parashat 20, Section 7), who cried out, "Woe to Pharaoh!" This is like a king whose son was going to a certain country and was staying with a wealthy man, etc. The king was sending letters to that man, etc., until he went and brought his son back himself. Then that man began to cry out, etc. So Pharaoh said, "When Israel was with me, the Holy One, blessed be He, was sending me a letter at every hour, saying, 'Thus says the Lord, let My people go,' etc. When the Holy One, blessed be He, took Israel out, Pharaoh began to cry out, 'Woe that I sent Israel!' Thus far the text. And it is difficult to understand because the parable does not resemble the allegory, for the letters that Pharaoh received were warnings about the plagues and not letters of honor. Why then was he so eager for them that he cried out 'Woe' for them?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author draws a parallel between Pharaoh's experience and a king whose son is taken away, emphasizing the divine communication through plagues as a form of warning rather than honor. Pharaoh initially received messages from God urging him to release the Israelites, which he disregarded, but upon their departure, he lamented his loss. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine intervention and human response, highlighting the tension between authority and the consequences of ignoring divine will. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound regret that can arise from failing to heed spiritual warnings.

passage_content: ב)לבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו וגו', הקשה האוהחה"ק וכי לרצונם שלחו. והלא הכו מכות גדולות ובע"כ שלחום, ולא הי' כאן שנוי רצון כלל, דרצונם עתה כרצונם מאז, ולא יתכן לומר ויהפך לבם.
translation: In the heart of Pharaoh and his servants to the people, they said, "What is this we have done..." The holy teacher asked, "Did they send them willingly?" But did they not strike them with great plagues and send them against their will? There was no change of will here at all, for their will now is as their will was then, and it is not fitting to say that their hearts were turned.
summary: הפסוק מתאר את רגעי השינוי בלב פרעה ועבדיו, כאשר הם מתעוררים לתחושת חרטה על שחרור בני ישראל. השאלה היא כיצד ניתן לומר שהשינוי היה ברצונם, כאשר הם חוו מכות קשות ולא הייתה כאן בחירה חופשית אמיתית. המסקנה היא שהרצון שלהם לא השתנה, אלא היה זה תהליך של הכרה פנימית, המצביע על כך שהלב יכול להתהפך גם כאשר נראה שאין רצון חופשי. זה מדגיש את הכוח של התעוררות רוחנית, גם במצבים קשים.

passage_content: ג)יל"ד מ"ש מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל וגו', ובאמת לא הי' כאן עשיה אחרת זולתי השליחות, והול"ל מה זאת שלחנו את ישראל וגו', ולמה האריך הכתוב לכתוב תרתי מילי עשי' ושליחות, ולפי הנראה אינו אלא חדא, גם הלשון כי שלחנו אינו מובן.
translation: 3) "What is this we have done that we have sent away Israel?" (Exodus 10:7). In truth, there was no other action here besides the sending away, and it should have said, "What is this we have sent away Israel?" And why does the text elaborate to write two terms: action and sending? It seems that it is only one. Also, the expression "that we have sent" is not clear.
summary: הקטע עוסק בשאלה מדוע הכתוב מתייחס לשני מושגים, "עשיה" ו"שליחות", כאשר למעשה מדובר באותו מעשה. הכותב מציע שההבדל בין השניים הוא מהותי, שכן שליחות נושאת עמה משמעות רוחנית עמוקה יותר מאשר פעולה פשוטה. המילים "כי שלחנו" מדגישות את הכוונה וההקשר הרוחני של המעשה, מה שמעיד על כך שהמעשה החיצוני הוא רק ביטוי לפנימיות ולכוונה של הנשמה.

passage_content: ד)במה שפי' רש"י ז"ל ויהפך נהפכו לרדוף אחריהם בשביל ממונם שהשאילום, ויש להבין למה שינה רש"י מהטעם המפורש בקרא כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, ונתן טעם חדש בשביל ממונם שאינו מרומז בכתוב כלל.
translation: In what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explained, "and he turned to pursue them for the sake of their money that he had borrowed from them," one must understand why Rashi altered the explicit reason in the verse, "for we have sent away the Israelites from our service," and provided a new reason concerning their money, which is not hinted at in the text at all.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses Rashi's interpretation of the verse regarding the Egyptians' pursuit of the Israelites, suggesting that their motivation was driven by the desire to reclaim their borrowed wealth. This interpretation introduces a new reason for the Egyptians' actions, diverging from the explicit biblical text that emphasizes their desire to retain control over the Israelites as servants. The theological insight highlights the complexity of human motivations and the interplay between material possessions and spiritual freedom, reflecting a deeper understanding of divine providence and the struggles inherent in the journey towards liberation.

passage_content: ה)(ס"י) ויהי בשלח פרעה הה"ד אמרו לאלקים מה נורא מעשיך ברוב עוזך יכחשו לך אויביך וכו' ר' ברכיה אמר יעשו כזבים בדבריהם כענין שנאמר וכחש בעמיתו, מתחלה אמר וגם את ישראל לא אשלח, ואח"כ הוא הי' מחזיר על פתחיהן של ישראל וא"ל לכו לשלום צאו לשלום הוי ברוב עזך יכחשו לך אויביך ע"כ, ראוי להבין דלכאורה אין זה בגדר כחש וכזב, דמתחלה כשאמר את ישראל לא אשלח כן הי' דעתו ורצונו באמת, ופיו ולבו שווין, וגם עתה לא נשתנה רצונו, אלא שבע"כ שלחם, ולא שינה דיבורו דמ"ש לא אשלח כוונתו שלא ישלח ברצון עצמו, ולא עבר ע"ז. ואין זה בגדר כחש וכזב, גם קשה דהול"ל דרשא זו על פסוק קומי צאי מתוך עמי, כי שם מקומו בפ' הקודמת, ולמה המתין עד הכא. ואיך שייכא דרשא זו לכאן.
translation: And it was when Pharaoh sent out the people, as it is said, "Say to God, how awesome are Your deeds; in the abundance of Your strength, Your enemies will lie to You," etc. Rabbi Berachiah said they will make falsehoods in their words, as it is stated, "and he lied to his fellow." At first, he said, "I will not send out Israel," and afterwards he was returning to the doorways of Israel and said to them, "Go in peace, depart in peace; in the abundance of Your strength, Your enemies will lie to You." Therefore, it is appropriate to understand that seemingly this is not in the category of lying and falsehood, for at first when he said, "I will not send out Israel," that was indeed his true intention and desire, and his heart and mouth were in agreement. And even now, his desire has not changed, except that he was compelled to send them out, and he did not change his words, for when he said, "I will not send," his intention was that he would not send them of his own will, and he did not transgress this. And this is not in the category of lying and falsehood. It is also difficult, for this teaching should have been stated on the verse "Get up, go out from among my people," for there is its place in the previous chapter, and why did he wait until here? And how is this teaching relevant here?
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of Pharaoh's statements regarding the Israelites' release, highlighting the tension between his initial refusal and subsequent actions. It emphasizes that Pharaoh's intentions remained consistent, as he did not change his will but was compelled to act against it. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine intervention, where God's will can override human intentions without altering their essence. The text invites contemplation on the complexities of truth and deception in the context of divine authority and human agency.

passage_content: ו)ויהי בשלח פרעה וגו' ילמדינו רבינו השולח יד בפקדונו של חבירו כיצד הוא נגבה, כך שנו רבותינו השולח יד בפקדון ב"ש אומרים ילקה בחסר וביתר, וב"ה אומרים כשעת הגזילה וכו' ומנין שהיו ישראל בידו פקדון. שכן הוא אומרלמשה שיאמר לישראל פקד פקדתי אתכם וכו' ובשביל ששלח יד בהם שבר הקב"ה את זרועו וכו', ולכאורה קשה דלמה לי טעמא דפקדון, והלא בלא"ה ראוי שיענש, שהושלכו ילדיהם ליאור על פקודתו ושקעם בבנין, והכו ע"י הנוגשים, והרבה עליהם גזירות רעות, ומי שעושה כל אלה ראוי שיענש אפי' אינם בתורת פקדון אצלו, גם ראוי להבין דהול"ל דרשא זו בפ' שמות עה"פ הבה נתחכמה, וימררו את חייהם, כי שם מקומו, ולמה הסמיכו דרשא זו לפ' ויהי בשלח פרעה, וצ"ב.
translation: And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth, etc. Our Rabbi teaches us how one who sends his hand upon the deposit of his friend is punished. Thus our Rabbis taught: One who sends his hand upon a deposit, Beit Shammai says he is punished for the deficiency and for the excess, and Beit Hillel says he is punished as at the time of the theft, etc. And from where do we know that Israel was in his hand as a deposit? For it is said to Moses to tell Israel, "I have surely remembered you," etc. And because he sent his hand upon them, the Holy One, blessed be He, broke his arm, etc. However, it is difficult to understand why we need the reasoning of a deposit, for without it he is certainly deserving of punishment, as he cast their children into the Nile at his command and crushed them in the buildings, and he struck them through the taskmasters, and he imposed many evil decrees upon them. And one who does all these things is deserving of punishment even if they are not considered a deposit in his eyes. It is also necessary to understand why this interpretation is stated in Parashat Shemot on the verse "Come, let us deal wisely," and they made their lives bitter, for there is its place, and why is this interpretation connected to the portion "And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth"? This is a question.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine justice in relation to the suffering of the Israelites in Egypt, emphasizing that Pharaoh's actions against them were akin to mishandling a deposit (פקדון). It highlights that despite the severe oppression, the punishment for Pharaoh is justified not only by his direct actions but also by the inherent moral obligation to protect the vulnerable. The text questions why this interpretation is placed in the context of Pharaoh's sending the Israelites away, suggesting a deeper connection between the themes of oppression and divine retribution. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexity of justice and the necessity of understanding the spiritual implications of one's actions.

passage_content: ולבארכל הענין נקדים מה שהקשה האוהחה"ק בפ' שמות וז"ל: צריך לתת לב, למה יצו ה' דברים שאינם מהמוסר, לגנוב דעתם של המצרים במ"ש נלכה נא דרך שלשת ימים, כי ח"ו לא קצור קצרה ידו מפדות ישראל בע"כ, גם בהשאלת כליהם למה יצטרכו לעשות דרך ערמה, הלא הי' ביכולת השי"ת להוציא ממונם בע"כ ועיניהם רואות וכלות, גם היו המצרים נותנים להם ברצונם אפי' בדרך מתנה כמ"ש במדרש שאמרו עול שנים וצא, כי אמרו כולנו מתים, ותירץ האוהחה"ק כי נתכוין ה' בזה להטעותם כדי שירדפו אחריהם, וזולת השאלה, גם זולת הליכתם בדרך זה על דעת לחזור, לא היו המצרים רודפים אחריהם והיו מתייאשים מחזרתם, ומ"ש נלכה נא דרך שלשתימים לא הי' דברי השי"ת, אלא זקני ישראל אמרו כן, גם השאלת כליהם אין בו דברי שקר, כי בתורת שאלה בא לידם אלא שעכבוהו בעד תביעתם של שכר שכיר שעבדו להם וכו' עיי"ש.
translation: To clarify the entire matter, we will begin with what the holy author of Chassidus questioned in Parashat Shemot, and he said: One must pay attention to why the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded things that are not from the realm of ethics, to deceive the Egyptians with the statement "Let us go a three-day journey," for Heaven forbid, His hand is not too short to redeem Israel against their will. Also, regarding the borrowing of their vessels, why would they need to act in a cunning manner? Surely, it was within the ability of the Blessed One to take their possessions against their will, and their eyes see and are consumed. Moreover, the Egyptians would have willingly given them even as a gift, as stated in the Midrash, where they said, "We are all dying, go and take." The holy author of Chassidus answered that the intent of the Holy One was to mislead them so that they would pursue them. Without this question, and aside from their journey in this manner with the intention of returning, the Egyptians would not have pursued them and would have despaired of their return. And the statement "Let us go a three-day journey" was not the words of the Blessed One, but rather the elders of Israel said this. Also, the borrowing of their vessels does not contain falsehood, for it came to them as a loan, but they were held back due to their claim for the wages of the labor they had done for them, etc. See there.
summary: The passage discusses the divine strategy behind the Israelites' request to the Egyptians to borrow their possessions and to travel a three-day journey, emphasizing that these actions were not mere deception but part of God's plan to lead the Egyptians to pursue the Israelites. The author, drawing from Hasidic thought, suggests that this approach was necessary to ensure the Egyptians would chase after the Israelites, preventing them from losing hope in their escape. The narrative highlights the interplay between divine providence and human actions, illustrating how God orchestrates events to fulfill His will while allowing for human agency. Ultimately, it reflects on the deeper purpose behind seemingly mundane actions in the context of redemption.

passage_content: אמנםעדיין צ"ב כי למה יצטרך להטעותם בשביל שיתנו לב לרדוף אחריהם, והרי כמה דרכים למקום, והי' אפשר שיתן השי"ת בלבם כבדות לב שירדפו אחריהם אף אם יהי' תחילת הליכתם שלא ע"מ לחזור, ואמרו ז"ל במדרש שפרעה שחרר אותם לגמרי בשעה שיצאו וא"ל הרי אתם בן חורין הרי אתם ברשותכם, ואעפ"כ הפך לבו ורדף אחריהם, וכמו"כ הי' רודף אחריהם אף אם לא אמרו לו מתחלה נלכה נא דרך שלשת ימים. גם מה שתירץ האוהחה"ק דזקני ישראל אמרו כן, ולא הי' דברי השי"ת, אינו מתורץ בזה כל צרכו, שהרי אמרו חכז"ל במס' סוכה (דף מ"ו ע"ב) לא לימא איניש לינוקא דיהיבנא לך מידי ולא יהיב לי' משום דאתי לאגמורי' שיקרא, שנאמר למדו לשונם דבר שקר, ואיך יתכן שבשעת שיצאו ישראל ממצרים והיו מוכנים לקבלת התורה, ועתה הי' התחלת הדרכתם לתורה ומצות, שילמדו לשונם דבר מרמה, וצ"ב.
translation: However, it is still questionable why He needed to deceive them so that they would pay attention to pursue them, as there are many paths to the place, and it would have been possible for the Holy One, Blessed be He, to place heaviness in their hearts so that they would pursue them even if their initial intention was not to return. And our Sages, of blessed memory, said in the Midrash that Pharaoh completely freed them at the moment they left and said to them, "Behold, you are free men; you are in your own authority," and nevertheless, his heart was turned and he pursued them. Similarly, he would have pursued them even if they had not initially said, "Let us go a three-day journey." Also, the explanation given by the holy author that the elders of Israel said so, and it was not the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is not fully resolved by this, for our Sages, of blessed memory, said in Tractate Sukkah (46b) that one should not say to a child, "I will give you something," and then not give it to him, for he will come to learn to speak falsehood, as it is said, "They taught their tongue to speak deceit." How is it possible that at the time the Israelites left Egypt and were prepared to receive the Torah, and now was the beginning of their guidance towards the Torah and commandments, they would learn to speak words of deception? This remains a question.
summary: The passage questions why God would need to deceive the Egyptians to prompt their pursuit of the Israelites, suggesting that divine intervention could have led the Egyptians to pursue them regardless. It references the Midrash, which states that Pharaoh released the Israelites, yet his heart was hardened to chase them. Additionally, it raises concerns about the integrity of the Israelites' initial intentions, as they were preparing to receive the Torah, yet were instructed to speak deceitfully, highlighting the tension between divine guidance and human morality in the context of redemption and spiritual growth.

passage_content: ולבארכל אלה נקדים מה שהקשה הפרשת דרכים (בדרוש ה' דרך מצרים) וז"ל איך דן הקב"ה את המצריים במיתה וממון, והא קיי"ל דאין אדם מת ומשלם. וכתבו התוס' בפ"ה דמס' ע"ז (דף ע"א) דגם בבני נח אמרינן קים לי' בדרבה מיני' וא"כ כיון שהמצריים נתחייבו מיתה איך נענשו גם בממון, ותירץ דקיי"ל כרבנן דס"ל דלא אמרינן קים לי' בדרבה מיני' אלא במיתה בידי אדם, אבל במיתה בידי שמים אדם מת ומשלם דלא קיי"ל כר' נחוניא בן הקנה שהי' עושה את יוהכ"פ כשבת עיי"ש, ובדרך המצפה (בדרוש כ"ו) כתב לתרץ קושיא זו דאפי' לדברי ר' נחוניא בן הקנה א"ש, עפימ"ש התוס' בכתובות (דף ל' ע"ב ד"ה זר), דגזירת הכתוב הוא בהקדש ותרומה דלא אמרינן קים לי' בדרבה מיני', ואמרי בהו מת ומשלם, ומעתה א"ש אפי' לר' נחוניא דכיון דישראל קודש וראשית תבואתו של הקב"ה דהיינו תרומה, כדמשמע מסוגית הגמ' קידושין (דף נ"ג ע"א) דראשית תבואתו היינו תרומה עיי"ש, וע"כ מדינא חייבים המצריים וכל האומה"ע המריעים לישראל להיות לוקים ומשתלמים על ידיהם, ופי' בזה הכתוב קודש ישראל לה' ראשית תבואתו, ע"כ כל אוכליו יאשמו, ר"ל שחייבים לשלם מלשון ואת אשמו ישוב בראשו, וגם רעה תבוא עליהם שיענשו בידי שמים, עכת"ד ז"ל. ומעתה א"ש דהי' ההכרח ליקח מידם הרכוש בתורת שאלה, דאלמלי הגיע לידם מעיקרא בתורת תשלומין, הי' פתחון פה למקטרג שלא יוכו המצריים עוד שאין אדם לוקה ומשלם, ע"כ קבלוהו מעיקרא בתורת שאלה, ואחר שיצאו ונעשו הקדש כמו שיתבאר להלן זכו בהרכוש להיות שלהם לחלוטין.
translation: To explain all these matters, we will first address the difficulty raised by the separation of paths (in the discourse "The Way of Egypt"), which states: how did the Holy One, blessed be He, judge the Egyptians with death and monetary loss, when we hold that a person does not die and pay? The Tosafot wrote in the fifth chapter of Avodah Zarah (page 71) that even regarding the sons of Noah, we say that he has a claim in many ways. Therefore, since the Egyptians were liable for death, how were they also punished in monetary matters? It was answered that we hold like the Rabbis who say that we do not say he has a claim in many ways except for death at the hands of man, but in death at the hands of Heaven, a person dies and pays, as we do not hold like Rabbi Nechunya ben HaKana, who treated Yom Kippur like Shabbat, as mentioned there. In the discourse of the watchtower (in discourse 26), it was written to resolve this difficulty that even according to the words of Rabbi Nechunya ben HaKana, it is fine, as the Tosafot state in Ketubot (page 30b, "Zar"), that it is a decree of Scripture regarding consecrated items and offerings that we do not say he has a claim in many ways, and they say about them that he dies and pays. Therefore, it is fine even for Rabbi Nechunya, since Israel is holy and the first of the produce of the Holy One, blessed be He, which is the offering, as implied in the Gemara's discussion in Kiddushin (page 53a) that the first of his produce refers to the offering, as mentioned there. Thus, by law, the Egyptians and all the nations of the world that harm Israel are liable to be struck and to pay through them. The verse explains this: "The holiness of Israel is to the Lord, the first of His produce," therefore, all who eat of it will be guilty, meaning they are obligated to pay, from the language of "and his guilt shall return upon his head," and also evil will come upon them, that they will be punished at the hands of Heaven. Thus far is his holy word. And now it is clear that it was necessary to take the property from them as a loan, for if it had originally come to them as payment, there would have been a justification for the accuser that the Egyptians would not be struck again, since a person does not get struck and pay. Therefore, they accepted it from the beginning as a loan, and after they left and it became consecrated, as will be explained below, they merited that the property should be entirely theirs.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of God's judgment on the Egyptians, who were punished with death and financial loss despite the principle that a person does not pay for their own death. It explains that, according to certain interpretations, the Egyptians were liable for both death and financial restitution because their actions against the Israelites warranted such punishment. The text emphasizes the sanctity of Israel as God's chosen people, suggesting that their status as "the first fruits" obligates others to compensate for their wrongs. Ultimately, it concludes that the Egyptians' possessions were taken as a loan, allowing for their eventual transfer to the Israelites as a form of divine justice.

passage_content: ובזהיתבארו דברי רש"י ז"ל ויהפך לבב פרעה וגו' נהפכו לרדוף אחריהם בשביל ממונםשהשאילום, שאמרו לקינו ונטלו ממוננו ושלחנום וכו', כי מעיקרא היו מוכרחים לשלחם מפני המכות, ושמחו מצרים בצאתם, אבל עכשיו שנטלו את ממונם לחלוטין חשב פרעה כי מעתה בלא"ה לא היו לוקין עוד, כי אין אדם לוקה ומשלם וע"כ התחרט על מה ששלחם, וזה שפרש"י ויהפך לבב פרעה וסיבת ההחרטה הי' בשביל ממונם שהשאילום שאמרו לקינו ונטלו ממוננו ושלחנום, כי לא הי' מוכרח עוד השליחות כי בלא"ה לא היינו לוקים עוד אחרי שנטלו ממוננו, ולא ידע פרעה גם לא האמין שיש להם דין הקדש ע"כ התחרט על ששלחם, וסיבת החרטה היתה בשביל ממונם כמו שפירש"י וא"ש.
translation: And in this, the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, are clarified: "And He hardened the heart of Pharaoh," etc. They turned to pursue them because of their possessions that they had borrowed, as they said, "They have taken our money and sent us away," etc. For initially, they were compelled to send them away because of the plagues, and the Egyptians rejoiced at their departure. But now that they had taken their possessions completely, Pharaoh thought that from now on they would not be stricken anymore, for no one is stricken and pays. Therefore, he regretted having sent them away. This is what Rashi explains: "And He hardened the heart of Pharaoh," and the reason for the regret was because of their possessions that they had borrowed, as they said, "They have taken our money and sent us away," for he was no longer compelled to send them away since, in any case, they would not be stricken anymore after they had taken our possessions. And Pharaoh did not know, nor did he believe, that they had the status of holy property; therefore, he regretted having sent them away, and the reason for the regret was because of their possessions, as Rashi explained, and it is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Pharaoh's heart, as explained by Rashi, emphasizing that his regret for releasing the Israelites stemmed from the loss of their possessions, which he believed would prevent further plagues. Initially, the Egyptians were compelled to let the Israelites go due to the plagues, but after the Israelites took their wealth, Pharaoh thought they would no longer suffer consequences. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between material possessions and spiritual accountability, highlighting Pharaoh's misunderstanding of divine justice and the sanctity of the Israelites' status. Ultimately, Pharaoh's change of heart was driven by a concern for his own loss rather than a recognition of the divine will.

passage_content: ונקדיםעוד מ"ד במד"ר פרשת בא (פ' ט"ז סימן ב') משכו וקחו לכם צאן הה"ד בשובה ונחת תושעון וצ"ב, אכן יתבאר עפי"ד הירושלמי במס' תענית (פ"א ה"א) ר' אחא בש"ר תנחום בי ר' חייה אמר אילו ישראל עושין תשובה יום א' מיד הי' בן דוד בא, מ"ט היום אם בקולו תשמעו, א"ר לוי אילו היו ישראל משמרין שבת אחת כתיקונה מיד הי' בן דוד בא, מ"ט דכתיב כי שבת היום לה' חד יום, (ופי' בקרבן העדה דיליף לי' גז"ש היום היום, מפסוק הנ"ל היום אם בקולו תשמעו) ואומר בשובה ונחת תושעון, בשובה ונייח תתפרקון ע"כ, עכ"פ דרשת הירושלמי מהאי קרא דע"י תשובה ומנוחת השבת יזכו ישראל לגאולתם, בשובה היינו תשובה, ונייח היינו מנוחת השבת, ובזכותם תושעון, והנה קיימו ישראל ב' בחינות הנ"ל, דמצוה זו דמשכו וקחו לכם קיימו בעשור לחודש שהי' שבת הגדול, ואמרו חכז"ל משכו ידיכם מע"ז וכו' ואיתא במדרש שכפרו בע"ז ועשו תשובה הגונה, נמצא שהי' להם ב' הזכותים, זכות השבת, וזכות התשובה, והיו ראויים להגאל, ועפימ"ש הטו"ז (בסי' רמ"ב) עמ"ש חז"ל כל המשמר שבת כהלכתה אפי' עוע"ז כדור אנוש מוחלין לו. איכא למידק ממנ"פ אי לא עשה תשובה שבת מאי מהניא, ואי עשה תשובה שבת ל"ל, ותירץ דמיירי שעשה תשובה, אלא דתשובה לא מהני שיהא מוחלין לו לגמרי כדאיתא במס' יומא בפ' יוהכ"פ, עבר על כריתות ומיתות ב"ד תשובה תולה ומיתה ממרקת, קמ"ל כאן דאם בעשותו תשובה שומר שבת כהלכתה, מהני התשובה שיהא נמחל לו לגמרי, וע"כ בנ"י במצרים שהיו עוע"ז ועברו על מיתת ב"ד, היו צריכין לתשובה בצירוף שמירת שבת, ועי"ז נמחלו עונותיהם והי' ראויים לגאולה, וז"ש במדרש הנ"ל משכו וקחו לכם הה"ד בשובה ונחת תושעון. שהי' להם כאן צירוף זכות שניהם תשובה ושבת, ובזכות זה נגאלו וא"ש.
translation:
And we will further precede with what is stated in the Midrash on Parashat Bo (Chapter 16, Section 2): "Draw and take for yourselves sheep," which corresponds to the verse "In returning and rest you shall be saved," and there is a question. However, it will be explained according to the teaching of the Jerusalem Talmud in Tractate Ta'anit (Chapter 1, Halacha 1), Rabbi Acha in the name of Rabbi Tanḥum, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, said: "If Israel would repent for one day, immediately the son of David would come." What is the reason? "Today, if you will listen to His voice." Rabbi Levi said: "If Israel would observe one Shabbat properly, immediately the son of David would come," for it is written, "For today is a Sabbath to the Lord, a single day." (And the explanation in the Korban HaEdah derives from the verse "Today, today," from the aforementioned verse "Today, if you will listen to His voice.") And it says, "In returning and rest you shall be saved," meaning in returning and resting you will be redeemed. Therefore, the teaching of the Jerusalem Talmud from this verse indicates that through repentance and the rest of Shabbat, Israel will merit their redemption. "In returning" refers to repentance, and "resting" refers to the rest of Shabbat, and by virtue of them, "you shall be saved." 

And behold, Israel fulfilled these two aspects mentioned, for this commandment of "Draw and take for yourselves" they fulfilled on the tenth of the month, which was the Great Shabbat. And our sages said: "Withdraw your hands from idolatry," etc., and it is stated in the Midrash that they renounced idolatry and did proper repentance. Thus, they had two merits: the merit of Shabbat and the merit of repentance, and they were worthy of redemption. 

And according to what is stated in the Taz (in Section 152), our sages said: "Whoever observes Shabbat properly, even if he is an idolater like the generation of Enosh, he is forgiven." One might ask: If he did not repent, what benefit is there from Shabbat? And if he repented, what need is there for Shabbat? And it was answered that it speaks of one who repented, but repentance alone does not suffice for him to be completely forgiven, as it is stated in Tractate Yoma in the chapter on Yom Kippur: "If one transgressed the prohibitions of kareit and the death penalties of the court, repentance suspends [the punishment] and death atones." Here it teaches us that if, in his repentance, he observes Shabbat properly, the repentance is effective for him to be completely forgiven. 

And therefore, the Children of Israel in Egypt, who were idolaters and transgressed the death penalties of the court, needed repentance along with the observance of Shabbat. And through this, their sins were forgiven, and they were worthy of redemption. And this is what is stated in the aforementioned Midrash: "Draw and take for yourselves," which corresponds to "In returning and rest you shall be saved," for they had here the combination of both merits: repentance and Shabbat, and by virtue of this, they were redeemed, and it is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between repentance (teshuva) and the observance of the Sabbath (Shabbat) as prerequisites for redemption. It cites teachings from the Jerusalem Talmud, emphasizing that if the Israelites had repented even once or properly observed the Sabbath, they would have immediately merited the arrival of the Messiah. The text highlights that during their time in Egypt, the Israelites combined both repentance and Sabbath observance, which led to the forgiveness of their sins and ultimately their redemption. Thus, the dual merits of teshuva and Shabbat are presented as essential for achieving salvation.

passage_content: ונקדיםעוד מ"ש המראה פנים להקשות על דברי ירושלמי הנ"ל ממה דאיתא בגמ' שבת (דף קי"ח ע"ב) אמר ר' יוחנן אמר רשב"י אלמלא משמרין ישראל שתי שבתות כהלכתן מיד נגאלים שנא' כה אמר ה' לסריסים אשר ישמרו את שבתותי, וכתיב בתרי' והביאותים אל הר קדשי וגו' ובירושלמי הנ"ל מבואר דע"י שמירת שבת א' מיד נגאלין, עיי"ש שכתב דפליגי הבבלי והירושלמי, אמנם אין סברא לאפושי פלוגתא במקום שאפשר להשוות דבריהם ואפשר לתרץ בהקדם מה שהקשה המהרש"א ז"ל (במס' נדה דף ל"ח ע"א) דאיך למדו רז"ל מהאי קרא דאשר ישמרו אתשבתותי, אלמלי שמרו ישראל ב' שבתות מיד נגאלין, מדכתיב שבתותי ומעוט רבים שנים, הא כתיב בתורה כה"ג כמו אך את שבתותי תשמרו וכולל כל השבתות עד סוף ימי עמידת העולם ומהיכי תיתי לדרוש כאן על ב' שבתות לבד ע"כ קושיתו.
translation: And we will further precede what was said regarding the face of the matter to challenge the words of the aforementioned Jerusalem Talmud from what is stated in the Gemara Shabbat (page 118b): Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai, "If Israel would observe two Shabbats properly, they would be redeemed immediately," as it is written, "Thus says the Lord to the eunuchs who keep My Shabbats," and it is written afterwards, "And I will bring them to My holy mountain," etc. And in the aforementioned Jerusalem Talmud, it is explained that through the observance of one Shabbat, they are redeemed immediately. See there that it is written that the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmud disagree. However, there is no reason to broaden the dispute where it is possible to reconcile their words, and it is possible to address in advance what the Maharsha, of blessed memory, questioned (in Tractate Niddah, page 38a), how the sages learned from this verse, "who keep My Shabbats," that if Israel would keep two Shabbats, they would be redeemed immediately, since it is written "My Shabbats," which implies plurality, two. But it is written in the Torah in this manner, "But you shall keep My Shabbats," which includes all the Shabbats until the end of the days of the world's standing, and from where do we derive to interpret here about only two Shabbats alone? Thus is his question.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of observing the Sabbath in relation to redemption, highlighting a debate between the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmuds. Rabbi Yochanan cites Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai, suggesting that if Israel were to properly observe two Sabbaths, they would be redeemed immediately. The text emphasizes the importance of Sabbath observance as a means of spiritual elevation and connection to divine promise, while addressing the complexity of interpreting scriptural references to the Sabbath. Ultimately, it reflects a deep theological insight into the relationship between ritual observance and redemption in Jewish thought.

passage_content: וק"זהישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' תשא) כתב לתרץ קושיא זו ותו"ד דיסוד האי כללא שאמרו חכז"ל מיעוט רבים שנים, אף דלכאורה ראוי לן למיזל לחומרא ולומר שרבים משמעותו יותר משנים, אבל אם תרבה אין לו שיעור, ולא בא הכתוב לסתום אלא לפרש, והי"ל להכתוב לפרש כמה, ע"כ אוקמי' אמיעוטי' ומיעוט רבים שנים והיינו רק במקום שבוודאי יש לו סוף ושעור, אלא שאין ידוע כמה אז אמרינן מעוט רבים שנים, אבל במקום שבאמת אין לו סוף, א"כ לא בא הכתוב לסתום, דפירושו באמת לעולם, וא"ש דמ"ש אך את שבתותי תשמורו פירושו לעולם, אבל מ"ש ז"ל דאלמלא שמרו ישראל ב' שבתות מיד נגאלין ולמדו כן מדכתיב אשר ישמרו את שבתותי, ע"כ אין פירושו לעולם דכי עד עולםלא יגאלו ח"ו עד שישמרו כל שבתות עולם, א"ו יש בו שיעור ולא ידוע כמה, בזה אמרינן מעוט רבים שנים דלא בא הכתוב לסתום, ואם תאמר יותר הי"ל להכתוב לפרש, עכת"ד ז"ל.
translation: And this is what Moshe, may his memory be blessed, wrote to resolve this question and the foundation of this principle that our sages, may their memory be blessed, said regarding the limitation of many to two. Although it seems appropriate for us to be stringent and say that "many" means more than two, if it increases, it has no measure, and the scripture did not come to close off but to clarify. The scripture could have clarified how much, therefore we establish the limitation of many to two, and this is only in a place where it certainly has an end and a measure, but it is not known how much. Then we say "the limitation of many to two," but in a place where it truly has no end, then the scripture did not come to close off, for its meaning is indeed forever. And it is clear that when it says, "But you shall keep My Sabbaths," it means forever. However, when our sages said that had Israel kept two Sabbaths they would have been redeemed immediately, and they learned this from the verse "who shall keep My Sabbaths," therefore its meaning is not forever, for if it were forever, they would not be redeemed, Heaven forbid, until they keep all the Sabbaths of the world. Rather, there is a measure, and it is not known how much, in this we say "the limitation of many to two," that the scripture did not come to close off. And if you say it would have been better for the scripture to clarify, thus concludes his words.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "minority among the majority" in relation to the observance of Shabbat, emphasizing that while the Torah implies a universal obligation to keep the Sabbath, it also acknowledges a specific measure of observance necessary for redemption. It suggests that the phrase "but you shall keep My Sabbaths" indicates a requirement that is not infinite but has a defined limit, contrasting with the eternal nature of certain commandments. The text highlights the importance of understanding the balance between the infinite and the finite in divine commandments, particularly in the context of redemption and the observance of Shabbat.

passage_content: ויתבארעוד בהקדם מ"ש ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה בפ' תשא) דכתבו המפורשים הטעם מ"ש חכז"ל שני שבתות דוקא, דלא הוי שבת אמיתי כמאמרם שביתה ביום השביעי, רק אם שומר מקודם שבת א'. וא"כ מתחילין אחריו ששת ימי המעשה ואח"כ שובת ביום השביעי, הרי קיים בזה מצות שבת כהלכתה, אבל שבת הראשון ששמר, אין זה יום השביעי אחר ששת ימי המעשה, רק אחר כמה מאות או אלפים ימי המעשה, ולא קיים המצוה כהלכתה, ופי' בזה ושמרו בנ"י את השבת ר"ל שצריכין לשמור שבת א', לעשות את השבת, ר"ל כדי שיעשו את השבת האחר לשבת אמיתי ואז לדורותיכם לברית עולם, ובזכות זה יהיו נגאלין ויהי' כולו שבת עכדה"ק.
translation: And it will be explained further in advance what is written (in Parashat Tisa) that the commentators wrote the reason for what our Sages said about two specific Shabbatot, that it is not a true Shabbat according to their statement of resting on the seventh day, only if one observes from before the first Shabbat. And therefore, they begin after it the six days of work, and then rest on the seventh day, thus fulfilling the commandment of Shabbat properly. However, the first Shabbat that he observed is not the seventh day after the six days of work, but rather after several hundreds or thousands of days of work, and he has not fulfilled the commandment properly. And the explanation of "And the children of Israel shall observe the Shabbat" means that they need to observe the first Shabbat, to make the Shabbat, meaning in order to make the other Shabbat a true Shabbat, and then for your generations, it will be a covenant forever. And through this merit, they will be redeemed, and it will all be Shabbat, blessed be His Name.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of observing the first Shabbat in relation to the true essence of Shabbat as a day of rest. It emphasizes that the first Shabbat, if not preceded by six days of work, does not fulfill the commandment of Shabbat as intended. The text highlights the necessity for the Jewish people to properly observe the first Shabbat to ensure that subsequent Shabbatot are genuine and meaningful, ultimately leading to redemption and the establishment of an eternal covenant. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of the relationship between observance, time, and spiritual fulfillment.

passage_content: ומעתהלא יקשה קושית המראה פנים, ולא יהי' סתירה בין הבבלי והירושלמי, דבאמת אלו שמרו ישראל שבת א' מיד נגאלין כמ"ש בירושלמי, וגם הבבלי סובר כן, ומ"ש במס' שבת הנ"ל דצריך שני שבתות, הוא לטעם הנ"ל דא"א שיהי' שבת א' כהלכתה, אא"כ יקדים לה עוד שבת כדי שיהי' שמירת שבת ביום השביעי שאחר ששת ימי המעשה, ומתורץ ג"כ קושית המהרש"א ז"ל דבאמת ע"י שמירת שבת א' מיד נגאלין ונדרש כן ממ"ש שבת היום כמ"ש בירושלמי, ומ"ש שני שבתות היינו טעמא משום דא"א שיהי' שמירת שבת כהלכתה, בלתי אם יקדים לה שבת א', אבל לא הכריחו כן מדכתיב שבתות ומיעוט רבים שנים, ול"ק קושית המהרש"א ז"ל.
translation: And from now on, the question of the appearance of faces will not be difficult, and there will be no contradiction between the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmuds, for in truth, if Israel observes one Shabbat, they are immediately redeemed, as it is stated in the Jerusalem Talmud. The Babylonian Talmud also holds this view, and what is stated in the aforementioned tractate of Shabbat that two Shabbatot are required is for the reason that it is impossible for there to be one Shabbat observed properly unless another Shabbat is observed beforehand, so that the observance of Shabbat is on the seventh day after the six days of work. This also resolves the question of the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, that indeed through the observance of one Shabbat, they are immediately redeemed, and it is derived from what is said, "Shabbat today," as stated in the Jerusalem Talmud. And when it mentions two Shabbatot, the reason is that it is impossible for there to be a proper observance of Shabbat unless another Shabbat is observed beforehand. However, they did not derive this from the fact that it is written "Shabbatot" and the minority of many is two, and the question of the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, is not difficult.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmuds regarding the redemption of Israel through the observance of Shabbat. It emphasizes that if Israel observes one Shabbat properly, they can be redeemed immediately, as stated in the Jerusalem Talmud. The Babylonian Talmud's requirement for two Shabbatot is explained as a necessity for ensuring that the first Shabbat is observed correctly, thus allowing for the true sanctity of the seventh day to be realized. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the significance of Shabbat as a catalyst for redemption and spiritual elevation.

passage_content: ובזהיתורץ קושית האוהחה"ק במאמה"כ דרך שלשת ימים נלך דאפשר שמעיקרא הי' יציאתם רק על ג' ימים, דהנה בעשור לחודש שמרו ישראל שבת ראשונה כהלכתה בצירוף התשובה, כמ"ש הטו"ז דצריך שמירת שבת בצירוף תשובה, אולם עדיין חסרו להם ששת ימי המעשה, דא"א שמירת שבת כהלכתה מבלי שיקדים לה ששת ימי המעשה, וע"כ הי' צורך לזכות גאולתם עוד שמירת שבת א', והנה כשיצאו ישראל ממצרים חמישי בשבת הי' וביום ג' שלאחר יציאתם שבת הי', ע"כ מתחלה יצאו רק על ג' ימים. והי' תלוי זכות גאולתם בשבת הבאה, וכששמרו שבת שני' כתיקונה נגאלו לחלוטין ואלולי כן היו מוכרחים לחזור למצרים אחר ג' ימים, נמצא דמ"ש נלכה נא דרך שלשת ימים, האמת כן הי' בשעת אמירתם, ולא הי' בזה רמאות ושקר חלילה והבוי"ת מגיד מראשית אחרית ידע מתחלה שישמרו שבת שני' כהלכתה, וע"כ לא נזכר במאמר השי"ת הזמן של ג' ימים, כי היתה ידיעה אצלו שלא יחזרו לסוף ג' ימים למצרים, אבל זקני ישראל הם שאמרו לפרעה נלכה נא דרך ג' ימים כי כן הי' התנאי בשעת יציאתם כנ"ל.
translation: And in this, the question of the holy Torah is resolved regarding the statement, "We will go three days' journey into the wilderness," that it is possible that initially their departure was only for three days. Behold, on the tenth of the month, Israel observed the first Shabbat properly, along with repentance, as the Taz writes that Shabbat observance must be accompanied by repentance. However, they still lacked the six days of work, for it is impossible to observe Shabbat properly without having first completed the six days of work. Therefore, there was a need to merit their redemption through another Shabbat observance. And behold, when Israel left Egypt, it was on a Friday, and the following Tuesday was Shabbat. Thus, initially, they only left for three days. Their merit for redemption was dependent on the next Shabbat, and when they observed the second Shabbat properly, they were completely redeemed. Had it not been so, they would have been compelled to return to Egypt after three days. It turns out that what they said, "Let us go three days' journey," was indeed true at the time of their statement, and there was no deception or falsehood, heaven forbid. The Blessed One, who declares the end from the beginning, knew from the outset that they would observe the second Shabbat properly. Therefore, the time of three days was not mentioned in the statement of the Holy One, for it was known to Him that they would not return to Egypt after three days. Rather, it was the elders of Israel who said to Pharaoh, "Let us go three days' journey," for that was the condition at the time of their departure, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' initial request to Pharaoh to journey for three days, emphasizing that their redemption was contingent upon their observance of the Sabbath. It highlights the necessity of preparing for the Sabbath through six days of work, indicating that true observance of the Sabbath requires prior engagement in the mundane. The text suggests that while the Israelites' claim was genuine at the time, divine foreknowledge ensured that they would ultimately observe the Sabbath correctly, leading to their complete redemption. Thus, the interplay between human intention and divine providence is a key theme in this Hasidic interpretation.

passage_content: ואפשרדע"י ששמרו ישראל שבת שני' כהלכתה ובצירוף תשובה הגונה נעשו ישראל קודש לה', ומעתה דינם של המצרים להיות לוקים ומשלמים על ידיהם, ומתחלה הי' ההכרח ליקח מידם הרכוש בתורת שאלה כמו שכתבנו לעיל, ואחר שנעשו קודש זכו בה ועכבוהו בתורת תשלומין, ויובן בזה מה שפירש"י ז"ל בשם המכילתא ויסע משה את ישראל מים סוף, הסיען בעל כרחן שלא רצו לפרוש מפני ביזת הים שהי' גדולה מאוד והוצרך להסיען בע"כ, ולכאורה קשה ממ"ש ז"ל (במס' ברכות דף ז') דבר נא באזני העם וישאלו איש מאת רעהו וגו' אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, בבקשה ממך הזהירם על כך שלא יאמר אותו צדיק אברהם ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם, הרי שלא רצו ליטול הרכוש והוצרך לבקשם ולהזהירם, ומדוע נשתנה רצונם בביזת הים שלא רצו לפרוש ממנה, ולדרכינו א"ש כי מתחלה הוכרחו ליטלו בדרך שאלה דייקא וע"כ לא הי' רצונם לקבלו, כי למה להם להטריח ברכוש שאינה שלהם. אבל בקריעת ים סוף שזכו בה בתורת תשלומין להיות מוחלטת אצלם, שכבר הי' דינם כקודש להיות המצריים לוקין ומשלמין, מעתה לקחוהו ברצון לבם.
translation: And it is possible that by the fact that Israel kept the Sabbath properly and with the addition of a proper repentance, Israel became holy to the Lord. From now on, the Egyptians are to be punished and pay for their actions. Initially, it was necessary to take the possessions from them as a loan, as we wrote above, and after they became holy, they merited it and retained it as a payment. This can be understood from what Rashi, of blessed memory, explained in the name of the Mechilta: "And Moses led Israel from the Sea of Reeds," he led them against their will because they did not want to depart due to the great spoils of the sea, and he had to lead them forcibly. At first glance, it is difficult to understand what our sages said (in Berakhot 7): "Speak now in the ears of the people and let them ask each man from his neighbor," etc. The word "now" is only a term of request, as if to say, "I beseech you, warn them not to say that righteous Abraham was not fulfilled when they later left with great wealth." Thus, they did not want to take the possessions and he needed to request and warn them. Why then did their desire change regarding the spoils of the sea, where they did not want to depart from it? According to our approach, it is clear that initially they were compelled to take it as a loan, and therefore they did not want to accept it, for why should they trouble themselves with possessions that are not theirs? But at the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, they merited it as a payment, being that their judgment was as holy, with the Egyptians being punished and paying. From then on, they took it willingly with their hearts.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of the Israelites into a holy people through their observance of the Sabbath and sincere repentance, which allowed them to rightfully claim the wealth of the Egyptians. Initially, they were compelled to take the riches as a loan, reflecting their reluctance to accept what did not belong to them. However, after the miraculous event of the splitting of the Red Sea, they were able to take the wealth willingly, as it was now considered a rightful payment for the suffering inflicted upon them by the Egyptians. This shift illustrates the theological concept of divine justice, where the Israelites' status as a holy nation enabled them to receive their due recompense.

passage_content: באופןאחר אפשר לתרץ קושית האוהחה"ק הנ"ל, עפי"מ דאיתא בפסיקתא הנ"ל דישראל היובתורת פקדון במצרים כמ"ש פקד פקדתי אתכם וגו' והדין בשומר ששלח יד בפקדון ושינה מדעת הבעלים שחייב לשלם הנזק ולהחזיר את הפקדון מיד, שיכולים הבעלים לומר אינך נאמן עוד על השמירה, ואפי' בשואל ששאל על זמן קצוב ואין ביד הבעלים להחזירו מידו עד סוף ימי השאלה, אבל אם שלח בה יד ושינה מדעת הבעלים. דבר פשוט שיכולין הבעלים להחזירו מידו לפני תשלום הזמן. כי אינו נאמן על שמירתו, ובזה יתבאר דמתחלה בשליחות הראשונה אמרו לפרעה דרך שלשת ימים נלך והי' האמת כן כי הי' תליא גאולתם בזכות המעשים כנ"ל, אבל אחרשסירב כ"כ ולא רצה לשלחם במצות השי"ת אף על ג' ימים, הי' שולח יד בפקדון ושינה מדעת הבעלים ופסקה שמירתו והפקדון חזרה לבעלים הראשונים, וע"כ נעשו בן חורין לחלוטין, ולא חזרו אליו אחר ג' ימים.
translation: In another way, it is possible to resolve the question of the aforementioned holy author, according to what is stated in the aforementioned Pesikta, that Israel was entrusted with a deposit in Egypt, as it is written, "I have surely remembered you," etc. The law regarding a guardian who misappropriates a deposit and alters it against the will of the owners is that he is obligated to pay for the damage and return the deposit immediately, as the owners can say, "You are no longer trustworthy regarding the guarding." Even in the case of a borrower who borrowed for a fixed time and the owners cannot reclaim it from him until the end of the borrowing period, if he misappropriated it and altered it against the will of the owners, it is clear that the owners can reclaim it from him before the time of payment, for he is not trustworthy regarding its guarding. And this will clarify that initially, in the first mission, they told Pharaoh, "We will go a three-day journey," and it was indeed true, for their redemption depended on the merit of their deeds, as mentioned. However, after he refused so much and did not want to send them at the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, even for three days, he misappropriated the deposit and altered it against the will of the owners, and his guarding ceased, and the deposit returned to the original owners. Therefore, they became completely free and did not return to him after three days.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of Israel's redemption from Egypt as a divine deposit, emphasizing that when Pharaoh refused to release them, he effectively altered the terms of their "guardianship." This act of rebellion against God's command led to a loss of Pharaoh's claim over the Israelites, allowing them to be considered free. The theological insight highlights the importance of divine authority and the consequences of failing to honor it, illustrating that true freedom is attained through adherence to God's will. Ultimately, the text underscores the idea that Israel's liberation was contingent upon their actions and the divine promise.

passage_content: והנהפרעה לא ידע דע"י זכות שמירת שבת וכח התשובה נגאלו לחלוטין, אבל חשב דרק בשביל שפשע מדעת הבעלים וסירב מלשלחם, ע"כ נפסקה שמירתו ולא חזרו לידו, ולזה התחרט על מה שסירב ולא אבה לשלחם על שלשת ימים, וחשב שאלמלי נתרצה לשלחם על ג' ימים ולא הי' מסרב לדברי השי"ת, היו חוזרים להתעכב בארצו עד כלות זמן הפקדון ד' מאות שנה, וזה שאמה"כ ויהפך לבב פרעה שהתחרט על מעשיו, מה שסירב לשמוע בשליחות השי"ת, ואמר מה זאת עשינו ר"ל לשלוח יד בפקדון, ועי"ז כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, וע"ד שדרשו חכז"ל ושלחה מי שמשלחה ואינה חוזרת, וז"ש כי שלחנו את ישראל, שאנחנו גרמנו ששלחנום לחלוטין ולא יחזרו עוד.
translation: And behold, Pharaoh did not know that through the merit of observing the Sabbath and the power of repentance, they were completely redeemed. Rather, he thought that it was only because he transgressed against the will of the owners and refused to send them away, therefore his protection was severed and they did not return to him. For this reason, he regretted what he had refused and did not want to send them away for three days, and he thought that had he consented to send them away for three days and not refused the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, they would have remained in his land until the completion of the time of the deposit of four hundred years. This is as it is written, "And the heart of Pharaoh was changed," that he regretted his actions, that he refused to listen to the mission of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and he said, "What is this we have done," meaning to send forth our hand against the deposit, and by this, since we sent Israel from our service. And according to what our Sages, of blessed memory, have said, "And he sent away whoever sends away and does not return," this is what is meant by "for we sent away Israel," that we caused that they should be sent away completely and not return again.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's realization that the Israelites' redemption was not merely due to his refusal to release them, but rather through the merit of observing the Sabbath and the power of repentance. Pharaoh regrets his stubbornness, understanding that had he consented to let them go for three days, they would not have returned, thus emphasizing the divine orchestration in their liberation. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the transformative power of repentance and the significance of divine commandments, illustrating how human actions can influence spiritual outcomes. Ultimately, it highlights the idea that true freedom comes from aligning with God's will.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דברי המדרש שהתחלנו בפתח דברינו, מי צווח ווי פרעה צווח ווי משל למלך וכו' כך פרעה אמר כשהיו ישראל אצלו, הי' הקב"ה משלח לו אגרות בכל שעה, כה אמר ד' שלח עמי וגו' הכוונה בזה כי פרעה הי' סבור שאלמלי היה משלחם על ג' ימים ולא הי' מסרב, היו ישראל חוזרים לארצו עד כלות הזמן של ד' מאות שנה ובכל פעם שהי' רצון השי"ת שיזבחו לפניו במדבר, הי' משלח אליו אגרות ושליחים לאמר שלח עמי ויחוגו לי במדבר, וא"ש מה שהתחרט פרעה וצווח ווי, והמשל דומה לנמשל.
translation: And in this, we can clarify the words of the Midrash that we began with in the introduction to our discourse, who cried out "Woe to Pharaoh" is likened to a king, etc. Thus, Pharaoh said when the Israelites were with him, the Holy One, blessed be He, was sending him letters at all times, saying, "Thus says the Lord: Let My people go," etc. The intention here is that Pharaoh thought that if he were to send them away for three days and not refuse, the Israelites would return to their land by the end of the four hundred years. And every time the Blessed One desired that they should offer sacrifices to Him in the desert, He would send him letters and messengers saying, "Let My people go, that they may celebrate a feast to Me in the wilderness." And it is understood why Pharaoh regretted and cried out "Woe," and the parable is similar to the interpretation.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's resistance to releasing the Israelites, interpreting it through a Hasidic lens. It suggests that God continually sent messages to Pharaoh, urging him to let the Israelites go for a short time to worship Him in the desert. Pharaoh believed that if he complied even temporarily, the Israelites would return to their land, thus prolonging their bondage beyond the prophesied 400 years. The text highlights the tension between divine will and human obstinacy, illustrating the deeper spiritual struggle inherent in the redemption process.

passage_content: ומעתהיובן דברי המדרש הנ"ל הה"ד ברוב עוזך יכחשו לך אויביך וכו' ר' ברכיה אמר יעשו כזבים בדבריהם כענין שנא' וכחש בעמיתו, הכוונה בזה דע"י שאמר גם את ישראל לא אשלח שלח יד בפקדון, וע"כ דרשו חכז"ל יכחשו מלשון וכחש בעמיתו ר"ל שהכחש האמור כאן הכוונה ששלח יד בפקדון כמ"ש וכחש בעמיתו בפקדון, וע"כ סיימו במדרש בשביל שאמר וגם את ישראל לא אשלח, אח"כ הוא הי' מחזיר על פתחיהן של ישראל וא"ל צאי לשלום, ונשתחררו מתחת ידו לחלוטין, וזה כוונת הפסיקתא שהביא לכאן האי דינא דשולח יד בפקדון, דפרעה שלח יד בפקדונו ולכך הוציא השי"ת את ישראל מתחת ידו, וע"כ צווח פרעה ווי, כי התחרט על מה ששלח יד בהם, וא"ש קישור דרשא זו לכאן.
translation: And from now on, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be understood, as it is said, "In the greatness of Your strength, Your enemies will lie to You," etc. Rabbi Berachiah said they will make falsehoods in their words, as it is stated, "And he lied to his fellow." The intention here is that by saying, "I will not send Israel away," he sent forth his hand upon the deposit. Therefore, our Sages interpreted that "they will lie" is from the language of "and he lied to his fellow," meaning that the lying mentioned here refers to sending forth his hand upon the deposit, as it is written, "and he lied to his fellow regarding the deposit." Therefore, they concluded in the Midrash that because he said, "I will not send Israel away," afterwards he was returning to the doorways of Israel and said to them, "Go in peace," and they were completely freed from his hand. This is the intention of the Pesikta that brought here the law of sending forth the hand upon the deposit, for Pharaoh sent forth his hand upon his deposit, and therefore the Holy One, blessed be He, took Israel out from under his hand. Hence, Pharaoh cried out, "Woe," because he regretted having sent forth his hand against them. And this explains the connection of this teaching here.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine justice and the protection of the Jewish people, emphasizing that when Pharaoh wrongfully seized what belonged to Israel, God intervened to liberate them. The term "יכחשו" (they will deny) is interpreted as a reference to deceit in the context of wrongful claims, highlighting the moral implications of betrayal. The text illustrates that God's promise not to abandon Israel ultimately leads to their complete release from oppression, showcasing the theme of redemption and divine retribution against those who harm His people. This reflects a deep theological insight into the relationship between God and Israel, emphasizing faithfulness and the consequences of transgression.

passage_content: באופןאחר אפ"ל דברי המדרשים והדקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם דברי התנחומא ופרעה הקריב וגו' הקריב את ישראל לתשובה, כיון שראו ששבו ישראל לאחוריהם וחנו לפני פי החירות לפני בעל צפון. אמר פרעה בעל צפון הסכים על גזרתי לאבדם במים, התחיל לזבח לקטר ולנסך לע"ז לכך נאמר ופרעה הקריב עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב דרישי' לאו סיפי'. דברישא דרשו הקריב את ישראל לתשובה, וסיום דבריהם הקריב לע"ז והול"ל דבר אחר לחלק ביניהם. ומדערבינהו נראה דיש קישור ביניהם וצ"ב הקישור.
translation: In another way, one can say that the words of the Midrashim and the grammatical interpretations mentioned above precede the words of the Tanchuma: "And Pharaoh drew near," etc., "he drew Israel to repentance," for when they saw that Israel had turned back and encamped before the mouth of freedom, before Baal Tzafon, Pharaoh, Baal Tzafon, agreed to my decree to destroy them in the waters. He began to offer sacrifices, to incense, and to libate to idolatry; therefore it is said, "And Pharaoh drew near," thus concludes the Midrash. However, it is puzzling why they did not conclude with a different interpretation. In the beginning, they interpreted "he drew Israel to repentance," and at the end of their words, they interpreted "he drew to idolatry," and it should have been stated differently to differentiate between them. From their understanding, it seems that there is a connection between them, and the connection is puzzling.
summary: The passage discusses the dual interpretations of Pharaoh's actions in relation to the Israelites' return to repentance. Initially, it highlights that Pharaoh's recognition of Israel's repentance led him to bring them closer to God, while ultimately, his actions devolved into idolatry and sacrifices to false gods. This juxtaposition suggests a deeper connection between the themes of repentance and the allure of idolatry, prompting reflection on the spiritual struggle inherent in the human experience. The text invites contemplation on the relationship between divine mercy and the temptation to stray from true faith.
