passage_content: ז)(בפ' שמות) ואת המטה הזה תקח בידך אשר תעשה בו האותות, וכן סידר המגיד ובאותות זה המטה שנאמר ואת המטה הזה תקח בידך וגו' הנה ביאר הרמב"ן ז"ל (בפ' ראה) עה"פ כי יקום בקרבך נביא וגו' ונתן אליך אות או מופת, וז"ל ענין אות סימן על דבר שיהי' אח"כ בדמיונו, כי כשיבוא הנביא ויאמר, דבר פלוני עתיד להיות לדמיון שיהי' כך, יקרא אות וכו', והמופת יאמר על דבר מחודש שיעשה לפנינו בשינוי טבעו של עולם עכ"ל, ולפי"ז מ"ט נקרא המטה אות ומהו ענין הדמיון שבו, ויותר יאות שיקרא מופת ע"ש הפלאים שנעשו על ידו במכות מצרים.
translation: (7) (In Parashat Shemot) "And this staff you shall take in your hand, with which you shall perform the signs." Thus the Maggid arranged, and in the signs, this staff is mentioned, as it is said, "And this staff you shall take in your hand," etc. Behold, the Ramban, of blessed memory, explained (in Parashat Re'eh) regarding the verse, "If a prophet arises among you," etc., "and he gives you a sign or a wonder." He said, "The matter of a sign is a symbol of something that will later be in his imagination, for when the prophet comes and says, 'Such and such a thing is destined to be,' it will be a sign, etc. And a wonder refers to something new that will be done before us, changing the nature of the world." Thus far his words. According to this, why is the staff called a sign, and what is the matter of the imagination within it? It would be more appropriate for it to be called a wonder, due to the miracles that were performed through it in the plagues of Egypt.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of the staff (mateh) that Moses is instructed to take, which serves as a symbol of divine authority and miraculous power. The Ramban explains that an "ot" (sign) represents a future event envisioned by the prophet, while a "mofet" (wonder) refers to a miraculous act that alters the natural order. The staff is thus seen as both a sign of impending events and a tool for performing wonders, highlighting the interplay between prophecy and divine intervention in the world. This reflects key Hasidic concepts of faith in the miraculous and the transformative power of divine signs.

passage_content: ויתבארכל הענין עפימ"ש במכילתא דאלמלי זכו ישראל היו נגאלים במצרים גאולה לדורות שאין אחרי' גלות עוד, אלא שלא היתה זכותם מספקת לכך וע"כ היתה רק גאולה לשעה, ונקדים מ"ש בספה"ק קדושת לוי זלה"ה לפרש אומרם ז"ל (פסחים קי"ח ע"ב) הללו את ה' כל גוים אגבורות ונפלאות דעביד בהדייהו, כל שכן אנו דגבר עלינו חסדו ולכאורה דברי רז"ל נעלמים מאתנו וכו', הלא מקרא כתיב או הנסה אלקים לבוא לקחת לו גוי מקרב גוי, בזה עיקר הבטחותינו שהבוי"ת מראה גודל אהבתו ותשוקתו לעמו בית ישראל שבכל דור ודור עושה לנו נסים ונפלאות ומשלם גמול לכל אויבי נפשינו, וחלילה לומר שהשי"ת עושה להם נסים ונפלאות, ותוכן תירוצו דע"י הכאות הרשעים שהבוי"ת עושה בהם דין, נתגדל ונתקדש שמו ית' בעולם, וזה באמת טובה גדולה גם להם דמאתו לא תצא רעה כתיב, וכאשר יפקחו עיניהם יראו גודל התועלת המגיע להם, רק הרשעים הם ערלי לב ולבם אטום מהבין זאת וכו', וז"פ הגמרא דבאמת אין הקב"ה עושה נסים ונפלאות רק לישראל עם קרובו. ולאומה"ע מכה אותם השי"ת בעונשין וגואל את ישראל מתוכם, ועי"ז נתקדש ש"ש וצריכים הם להלל את השי"ת מה שנתקדש על ידם ש"ש וז"פ הללו את ה' כל גוים אנסים ונפלאות שעושה הקב"ה עם ישראל ונפרע להם מכל צריהם הוא בהדייהו, כלומר שאלו הנסים והטובות הם מחמתם, שע"י הכאתם נעשה נסים לישראל ונתקדש ש"ש על ידם, ולעתיד גם האומות ישמחו ויהללו וישבחו לה' על החסד שעושה לישראל, וכמו שפי' בספר בינה לעתים (דרוש י"ט) עה"פ הנ"ל הללו את ה' כל גוים וגו' כי גבר עלינו חסדו, וקשה ראובן בשמחה שמעון מה איכפת לי' ואיך יצוה לגוים שיהללו וישבחו על כי גבר עלינו חסדו, ותי' שטובה ותועלת גדולה נמשך לאומות ממה שעושה הקב"ה נסים ונפלאות לישראל, כי בעודנו בגלות אין השגחתו ית' מתפרסמת ולא ניכר אלקותו האמיתי אצל הכל, כי הם נעדרי ידיעתו, אבל לעתיד ע"י גאולת ישראל תתפרסם גדולתו ויכלתו, וכל העולם יכירו וידעו כי אמת מלכינו ואפס זולתו, היש תועלת גדול מזה לעוורים לא ראו אור, ולזה אמר אתם הגוים הללו ושבחו שמו ית', על כי גבר עלינו חסדו להוציאנו מאפילה לאורה, כי הלא ע"י חסד זה ואמת ה' לעולם: האמת הגמור מאלקותו ית' מתפשט לעולם בכללי כי כולם יכירהו, וכיון שכן גם אתם חייבים להללו ולשבחו ע"כ דבריו.
translation: And the entire matter will be clarified according to what is said in the Mechilta: Had the Jewish people merited, they would have been redeemed in Egypt with a redemption for all generations, with no subsequent exile. However, their merit was not sufficient for that, and therefore it was only a temporary redemption. We will precede with what is stated in the holy book Kedushas Levi, may his merit protect us, to explain the words of our sages, of blessed memory (Pesachim 118b): "Praise the Lord, all you nations; praise Him for His mighty deeds and wonders that He has done with them." All the more so for us, who have been favored by His kindness. And seemingly, the words of our sages are hidden from us, etc. Is it not written: "Or has God attempted to go and take for Himself a nation from the midst of another nation?" In this lies the essence of our promises, that the Blessed One shows the greatness of His love and desire for His people, the House of Israel, that in every generation He performs miracles and wonders for us and repays all our enemies. And it is forbidden to say that the Holy One, blessed be He, performs miracles and wonders for them. The essence of your answer is that through the punishments of the wicked, which the Blessed One administers to them, His name is magnified and sanctified in the world. And this is indeed a great benefit for them, for from Him no evil will come, as it is written. And when their eyes are opened, they will see the great benefit that comes to them; only the wicked are uncircumcised in heart, and their hearts are sealed from understanding this, etc. Thus, the Gemara clearly states that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not perform miracles and wonders except for Israel, His close people. And for the nations of the world, the Holy One punishes them, and redeems Israel from among them. And through this, His name is sanctified, and they must praise the Holy One for the sanctification that occurs through them. Thus, it is said: "Praise the Lord, all you nations, for the mighty deeds and wonders that the Holy One does with Israel," and He exacts retribution from all their troubles upon them, meaning that these miracles and benefits are because of them, for through their punishment, miracles are done for Israel, and His name is sanctified through them. In the future, even the nations will rejoice and praise and glorify the Lord for the kindness He does for Israel, as explained in the book Bina Le'itim (Drush 19) on the above verse: "Praise the Lord, all you nations, for His kindness has been great upon us." And it is difficult: Reuven, in joy, asks Shimon, "What does it matter to him, and how can he command the nations to praise and glorify Him for His kindness that has been great upon us?" And the answer is that a great benefit and advantage comes to the nations from what the Holy One does, miracles and wonders for Israel, for while we are in exile, His providence is not revealed, and His true divinity is not apparent to all, for they lack knowledge of Him. But in the future, through the redemption of Israel, His greatness and power will be revealed, and the whole world will recognize and know that our King is true and there is none besides Him. Is there a greater benefit than this for the blind who have not seen light? Therefore, it is said: "You nations, praise His name," for His kindness has brought us from darkness to light, for through this kindness and the truth of the Lord is forever: the complete truth of His divinity will spread throughout the world universally, for all will recognize Him. And since this is so, you too are obligated to praise and glorify Him; thus are His words.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of divine redemption and the relationship between God and the Jewish people, emphasizing that Israel's redemption from Egypt was a temporary measure due to insufficient merit. It highlights that God's miracles and kindness towards Israel serve to sanctify His name in the world, and that even the nations will ultimately recognize and praise God for the benefits they receive through Israel's redemption. The text asserts that God's true greatness and presence will be revealed through the future redemption, leading all nations to acknowledge His sovereignty and the goodness of His actions towards Israel.

passage_content: וכתבהרמב"ם ז"ל באגרת תימן שכשיבוא מלך המשיח, לא יצטרך ללחום עם מלכי האומות רק ע"י שיראו גודל חכמתו וקדושתו יהי' להם התבטלות נגדו בלי שום מלחמה, נמצא לפי"ז אלמלי הי' גאולת מצרים גאולה שלימה שהי' מציאות לזה כנ"ל, אז לא הי' מתחרט פרעה מה ששלח את ישראל מארצו, שהרי הי' משיג את גודל התועלת שהגיע גם אליו מה שנתקדש על ידו ש"ש, ורק מפני שלא הי' עדיין השלימות הגמור, לא באו האומות להשגה זו לראות האמת, ע"כ צווח ווי על ששלח את ישראל מארצו, ומבואר בספה"ק דאלמלי זכו ישראל אז לתיקון השלימות הי' משרע"ה נכנס לא"י עמהם, והי' הוא בונה ביהמ"ק ולא הי' נחרב לעולם דלאשלטו האויבים במעשה ידיו, נמצא דמה שלא נכנס משרע"ה לא"י מיד, מפני שלא הגיעו ישראל לתכלית השלימות עדיין.
translation: And as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote in the Letter to Yemen, when the King Messiah comes, he will not need to wage war against the kings of the nations; rather, by the greatness of his wisdom and holiness, they will be nullified before him without any war. Therefore, according to this, had the redemption from Egypt been a complete redemption, which had the potential for this as mentioned, then Pharaoh would not have regretted sending Israel out of his land, for he would have realized the great benefit that came to him from the sanctification that occurred through him, blessed be He. And only because the complete perfection had not yet been achieved, the nations did not come to this understanding to see the truth; hence, he cried out, "Woe to me for having sent Israel out of my land." It is explained in the holy books that had Israel merited the rectification of completeness at that time, Moses would have entered the Land of Israel with them, and he would have built the Holy Temple, which would never have been destroyed, for the enemies would not have had dominion over his handiwork. Thus, the reason that Moses did not enter the Land of Israel immediately was because Israel had not yet reached the ultimate perfection.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the Messiah's arrival, emphasizing that he will not need to wage war against nations, as his wisdom and holiness will compel their submission. It reflects on the incomplete redemption during the Exodus, suggesting that had the Israelites achieved a higher level of spiritual perfection, Pharaoh would not have regretted releasing them. The text implies that Moses would have led the Israelites into the Promised Land, building the Temple, which would have remained intact forever, had they reached this ultimate completeness. Thus, the delay in entering the land is attributed to the Israelites' lack of spiritual fulfillment at that time.

passage_content: ובזהיתיישבו דברי המדרשים הנ"ל פרעה צווח ווי, ואידך דברי המדרש משה אמר ווי על שאינו נכנס עמהן לארץ ושניהן על קוטב א' יסובבו, דמפני שלא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים, מטעם פן ינחם העם וגו' ושבו מצרימה, ה"ז מורה שלא הגיעו ישראל עדיין לשלימות האמיתי, ומה"ט משה צווח ווי על שלא יכנס לארץ, וגם פרעה צווח ווי על ששלחם, ואלמלי הי' תיקון השלימות מיד, הי' שש ושמח על כי גבר עלינו חסדו ית' כנ"ל. ויתבאר בזה גם דברי המכילתא הנ"ל כי קרוב הוא קרובה השבועה שנשבע אברהם אבינו לאבימלך וכו' ועדיין נכדו קיים, והוא מקושר עם טעם הכתוב פן ינחם העם וגו' דאלמלי זכו ישראל לתיקון השלימות היו הפלשתים בעצמם מבטלים השבועה. דהנשבע על דעת חבירו אינו יכול להתיר שבועתו שלא בפניו, אבל על דעת המודר יכול להתיר, ואז היו כל האומות מכירין שגדולתם של ישראל טובה ותועלת גם להם ובל"ס היו מוותרין על השבועה, אלא מפני שהי' קיים החשש זה פן ינחם העם וגו' ושבו מצרימה, וכמו שאמרו אח"כ נתנה ראש ונשובה מצרימה, ודרשו רז"ל אין ראש אלא ע"ז, ע"כ לא זכו לגאולה נצחיות מיד ומה"ט כח השבועה עדיין במקומה עומדת, ולז"א במכילתא קרובה השבועה שנשבע אאע"ה וכו' ועדיין נכדו קיים, והוא טעם א' עם טעם המפורש בפסוק פן ינחם העם וגו'.
translation:
And in this, the words of the aforementioned Midrash are settled: Pharaoh cried "Woe!" and on the other hand, the words of the Midrash state that Moses said "Woe!" for not entering the land with them, and both are revolving around one pole. This is because God did not lead them through the land of the Philistines, for fear that the people would have a change of heart and return to Egypt. This indicates that Israel had not yet reached true completeness. For this reason, Moses cried "Woe!" for not entering the land, and Pharaoh cried "Woe!" for having sent them away. Had the rectification of completeness occurred immediately, he would have been joyful and happy that His kindness had prevailed over us, as mentioned above. 

This also clarifies the words of the aforementioned Mekilta, for the oath that Abraham our father swore to Abimelech is close, and his grandson still exists. This is connected to the reason stated in the verse, "for fear that the people would have a change of heart," for had Israel merited the rectification of completeness, the Philistines themselves would have nullified the oath. For one who swears on behalf of another cannot annul his oath without the presence of the one he swore for, but on behalf of one who is prohibited, he can annul it. Then all the nations would recognize that the greatness of Israel is beneficial and advantageous to them, and certainly they would have waived the oath. However, because this concern existed, "for fear that the people would have a change of heart," and they would return to Egypt, as they later said, "Let us appoint a leader and return to Egypt," and our Sages interpreted that "a leader" refers to idolatry. Therefore, they did not merit an eternal redemption immediately, and for this reason, the power of the oath still stands in its place. And this is what is meant in the Mekilta, that the oath that Abraham our father swore is close, and his grandson still exists, which is one reason along with the reason explicitly stated in the verse, "for fear that the people would have a change of heart."
summary: The passage discusses the interconnectedness of the Israelites' spiritual state and their journey to the Promised Land, highlighting that their lack of readiness for true completeness led to both Moses and Pharaoh expressing sorrow. It emphasizes that had the Israelites achieved spiritual perfection, the Philistines would have nullified Abraham's oath, allowing for a smoother transition to freedom. The text underscores the idea that the Israelites' potential for redemption was hindered by their spiritual shortcomings, as reflected in the fear of returning to Egypt. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound relationship between divine providence, human readiness, and the fulfillment of promises.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבארו דברי המדרשים הנ"ל בענין קרי"ס, בהקדם מה שפירשתי בספרי ויואל משה (מאמר א' סי' כ"ד) מ"ש רז"ל (כתובות קי"א ע"א) שהשביע הקב"ה את ישראל שלא ידחקו את הקץ פירש"י ז"ל שלא ירבו בתחנונים על כך יותר מדאי, וק"ז זלה"ה בתפלה למשה (סי' קכ"ז) ובפי' על שה"ש עמד בדברי רש"י אלו דאינו מובן מה הוא הגבול של בקשת רחמים ומה נקרא יותר מדאי, ועו"ק למה לא מצינו בדברי הפוסקים שיזהירו שלא להפציר בתפלה על הגאולה, עיי"ש שפי' לדרכו, והנלפענ"ד עפי"ד הגמ' ב"מ (דף פ"ה ע"ב) אלי' הוה שכיח במתיבתא דרבי, יומא חד הוה נגה לי' ולא אתא, א"ל מאי טעמא נגה לי' למר א"ל אדאוקימנא לאברהם ומשינא ידי' ומצלי ומגנינא לי' וכן ליצחק וכן ליעקב, ולוקמינהו בהדי הדדי, סברי תקפי ברחמי ומייתי לי' למשיח בלא זמני', א"ל ויש דוגמתן בעוה"ז, א"ל איכא ר' חייא ובניו, גזר רבי תעניתא אחתינהו לר' חייא ובניו, אמר משיב הרוח ונשב זיקא, אמר מוריד הגשם ואתא מיטרא: מטא למימר מחיה המתים רגש עלמא, אמרי ברקיעא מאן גלי רזיא בעלמא, אמרי אלי' וכו' אתא אידמי כדובא דנורא על בינייהו וטרדינהו, ופי' שם המהרש"א ז"ל דאתי לומר שלא אתי עדיין זמן המשיח עיי"ש, הרי מבואר שיש מדריגת צדיקים אשר להם הכח בתפלתם להביא משיח בלא זמני', אלא שמנעום מן השמים להתפלל תפלה כזו המכרחת ואתי אלי' וטרדינהו, ותפלה כזה הוא בגדר דחיקת הקץ, ולכן לא ביארו הפוסקים מהו הגבול של רבוי תחנונים יותר מדאי, דכח תפלה כזו המכרחת לא נמצא כ"א ביחידי סגולה כמו ר' חייא ובניו, ומשמרים אותם מן השמים שלא יבואו לידי כך כמ"ש בגמ', ומי שלא הגיע למעלה זו מותר לו להתפלל כמה שירצה ומצוה להתפלל ולאפושי ברחמי שימהר השי"ת ויגאלינו, עייש"ד באריכות.
translation: And similarly, the words of the aforementioned Midrashim regarding the matter of the redemption will be clarified, by first mentioning what I explained in my book Vayoeil Moshe (Article 1, Section 24) regarding what our Sages of blessed memory stated (Ketubot 111a) that the Holy One, blessed be He, admonished Israel not to hasten the end. Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that this means not to increase their supplications on this matter excessively. And this is also hinted at in the prayer of Moses (Section 127) and in the commentary on the Song of Songs, where he stood by these words of Rashi, as it is not understood what the limit of requesting mercy is and what is considered excessive. Furthermore, it is puzzling why we do not find in the words of the halachic authorities a warning against urging in prayer for redemption. There, he explained according to his way, and I believe that according to the Gemara in Bava Metzia (55b), it was common for Eliyahu to be in the study hall of Rabbi. One day, he was shining for him and did not come. He asked, "What is the reason he is shining for my master?" He replied, "I was about to bring him to Abraham, and I changed my mind and prayed, and I protected him, and so too for Isaac and for Jacob, and I established them together. They thought to be strong in mercy and bring him without a set time." He said, "And there are similar cases in this world." He said, "There is Rabbi Chiya and his sons." Rabbi decreed a fast for Rabbi Chiya and his sons. He said, "He who returns the wind, and the storm blew." He said, "He who brings down the rain, and the rain came." When it came to saying, "He who revives the dead," the world trembled. They said in the heavens, "Who revealed the secret in the world?" They said, "To Eliyahu," etc. A fire came and burned between them and drove them away. And there, the Maharsha, of blessed memory, explained that this indicates that the time of the Messiah has not yet come. It is clear that there is a level of righteous individuals who have the power in their prayers to bring the Messiah without a set time, but they are prevented from Heaven from praying such a compelling prayer that would bring him and drive him away. Such a prayer falls under the category of hastening the end. Therefore, the halachic authorities did not clarify what the limit of excessive supplications is, for the power of such a compelling prayer is found only in unique individuals like Rabbi Chiya and his sons, and they are guarded from Heaven so that they do not come to such a state, as stated in the Gemara. And one who has not reached this level is permitted to pray as much as he wishes, and it is a mitzvah to pray and to plead for mercy that the Holy One, blessed be He, should hasten and redeem us, as I have explained at length.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of prayer and its limitations regarding the redemption, emphasizing that while the Torah warns against excessive pleas that could "push the end," there are exceptional righteous individuals, like Rabbi Chiya and his sons, who possess the unique ability to invoke the Messiah's arrival through their prayers. However, the heavens prevent them from doing so to avoid forcing the timing of redemption. For the general populace, it is encouraged to pray fervently for mercy and redemption without concern for overstepping boundaries, as such prayers are seen as a mitzvah. Ultimately, the text highlights the balance between human supplication and divine timing in the context of redemption.

passage_content: והנהמשה רבינו וודאי הי' לו כח תפלה זו המכרחת כר' חייא ובניו, ואפשר שעד"ז היתה תפלת משרע"ה על ישראל בעמדם על שפת הים, כי ידע שינצלו ישראל מיד מצרים ולא יטבעו בים כי כבר הבטיחו הבוי"ת בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, ובהכרח שיצילם השי"ת כדי שיהיו ראויים לקבל התורה ולהכניסם לא"י, אמנם רצה משרע"ה לפעול בתפלתו שתהי' גאולה נצחיות שאין אחרי' גלות עוד, ולא הניחוהו מן השמים דלא הי' עדיין זמנו, ולז"א לו הקב"ה מה תצעק אלי, וכפירש"י עלי הדבר תלוי ולא עליך, דענין הגאולה לא נמסר לשום נברא, כ"א ביד הבוית"ש לבדו ואפס בלתך גואלינו לימות המשיח. ולטעם זה מנעו מן השמים רצון צדיק ולא הרשוהו להתפלל תפלה המכרחת למהר הגאולה לפני זמנו.
translation: And behold, Moshe Rabbeinu certainly had the power of this prayer that compels, like Rabbi Chiya and his sons, and it is possible that similarly was Moshe Rabbeinu's prayer for Israel as they stood by the edge of the sea, for he knew that Israel would be saved from the hand of Egypt and would not drown in the sea, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already promised, "When you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain." It was necessary that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would save them so that they would be worthy to receive the Torah and to bring them into the Land of Israel. However, Moshe Rabbeinu wanted to invoke in his prayer a redemption that would be eternal, with no subsequent exile, but they did not allow him from the heavens, for his time had not yet come. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Why do you cry out to Me?" As Rashi explains, "The matter depends on Me and not on you," for the matter of redemption was not entrusted to any created being, but only in the hands of the Holy One, Blessed be He alone, and there is no other redeemer for us until the days of the Messiah. For this reason, they prevented him from the heavens from expressing the desire of the righteous and did not allow him to pray a compelling prayer to hasten the redemption before its time.
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on Moses' prayer at the Red Sea, emphasizing that while Moses possessed the power to pray for Israel's salvation, he sought a permanent redemption that would prevent future exiles. However, the heavens did not permit this, as the timing for such redemption was not yet right, illustrating that the ultimate control over redemption lies solely with God. The text highlights the idea that the matter of redemption is beyond human influence, reserved for divine will, and underscores the belief in a future messianic redemption that is yet to come.

passage_content: וז"פהמדרש דבר אל בני ישראל ויסעו יסיעו הדבר מלבן, ר"ל שילמד לבנ"י דעת שדבר זה לעשותפעולה בענין הגאולה יסיעו מלבן ודעתם, וכמו שפירשתי אמרם ז"ל (סנהדרין צ"ז) אין בן דוד בא עד שיתייאשו מן הגאולה וכו', כי הא דר' זירא כי הוה משכח רבנן דמעסקי בי', (פירש"י לידע מתי יבוא) אמר להו במטותא בעינא מינייכו לא תרחקוה דתניא ג' באין בהיסח הדעת אלו הן משיח וכו' ולכאורה ה"ה מעיקרי האמונה להאמין בביאת המשיח ובזכות אמונה זו יהיו ישראל נגאלים, ואיך יובן אמרם ז"ל דאין ב"ד בא אלא בהיסח הדעת, אמנם הכוונה בזה שלא להיות ממחשבי קיצין ושלא לצייר בדעתינו שום מחשבה לקרב הגאולה ע"י פעולת אדם, רק לצפות ולחכות על ישועתו ית', ולקבוע בלבנו שאין בדעת האדם להשיג קץ הפלאות, וזהו בחי' היסח הדעת שאמרו רז"ל.
translation: And the Midrash says, "Speak to the children of Israel, and they shall journey," meaning that one should teach the children of Israel the understanding that this matter is to take action regarding the redemption, to journey from their understanding. As I have explained, our sages, of blessed memory, said (Sanhedrin 97) that the Messiah will not come until they despair of the redemption, etc. This is like the case of Rabbi Zeira, who, when he found the sages engaged in this matter (as Rashi explains, to know when he will come), said to them, "I request of you not to distance yourselves," for it is taught that three come without the thought of the mind; these are the Messiah, etc. And seemingly, this is also one of the fundamentals of faith, to believe in the coming of the Messiah, and through the merit of this faith, Israel will be redeemed. But how can we understand the statement of our sages, of blessed memory, that the Messiah comes only with the distraction of the mind? The intention here is not to be among those who calculate the end and not to conceive in our minds any thought to bring the redemption through human action, but rather to anticipate and wait for His salvation, blessed be He, and to establish in our hearts that it is beyond human understanding to grasp the end of wonders. This is the aspect of the distraction of the mind that our sages spoke of.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of faith in the coming of the Messiah and the concept of "hesach hada'at," or distraction of the mind, as a prerequisite for redemption. It suggests that true belief in the Messiah's arrival requires one to refrain from calculating the end times or attempting to hasten redemption through human actions. Instead, one should focus on waiting for divine salvation, acknowledging that the ultimate timing of redemption is beyond human comprehension. This reflects a deep trust in God's plan and the necessity of spiritual readiness over intellectual speculation.

passage_content: והנהאמרז"ל במד"ר (פ' קרח פ' י"ח סי' כ"ג) עה"פ ומטה אהרן וגו' יש אומרים שהוא המטה שהי' ביד משה וכו' ואותו המעה הי' ביד כל מלך ומלך עד שחרב ביהמ"ק ונגנז, ואותו המטה עתיד להיות ביד מלך המשיח במהרה בימינו שנאמר מטה עוזך ישלח ה' מציון וגו' עכ"ד המדרש נמצא שזהו מסימני הגאולה האמיתית, כשיראו ישראל מטה משה רבינו ביד הגואל העתיד, הוא הגואל האמיתי שכך קבלו רבותינו ז"ל שאותו המטה עתיד להיות ביד מלך המשיח, ואולי לטעם זה א"ל הקב"ה למשה רבינו ואתה הרם את מטך ונטה את ידך על הים ובקעהו, שכח הגאולה אשר בו נגנז עד שיבוא מלך המשיח. וע"כ הי' נס קריעת ים סוף ע"י נטיית ידו של משרע"ה ולא באמצעות המטה, וצוהו הקב"ה להרימו כלפי מעלה להורות לישראל שבחי' הגאולה הוא ביד הקב"ה לבדו, עד שיעלה רצון העליון וימסרנה ביד מלך המשיח, גם אפשר שענין הרמתו הי' כדי להראותו לכל ישראל שיכירו בו לסימן הגאולה ולא יטעו בגאולה כוזבת, ולטעם זה נקרא המעה אות, שזהו סימן על הגאולה, וכמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל דענין האות הוא סימן על דבר שיהי' כן בדמיונו.
translation: And behold, our sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash (Parashat Korach, Chapter 18, Section 23) regarding the verse "And the staff of Aaron, etc." that some say it is the staff that was in the hand of Moses, etc. And that staff was in the hand of every king until the Holy Temple was destroyed and it was hidden away. And that staff is destined to be in the hand of the King Messiah speedily in our days, as it is said, "The staff of Your strength the Lord will send from Zion," etc. Thus, it is found that this is one of the signs of the true redemption, when Israel will see the staff of our teacher Moses in the hand of the future redeemer, who is the true redeemer, as our sages of blessed memory received that this staff is destined to be in the hand of the King Messiah. And perhaps for this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to our teacher Moses, "And you lift up your staff and stretch out your hand over the sea and split it," for the power of redemption which was hidden until the King Messiah comes. Therefore, the miracle of the splitting of the Sea of Reeds was through the stretching of the hand of Moses and not through the staff, and the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded him to lift it upwards to indicate to Israel that the essence of redemption is in the hands of the Holy One alone, until the supreme will arises and it is given into the hand of the King Messiah. It is also possible that the matter of lifting it was to show it to all of Israel so that they would recognize it as a sign of redemption and not be misled by a false redemption. For this reason, the staff is called a sign, as it is a symbol of the redemption, and as the Ramban of blessed memory wrote, the matter of the sign is a symbol of something that will be so in its imagination.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Aaron's staff, which is seen as a symbol of redemption and is believed to be held by the Messiah in the future. It emphasizes that the true redemption will be recognized when the staff of Moses is in the hands of the future redeemer, highlighting the divine nature of redemption as being solely in God's control until the arrival of the Messiah. The act of raising the staff during the splitting of the Red Sea serves as a reminder that the ultimate redemption is a divine act, and the staff itself is a sign to distinguish true redemption from false claims. This reflects a deep theological insight into the nature of salvation and the role of divine signs in the process of redemption.

passage_content: ובזהיובן דברי המדרש באותה שעה אמרו ישראל ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, דממה שראו ישראל שנמנע משרע"ה מלהתפלל תפלה המכרחת להחיש הגאולה, גם ממה שצוה לו ית' ואתה הרם את מטך כפי' הנ"ל, השיגו ישראל שעדיין לא קרבה עת הגאולה הנצחית, ולכן אמרו ה' ימלוך לעתיד לבוא, דאיתא במדרש אילו אמרו ישראל ה' מלך לא היתה אומה ולשון שולטת בהם לעולם, אמנם השיגו ישראל שעדיין לא זכו לתיקון השלימות, לז"א ה' ימלוך לעתיד לבוא.
translation: And with this, the words of the Midrash are understood: at that time, Israel said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," for from what Israel saw that it was prevented for Moshe Rabbeinu to pray a prayer that would hasten the redemption, and also from what He commanded him, "And you raise your staff," as mentioned above, Israel understood that the time for the eternal redemption had not yet drawn near. Therefore, they said, "The Lord shall reign in the future to come," for it is stated in the Midrash that if Israel had said, "The Lord is King," no nation or tongue would have ruled over them forever. However, Israel understood that they had not yet merited the rectification of completeness, hence they said, "The Lord shall reign in the future to come."
summary: In this passage, the Israelites recognize that the time for the ultimate redemption has not yet arrived, as evidenced by Moses being unable to pray for an immediate salvation. They express their understanding that true completion and rectification have not been achieved, leading them to declare, "The Lord will reign in the future." This reflects a Hasidic belief in the progressive nature of redemption and the importance of recognizing the current state of spiritual imperfection. The statement emphasizes the anticipation of a future, perfected state of divine kingship.

passage_content: באופןאחר אפ"ל דברי המדרש משה צוח ווי וכו' בהקדם קושית הח"ס זלה"ה, דמה צורך לטעם פן ינחם העם ושבו מצרימה, הרי הי' הכרח בלא"ה להנחותם דרך המדבר כדי שתנתן להם התורה בהר סיני, כי הי' ההר הזה דייקא מוכן לכך כמבואר בדרז"ל, ובמכילתא דרשו רז"ל כי קרוב הוא, קרוב הוא הדבר שאמר הקב"ה למשהבהוציאך וגו' תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה ע"כ, א"כ טעם זה לבד מספיק ומה צורך לטעם פן ינחם העם, ע"כ קושיתו ונשאר בצ"ע.
translation: In another way, one could say the words of the Midrash: "Moshe cried out, 'Woe!' etc., in light of the question of the Chasam Sofer, may his memory be blessed, regarding what need there is for the reason 'lest the people regret and return to Egypt.' For it was necessary, regardless, to guide them through the desert so that the Torah would be given to them at Mount Sinai, as this mountain was specifically prepared for that purpose, as explained in the teachings of our Sages. And in the Mechilta, our Sages expounded that it is close, it is close, the matter that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moshe, 'When you bring them out, you shall serve God on this mountain.' Therefore, this reason alone is sufficient, and what need is there for the reason 'lest the people regret'? Thus, his question remains, and it is left as an open question.
summary: The passage discusses a question raised by the Chasam Sofer regarding the necessity of God's concern that the people might regret leaving Egypt and return, given that it was essential for them to travel through the desert to receive the Torah at Mount Sinai. The author emphasizes that Mount Sinai was specifically prepared for this purpose, as indicated by the sages. Thus, the concern about the people's potential regret seems unnecessary, leaving the question unresolved and highlighting the complexity of divine guidance and human emotions in the context of spiritual journeying.

passage_content: ואפ"לעפימ"ש ק"ז זלה"ה (בתפלה למשה ס"ח) לפרש מה שיסד רבינו מאיר בקינה וזלה"ק: סיני העל כן בחר בך אלקים ומאס בגדולים וזרח בגבולך, להיות לאות ולמופת לדת כי תמעט ותרד מכבודה, דלכאורה הוא נגד דברי רז"ל במס' מגילה וכו' א"ר יוסף לעולם ילמוד אדם מדעת קונו, שהרי הניח השי"ת כל ההרים וגבעות שבעולם ולא השרה שכינתו אלא על הר סיני, פירש"י ילמוד אדם מדעת קונו לאהוב הנמיכות, א"כ מבואר דהיא ללמד ענוה ולא לסימן לדת שתרד מכבודה, ולמה שאבאר דברי רבינו מאיר המה אחדים עם דברי רז"ל ובקנה אחד עולים, דהלא כבר הרגישו המפורשים במדרש שהביא היפ"ת (סדר ויחי פ' צ"ט) עה"פ נכון יהי' הר בית ה' בראש ההרים, ההרים שהיו כבר עכ"ד המדרש, והקשו הלא השי"ת בוחר בנמוכים וכו', ואבאר זה דבאמת וודאי כבוד שמים הוא להיות מקום כבודו והשראתו ית"ש ברומו של עולם וכו', אך קודם שנתגלה מלכותו כי בכל משלה, וקודם שנודע לכל שאין זולתו, רצונו ית"ש להסתיר לבוש הגאות ולא להתלבש בו, כדי שלא יטעו עי"ז מכח מאמר נעשהאדם, כי יאמרו הלא אינו מתנהג בענוה, והם לא יבינו כי בא ללמד ענוה לאחרים ויפלו באמונות שניות ח"ו, ע"כ בחר לו ה' לשכון במקום נמוך, אבל לעתיד שיתגלה לעין כי אפס בלתו וכו', אז יתלבש בלבושו ההדר לו וכו', ועפי"ז א"ש דברי רבינו מאיר הנ"ל, כי ידוע כי התורה ניתנה ע"ד חירות וכו', דאילו לא חטאו הי' נשאר כבוד ה' כמו שיהי' לעתיד, וא"כ למה בחר הנמיכות, אלא הוא כי הכל צפוי אף שהרשות נתונה, וא"כ א"ר מאיר שפיר סימן לדת שתרד מכבודה, כי אלולי כן לא הי' בוחר הנמוך כמו שלא יבחר לעתיד עכל"ק.
translation:
And I will explain, according to the words of our Rabbi Meir in the lamentation, as follows: "Sinai, therefore God chose you and rejected the great ones, and shone in your borders, to be a sign and a wonder for the faith, for it will diminish and descend from its glory." This seemingly contradicts the words of our Sages in Tractate Megillah, etc. Rabbi Yosef said: "A person should always learn from the knowledge of his Creator," for the Holy One, Blessed be He, left all the mountains and hills of the world and did not rest His Shechinah except on Mount Sinai. Rashi explains that a person should learn from the knowledge of his Creator to love humility. Therefore, it is clear that this is to teach humility and not as a sign for the faith that it will descend from its glory. 

As I will explain, the words of our Rabbi Meir are in harmony with the words of our Sages and rise together in one measure, for the interpreters have already noted in the Midrash that the Yefet brought (in the order of Vayechi, Parashat 39) on the verse "It shall be established that the house of the Lord is at the top of the mountains," the mountains that were already, as the Midrash states, and they questioned: "But the Holy One, Blessed be He, chooses the lowly," etc. 

I will explain this: In truth, it is certainly the honor of Heaven to have the place of His honor and His dwelling, Blessed be He, in the heights of the world, etc. However, before His kingship is revealed, for He rules over all, and before it is known to all that there is none besides Him, His will, Blessed be He, is to conceal the garment of pride and not to be clothed in it, so that they will not be misled by the saying "Let us make man," for they will say: "Behold, He does not conduct Himself with humility," and they will not understand that He comes to teach humility to others and will fall into secondary beliefs, Heaven forbid. Therefore, the Lord chose to dwell in a low place. 

But in the future, when it will be revealed to the eye that there is none besides Him, etc., then He will be clothed in His glorious garment, etc. According to this, the words of our Rabbi Meir mentioned above are understood, for it is known that the Torah was given in the manner of freedom, etc. For had they not sinned, the honor of the Lord would have remained as it will be in the future. And if so, why did He choose the lowly? Rather, it is because everything is foreseen even though the permission is given. And thus, Rabbi Meir said that it is indeed a sign for the faith that it will descend from its glory, for were it not so, He would not have chosen the lowly, just as He will not choose in the future, as is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of God's choice of Mount Sinai, a lowly mountain, as the site for the giving of the Torah, emphasizing humility and the concept of divine concealment. It contrasts this choice with the future revelation of God's glory, where He will be adorned in majesty. The text suggests that the initial choice of a humble place serves to teach humility and prevent misconceptions about God's nature, while also indicating that the decline in the Torah's honor is a reflection of this initial choice. Ultimately, it highlights the interplay between divine sovereignty, humility, and the future restoration of God's glory.

passage_content: ובזהיתיישב קושית החת"ס זלה"ה, דדרשת המכילתא כי קרוב הוא קרוב הוא הדבר שאמר הקב"ה למשה בהוציאך את העם וגו' תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, מקושר הוא עם טעם המפורש בכתוב פן ינחם העם ושבו מצרימה, דאלמלי זכו ישראל לשלימות התיקון בבחי' דלעתיד, הי' ניתנה להם התורה בהר תבור וכרמל וסיני בבחי' שיתאחדו כולם לעתיד במקום המקדש, ולא הי' צורך להוליכם דרך המדבר לטעם זה שתנתן להם התורה בהר סיני, אבל מפני כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם ושבו מצרימה, ועדיין לא הגיעו אל השלימות, ע"כ הי' צורך להוליכם דרך המדבר כדברי המכילתא כי קרוב הדבר שאמר הקב"ה למשה תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, ומזה השיג משרע"ה שלא יכנס לארץ וע"כ צווח ווי.
translation: And in this, the difficulty of the Chasam Sofer, may his memory be blessed, is resolved, that the Midrash interprets that it is close, it is close, the matter that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "When you bring out the people... you shall serve God on this mountain," is connected to the reason explicitly stated in the verse, "lest the people regret and return to Egypt," for had Israel merited the completeness of the rectification in the aspect of the future, the Torah would have been given to them on Mount Tabor and Carmel and Sinai in a way that they would all unite in the future at the place of the Temple, and there would have been no need to lead them through the desert for this reason that the Torah would be given to them on Mount Sinai. But because God said, "lest the people regret and return to Egypt," and they had not yet reached completeness, therefore it was necessary to lead them through the desert, as the Midrash states, that it is close, the matter that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "You shall serve God on this mountain," and from this, Moses understood that he would not enter the land, and therefore he cried out, "Woe."
summary: The passage discusses the reasoning behind God's command to Moses regarding the Israelites' worship at Mount Sinai, linking it to the concern that the people might regret their liberation and return to Egypt. It suggests that had the Israelites achieved spiritual perfection, the Torah could have been given at a more exalted location, such as Mount Tabor or Carmel, symbolizing a future unity in the Messianic era. However, due to their incomplete spiritual state, they were led through the desert to receive the Torah at Sinai, highlighting the necessity of this journey for their growth. This realization led Moses to lament his exclusion from entering the Promised Land.

passage_content: ויהיבשלח פרעה את העם וגו', במד"ר (פרשה כ' סימן ב') הה"ד (ירמיה ז') כה אמר ה' צבאות וכו' מלה"ד לאדם שהי' לו פרדס, א"ל חבירו מכור לי את הפרדס הזה, מכרו לו במנה ולא הי' יודע בעל הפרדס מה בתוכו, אמר לו בכמה מכרת את הפרדס, א"ל במנה, א"ל יש בו זתים בק' מנה וכו' ואילו לא הי' של לוקח אלא מעיינות שבתוכו די שנאמר מעין גנים וגו', התחיל המוכר תוהא, כך הי' פרעה כששלח את ישראל לא היו לפניו כלום, א"ל גדולי מלכות מה עשית אילו לא הי' בידם אלא הביזה לבדם דיים שנאמר וגם ערב רב עלה אתם וכו', באותה שעה התחיל קורא ווי ווי הוי ויהי בשלח עכ"ד המדרש, וראוי להבין ענין הנמשל אילו לא הי' בידם אלא הביזה לבדם דיים שנא' וגם ערב רב עלה אתם וגו' ומה רבותייהם דערב רב, ואיך יתאים אל דמיון המשל שא"ל אילו לא הי' בידו אלא מעיינות שבתוכו די, גם מדוע יכנה הערב רב בשם ביזה ומה ענין התייחסות שם זה להם.
translation:
And Pharaoh sent the people away, etc. In the Midrash (Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 2), it is stated (Jeremiah 7): "Thus says the Lord of Hosts," etc. This is comparable to a person who had an orchard. His friend said to him, "Sell me this orchard." He sold it to him for a certain amount, not knowing what was inside the orchard. The buyer asked him, "For how much did you sell the orchard?" He replied, "For a certain amount." The buyer then said, "There are olive trees worth a hundred times that amount," etc. And if the buyer had only the springs within it, it would have been sufficient, as it is said, "a spring of gardens," etc. The seller began to wonder. So it was with Pharaoh when he sent Israel away; he had nothing before him. The nobles of the kingdom said to him, "What have you done? If they had only the plunder, it would have been enough, as it is said, 'And a mixed multitude went up with them,' etc." At that moment, he began to cry, "Woe, woe!" And it was when he sent them away. Thus far is the Midrash. 

It is fitting to understand the matter of the parable: if they had only the plunder, it would have been enough, as it is said, "And a mixed multitude went up with them," etc. And what is the significance of the great multitude? How does it fit with the analogy that he said, "If he had only the springs within it, it would have been enough"? Also, why is the mixed multitude referred to as plunder, and what is the significance of this name in relation to them?
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the moment Pharaoh released the Israelites, likening it to a man who sells a garden without knowing its true value. The key Hasidic insight emphasizes that the Israelites, despite appearing to leave with only the spoils of Egypt, carried with them the spiritual wealth symbolized by the "mixed multitude" (ערב רב), which represents the potential for deeper spiritual connection and growth. This reflects the idea that true value lies not in material possessions but in the spiritual essence and potential that one carries within. The mention of the ערב רב highlights the transformative power of collective spiritual elevation, suggesting that even those who seem like mere "spoils" can contribute significantly to the spiritual journey.

passage_content: ב)(פ' כ' סימן ח') ד"א ויהי בשלח פרעה, מי אמר ווי משה אמר ווי, משל לאחד שנעשה לבתו של מלך שושבין, והי' רואה במזל שהוא מוציאה מבית אביה ואינו בא עמה לבית החתן לחופתה, התחיל בוכה וכו', כך אמר משה צועק אני שנתייגעתי להוציא את ישראל ממצרים ואיני נכנס עמהן לארץ לכך ויהי בשלח עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב קישור ענין זה לכאן, ויותר נכון מקומו לעיל בפ' בא בסיפור יציאת ישראל ממצרים או להלן כשנגזר עליו שלא יכנס לארץ.
translation: In (Parashat Ki Teitzei, Siman 8) D'var Acher, "And it was when Pharaoh sent out," who said "Woe"? Moses said "Woe." It is like a certain man who became the groomsman for the daughter of a king, and he saw in the stars that she was being taken from her father's house and he was not coming with her to the groom's house for the wedding; he began to cry, etc. Thus, Moses said, "I cry out, I have toiled to bring Israel out of Egypt and I am not entering with them into the Land." Therefore, "And it was when Pharaoh sent out," thus concludes the Midrash. And it is puzzling how this matter connects here, and it is more appropriate for it to be placed earlier in Parashat Bo in the narrative of Israel's exodus from Egypt or later when it was decreed upon him that he would not enter the Land.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the emotional turmoil of Moses as he leads the Israelites out of Egypt but realizes he will not enter the Promised Land with them. The metaphor of a groom's attendant who sees the bride leaving her father's house but cannot accompany her to the wedding symbolizes Moses' deep sorrow and sense of loss. This highlights the Hasidic themes of spiritual struggle and the bittersweet nature of leadership, emphasizing the sacrifices made for the sake of others. The connection to the broader narrative of the Exodus underscores the tension between divine mission and personal fulfillment.

passage_content: ג)(פ' כ' סימן ג') ויהי בשלח פרעה וכי פרעה שלחם, בלעם אמר א"ל מוציאם ממצרים וכאן כתיב ויהי בשלח פרעה, אלא מלמד שהי' פרעה מלוה אותם וכו' ואין שילוח האמור כאן אלא לוי' שנאמר ואברהם הולך עמם לשלחם, אמנם לפי פשוטו קשה וכי פרעה שלחם וכו'.
translation: And it was when Pharaoh sent them away, and when Pharaoh sent them, Balaam said to him, "He is taking them out of Egypt," and here it is written, "And it was when Pharaoh sent them away." Rather, it teaches that Pharaoh was accompanying them, etc., and the sending mentioned here is nothing but an escort, as it is said, "And Abraham went with them to send them off." However, according to its simple meaning, it is difficult: Did Pharaoh send them away, etc.?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the moment of Pharaoh's sending away the Israelites from Egypt, emphasizing that Pharaoh did not merely release them but accompanied them, symbolizing a deeper connection. The text highlights the concept of "leaving" as a form of escorting, akin to Abraham's act of accompanying those he sent away. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the spiritual significance of departure, suggesting that true liberation involves a guiding presence. The passage invites contemplation on the nature of freedom and the roles of both the liberator and the liberated in the journey towards spiritual fulfillment.

passage_content: ונל"פעפ"י הידוע בדברי חז"ל ובזוה"ק שבכ"מ שנאמר העם הכוונה על הערב רב, ולכאורה יש לתמוה איך יצאו הערב רב ממצרים, וחז"ל דרשו עה"פ כי הוציא ה' את ישראל ממצרים זו גדולה על כולם שהרי אין עבד יכול לברוח ממצרים, והתינח בנ"י יצאו בדרך נס שהוציאם הקב"ה ביד חזקה ובזרוע נטוי', אבל הערב רב לא הסכים הקב"ה שיצטרפו אל בני ישראל ביציאתם ממצרים כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל עה"פ שחת עמך אשר הוצאת ממצרים שחת העם לא נאמר, אלא שחת עמך, ערב רב שקבלת מעצמך ולא נמלכת בי, ואמרת טוב שידבקו גרים בשכינה הם שחתו והשחיתו עכ"ל, וא"כ איך זכו הם לנס היציאה שהי' נמנע בדרך הטבע לצאת משם כאמרז"ל, וקושיא זו כחה יפה גם על בני אפרים שאמרו חז"ל שיצאו שלשים שנה לפני הזמן נשיהןבניהם ובנותיהם, ואיך יכלו לצאת עם רב וארץ מצרים היתה מוקפת בכשפים שאף עבד לא יכול הי' לברוח משם.
translation: And it is known from the words of our Sages and the Zohar that wherever it says "the people," it refers to the mixed multitude (Erev Rav). At first glance, one might wonder how the Erev Rav left Egypt, and our Sages expounded on the verse "For the Lord took Israel out of Egypt" that this is a great miracle above all, for no slave could escape from Egypt. It is understandable that the Children of Israel left through a miracle, as the Holy One, blessed be He, took them out with a strong hand and an outstretched arm. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, did not allow the Erev Rav to join the Children of Israel in their exodus from Egypt, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explains on the verse "You have brought forth Your people whom You have taken out of Egypt" that it does not say "the people," but rather "Your people," the Erev Rav that You accepted upon Yourself without consulting Me, and You said it is good for converts to cling to the Divine Presence; they have corrupted and destroyed. Therefore, how did they merit the miracle of the exodus, which was naturally impossible for them to leave, as our Sages have said? This question also applies strongly to the Children of Ephraim, of whom our Sages said that they left thirty years before the time, with their wives, sons, and daughters. How could they leave with a multitude when the land of Egypt was surrounded by sorcery, such that even a slave could not escape from there?
summary: הקטע עוסק בשאלה כיצד יצא הערב רב ממצרים, כאשר חז"ל מדגישים שהיציאה הייתה נסית ולא טבעית, שכן עבד לא יכול לברוח משם. המדרש מציין שהקב"ה לא רצה שהערב רב יצטרף לעם ישראל, והם נחשבים ל"עם" שנשחת. השאלה מתרחבת גם על בני אפרים שיצאו לפני הזמן, מה שמצביע על הקושי בהבנת הנס וההשתלבות של קבוצות אלו ביציאה ממצרים, תוך הדגשת ההבדל בין ישראל לערב רב.

passage_content: אכןל"ק דמה שלא הי' עבד יכול לברוח ממצרים הי' ע"י כח הכשפים שהם כוחות הסט"א והואיל ובני אפרים עשו שלא כדת לעבור את פי ה' ליקח לעצמם חירות וגאולה לפני הזמן לכן לא מנעו בעדם כוחות הסט"א, ועוד סייעו בידם לעבור את פי ה' לקחת חירות וגאולה לפני הזמן, לכן פתחה להם הסט"א פתח כפתחו של אולם ויצאו בדרך הטבע באין מפריע ואין לתמוה מה שרדפו אח"כ המצריים אחריהם והרגום, דזהו דרך הסט"א לפתות את ישראל לדבר עבירה ואח"כ מקטרגים עליהם להענישם, וכענין הזה הי' גם בערב רב שעלו עם ישראל, דהנה המה היו המביאים וגורמים לבנ"י לכל חטאת ולכל עון למעול מעל בה', והם שעשו את העגל והחטיאו את ישראל וגרמו למשרע"ה שלא יכנס לארץ לכן סייע להם הסט"א שיוכלו לצאת עם ישראל, ופרעה והמצריים לא התנגדו ליציאתם, ואדרבה שלחו אותם כדי שיהיו לבנ"י לאבן נגף ולמכשול, וז"ש הפסוק ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם היינו הערב רב ול"ק קושית המדרש בלעם אמר אל מוציאם ממצרים דזה נאמר על בנ"י והקב"ה הוציאם ולא פרעה שלחם, אבל את העם היינו הע"ר שלח פרעה עם ישראל מרצונו כדי להצר לישראל.
translation: Indeed, it is explained that the reason why a servant could not escape from Egypt was due to the power of sorcery, which are the forces of the Other Side (Sitra Achra). Since the children of Ephraim acted improperly by transgressing the word of Hashem to take for themselves freedom and redemption before the appointed time, the forces of the Other Side did not prevent them, and moreover, they assisted them in transgressing the word of Hashem to take freedom and redemption prematurely. Therefore, the Other Side opened for them a passage like the opening of a hall, and they went out naturally without hindrance. It is not surprising that the Egyptians later pursued them and killed them, for this is the way of the Other Side to entice Israel to sin and then to accuse them in order to punish them. A similar situation occurred with the mixed multitude that ascended with Israel; they were the ones who brought and caused the children of Israel to commit all sins and transgressions against Hashem. They were the ones who made the golden calf and caused Israel to sin, leading to Moses not entering the land. Therefore, the Other Side assisted them so that they could leave with Israel, and Pharaoh and the Egyptians did not oppose their departure. On the contrary, they sent them so that they would be a stumbling block and a trap for Israel. This is what the verse means when it says, "And it was when Pharaoh sent the people," referring to the mixed multitude. This resolves the difficulty of the Midrash that Balaam said about those who brought them out of Egypt, for this is said about the children of Israel, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, brought them out, not Pharaoh who sent them. But regarding the people, it was the mixed multitude that Pharaoh sent willingly to cause distress to Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual forces, particularly the powers of the "Sitra Achra" (the Other Side), which enabled the Israelites, specifically the tribe of Ephraim, to escape Egypt prematurely by transgressing God's will. This act of defiance was supported by these dark forces, which later sought to accuse the Israelites for their sins. Additionally, the passage highlights the role of the "Erev Rav" (mixed multitude) in leading the Israelites astray, ultimately serving as a stumbling block to their spiritual journey. The text emphasizes that while God orchestrated the Exodus, the Erev Rav was sent by Pharaoh to hinder the Israelites' progress.

passage_content: ואמרז"לבספרי וגם ערב רב עלה אתם כאן נתקיים בהם ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול וצ"ב, והוא כעין מה שדרשו ז"ל במדרש הנ"ל וגם ערב רב עלה אתם היא הביזה ושניהם צריכין ביאור, ואפ"ל שטעמו של משרע"ה שקבל הערב רב הי' מחמת שראה ברוח קדשו שנבלע בתוכם נשמות קדושות שעתידין להתברר ולהתקרב אל הקדושה לעתיד, ובאמת הי' ג"כ רצון הבוי"ת לקבלם ולהציל נשמות שבתוכם דלא יצוייר שעשה משרע"ה דבר נגד רצונו ית', אלא מפני שראתה חכמתו ית' שיצא תקלה לישראל ע"י הערב רב, לא צוהו על ככה אלא משרע"ה מגרמי' עבד ונקראת על שמו, דלא יאות שיתייחס פעולת הרע אליו ית', וכעי"ז מצינו בזוה"ק פ' לך (דף פ"ב ע"א) א"ר יצחק בגין כך לא פקיד קוב"ה (לאאע"ה) לנחתא למצרים, אלא הוא מגרמי' נחת, בגין דלא יהא פתחון פה לבני עלמא, דאמר לי' כן ולבתר אצטער על אתתי' עכ"ל, ומבואר שם בזוה"ק (דף פ"ג ע"א) שהי' רצון הבוי"ת שירד למצרים עיי"ש, אלא שלא צוהו על ככה לטעם המבואר לעיל בדברי הזוה"ק, ולעיל בדברינו (פ' לך עמוד רל"ז) ביארנו מ"ש בזוה"ק שם כיון דנחת אברהם למצרים בלא רשו, אשתעבידו בנוי במצרים ד' מאה שנין וכו', דאף שהי' רצונו ית' כך, מ"מ נחשב לו לפגם בבחי' נורא עלילה עיי"ש, ועד"ז בשליחות המרגלים א"ל הקב"ה למשה אני איני מצוה אותך אם תרצה שלח, וכמו"כ בענין הערב רב רצונו ית' הי' שיעשה משרע"ה מעצמו, והשיג משרע"ה שעתידין לצאת מהם נשמות גבוהות וע"כ קיבלם.
translation: And our sages of blessed memory said in the books that also the mixed multitude went up with them, and here it was fulfilled in them, and afterwards they went out with great wealth, and this requires clarification. It is similar to what our sages of blessed memory expounded in the aforementioned Midrash, and also the mixed multitude went up with them refers to the plunder, and both need explanation. One could say that the reason of Moshe Rabbeinu accepting the mixed multitude was because he saw in his holy spirit that holy souls were absorbed within them that would eventually be clarified and drawn closer to holiness in the future. And indeed, it was also the will of the Blessed Creator to accept them and to save the souls within them, for it cannot be imagined that Moshe Rabbeinu did something against His will, but rather because he saw the wisdom of the Blessed One that a remedy would come to Israel through the mixed multitude, he was not commanded to do so, but Moshe Rabbeinu acted of his own accord and it is called by his name, for it is not fitting that the action of evil should be attributed to Him. And similarly, we find in the Zohar, Parashat Lech (page 82a), Rabbi Yitzchak said that for this reason the Holy One, blessed be He, did not command to descend to Egypt, but he acted of his own accord, so that there would not be a claim against the Holy One, blessed be He, that He said this and afterwards regretted His descent. It is explained there in the Zohar (page 83a) that it was the will of the Blessed Creator that he should descend to Egypt, as stated there, but He did not command him to do so for the reason explained above in the words of the Zohar. And earlier in our discussion (Parashat Lech, page 237) we explained what is stated in the Zohar there, that since Abraham descended to Egypt without permission, he was enslaved there for four hundred years, etc. For although it was His will, nonetheless, it was considered a blemish in the aspect of a terrible accusation, as stated there. And similarly, regarding the mission of the spies, the Holy One, blessed be He, told Moshe, I do not command you; if you wish, send. And likewise, concerning the mixed multitude, His will was that Moshe Rabbeinu should do it of his own accord, and Moshe Rabbeinu understood that there were high souls destined to come out from them, and therefore he accepted them.
summary: The passage discusses the complex relationship between Moses and the "Erev Rav" (mixed multitude) that joined the Israelites, suggesting that Moses accepted them due to a prophetic insight into the holy souls within them that would eventually be redeemed. It emphasizes that God's will was to save these souls, even though Moses acted independently in this decision, reflecting a divine wisdom that allows for the emergence of good from seemingly negative circumstances. The text also highlights the idea that God's intentions can be fulfilled through human actions, even when those actions are not explicitly commanded. Ultimately, it illustrates the interplay between divine providence and human agency in the unfolding of spiritual redemption.

passage_content: ונקדיםדברי ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה (פ' תולדות ד"ה ויאהב יצחק) לפרש הפסוק ובביזה לא שלחו את ידם עפי"מ שמצינו בגמ' (גיטין דף נ"ז ע"ב) שמבני בניו של המן למדו תורה ברבים, הרי שלא כלה זרעו לגמרי, והטעם ע"ד דכתיב וירא כי אין איש עתיד להתגייר ע"כ ויך את המצרי וגו' ולכך באלו שראו ברוה"ק שהיו בהם ניצוצות קדושות לא נגעו בהן, וידוע מה שפירשו וראיתי את דמעת העשוקים, דקאי על ניצוצות הקדושה העשוקים בתוך הטומאה, וז"ש ובביזה, במקום ביזה לא שלחו את ידם לנגוע בהם עכ"ל, ובזה יובן דברי המדרש הנ"ל אמרו לו גדולי מלכות מה עשית אילו לא הי' בידם אלא הביזה לבדם דיים, היינו הנשמות הקדושות שהוליכו עמהם ממצרים שהם נקראים ביזה כפי' היש"מ, שנאמר וגם ערב רב עלה אתם דמה"ט קבלם משה רבינו מפני שראה בהם נשמות קדושות, ונצטערו המצריים מאוד שנשמות אלו נתקרבו אל הקדושה ולפיכך צוח פרעה ווי.
translation: And we will precede the words of K"Z the holy Yishma'el (Parashat Toldot, D"Ha Vaye'ahav Yitzchak) to explain the verse "And in the plunder they did not send forth their hand," as we find in the Gemara (Gittin 57b) that from the descendants of Haman, they learned Torah in public, thus it is evident that his seed was not completely destroyed. The reason is as it is written, "And he saw that there was no man who would convert," therefore he struck the Egyptian, etc. And for this reason, those who saw in the Holy Spirit that there were within them holy sparks did not touch them. It is known what is explained, "And I saw the tears of the oppressed," which refers to the holy sparks oppressed within the impurity. Therefore it is said, "And in the plunder," in a place of plunder, they did not send forth their hand to touch them. Thus, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be understood: The great ones of the kingdom said to him, "What have you done? If they had only the plunder in their hands, it would have been enough," meaning the holy souls that they took with them from Egypt, which are called plunder according to the holy Yishma'el, as it is said, "And a mixed multitude went up with them." For this reason, Moshe Rabbeinu accepted them because he saw within them holy souls, and the Egyptians were very distressed that these souls were drawing close to holiness, and therefore Pharaoh cried out, "Woe!"
summary: The passage discusses the concept of holy sparks within the context of the Jewish exodus from Egypt, emphasizing that not all of Haman's descendants were lost, as some retained the potential for holiness. It highlights the idea that the Jewish people refrained from touching these holy sparks, represented as "biza" or plunder, during their departure. The text also reflects on the suffering of the Egyptians, particularly Pharaoh, who lamented the loss of these sacred souls that were drawn towards holiness, illustrating the tension between purity and impurity in the spiritual realm.

passage_content: ויובןבזה דמיון הנמשל למעיינות שבפרדס, דכמו שהמעיין תמיד הוא נובע ומתרבה, וכאשר האדם מסתכל בו אינו רואה מקורו ולא ישיג אכותו ומהותו דמקור המעיין מכוסה מעין, כמו כן הערב רב שקבלם משה רבינו שלפי ראות העין לא היו ראוייןלהתקרב אל הקדושה, אעפ"כ הי' מובלעים בתוכם נשמות יקרות שעתידין להתברר אחר ביאת המשיח, וזה ראה משה רבינו וע"כ קיבל אותם, ומבואר בדברי חכז"ל דאלמלי נכנס משה רבינו ע"ה לארץ ישראל הי' מיד עולם התיקון. ואז היו מתבררין כל הנשמות של הע"ר, ובוודאי לא הי' פרעה משלח אותם, כי לא הי' ברצונו להוסיף קדושה על קדושה, ורק מפני שראה שלא קרבה הגאולה שלימה כמו שאמר בלעם אראנו ולא עתה אשורנו ולא קרוב, ע"כ הסכים לשלוח הע"ר עם ישראל כדי להצר להם, ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם, ר"ל הע"ר עם ישראל, משה צווח ווי שלא יכנס לארץ.
translation: It will be understood here that the analogy is like the springs in the orchard, for just as the spring is always flowing and increasing, when a person looks at it, he does not see its source and cannot grasp its quality and essence, for the source of the spring is hidden from sight. Similarly, the mixed multitude that Moshe Rabbeinu accepted, according to what is seen with the eye, were not worthy to approach holiness; nevertheless, within them were concealed precious souls that will be clarified after the coming of the Messiah. This Moshe Rabbeinu saw, and therefore he accepted them. It is explained in the words of our Sages that had Moshe Rabbeinu entered the Land of Israel, the world of rectification would have immediately begun. Then all the souls of the mixed multitude would have been clarified, and certainly Pharaoh would not have sent them away, for he did not wish to add holiness upon holiness. Only because he saw that the complete redemption was not approaching, as Bilaam said, "I see him, but not now; I behold him, but not near," did he agree to send the mixed multitude with Israel in order to trouble them. In this, the words of the Midrash will be clarified: "And it was when Pharaoh sent the people," meaning the mixed multitude with Israel, Moshe cried out, "Woe that I will not enter the Land."
summary: The passage draws a parallel between the hidden source of a spring and the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) that accompanied the Israelites, suggesting that although they appeared unworthy of holiness, they contained precious souls destined for redemption in the Messianic era. Moses recognized this potential and accepted them, understanding that their eventual purification was crucial for the completion of the world’s rectification. The text emphasizes that had Moses entered the Land of Israel, the process of redemption would have accelerated, revealing the hidden sanctity within the Erev Rav, which Pharaoh opposed, fearing the increase of holiness. Ultimately, the narrative reflects on the tension between visible reality and hidden spiritual potential, underscoring the importance of faith in the unseen.

passage_content: ויהיבשלח פרעה את העם ולא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים כי קרוב הוא, במכילתא לא הביאן הקב"ה דרך פשוטה לארץ ישראל אלא דרך המדבר, אמר הקב"ה אם אני מביא עכשיו ישראל לארץ, מיד מחזיקים אדם בשדהו ואדם בכרמו, והן בטלים מן התורה, אלא אקיפם במדבר מ' שנה, שיהיו אוכלין מן ושותין מי הבאר, והתורה נבללת בגופן, מכאן הי' ר' שמעון אומר לא ניתנה תורה אלא לאוכלי המן, ושניים להם אוכלי תרומה עכ"ד המכילתא, וצ"ב דאין זה הטעם המפורש בכתוב פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה וגו', ומדוע נטו חכז"ל בדרשתם ליתן טעם חדש שונה מהמפורש בפסוק.
translation: And Pharaoh sent the people away, and God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, for it was near. In the Mechilta, it is stated that the Holy One, blessed be He, did not bring them by a straightforward path to the Land of Israel, but rather through the wilderness. The Holy One, blessed be He, said: If I bring Israel to the land now, immediately a person will take hold of his field and another will take hold of his vineyard, and they will be distracted from the Torah. Rather, I will encircle them in the wilderness for forty years, so that they will eat from the manna and drink from the water of the well, and the Torah will be absorbed within them. From here, Rabbi Shimon would say that the Torah was given only to those who eat the manna, and to those who eat terumah, thus concludes the Mechilta. And it is to be questioned why this is not the explicit reason given in the verse, "lest the people change their minds when they see war," and why the sages inclined in their interpretation to provide a new reason that differs from what is stated in the verse.
summary: The passage discusses God's decision to lead the Israelites through the desert rather than directly to the Promised Land, emphasizing the importance of spiritual preparation over immediate physical settlement. It highlights the idea that prolonged reliance on divine sustenance, such as the manna, was necessary for the Israelites to internalize the Torah, as they would be distracted by their possessions if they settled too soon. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the relationship between material needs and spiritual growth, suggesting that true devotion requires a period of spiritual refinement away from worldly distractions. The text raises questions about the differing interpretations of divine intentions, indicating a deeper theological exploration of God's guidance and the nature of faith.

passage_content: ב)(פרשה כ' סי' ט"ז) ד"א ולא נחם אלקים, למה דרך פלשתים, א"ר שמעון בן אבא א"ר יוחנן כיון ששמעו הכנענים שישראל נכנסין לארץ, עמדו וקצצו הנטיעות שהיו להם, כיון ששמעו שנתעכבו במדבר מ' שנה היו סבורים שבמדבר תהא דירתם, עמדו ונטעו נטיעות וגדלו אותן ואח"כ הכניסן לארץ עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה גם זה צ"ב דאין זה טעם המפורש בכתוב פן ינחם העם וגו'.
translation: In the section (Parashat) 20, Siman 16, it is said: "And God did not lead them the way of the Philistines." Rabbi Shimon ben Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: When the Canaanites heard that Israel was entering the land, they stood up and cut down the saplings they had. When they heard that they were delayed in the desert for 40 years, they thought that their dwelling would be in the desert. They stood up, planted saplings, and nurtured them, and afterwards brought them into the land. Thus is the teaching of the Midrash. And at first glance, this also requires explanation, for this is not the reason explicitly stated in the verse, "lest the people regret..."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the discussion centers on why God chose not to lead the Israelites through the land of the Philistines, as explained by Rabbi Shimon ben Abba in the name of Rabbi Yochanan. The Canaanites, upon hearing of the Israelites' entry into the land, cut down their trees, believing that the Israelites would remain in the desert for forty years. This reflects a deeper theological insight into divine providence and the interplay between human actions and God's plans, emphasizing the importance of faith and the consequences of doubt in the face of divine promises.

passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם לבאר בדברי המדרש הנ"ל דהטעם שהסיבם הקב"ה דרך המדבר, הי' בשביל שקצצו הכנענים כל הנטיעות, והקב"ה הבטיח לישראל להביאם אל ארץ טובה ורחבה וע"י שנתעכבו ישראל מ' שנה במדבר, חזרו ונטעו נטיעות חדשים, ולכאורה טעם זה צ"ב דכמו שנתן הקב"ה בלבם לנטוע נטיעות חדשים אח"כ, כמו"כ הי' היכולת בידו ית' למנוע אותם מתחלה, או ליתן בלבם עצה שלא לקצצם, ומדוע בשביל טעם זה בלבד הי' ההכרח לסבבם מ' שנה במדבר, אלא וודאי שהי' רצון הבוי"ת כן שיקצצו כל הנטיעות וינטעו חדשים וצ"ב הטעם,
translation: And it is necessary to explain in light of the aforementioned Midrash that the reason the Holy One, blessed be He, led them through the desert was because the Canaanites had cut down all the saplings, and the Holy One, blessed be He, promised Israel to bring them to a good and spacious land. And since Israel was delayed for forty years in the desert, they returned and planted new saplings. At first glance, this reason is puzzling, for just as the Holy One, blessed be He, put it in their hearts to plant new saplings afterward, so too it was within His ability to prevent them from cutting them down in the first place, or to give them counsel not to cut them. And why, for this reason alone, was it necessary to cause them to wander for forty years in the desert? Rather, it is certain that it was the will of the Creator that all the saplings be cut down and new ones be planted, and the reason for this is indeed a question.
summary: המעבר של בני ישראל במדבר במשך ארבעים שנה נועד לאפשר להם לנטוע נטיעות חדשות לאחר שהכנענים קצצו את הנטיעות הקודמות. השאלה היא מדוע הקב"ה לא מנע את קציצת הנטיעות מלכתחילה, אם היה יכול להנחות את בני ישראל לנטוע מחדש. התשובה טמונה ברצון האלוהי, שמטרתו הייתה להביא את ישראל לתהליך של חידוש ויצירה, מה שמעיד על חשיבות התהליך הרוחני והפנימי של העם.

passage_content: ויתבארבהקדם דברי הגמ' (ע"ז דף נ"ג ע"ב) א"ר אלעזר וכו' דאמר רחמנא ואשיריהם תשרפון באש, מכדי ירושה הוא להם מאבותיהם, ואין אדם אוסר דבר שאינו שלו, ואי משום הנך דמעיקרא, (פירש"י משום אשירות דמעיקרא היו קודם שניתנו לאברהם, ולא ידעינן הי נינהו), בביטולא בעלמא סגי להו, (פירש"י דקיי"ל נכרי מבטל ע"ז של עכו"ם על כרחו ליכפינהו לעובדי כוכבים וליבטלינהו), ותירצו בגמ' מדפלחו ישראל לעגל גלו אדעתייהו דניחא להו בע"ז, וכי אתו עכו"ם שליחותא דידהו עבדי, (פירש"י הלכך הוי ע"ז של ישראל ואינה בטילה עולמית) עכ"ד הגמ' לענינינו, והנה דרשו רז"ל עה"פ נתנה ראש ונשובה מצרימה, אין ראש אלא ע"ז שנאמר ויהי דוד בא עד הראש, ולפי שהי' גלוי וידוע לפניו ית' שיחשבו ישראל מחשבה אחרת ויטעו בעגל, ומעתה יאסרו כל הנטיעות שעבדו להם הכנענים, דגלו ישראל אדעתייהו דניחא להו והוי כע"ז של ישראל, ע"כ נתן השי"ת בלב הכנענים שיעקרו כל הנטיעות ויתבטל הע"ז, דבלא"ה לא יוכלו ישראל ליהנות מהם ויצטרכו לעקרם, ואחר שעשו ישראל תשובה על חטא העגל, ונטעו הכנענים נטיעות חדשים ולזה מהני ביטול דלא הוי כע"ז של ישראל, דכבר גלו ישראל אדעתייהו דלא ניחא להו בע"ז, אלא שחכז"ל נתנו סימנא להכיר האשירות האסורים כאמרז"ל (ע"ז דף מ"ה ע"ב) אר"ע כל מקום שאתה מוצא הר גבוה וגבעה נשאה ועץ רענן דע שיש שם ע"ז, ואפשר דאלו לא נעקרו ע"י הכנענים והניחום לתקלה לישראל ולזה לא מהני להו ביטול כע"ז של ישראל, אבל שאר הנטיעות שנטעו הכנענים אח"כ יכלו ישראל ליהנות מהם ע"י ביטול.
translation: And it will be explained in advance the words of the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 53b) that Rabbi Elazar said, etc., that the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "And their ashes you shall burn in fire." Since it is an inheritance for them from their ancestors, and a person cannot prohibit something that does not belong to him, and if it is because of those that were from the beginning (Rashi explains that it is because the wealth was originally theirs before it was given to Abraham, and we do not know who they are), it is sufficient for them to be nullified in a mere annulment (Rashi explains that we hold that a non-Jew can nullify the idol of a gentile against his will and nullify it). And the Gemara answers that since the Jews worshipped the calf, they revealed their intention that they were pleased with idolatry, and when the gentiles come, they are their agents (Rashi explains that therefore it is considered idolatry of the Jews and it cannot be nullified forever). Thus concludes the Gemara regarding our matter. And behold, our sages expounded on the verse "He gave a head and we will return to Egypt," that there is no head except for idolatry, as it is said, "And it was when David came to the head." And since it was revealed and known before Him, blessed be He, that the Jews would think another thought and be misled by the calf, from now on all the plantings that the Canaanites worked for them would be prohibited, for the Jews revealed their intention that they were pleased with it and it is like the idolatry of the Jews. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, put it in the hearts of the Canaanites to uproot all the plantings so that the idolatry would be nullified, for otherwise the Jews would not be able to benefit from them and would need to uproot them. And after the Jews repented for the sin of the calf, and the Canaanites planted new plantings, for this the nullification is effective, as it is not considered idolatry of the Jews, for the Jews have already revealed their intention that they are not pleased with idolatry. However, our sages gave a sign to recognize the forbidden wealth, as our sages said (Avodah Zarah 45b), "Wherever you find a high mountain and a raised hill and a fresh tree, know that there is idolatry there." And it is possible that if these were not uprooted by the Canaanites and they left them as a stumbling block for the Jews, then the nullification would not be effective as idolatry of the Jews, but the other plantings that the Canaanites planted afterwards, the Jews could benefit from them through nullification.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of idolatry and its connection to the Jewish people, emphasizing that the Israelites' involvement with the Golden Calf led to a unique status of idolatry that could not be nullified. It highlights the divine foresight of God, who anticipated Israel's potential transgression and allowed the Canaanites to uproot their idolatrous practices to prevent Israel from benefiting from them. After the Israelites repented, new plantings by the Canaanites could be enjoyed by the Israelites, as they were no longer considered idolatrous. The text underscores the importance of recognizing and addressing the spiritual dangers associated with idolatry, as well as the possibility of redemption and restoration through repentance.

passage_content: ומעתהא"ש דמ"ש במדרש דטעם עיכובם של ישראל במדבר הי' בשביל הנטיעות, הוא מקושר עםטעם המפורש בכתוב פן ינחם העם וגו', דמפני שהי' חשש זה קיים שיחשבו מחשבה אחרת לטעות אחר ע"ז, וכמו שאירע באמת שטעו אחר העגל ונאסרו כל הנטיעות, לכן נתעכבו ישראל במדבר עד שנטעו חדשים לאחר שעשו ישראל תשובה והותרו להם, ועד"ז אפ"ל דגם טעם המכילתא מקושר עם טעם המפורש בכתוב, דהנה הבטיח הקב"ה לישראל שיביאם אל ארץ טובה ורחבה וגו' בתים מלאים כל טוב, כרמים וזתים אשר לא נטעת, וא"כ לא יצטרכו לעבוד עבודת שדה וכרם כלל, ומדוע חש הקב"ה שיחזיקו איש בשדהו ובכרמו ויתבטלו מן התורה אמנם מפני שהי' חשש זה קיים פן ינחם העם כנ"ל. ולזה הי' צורך שיעקרו הכנענים כל הנטיעות, ואלמלי נכנסו ישראל מיד, היו צריכים לעמול בעבודת שדה וכרם ויתבטלו מן התורה, וע"כ הקיפם הקב"ה במדבר מ' שנה שיהיו אוכלין מן ושותין מי באר והתורה נבללת בגופן שם כי לא הי' מתקיים עסק התורה בידם בארץ ישראל, ולאחר שחזרו ונטעו הכנענים כל הנטיעות, נכנסו לארץ מלאה כל טוב ונתקיים עסק התורה בידם גם לאח"כ, וא"ש דכולהו טעמים שאמרז"ל נרמזו בטעם הכתוב פן ינחם העם וגו'.
translation: And from the time of the evening, as stated in the Midrash, that the reason for the delay of Israel in the desert was because of the plantings, it is connected with the reason explicitly stated in the verse, "lest the people regret..." For since this concern existed that they might think another thought to err after idolatry, and as it indeed happened that they erred after the calf and all the plantings were forbidden, therefore Israel was delayed in the desert until they planted anew after Israel repented and it was permitted to them. Similarly, it can be said that the reason of the Mechilta is also connected with the reason explicitly stated in the verse, for behold, the Holy One, Blessed be He, promised Israel that He would bring them to a good and spacious land... houses full of all good things, vineyards and olive trees which they did not plant. Therefore, they would not need to work the fields and vineyards at all. And why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, fear that a man would hold onto his field and vineyard and become distracted from the Torah? It was because this concern existed, "lest the people regret," as mentioned above. For this reason, it was necessary for the Canaanites to uproot all the plantings, and had Israel entered immediately, they would have had to toil in the work of the fields and vineyards and would have been distracted from the Torah. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, surrounded them in the desert for forty years so that they would eat from the manna and drink from the well, and the Torah would be absorbed within them there, for the study of Torah would not have been sustained in their hands in the Land of Israel. And after the Canaanites returned and planted all the plantings, they entered a land full of all good things, and the study of Torah was sustained in their hands even afterwards. And it is clear that all the reasons mentioned by our Sages are hinted at in the reason of the verse, "lest the people regret..."
summary: The passage discusses the reasons for the Israelites' prolonged wandering in the desert, linking it to the need for spiritual preparation and the avoidance of idolatry. It emphasizes that the fear of the people returning to false beliefs necessitated their delay until they repented and were ready to enter the Promised Land. Additionally, it highlights that if they had entered immediately, they would have been distracted by agricultural work, hindering their commitment to Torah study. Ultimately, the text illustrates how divine providence ensured that the Israelites were spiritually and physically prepared to inherit a land filled with blessings.

passage_content: ויהיבשלח פרעה וגו' במד"ר (פ' כ' סי' ה') הה"ד (שה"ש ד') שלחיך פרדס רמונים, א"ר לוי משל לאחד שהי' לו שדה והי' בה גל של צרורות, עמד ומכרה לאחר, עמד אותו האיש שקנאה והעביר אותו הגל מתוכה, ומצא תחתיו מים חיים: נטעה גפנים עשאה שורות שורות נטע בה כל מיני בשמים וכו' והושיב בתוכה שומר וכו', עבר עלי' אותו האיש שמכרה ראה אותה מליאה כל טוב, אמר אוי לי שכך מכרתי, אוי לי שכך הוצאתי מידי, כך היו ישראל במצרים גל של צרורות וכו', כיון שיצאו נעשו פרדס רמונים וכו' לכך נאמר ויהי בשלח פרעה עכ"ד המדרש וצ"ב דמיון המשל שאינו מתאים לכאורה עם הנמשל, כי בסיפור המשל הי' המעיין מכוסה בגל של צרורות, ולא הרגיש בו המוכר כלל ופנים חדשות באו אח"כ ביד הקונה, משא"כ פרעה הכיר וידע איכותם ומספרם של ישראל גם במצרים, ומה נתגלה לו מגדולתם יותר בעמדם על הים, ואם לצד שנתעלו במעלות הנפשות וברוחני, אין זה סיבה לפרעה שיתחרט עבור זה.
translation:
And it was when Pharaoh sent, etc. (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 5) as it is said (Song of Songs 4:13) "Your shoots are a paradise of pomegranates." Rabbi Levi said: This is comparable to a man who had a field and there was a mound of pebbles in it. He stood up and sold it to another. That man who bought it removed the mound from it and found under it living waters. He planted vines, made rows, and planted in it all kinds of spices, etc., and he set a guard over it, etc. The man who sold it passed by and saw it full of goodness. He said, "Woe to me for having sold it! Woe to me for having taken it out of my hands!" Thus were the Israelites in Egypt, a mound of pebbles, etc. When they went out, they became a paradise of pomegranates, etc. Therefore, it is said, "And it was when Pharaoh sent." Thus far is the Midrash. 

And it is difficult to understand the analogy of the parable, which seemingly does not fit with the interpretation, for in the story of the parable, the spring was covered by a mound of pebbles, and the seller did not feel it at all, and new faces came later into the hands of the buyer. Whereas Pharaoh recognized and knew the quality and number of the Israelites even in Egypt, and what was revealed to him of their greatness more when they stood by the sea. And if it is because they were elevated in the levels of souls and spirituality, this is not a reason for Pharaoh to regret it.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel uses a parable to illustrate the transformation of the Israelites from a state of oppression in Egypt, likened to a field covered with stones, to a flourishing garden filled with blessings upon their liberation. It highlights the contrast between the superficial perception of their worth by Pharaoh and the profound spiritual elevation they achieved after leaving Egypt. The theological insight emphasizes that true value and potential can often be obscured by external circumstances, and that liberation reveals the inherent greatness within the soul. Ultimately, it questions Pharaoh's understanding of the Israelites' true significance, suggesting that their spiritual ascent was not recognized until their miraculous crossing of the sea.
