passage_content: ואפ"לבהקדם מה שפירשתי דברי הזוה"ק (ר"פ ויקהל קצ"ה ע"א) ויקהל משה וגו' מאן אתר כניש לון. אלא בגין דהוו אינון ערב רב בינייהו אצטריך משה לאכנשא לון וליחדא לון מבינייהו עכ"ד הזוה"ק, ולכאורה אם התכוין משרע"ה רק להפרידן מן הע"ר הו"ל להכתוב לומר ויפרד משה, דאין זה פעולת הקהלה כ"א פעולת הפרדה, ויתבאר עפימ"ש בס' אוהל יעקב פ' וישב לפרש הכתוב (איוב ט"ו) כי עדת חנף גלמוד היות ידענו גם בעסקיהעוה"ז, כי הדבר המוסכם באסיפת הרבים יותר מקובל מהמוסכם ביחיד, אבל זה אינו רק אם הנאספים לחקור על הדבר אין כוונתם להנאת עצמם, בלתי להעמיק בתכלית ואמיתת הענין, משא"כ באם המה בהסכמתם על הדבר כוונו כל אחד לפי ענינו הטמון בקרבו לטובתו, אז אין לסמוך על המוסכם מפיהם יותר מעל המוסכם מאיש פרטי, וזהו עדת חנף גלמוד פי' בשגם יהי' עדה גדולה עכ"ז אינו חשוב כ"א כיחידים פרטים כי כל אחד מובדל ומרוחק מזולתו עכת"ד, ובזה יתבארו דברי הזוה"ק ופי' הכתוב, דכ"ז שהיו הערב רב מעורבין בישראל, היו מכניסים פירוד לבבות ומחשבת פניות גם בישראל, וע"כ אף שהיו עם רב ועדה גדולה לא היו נחשבים כ"א כיחידים פרטים וע"י שהפרידן מן הערב רב נעשו ישראל קהלה אחת בהתאחדות הלבבות לעשות רצון הבוית"ש, וז"א ויקהל משה שהפרידן מן הערב רב שעי"ז נעשו קהלה אחת בהתאחדות גמור.
translation: And although I have previously explained the words of the Zohar (Parashat Vayakhel 35a) "And Moses gathered," who is the one who gathers them? Rather, because they were the mixed multitude among them, Moses needed to gather them and unite them from among them, thus said the Zohar. And seemingly, if Moshe intended only to separate them from the mixed multitude, it should have been written "And Moses separated," for this is not an act of gathering but rather an act of separation. This will be clarified according to what is stated in the book Ohel Yaakov, Parashat Vayeshev, to explain the verse (Job 15) "For the congregation of the hypocrites is barren," as we know even in the affairs of this world, that the consensus in a gathering of many is more accepted than the consensus of an individual. However, this is only if those gathered intend to investigate the matter not for their own benefit, but to delve into the essence and truth of the matter. Whereas if they, in their agreement on the matter, each intend according to their own interests hidden within them for their own good, then one cannot rely on the consensus of their mouths more than on the consensus of an individual. And this is the meaning of "the congregation of the hypocrites is barren," meaning that although there may be a large congregation, it is not significant except as individual particulars, for each one is separate and distant from the other. Thus, the words of the Zohar and the explanation of the verse will be clarified: as long as the mixed multitude was mixed among Israel, they brought division of hearts and thoughts of ulterior motives even among Israel. Therefore, even though they were a large people and a great congregation, they were not considered anything more than individual particulars. And by separating them from the mixed multitude, Israel became one congregation through the unification of hearts to do the will of the Blessed One, and this is the meaning of "And Moses gathered," that he separated them from the mixed multitude, and through this they became one congregation in complete unity.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of unity among the Jewish people, as highlighted in the Zohar's interpretation of Moses gathering the Israelites. It emphasizes that the presence of the "erev rav" (mixed multitude) caused division and self-interest among the people, preventing true collective purpose. By separating the Israelites from the erev rav, Moses facilitated a genuine unity of hearts, allowing them to become a cohesive community dedicated to fulfilling God's will. This illustrates the Hasidic concept that true communal strength arises from shared intention and spiritual alignment rather than mere numerical presence.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבאר ענין המשל שבמדרש הנ"ל, דהנה רשעי ישראל היו במצרים מרובים על הכשרים פי כמה, כאמרז"ל במדרש דא' מחמשה יצאו, ולחד מ"ד א' מחמש מאות, ואיכא למ"ד ב' מס' רבוא והשאר מתו בג' ימי אפילה על שהיו רשעים ולא רצו לצאת ממצרים, והן היו פטרונין לפרעה, עכ"פ כ"ז שהיו הרשעים ביניהם ומרובין עליהם לא הכיר פרעה מעלתם וחשיבותן של ישראל, כי היו בטלין לגביהם וכיחידים נפרדים נחשבו מחמת הרוב הגדול שהתנגד לדעתם, וזהו דמיון המשל למים חיים שמכוסהבגל של צרורות היינו הע"ר, וכשיצאו ישראל ממצרים מתו כל אלו הרשעים בג' ימי אפילה, והע"ר שיצאו עמהם לא היו מעורבים כ"כ ביניהם, שעמדו חוץ לעננים, ואז השיג פרעה חשיבותן של ישראל, וכח הגדול שיש לאומה זו בשעה שהם נפרדים מן הרשעים ונקהלים יחד, וע"כ צווח וויי שכך הוצאתי מידי.
translation: And similarly, the matter of the parable in the aforementioned Midrash is explained: behold, the wicked of Israel in Egypt were many times more numerous than the righteous, as our Sages said in the Midrash, "One out of five went out," and according to one opinion, "One out of five hundred," and there is an opinion that says "Two out of ten thousand," and the rest died during the three days of darkness because they were wicked and did not want to leave Egypt. They were patrons to Pharaoh; at least as long as the wicked were among them and were more numerous than the righteous, Pharaoh did not recognize their merit and the importance of Israel, for they were nullified in relation to him and were considered as separate individuals due to the great majority that opposed their opinion. This is analogous to the parable of living waters that are covered by a heap of stones, which is the wicked. And when Israel left Egypt, all those wicked ones died during the three days of darkness, and the righteous who left with them were not so mixed among them, as they stood outside the clouds. Then Pharaoh grasped the importance of Israel and the great power that this nation has at the time they are separated from the wicked and gathered together. Therefore, he cried out, "Woe, how have I brought this upon myself!"
summary: The passage discusses the significant disparity between the righteous and the wicked among the Israelites in Egypt, highlighting that the wicked outnumbered the righteous, which obscured their value in Pharaoh's eyes. It uses the metaphor of living waters covered by a layer of refuse to illustrate how the presence of the wicked diminished the recognition of the righteous. Upon the death of the wicked during the three days of darkness, the righteous were able to stand apart, allowing Pharaoh to finally perceive their true importance and strength as a united nation. This separation from the wicked underscores the theological concept of the collective power and sanctity of the righteous when they are united and distinct from evil.

passage_content: ויסבאלקים את העם דרך המדבר ים סוף וחמשים עלו בני ישראל מארץ מצרים, יל"ד בשנותו את טעמו מהעם לבני ישראל, שהתחיל הכתוב ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם וגו' פן ינחם העם וגו' ויסב אלקים את העם וגו', ואח"כ וחמשים עלו בני ישראל, וידוע דבני ישראל לאו היינו העם וצ"ב הכוונה.
translation: And God turned the people toward the way of the wilderness of the Red Sea, and fifty went up from the land of Egypt, as it is said in the years of his changing his taste from the people to the Children of Israel, that the scripture began, "And it was when Pharaoh sent out the people," etc., "lest the people regret," etc., and God turned the people, etc., and afterwards, "and fifty went up from the Children of Israel," and it is known that the Children of Israel are not the same as the people, and the question remains as to the intention.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the divine guidance of the Israelites as they journey through the wilderness after their exodus from Egypt. The distinction between "the people" and "the children of Israel" highlights a deeper spiritual identity, suggesting that while all are part of the collective, the true essence of the Israelites lies in their unique relationship with God. The text emphasizes the importance of divine intervention in shaping their path, illustrating the Hasidic belief in the necessity of spiritual elevation and the transformative power of faith.

passage_content: ב)עלו בני ישראל פרש"י אין חמושים אלא מזויינים וכו', דבר אחר חמשים מחומשים, אחד מחמשה יצאו וד' חלקים מתו בג' ימי אפילה, ולכאורה צ"ב לשני הפירושים דאין כאן מקומה של הודעה זו, ולעיל היל"ל בפ' בא בהזכרת יציאת מצרים, וברש"י במוסגר (פי' בשם רש"י ישן) לפי שהסיבתן במדבר גרם להם שעלו מחומשים וכו', וכתוב זה לא נכתב כ"א לשבר את האוזן שלא תתמה במלחמת עמלק ובמלחמות סיחון ועוג ומדין מהיכן היו להם כלי זיין וכו' עכ"ל, אמנם גם טעם זה צ"ב דבאמת לא הוצרכו ישראל לכלי זיין ולא בכח החרב נלחמו בעמלק, כמפורש בכתוב והי' כאשר ירים משה ידו וגבר ישראל, ודרשו רז"ל (ר"ה כ"ט ע"א) וכי ידיו של משה עושות מלחמה וכו', אלא כ"ז שישראל משעבדין את לבם לאביהם שבשמים היו נוצחים וכו', והכלי זיין שהוליכו עמהם הי' להם רק לנסיון, כמ"ש רז"ל ארבע כתין אתעבידו ישראל על ים סוף וכו' כת א' אמרה נסדר לקובליהון סדרי קרבא וכו' והשיב להם משה רבינו ד' ילחם לכם ואתם תחרישון, וא"כ יותר טוב הי' להם אם לא הי' בידם כלי זיין, כי אז לא באו לידי נסיון. ובפרט שלא הי' צורך להם לכלי זיין כלל, ולפי' השני שפרש"י חמשים מחומשים וכו' ודאי קשה דאין כאן מקומה להודיע זה והול"ל לעיל בפ' יציאת מצרים, וכמו"כ יל"ד במאמה"כ להלן ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו כי השבע השביע את בנ"י וגו', דהול"ל להכתוב להודיענו זה בפ' יציאת מצרים, שהרי כבר נתקיים דבר זה טרם יציאתם, ואז הי' חלות השבועה.
translation: B) The children of Israel went up, Rashi explains that they were not armed but equipped, etc. Another explanation is that they were fifty armed, one out of five went out, and four parts died during the three days of darkness. And at first glance, it is difficult to understand both interpretations, as this is not the place for this information. Earlier, it was stated in Parashat Bo regarding the mention of the Exodus from Egypt, and Rashi in parentheses (meaning in the name of an old Rashi) explains that their being in the desert caused them to go up equipped, etc. This writing was only written to break the ear, so that you should not wonder in the war against Amalek and in the wars of Sihon and Og and Midian where they had weapons, etc. However, this reason is also difficult, for in truth, the Israelites did not need weapons at all, nor did they fight Amalek with the strength of the sword, as it is explicitly written, "And it was when Moses raised his hand, Israel prevailed," and our sages have interpreted (Rosh Hashanah 29a), "And do the hands of Moses wage war?" Rather, as long as Israel subjugated their hearts to their Father in Heaven, they were victorious, etc. The weapons they took with them were only for a test, as our sages have said, "Four groups were formed by Israel at the Sea of Reeds," etc. One group said, "Let us arrange to gather them for battle," etc. And Moses our teacher replied, "The Lord will fight for you, and you shall hold your peace." Therefore, it would have been better for them if they had not had weapons at all, for then they would not have come to a test. Especially since they had no need for weapons at all. And according to the second explanation that Rashi gave, that they were fifty armed, etc., it is certainly difficult, for this is not the place to inform us of this, and it should have been stated earlier in the Exodus from Egypt. Likewise, it is necessary to understand in the verse later on, "And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, for he had made the children of Israel swear," etc. The verse should have informed us of this in the Exodus from Egypt, since this matter was already fulfilled before their departure, and then the oath would take effect.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites being armed during their exodus, emphasizing that their true strength came from their spiritual connection to God rather than physical weapons. It highlights that their victories in battles, such as against Amalek, were achieved through divine assistance rather than military might, suggesting that the presence of weapons was merely a test of faith. Additionally, it questions the necessity of mentioning certain details in the context of the exodus narrative, indicating a deeper theological understanding of divine providence and the fulfillment of promises, such as the oath regarding Joseph's bones. Ultimately, the text reflects on the importance of reliance on God over material means in the face of challenges.

passage_content: ג)אם שמוע תשמע לקול ד' אלקיך וגו' כל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים לא אשים עליך כי אני ד' רופאך, והקשו המפרשים דאם לא אשים רפואה למ"ל, ורש"י ז"ל פי' ואם אשים ה"ה כאלו לא הושמה כי אני ד' רופאך ולפי פירושו ג"כ צ"ב דעיקר חסר מן הספר, דלא כתיב ואם אשים.
translation: 3) "If you will diligently listen to the voice of the Lord your God, etc. All the sickness that I placed upon Egypt I will not place upon you, for I am the Lord your Healer." The commentators have questioned that if I will not place healing for the one who is sick, and Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that if I place it, it is as if it were not placed, for I am the Lord your Healer. According to his explanation, it is also problematic, as a fundamental aspect is missing from the text, for it is not written, "If I will place."
summary: In this passage, the author emphasizes the divine promise of healing from God, as expressed in the verse "I am the Lord, your healer." The discussion highlights the paradox of illness and healing, suggesting that if God is the ultimate healer, then any affliction that may arise is rendered insignificant. The interpretation of the verse implies that God's presence and power in healing transcend the existence of illness, reinforcing the Hasidic belief in the omnipotence and benevolence of God in the lives of the faithful. This reflects a deep theological insight into the relationship between divine will, human suffering, and the assurance of spiritual and physical restoration.

passage_content: ד)משה אליהם איש אל יותר ממנו עד בוקר ולא שמעו אל משה ויותירו אנשים ממנו עד בקר וגו', דקדק האוהחה"ק דלא הי' צ"ל אלא ויותירו וגו', ואני יודע שלא שמעו אל משה, גם צ"ב מ"ט קראם הכתוב אנשים, ורז"ל אמרו בכ"מ אין אנשים אלא צדיקים, ובמד"ר (פ' שלח פ' ט"ז סי' ה') איתא בכל מקום שנאמר אנשים בני אדם צדיקים. הם, ואלו שהותירו המן היו דתן ואבירם כמפורש במד"ר (פ' כ"ה סימן י') ובפרש"י ז"ל ומ"ט קראם הכתוב אנשים, והגם שמצינו במקצת מקומות מלת אנשים לא על צדיקים, כמו שני אנשים עברים נצים וכדומה, אה"נ דבכ"מ צריך ביאור ליישב.
translation: d) Moses said to them, "Let no man leave of it until morning," and they did not listen to Moses, and some men left of it until morning, etc. The holy Baal Shem Tov emphasized that it should have only said, "And they left," etc. I know that they did not listen to Moses. It is also necessary to understand why the scripture calls them "men," and our sages have said that in any place "men" refers only to the righteous. In the Midrash (Parashat Shelach, Parashat 16, Section 5) it is stated that wherever it says "men" or "human beings," it refers to the righteous. And those who left over the manna were Datan and Aviram, as is explicitly stated in the Midrash (Parashat 25, Section 10) and in Rashi's commentary. And why does the scripture call them "men"? Although we find in some places the word "men" not referring to the righteous, like "two Hebrew men were fighting" and similar cases, indeed, in any case, it requires explanation to clarify.
summary: The passage discusses the refusal of certain individuals to heed Moses' instructions regarding the collection of manna, highlighting the term "אנשים" (people) used in the text, which traditionally refers to the righteous. It emphasizes that those who disregarded Moses were not true followers, specifically identifying Datan and Aviram as examples of those who remained. The text suggests a deeper understanding of the nature of righteousness and the consequences of disobedience, reflecting on the distinction between true "צדיקים" and those who appear as such but fail to follow divine guidance.

passage_content: ה)אינו מובן כוונת המותירים, ואם לצד חסרון אמונתם שייראו לנפשותם שלא יהי' להם למחר לאכול, אין לך שטות גדול מזה, שהרי כבר ראו בחוש גודל הנס שירד להם לחם מן השמים. והבטיח להם הקב"ה ולקטו דבר יום ביומו ואיך ידאגו עוד דאגת מחר, ומה גם שלא לקטו רק איש לפי אכלו, וא"כ מה שהותירו החסירו משיעור אכילתם של אותו היום, והיו מענים את נפשם על לא דבר, ואף אם הי' כל כוונתם רק למרוד במשרע"ה, מ"מ בודאי הי"ל איזה חשבון והתחכמות, וזה דבר שאין לו הבנה כלל.
translation: 5) It is not understood what the intention of those who left over is, and if it is due to a lack of faith that they fear for their souls that they will not have to eat tomorrow, there is no greater folly than this, for they have already seen with their own eyes the greatness of the miracle that bread came down for them from the heavens. And the Holy One, Blessed be He, promised them that they would gather a portion each day, so how could they still worry about the worry of tomorrow? Moreover, they did not gather except for each person according to his eating, and thus what they left over diminished their portion for that day, and they were afflicting their souls for no reason. Even if their entire intention was only to rebel against Moshe Rabbeinu, nevertheless, they certainly should have had some calculation and cleverness, and this is something that has no understanding at all.
summary: The passage critiques the lack of faith exhibited by those who left over manna, questioning their understanding of God's provision. It emphasizes that witnessing the miraculous descent of heavenly bread should have assured them of God's promise for daily sustenance. The act of hoarding not only undermined their trust but also deprived them of the blessings intended for that day, highlighting a fundamental disconnect between their actions and the divine assurance they had received. Ultimately, it reflects on the importance of faith and reliance on God's continuous support.

passage_content: ו)בני ישראל ויאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא כי לא ידעו מה הוא ויאמר משה אליהם הוא הלחם אשר נתן ה' לכם לאכלה, ואחר שא"ל משרע"המצות השבת, כתיב וישבתו העם ביום השביעי, ויקראו בית ישראל את שמו מן, ולכאורה הרי כבר הזכיר לעיל ויאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא וגו', ומדוע חזר כאן לומר ויקראו בית ישראל את שמו מן, גם צ"ב טעם שינוי הלשונות דלעיל הזכיר ויראו "בני ישראל" ויאמרו איש אל אחיו וגו', וכאן ויקראו בית ישראל.
translation: And the children of Israel said to one another, "What is it?" for they did not know what it was. And Moses said to them, "It is the bread that the Lord has given you to eat." And after Moses told them about the commandments of the Sabbath, it is written, "And the people rested on the seventh day," and the house of Israel called its name "Manna." And seemingly, it has already been mentioned above, "And the children of Israel said to one another, 'What is it?'" So why does it repeat here, "And the house of Israel called its name 'Manna'?" Additionally, it is puzzling why there is a change in language; above it mentioned "And the children of Israel saw" and "And they said to one another," while here it says, "And the house of Israel called."
summary: In this passage, the Israelites question the nature of the manna, expressing uncertainty about its essence, to which Moses responds that it is the bread provided by God. The repetition of the term "מן" highlights the transformative understanding of the divine sustenance, as the people move from confusion to recognition. The shift in language from "בני ישראל" to "בית ישראל" signifies a deeper communal identity and connection to the divine gift, emphasizing the importance of collective faith and the sanctity of the Sabbath. This reflects key Hasidic themes of divine providence and the communal experience of spiritual revelation.

passage_content: ז)איתא ויראו בני ישראל ויאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא, דורשי רשימות אמרו ישראל קראו שמו מן, שנאמר הוא הלחם אשר נתן ה' לכם לאכלה, ולהלן עה"פ ויקראו בית ישראל את שמו מן, אמרו במכילתא דורשי רשימות אמרו בני ישראל קראו את שמו מן ע"כ, ושניהם צ"ב דמה הוסיפו על המפורש בקרא ומה צורך לדורשי רשימות, אחרי שמפורש בכתוב ויקראו בית ישראל את שמו מן, (עיין בישמח משה שביאר בזה עפ"י דרכו)
translation: 7) It is stated, "And the children of Israel saw and said to one another, 'What is it?'" The interpreters of the texts say that Israel called its name "Manna," as it is said, "This is the bread that the Lord has given you to eat." And further on, regarding the verse "And the house of Israel called its name Manna," it is said in the Mechilta that the interpreters of the texts said that the children of Israel called its name Manna. Therefore, both are puzzling: what did they add to what is explicitly stated in the verse, and what is the need for the interpreters of the texts, after it is explicitly written, "And the house of Israel called its name Manna"? (See in Yismach Moshe, who explained this according to his way.)
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of the name "מן" (manna) as given by the Israelites, highlighting the deeper spiritual meaning behind their inquiry. The reference to "דורשי רשימות" (those who seek deeper meanings) suggests that the name carries layers of understanding beyond its literal interpretation, emphasizing the divine provision of sustenance. The text reflects on the relationship between the physical and spiritual realms, illustrating how the Israelites' experience of receiving manna serves as a metaphor for God's ongoing care and nourishment. This insight invites contemplation on the nature of divine gifts and the importance of recognizing their spiritual implications.

passage_content: ולבארהענין נקדים מ"ש בספה"ק תפארת שלמה לפרש הפסוק ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו וגו' וזלה"ק, הנה בספר יהושע (כ"ד) כתיב ואת עצמות יוסף אשר העלו בנ"י ממצרים קברו בשכם, בגמ' (סוטה דף י"ג ע"ב) הקשו קראי אהדדי דהא כתיב ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו, והכא כתיב אשר העלו בני ישראל וכו', הנ"ל לרמז בזה כוונת יוסף לתועלת בני ישראל, שע"י כח קדושת עצמותיו של יוסף הצדיק שנשארו עמהם במצרים, הנה זה שזכו בנ"י לגאולה, כי זהו בחינת יוסף שנקרא גואל כיל"ח, ובזכות עצמותיו נגאלו, (וכעין זה מצינו בזוהר (פ' ויחי דף רכ"ב) אמר הקב"ה אי יוסף אסתלק מהכא גלותא לא אתקיים עיי"ש). וז"ש פקוד יפקוד אלקים אתכם. פי' הפקידה מהגאולה אשר יפקוד אתכם יהי' ע"י עצמותי וזה והעליתם את עצמותי מזה אתכם, שהם יסבבו את הגאולה לכם ולהעלות אתכם להשפיע לכם כל טוב לעולם, כי כן הוא גדול כח קדושת הבלא דגרמי של הצדיקים, אף לאחר פטירתם הם משפיעים כל טוב לבני ישראל ושפתותיהם דובבות בקבר, וז"ש חכז"ל קנה שם טוב קנה לעצמו קנה לו דברי תורה קנ"ה גימטריא יוסף עה"כ לרמז ע"י קדושת יסוד יוסף קנה לעצמו, פי' שגם עצמותיו משפיעים כ"ט והוא קנה לו ד"ת שנעשה כמעיין המתגבר, ועד"ז הוא שאמרו חכז"ל צדיק זכיותיו חקוקים על עצמותיו וכן להיפך, כי ענין עצמות רומז לבחי' יסוד לכן אמרו מי שלא נשא אשה מבן עשרים שנה ולמעלה תיפח עצמותיו, אבל בהתיקון כתיב עצמותיך יחליץ, הנה לכך כתיב ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו, כי משה רבינו ע"ה הי' יודע את כל אשר נעשה בשביל העצמות האלה שגרם להם הגאולה כמ"ש כי השבע השביע את בנ"י, לשון שבועה להשפיעם כל טוב לכן לקחם עמו בכל המסעות של בני ישראל כנ"ל, ומה שנאמר בספר יהושע ואת עצמות יוסף אשר העלו בני ישראל, הכי פירושו שהם העלו בנ"י ממצרים, כי בזכותם נגאלו כנ"ל, וכן הגאולה העתידה במהרה בימינו יהי' ג"כ ע"י הצדיק יסוד עולם וכו' עכלה"ק לענינינו
translation: To clarify the matter, we will begin with what is stated in the holy book Tiferet Shlomo regarding the verse "And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him," and thus it is written: In the Book of Joshua (24), it is written, "And the bones of Joseph, which the children of Israel brought up from Egypt, they buried in Shechem." The Gemara (Sotah 13b) asks a question on this, for it is written that "Moses took the bones of Joseph with him," and here it is written "which the children of Israel brought up," etc. The above hints at Joseph's intention for the benefit of the children of Israel, that through the sanctity of the bones of Joseph the righteous, which remained with them in Egypt, the children of Israel merited redemption. This is the aspect of Joseph, who is called a redeemer, as is known, and by the merit of his bones they were redeemed (and similarly, we find in the Zohar [Parashat Vayechi 212] that the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "If Joseph were to be removed from here, the exile would not be sustained," see there). Therefore, it is said, "God will surely remember you." The meaning of the remembrance from the redemption that He will remember you will be through my bones, and this is "and you shall bring up my bones from here with you," for they will cause the redemption for you and elevate you to bestow upon you all good forever, for indeed, the power of the sanctity of the bones of the righteous is great; even after their passing, they bestow all good upon the children of Israel, and their lips speak in the grave. This is what our sages of blessed memory said: "One who acquires a good name acquires for himself," and "one who acquires Torah acquires for himself," the numerical value of 95 corresponds to Joseph, as a hint that through the sanctity of the foundation of Joseph, he acquired for himself, meaning that even his bones bestow blessings, and he acquired for himself words of Torah, becoming like a wellspring that overflows. Similarly, our sages of blessed memory said, "A righteous person, his merits are engraved on his bones," and vice versa, for the matter of bones hints at the aspect of foundation. Therefore, they said, "Whoever does not marry a woman from the age of twenty and above, may his bones be crushed," but in the rectification, it is written, "Your bones shall be refreshed." Hence, it is written, "And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him," for Moses our teacher, peace be upon him, knew all that was done for these bones that caused them the redemption, as it is said, "For he made the children of Israel swear," a language of an oath to bestow upon them all good. Therefore, he took them with him on all the journeys of the children of Israel, as mentioned above. And what is said in the Book of Joshua, "And the bones of Joseph which the children of Israel brought up," means that they brought them up from Egypt, for by their merit they were redeemed, as mentioned above. Likewise, the future redemption, speedily in our days, will also be through the righteous, the foundation of the world, etc. Thus concludes the holy words regarding our matter.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph's bones in the context of the Jewish people's redemption from Egypt, emphasizing that the holiness of Joseph's remains played a crucial role in their liberation. It highlights the idea that the righteous, even after death, continue to influence and bring goodness to the world, as their spiritual essence remains active. The text connects Joseph's legacy to the future redemption, suggesting that the merit of the righteous will again facilitate salvation. Ultimately, it underscores the enduring power of the tzaddikim (righteous individuals) and their connection to the Jewish people's spiritual journey.

passage_content: ועד"זאפשר לרמוז במאמה"כ ויאר את הלילה ולא קרב זה אל זה כל הלילה, דהנה המצריים היו שטופים בזימה וקליפת מצרים הוא זימה, ובדרך זה רצו להתגבר על ישראל להכניס בלבם מחשבות זימה והרהורים רעים ולהביאם עי"ז לידי טומאה ר"ל, כמ"ש רז"ל (כתובות דף מ"ו ע"א) ונשמרת מכל דבר רע, שלא יהרהר אדם ביום ויבוא לידי טומאה בלילה, ובכוונה זו רדפו אחרי ישראל להשיגם ולהתגבר עליהם להחטיאם ר"ל, אלא שהציל הקב"ה את ישראל מידם, והבדיל הקב"ה בינם ובין ישראל ע"י מסך העננים, ולא יכלו להתקרב אל בני ישראל כלל, וז"פ ויאר את הלילה שהאיר להם הקב"ה את הלילה, שלא נכשל אף א' מישראל בהרהור או בחטא ח"ו, ולא קרב זה אל זה כל הלילה, שקליפת מצרים לא נתקרב לשום א' מישראל, שאם חוטאים ר"ל בחטא זה מוסיפים כח בסט"א ונעשים דבוקים להם ממש, אבל ישראל בקרי"ס הובדלו מהם ולא קרב זה אל זה כל הלילה, ונשארו כולם קדושים וטהורים שלא נכשל שום א' מישראל בחטא זה, וע"כ נשאר כח זה נצחי לדורות, והקריאה מעורר הזמן, שבאלו פרשיות של ימי השובבים שקורין בתורה יציאת מצרים וקרי"ס ומלחמת עמלק, המה מסוגלים לתקון חטא הידוע, ובכח זה ינצחו ישראל שרו של עמלק הוא הס"מ ומלחמה זו ישנו בכל דור ודור עד דורו של משיח כאמרז"ל.
translation: And similarly, it is possible to hint in the verse, "And He illuminated the night, and they did not come near one another all night." Behold, the Egyptians were immersed in immorality, and the Klipah of Egypt is immorality. In this way, they sought to overpower Israel by instilling in their hearts thoughts of immorality and evil reflections, thereby bringing them to a state of impurity, G-d forbid, as our Sages have said (Kethubot 46a), "And you shall guard yourself from any evil thing," that a person should not reflect during the day and come to impurity at night. With this intention, they pursued Israel to catch up with them and overpower them to cause them to sin, G-d forbid. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, saved Israel from their hands and separated between them and Israel through the screen of clouds, and they could not come near the Children of Israel at all. And this is the meaning of "And He illuminated the night," that the Holy One, blessed be He, illuminated the night for them, so that not a single one of Israel stumbled in thought or sin, Heaven forbid, and "they did not come near one another all night," for the Klipah of Egypt did not come near any one of Israel. For if they were to sin, G-d forbid, in this sin, they would strengthen the forces of evil and become truly attached to them. But Israel, through the merit of the Torah, were separated from them, and they did not come near one another all night, and all remained holy and pure, with not a single one of Israel stumbling in this sin. Therefore, this power remains eternal for generations, and the reading awakens the time, for in these sections of the days of Shovavim, which are read in the Torah— the Exodus from Egypt, the reading of the Torah, and the war with Amalek— they are capable of rectifying the known sin. And with this power, Israel will overcome the minister of Amalek, who is the Sitra Achra, and this war exists in every generation until the generation of the Messiah, as our Sages have said.
summary: The passage discusses the divine protection granted to the Israelites during their time in Egypt, emphasizing that God illuminated the night to prevent any Israelite from succumbing to sinful thoughts or actions. The separation between the Egyptians, who were steeped in immorality, and the Israelites was maintained by a divine barrier, ensuring that the forces of impurity could not influence them. This sanctity preserved by God is seen as a lasting strength for future generations, particularly during the readings of the Torah that recount the Exodus and the battles against Amalek, which are believed to have the power to rectify known sins and empower Israel in their ongoing spiritual struggles.

passage_content: והנהדרשו רז"ל במכילתא פקד יפקד אלקים אתכם פקד אתכם במצרים, יפקוד אתכם בים סוף פקד אתכם במדבר, יפקוד אתכם על נחלי ארנון, פקד אתכם בעוה"ז יפקוד אתכם לעוה"ב, הרי שרמז יוסף הצדיק בשבועתו על כל הדורות עד ימות המשיח, ועד"ז ירמוז והעליתם את עצמותי מזה אתכם על כל הדורות, שיאחזו בעצמות קדושת יוסף תקון היסוד, ועי"ז תעלו מן הגלות עמו ותזכו לגאולה, ובס' זכרון למרן הח"ס זלה"ה הובא מכתי"ק שהיה שעת חירום ומלחמה וסכנה גדולה לישראל ר"ל, ואמר בדרשתו שהשמירה מחטא זה סגולה להנצל מחצי האויב, שג"ז נקרא בלשון חץ בדברי רז"ל יורה כחץ וכתיב כחצים ביד גבור כן בני הנעורים, וע"כ מדה כנגד מדה יש בו סגולת הצלה מחצי המלחמה עייש"ד באריכות, ובעוה"ר גם עכשיו צריכים אנו לרחמי שמים להנצל מחבלי משיח. שלא יטרפו זאבי טרף את השה, ע"כ נראה לתקן כ"א פגמי נפשו ושלא לפגום עוד ובזכות זה נינצל ונזכה לישועה שלימה במהרה.
translation: And the sages have interpreted in the Mechilta: "God will surely visit you," He visited you in Egypt, "He will visit you at the Sea of Suf," He visited you in the desert, "He will visit you by the rivers of Arnon," He visited you in this world, "He will visit you in the World to Come." Behold, Joseph the righteous hinted in his oath to all generations until the days of the Messiah, and similarly, it hints, "And you shall carry up my bones from here with you" for all generations, that they will hold onto the bones of the holiness of Joseph, the rectification of the foundation, and through this, you will rise from the exile with him and merit redemption. And in the book of remembrance for our master the Chasam Sofer, may his merit protect us, it was brought from his handwritten notes that there was a time of emergency and war and great danger for Israel, may God save us, and he said in his sermon that the protection from this sin is a remedy to be saved from the enemy's arrows, which is also called in the language of arrows in the words of our sages, "He shoots like an arrow," and it is written, "Like arrows in the hand of a mighty man, so are the children of youth." Therefore, measure for measure, there is in it a remedy for salvation from the arrows of war, as explained at length. And in our times, even now we need the mercy of Heaven to be saved from the birth pangs of the Messiah, that the wolves do not tear the lamb. Therefore, it seems fitting to rectify each one's soul blemishes and not to blemish further, and in the merit of this, we will be saved and merit complete salvation speedily.
summary: The passage emphasizes the continuity of divine providence throughout Jewish history, as reflected in the repeated assurances of redemption from Egypt, the Sea of Reeds, and the wilderness, culminating in the promise of future salvation. It highlights the significance of Joseph's bones as a symbol of spiritual rectification and the foundation for redemption, linking the past to the Messianic future. The text also underscores the importance of moral vigilance and repentance as a means to protect against spiritual and physical dangers, particularly in times of crisis, invoking the idea that righteous actions can lead to divine mercy and ultimate salvation.

passage_content: ונחזורלבאר הכתוב כל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים לא אשים עליך כי אני ד' רפאך והדקדוקים הנ"ל (קושיא ג') בהקדם לפרש הפסוק (תהלים מ"א) אני אמרתי ד' חנני רפאה נפשי כי חטאתי לך, ולכאורה מה נתינת טעם הוא זה, וכי בשביל שחטא ינתן לו הרפואה, אמנם ידוע כי העון הוא חולת הנפש, וזהו שורש וסיבת כל חולי הגוף ר"ל, אלא שהבוי"ת מאריך אף ואינו מביא היסורים מיד, אולי ישוב האדם ויתקן פגמי נפשו ושב ורפא לו, וצריך האדםלהקדים תפלה לצרה שיזכה לתקן פגמי נפשו ויתרפא מחולי הנפש ואז לא יבואו עליו חולי הגוף כלל, וכמ"ש רז"ל שבת (ל"ב ע"א) לעולם יבקש אדם רחמים שלא יחלה, שאם יחלה אומרים לו הבא זכות והפטר, ועד"ז ביקש דוהמע"ה ד' חנני רפאה נפשי כי חטאתי לך, שירפאהו ד' מחולי הנפש הנגרם בסיבת החטא ולא יגיעו אליו חולי הגוף כלל, הנה המצריים לא נתרפאו מחטאם כי לא עשו תשובה, ע"כ הביא הקב"ה מכות ונטרדו מעוה"ז ועוה"ב, והבטיח הקב"ה לישראל אם שמוע תשמע לקול ד' אלקיך והאזנת למצותיו ושמרת כל חקיו וגו', אף שאין אדם צדיק בארץ אשר יעשה טוב ולא יחטא, אבל ירפאם ד' מחולי הנפש ע"י התשובה, ולא יבואו עליהם חולי הגוף להשחיתם ח"ו, וז"ש כל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים לא אשים עליך כי אני ד' רפאיך מחולי הנפש, ולא יגיעו עליך חולי הגוף כלל.
translation: And let us return to explain the verse: "All the sickness that I placed upon Egypt I will not place upon you, for I am the Lord your Healer." The aforementioned nuances (question 3) prompt us to interpret the verse (Psalms 41): "I said, 'O Lord, be gracious to me; heal my soul, for I have sinned against You.'" At first glance, what kind of reasoning is this? Is it because he has sinned that he is granted healing? However, it is known that sin is a sickness of the soul, and this is the root and cause of all bodily ailments, so to speak. Yet, the Blessed One prolongs His mercy and does not bring suffering immediately; perhaps the person will repent and rectify the flaws of his soul, and he will return and be healed. A person must precede prayer to avert trouble, so that he merits to rectify the flaws of his soul and be healed from the sickness of the soul, and then bodily ailments will not come upon him at all. As our sages of blessed memory said in Shabbat (32a): "A person should always seek mercy that he should not fall ill, for if he falls ill, they tell him to bring merit and be released." In a similar vein, David the King, peace be upon him, requested: "O Lord, be gracious to me; heal my soul, for I have sinned against You," that the Lord should heal him from the sickness of the soul caused by sin, and that bodily ailments should not come upon him at all. Behold, the Egyptians were not healed from their sin because they did not repent. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, brought plagues upon them, and they were troubled in this world and the next. And the Holy One, blessed be He, promised Israel: "If you will listen diligently to the voice of the Lord your God and will pay attention to His commandments and keep all His statutes," etc., even though there is no righteous person on earth who does good and does not sin, the Lord will heal them from the sickness of the soul through repentance, and bodily ailments will not come upon them to destroy them, God forbid. This is the meaning of "All the sickness that I placed upon Egypt I will not place upon you, for I am the Lord your Healer from the sickness of the soul, and bodily ailments will not come upon you at all."
summary: The passage emphasizes the connection between spiritual health and physical well-being, asserting that sin is the root cause of spiritual ailments, which in turn lead to physical illness. It highlights the importance of repentance and prayer as means to heal the soul, thereby preventing bodily afflictions. The text contrasts the fate of the Egyptians, who did not repent and suffered consequences, with the promise to Israel that through obedience and repentance, God will heal their spiritual wounds and spare them from physical suffering. Ultimately, it conveys the assurance that God is the healer of the soul, and through sincere repentance, one can attain both spiritual and physical health.

passage_content: ולבארהפסוקים בפ' המן נקדים מ"ש האוהחה"ק עה"פ ויאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא כי לא ידעו מה הוא, ואולי כי בראותם אותו הזמין ד' לפיהם, במקום שיאמרו מה הוא אמרו מן הוא, וזה שמו אשר קבע לו ד' ושם שמו בפי ישראל וכו', ואולי כי מזה נתחכמו בנ"י וקראו את שמו מן, דכתיב ויקראו בית ישראל שמו מן. שהשכילו בתיבת מן שאינה מן הרגיל בנדבר, ואין זה אלא רוח ד' דיבר ומלתו על לשונם כי זה שמו עכלה"ק, ובספה"ק אגרא דכלה כתב שמעתי מפה קדוש כבוד אדמו"ר הנ"ל זצוק"ל שהי' המן דק ובהיר כ"כ ברוחניות, עד שע"י אכילתו נזדכך הגוף, והי' ניכר לכ"א פנימיות חבירו ומחשבתו, והנה איש אשר הי' מכיר את חבירו ביום אתמול בלא הודע פנימיותיו וחשבו לצדיק או בהיפך, וכהיום שאכלו את המן נתוודע לו פנימיותו ולא הכירו, כי נדמה בעיניו לאיש אחר, וזה ויאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא, ר"ל מי הוא זה כי נהפך לאיש אחר עכ"ל, ובאמת כ"כ הרמב"ן ז"ל כי המן מתולדות אור העליון, ומעת שהשיגו ישראל לזיו השכינה בים, כמ"ש ראתה שפחה על הים מה שלא ראה יחזקאל הנביא, מאותה שעה נתעלית נפשם להתקיים בתולדותיו שהוא המן עכ"ד ז"ל, ובזה מובנים דברי האגרא דכלה מ"ש בשם רבו זלה"ה, דמפני שהי' המן מתולדות אור העליון, ע"כ נזדכך הגוף ע"י אכילתו והי' ניכר לכ"א פנימיות חבירו ומחשבתו.
translation: To explain the verses in Parashat HaMan, we will first mention what the holy Baal Shem Tov said regarding the verse "And they said to one another, 'What is it?' for they did not know what it was." Perhaps, when they saw it, God prepared their mouths, in a place where they would say "What is it?" they said "It is manna." This is the name that God established for it, and its name is in the mouths of Israel, etc. Perhaps from this, the Jewish people became wise and called it "manna," as it is written, "And the house of Israel called its name 'manna.'" They understood the word "manna," which is not a common term in conversation, and this is nothing but the spirit of God speaking and His word upon their tongues, for this is its name, as the holy books say. I heard from the holy mouth of the honored Rebbe, may his memory be blessed, that the manna was fine and so luminous in spirituality that by eating it, the body was refined, and it was evident to everyone the inner thoughts of his friend. A person who recognized his friend yesterday without knowing his inner thoughts and considered him righteous or the opposite, on the day they ate the manna, his inner self was revealed to him, and he did not recognize him, for he appeared to him as another person. This is what is meant by "And they said to one another, 'What is it?'" meaning who is this, for he has turned into another person. Indeed, this is what Ramban, may his memory be blessed, said, that the manna is a product of the upper light, and from the moment the Israelites attained the radiance of the Shechinah at the sea, as it is said, "A maidservant saw at the sea what Ezekiel the prophet did not see," from that hour their souls were elevated to exist in its products, which is the manna. Thus, the words of the holy Agra D'Kallah are understood, as he said in the name of his teacher, may his memory be blessed, that because the manna was a product of the upper light, therefore the body was refined by eating it, and it was evident to everyone the inner thoughts of his friend.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of the manna (מן) as a divine sustenance that revealed the inner essence of individuals, allowing them to perceive each other's true thoughts and spiritual states. It emphasizes that the manna, being a product of the upper light, had the power to purify the body and elevate the soul, leading to a profound spiritual awareness among the Israelites. The text also highlights the significance of the name "מן," which reflects a deeper understanding of its spiritual origins and the transformative experience it provided to those who consumed it. Ultimately, the manna served as a means for the Israelites to connect with the divine and recognize their own spiritual identities.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דברי המכילתא עה"פ ויראו בני ישראל ויאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא, דורשי רשימות אמרו ישראל קראו את שמו מן, שנאמר הוא הלחם אשר נתן ד' לאכלה, דלפי"ד האגרא דכלה זלה"ה יתפרש במשמעות הלשון ויאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא, דמלת מן הוא מוסב על אחיו, וא"כ מניין לנו ילפותא שישראל קראו את הלחם מן, וע"כ פירשו דורשי רשימות ישראל קראו את שמו מן, והביאו ראי'ממה שהשיב להם משה רבינו על אמרם ויאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא וגו' ויאמר משה אלהם הוא הלחם אשר נתן ד' לכם לאכלה, ר"ל שהשגת הדעת אשר זכו אליה להכיר כ"א פנימיות חבירו עד שאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא, הוא הלחם אשר נתן ד' לכם לאכלה, וזה הגורם, ומזה השכילו בני ישראל לקרוא שם הלחם מן וע"ד שכתב האוהחה"ק כי בראותם שהזמין ד' לפיהם תיבת מן שאינה מן הרגיל בנדבר, השכילו שאין זה אלא רוח ד' דיבר על לשונם, וזה שמו אשר קבע לו ד' ושם אותו בפי ישראל
translation: And in this, the words of the Mechilta are clarified on the verse "And the children of Israel saw and said to one another, 'What is it?'" The interpreters of the verses said that Israel called its name "Manna," as it is said, "It is the bread that the Lord has given you to eat." According to the explanation of the Agra D'Kallah, it will be understood in the meaning of the language, "And they said to one another, 'What is it?'" that the word "What is it?" is connected to "one another." And if so, from where do we have a teaching that Israel called the bread "Manna"? Therefore, the interpreters of the verses explained that Israel called its name "Manna," and they brought proof from what our teacher Moses replied to them when they said, "And they said to one another, 'What is it?'" And Moses said to them, "It is the bread that the Lord has given you to eat," meaning that the understanding that they merited to recognize each one's inner essence was such that they said to one another, "What is it? It is the bread that the Lord has given you to eat." This is the cause, and from this, the children of Israel understood to call the name of the bread "Manna." And as the holy author wrote, when they saw that the Lord had prepared for them the word "Manna," which is not usual in speech, they understood that this is nothing but the spirit of the Lord speaking through their tongue, and this is the name that the Lord established for it and placed it in the mouth of Israel.
summary: In this passage, the author explores the significance of the term "מן" (manna) as understood by the Israelites, who recognized it as a divine provision from God. The connection between the term and the communal experience of the Israelites highlights their spiritual insight into the nature of their sustenance, which was not merely physical but also a reflection of their inner unity and connection to the divine. The passage emphasizes that their ability to perceive the spiritual essence of the manna was a result of divine inspiration, illustrating the profound relationship between God and His people. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that true understanding comes from recognizing the spiritual dimensions of their experiences.

passage_content: והנהבני ישראל מורה על בני עלי', ובית ישראל על פחותי הערך כמ"ש ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה בהפטורת וארא עיי"ש, ואפשר שירמוז בית ישראל על הנשים ע"ד שדרשו רז"ל בית יעקב אלו הנשים, ובזה יתבאר שינוי הלשונות שבפסוקי הפרשה דבני עלי' שבישראל מיד ביום הראשון באכלם מהמן, זכו להזדככות נפלאה והשיגו שרשו בגבהי מרומים וקראו את שמו מן ע"ש בחינתו הרוממה, וז"ש ויראו "בני ישראל" ויאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא וגו', אבל בית ישראל שהם פחותי הערך והנשים לא באו להשגה זו מיד, כי השגת הדעת תליא באיכות בחי' הנפש והכנת המעשים כנודע, והשגת פנימיות התורה לא נמסרה לנשים, וכמו שפי' בספה"ק בני יששכר עה"פ כה תאמר לבית יעקב ודרשו רז"ל אלו הנשים, ותגד לבני ישראל אלו האנשים, כי מלת ותגיד מורה על אמירה דחכמתא, וזהו לבני ישראל דייקא ולא לנשים, אמנם אף שזכו ישראל להזדככות הגוף והנפש ע"י אכילת המן כנ"ל, מ"מ אינו דומה אכילתו בימות החול ליום השבת, דע"י קדושת השבת זכו על ידו להזדככות בבחי' גבוה יותר, כמבואר בספה"ק דע"י סעודות השבת זוכים להשפעת הדעת, וע"כ אחר שעבר עליהם השבת כמ"ש וישבתו העם ביום השביעי, חזר לומר ויקראו בית ישראל את שמו מן, שגם בית ישראל הם פחותי הערך והנשים זכו להזדככות נפלאה וקראו את שמו מן ע"ש בחינתו הרוממה, אמנם עדיין יש מקום לטעות שמה שבית ישראל קראו את שמו מן, הי' ע"ש המאורע ומפני שאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא ע"כ קראו שם הלחם מן, שכן הי' דרכם לקרות שמות ע"ש המאורע, וא"כ אין ראי' שזכו להזדככות ע"י המן וע"י השבת, וכדי שלא לטעות בזה ע"כ אמרו במכילתא כאן דורשי רשימות אמרו בני ישראל קראו את שמו מן, דבני ישראל היינו בני עלי' והם ודאי זכו להזדככות והשגה גדולה וע"ש כך קראו שמו מן, וכמו"כ על בחי' זה אמר הכתוב ויקראו בית ישראל את שמו מן, שגם הם נזדככו ע"י אכילתו וקדושת השבת והשיגו שרשו בגבהי מרומים, וע"ש כך קראו את שמו מן.
translation: And behold, the Children of Israel refer to the Sons of Eli, and the House of Israel to those of lesser value, as it is written, "Moses rejoiced greatly" in the Haftorah of Va'era, see there. It is possible that the House of Israel hints at the women, as our Sages have interpreted, "The House of Jacob, these are the women." And thus, the difference in language in the verses of the portion is explained: the Sons of Eli among Israel immediately on the first day, when they ate from the manna, merited a wonderful refinement and attained their root in the heights above, and they called its name "manna" in accordance with its elevated quality. Therefore it is said, "And the Children of Israel saw," and they said to one another, "What is it?" But the House of Israel, who are of lesser value and the women, did not attain this understanding immediately, for the attainment of knowledge depends on the quality of the soul's aspect and the preparation of deeds, as is known. The inner understanding of the Torah was not given to women, as explained in the holy book of Bnei Yissachar on the verse, "So shall you say to the House of Jacob," and our Sages have interpreted, "These are the women," and "And tell the Children of Israel," these are the men, for the word "and tell" indicates a teaching of wisdom, and this is specifically to the Children of Israel and not to the women. However, although Israel merited the refinement of body and soul through the eating of the manna, nevertheless, the eating during the weekdays is not comparable to that of the Sabbath, for through the sanctity of the Sabbath they merited a higher level of refinement, as explained in the holy book that through the Sabbath meals they attain the influence of knowledge. Therefore, after the Sabbath had passed over them, as it is written, "And the people rested on the seventh day," it returned to say, "And the House of Israel called its name 'manna'," for even the House of Israel, who are of lesser value, and the women, merited a wonderful refinement and called its name "manna" in accordance with its elevated quality. However, there is still room for error that the reason the House of Israel called its name "manna" was due to the event, and because they said to one another, "What is it?" therefore they named the bread "manna," for it was their way to name things after events. If so, there is no proof that they merited refinement through the manna and through the Sabbath. And in order not to err in this, it is therefore stated in the Mekilta here, "The interpreters of the verses said, the Children of Israel called its name 'manna'," that the Children of Israel, meaning the Sons of Eli, certainly merited refinement and a great understanding, and therefore they called its name "manna." Likewise, regarding this aspect, the verse states, "And the House of Israel called its name 'manna'," for they too were refined through its eating and the sanctity of the Sabbath and attained their root in the heights above, and therefore they called its name "manna."
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between "Bnei Yisrael" (the men) and "Beit Yisrael" (the women) in their spiritual elevation through the consumption of manna. It emphasizes that while the men achieved a higher level of spiritual refinement and understanding, the women, though considered of lesser status, also attained a remarkable level of sanctification through the manna and the holiness of Shabbat. The text highlights that the spiritual insights and inner teachings of the Torah were not fully accessible to women, yet they still experienced a significant elevation. Ultimately, both groups, despite their differences, recognized the divine nature of the manna, reflecting their respective spiritual journeys.

passage_content: והנהדתן ואבירם במה שהותירו מן המן הי' כל כוונתם ומחשבתם רק לחלוק על משה רבינו ולהרוס חומת הדת והקדושה ולז"א הכתוב ולא שמעו אל משה ויותירו וגו', שזה הי' תוכן כוונתם לעשות היפך דברי משה רבינו. אמנם בדור דיעה כדור המדבר לא יכלו לגלות רשעתם כי זהו כוונתם, דאלמלי כן לא היו ישראל שומעים להם וכוונתם הי' להמשיך גם את ישראל לרעתם כמו שעשו במחלוקת קרח, ע"כ הלבישו כל מעשיהם בלבוש של צדקות ובכוונה לש"ש, ואף כאן במה שהותירו מהמן אולי באו בטענת הסתה לש"ש, שלחביבות קדושתו מותירים ממנו מיומולחבירו, ומה גם ע"ד שכתב האוהחה"ק כי מצו' זו משה מעצמו דן אותה. להיות שראה כי ד' נותן להם דבר יום ביומו זה יגיד כי אין יום מכין לחבירו והבין דבר מתוך דבר ואסר להם עכ"ד, ומאחר שלא נאסר מפי הגבורה, ע"כ מלאו לבם לחלוק בסברא על דעתו של משרע"ה ואמרו דחביבות מצוה עדיפא, ועד"ז רצו להמשיך גם אחרים לדעתם, אמנם יראו לנפשותם כי המן בעצמו יגלה מצפוני לבביהם ומחשבתם הרשעה, כמ"ש בספה"ק אגרא דכלה שנזדכך הגוף ע"י אכילתו והי' ניכר לכ"א פנימיות חבירו ומחשבתו לכן התחכמו ברשעתם והתענו נפשותם ולא אכלו ממנו ביומו, כ"א הותירו אותו ליום המחרת ואכלוהו שלא כמצותו, ויתכן כי כח סגולה זו שנזדכך הגוף ע"י אכילתו, לא ניתן כ"א להנאכל ביומו כמצותו, ולזה התחכמו דתן ואבירם ויותירו מן המן ולא אכלוהו ביומו, כדי להסתיר פנימיות מחשבותיהם ויוכלו להטעות את ישראל לרעתם.
translation: And their intention, as well as that of Dathan and Abiram, in what they left over from the manna, was solely to oppose Moshe Rabbeinu and to destroy the wall of religion and holiness. This is what the verse means when it says, "And they did not listen to Moshe, and they left over, etc." This was the essence of their intention to do the opposite of the words of Moshe Rabbeinu. However, in the generation of knowledge, like the generation of the desert, they could not reveal their wickedness, for that was their intention. Had it been otherwise, the Israelites would not have listened to them, and their intention was to lead the Israelites to their detriment, as they did in the dispute of Korach. Therefore, they cloaked all their actions in the garb of righteousness and with the intention of doing it for the sake of Heaven. Even here, in what they left over from the manna, perhaps they came with the argument of a provocation for the sake of Heaven, that out of love for His holiness, they leave over from it from one day to another. Moreover, according to what the holy author wrote, this commandment Moshe himself judged, for he saw that Hashem gives them a thing day by day, which indicates that no day prepares for another, and he understood one thing from another and forbade them. And since it was not forbidden from the mouth of the Almighty, their hearts were filled to argue with reasoning against the opinion of Moshe Rabbeinu, and they said that the love of the commandment is preferable. In this way, they also wanted to lead others to their opinion. However, they should be wary for their souls, for the manna itself would reveal the secrets of their hearts and their wicked thoughts, as it is written in the holy books that when the body is refined through its eating, the inner essence of each person and their thoughts would be evident to all. Therefore, they schemed in their wickedness and afflicted their souls and did not eat from it on its day, but rather left it for the next day and ate it not according to its commandment. It is possible that this special power, that the body is refined through its eating, is only given to what is eaten on its day according to its commandment. For this reason, Dathan and Abiram schemed and left over from the manna and did not eat it on its day, in order to conceal the inner thoughts of their hearts and to be able to mislead the Israelites to their detriment.
summary: The passage discusses the intentions of Datan and Aviram, who sought to undermine Moses and the sanctity of the faith by misinterpreting the command regarding the manna. They disguised their rebellion under the guise of piety, believing that by leaving over the manna for the next day, they could conceal their wicked thoughts and lead others astray. The text emphasizes that true adherence to divine commandments reveals one's inner intentions, and by not eating the manna on the designated day, they attempted to mask their insincerity. Ultimately, their actions highlight the struggle between genuine faith and the deceptive nature of rebellion against divine authority.

passage_content: ובזהיתורץ מה שדקדק האוהחה"ק, דלא הי' צ"ל אלא ויותירו וגו' ואני יודע שלא שמעו אל משה,ויתר הדקדוקים (לעיל קושיא ד') ולדרכינו מאמר ולא שמעו אל משה לא קאי על פעולת ויותירו, אלא ולא שמעו אל משה בכל דבריו, וכל מגמתם הי' רק להסיר את ישראל מאחרי משה, ולטעם זה ויותירו וגו', שזה הי' התחכמות שלא יתגלה מזימתם ע"י המן, ומה שקורא אותם הכתוב אנשים שהוא תואר בכ"מ על צדיקים, מפני שהיו מתדמין כן ומראים א"ע בפני ישראל לצדיקים, וזהו טעם ויותירו אנשים, כדי שישארו בחזקת צדיקים ולא יתגלה פנימותם.
translation: And in this, it clarifies what the holy Baal Shem Tov was particular about, that it should only say "and they left over" etc., and I know that they did not listen to Moses, and the rest of the nuances (above, question 2). According to our approach, the statement "and they did not listen to Moses" does not refer to the action of "and they left over," but rather "and they did not listen to Moses" in all his words. Their entire intention was only to remove Israel from behind Moses, and for this reason "and they left over" etc., this was a cunning plan so that their scheme would not be revealed through the manna. And the fact that the scripture calls them "men," which is a title everywhere for the righteous, is because they were pretending to be so and showing themselves before Israel as righteous. This is the reason for "and they left over men," so that they would remain in the status of righteous and their true nature would not be revealed.
summary: The passage discusses the subtlety of the actions of certain individuals who sought to undermine Moses and lead the Israelites astray. It emphasizes that their intent was to conceal their true motives, presenting themselves as righteous figures to maintain the appearance of being "righteous men." The term "ויותירו" (and they left) reflects their cunning strategy to avoid revealing their deceitful nature, highlighting the tension between outward appearances and inner intentions in the context of faith and leadership. This underscores a key Hasidic concept of the importance of sincerity and the dangers of hypocrisy in spiritual life.

passage_content: נחזורלענינינו לבאר קישור הפסוקים שבריש הפרשה ויסב אלקים את העם וגו' וחמשים עלו בנ"י וגו' ודברי רש"י ז"ל (לעיל קושיא א' וב') עפימ"ד במדרש ילקוט ארבע כיתות נעשו ישראל על הים וכו', אחת אומרת נעשה מלחמה כנגדן וכו' נאמר להם ד' ילחם לכם עכ"ד המדרש, והנה זה הי' להם לנסיון גדול שעמדו בסכנה גדולה, והיו מזויינים בחרב וחנית וכלי מלחמה, ואעפ"כ לא עשו שום פעולה בהשתדלות אנושי, כ"א בטחו בישועתו ית' כאשר נצטוו ע"י משה מפי הגבורה, ד' ילחם לכם ואתם תחרישון, ואפשר שלטעם זה לקחו ישראל עמהם כלי זיין בצאתם ממצרים, כאמרז"ל במד"ר (פרשה כ' סי' י"ט) וחמשים עלו בנ"י מאמ"צ, שעלו מזויינים, ובודאי לא עשו דבר מדעתם, אבל כן הי' רצון הבוי"ת כדי להגדיל בחי' הנסיון ולהגדיל מעלתם, וע"ד שכתבו הרמב"ן והראב"ע ז"ל (בפ' וירא) כי ענין הנסיון להראות צדקת המנוסה עיי"ש, ואלמלי לא הי' בידם כלי זיין לא הי' בחי' הנסיון בשלימות, אמנם לא הי' אפשר לסמוך בזה כ"א על הכשרים שבישראל ובני עלי', משא"כ פשוטי העם ופחותי הערך אלמלי מסרו בידם כלי זיין, יש מקום לחשוש שמא לא יעמדו בנסיון וילחמו עם המצריים שלא ברצון הבוי"ת, ולז"א וחמשים עלו "בני ישראל" מארץ מצרים, היינו בני עלי' שנקראו בני ישראל יצאו מזויינים ולא העם, ומקושר גם עם פי' השני שפרש"י חמשים מחומשים, א' מחמשה יצאו וד' חלקים מתו בג' ימי אפילה, דמפני שמתו רשעי ישראל ולא יצאו כ"א הכשרים שנתחזקו באמונתם בהשי"ת, וקבלו עליהם הנסיון של לכתך אחרי במדבר וגו' ע"כ יצאו מזויינים להגדיל בחי' הנסיון ולהראות צדקתם, אבל אלמלי יצאו גם הרשעים עמהם שהיו מרובים פי כמה עליהם, הי' חשש קרוב שיתגברו עליהם להכריחם שילחמו במצרים, ולא הי' מקום שיצאו מזויינים כלל, וב' הפירושים הא בהא תליין.
translation: We will return to our topic to explain the connection of the verses at the beginning of the parasha: "And God turned the people, etc." and "And fifty went up, the children of Israel, etc." and the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed (above, question 1 and 2) according to the Midrash Yalkut: "Four groups were formed by Israel at the sea, etc., one says we will wage war against them, etc. It was said to them, 'The Lord will fight for you,' thus concludes the Midrash. And behold, this was a great test for them, as they stood in great danger, armed with sword, spear, and weapons of war, and nevertheless, they did not take any action through human effort, but rather trusted in His salvation, as they were commanded by Moses from the mouth of the Almighty: 'The Lord will fight for you, and you shall be silent.' It is possible that for this reason the Israelites took weapons with them when they left Egypt, as our sages have said in the Midrash (Parashat 20, section 19): "And fifty went up, the children of Israel from Egypt," that they went up armed. Certainly, they did nothing of their own accord, but this was the will of the Creator to enhance the nature of the test and to elevate their status, in accordance with what the Ramban and the Ra'avad, may their memories be blessed, wrote (in Parashat Vayera) that the purpose of the test is to demonstrate the righteousness of the tested, as stated there. And had they not had weapons, the nature of the test would not have been complete. However, it would only have been possible to rely on the righteous among Israel and the sons of elevation, whereas the simple folk and those of lesser value, had they been given weapons, there would be reason to fear that they would not withstand the test and would fight against the Egyptians against the will of the Creator. Therefore, it is said, "And fifty went up, the children of Israel from the land of Egypt," meaning the sons of elevation who are called the children of Israel went out armed, and not the common people. This is also connected to the second explanation that Rashi interprets: "Fifty from the five hundred," one from five went out, and four parts died in the three days of darkness, for the wicked of Israel died and only the righteous who strengthened themselves in their faith in the Holy One, blessed be He, went out. They accepted upon themselves the test of 'to walk after Me in the wilderness,' etc., therefore they went out armed to enhance the nature of the test and to demonstrate their righteousness. But had the wicked also gone out with them, who were many times more than them, there would have been a close concern that they would overpower them to force them to fight against the Egyptians, and there would have been no place for them to go out armed at all. And both interpretations are interconnected.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites being armed as they left Egypt, emphasizing that their reliance on divine intervention rather than human effort was a crucial test of faith. It highlights that only the righteous, referred to as "Bnei Aliyah," were permitted to carry weapons, ensuring that they would not succumb to the temptation of fighting against the Egyptians without God's will. This divine orchestration of events served to elevate their spiritual status and demonstrate their commitment to following God's command, reinforcing the idea that true faith is tested through trials. Ultimately, the text illustrates the interplay between divine providence and human agency in the context of faith and redemption.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבארו קישור הפסוקים ולא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים כי קרוב הוא, ר"ל לטעם שקרובה עדיין זמן יציאתם מזוהמת מצרים, וע"כ יש לחוש פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה ושבו מצרימה, ר"ל שימשכו לדעתם ושיטתם והו"ל כאילו שבו מצרימה דבמקום שמחשבתו של אדם שם הוא קביעותו כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל בענין ערובין, ופן ילחמו באומות שלא ברצון הבוי"ת ע"כ ויסב אלקים את העם דרך המדבר וגו' בשביל שתהי' התורה נבללת בגופן כדברי המכילתא, וחמשים עלו "בני ישראל" דייקא מארץ מצרים, ולא העם, ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו, היינו קדושת עצמותו שפעל ותיקן במדת היסוד, ובזכות זה נגאלו ישראל ונטהרו מזוהמתם.
translation: And similarly, the connection of the verses is explained: And God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, for it was near, meaning that the time of their departure from the impurity of Egypt was still close. Therefore, there was a concern that the people might regret it upon seeing war and return to Egypt, meaning they would be inclined to their own thoughts and ways, and it would be as if they had returned to Egypt, for where a person's thoughts are, there is his permanence, as the Ramban z"l explains regarding Eruvin. And lest they fight with the nations against the will of the Creator, therefore God turned the people toward the wilderness, etc., so that the Torah would be intertwined with their essence, as stated in the Mechilta. And "the children of Israel" specifically ascended from the land of Egypt, not the people, and Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, meaning the sanctity of his bones which he activated and rectified in the attribute of foundation. And by virtue of this, Israel was redeemed and purified from their impurity.
summary: The passage discusses the divine guidance of the Israelites out of Egypt, emphasizing that God avoided leading them through the land of the Philistines to prevent them from regretting their escape and returning to Egypt due to fear of war. It highlights the importance of maintaining a pure mindset, as one's thoughts shape their spiritual state. The reference to the bones of Joseph symbolizes the sanctity and rectification achieved through the attribute of foundation, which played a crucial role in the Israelites' redemption and purification from their Egyptian contamination.

passage_content: (מכתי"ק)ז"ל ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו כי השבע השביע וגו' ולמה לא השביע בניו שישאוהו מיד וכו' יעיי"ש, וכבר דקדקו קמאי מדוע לא הקשה רש"י זאת (בפ' ויחי) אצל סיפור השבועה הזאת ועי' בישמח משה ז"ל מ"ש ע"ז ואפשר לומר לפענ"ד דהנה אחז"ל בסוטה (דף י"ג) חכם לב יקח מצות (זה משה) ואויל שפתים ילבט (אלו ישראל) שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה ומשה עסק בעצמות יוסף. ובישמח משה פ' בא בפ' וגם ערב רב עלה אתם וגו' כתב יש להפליא כיון שמבואר בתוה"ק שישראל היו עוסקין אז בביזת מצרים שלא ברצונם, רק ע"י ציווי הקב"ה ומשה עבדו כמו שאמרו חכז"ל, א"כ אמאי אמרו עליהם חכז"ל אויל שפתים ילבט שנפנו על כסף וזהב, הלא כתורה עשו וע"י ההכרח, גם צריך להבין אם חכז"ל ראו זה לחסרון מה שנפנו אל כסף וזהב א"כ הי' החסרון במעשה, ולמה דרשו עליהם המקרא דאויל שפתים ילבט דמשמע שהי' החסרון רק בשפתים שלא הוזכר במקרא הזה שום עשי'.
translation: (Mikhtav Yad Kodesh) Blessed be His Name, and Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, for he had made the children of Israel swear, etc. And why did he not make his sons swear to carry him immediately, etc.? See there. And the early ones have already noted why Rashi did not ask this (in Parashat Vayechi) regarding the story of this oath. And see what the Yismach Moshe, blessed be his memory, writes about this. And it can be said, in my humble opinion, that our Sages taught in Sotah (13a) "A wise heart will take commandments" (this refers to Moses) "and a fool of lips will stumble" (this refers to Israel). For all of Israel were engaged in the plunder, while Moses was occupied with the bones of Joseph. And in the Yismach Moshe, in Parashat Bo, regarding "and a mixed multitude went up with them," he wrote that it is astonishing, for it is clear in the Holy Torah that Israel was engaged in the plunder of Egypt against their will, only by the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and Moses served as they said, our Sages of blessed memory. Therefore, why did our Sages say about them "a fool of lips will stumble," that they turned to gold and silver? Did they not act according to the Torah and by necessity? It also needs to be understood if our Sages saw this as a deficiency in that they turned to gold and silver, then the deficiency was in the action. And why did they interpret the verse about them as "a fool of lips will stumble," which implies that the deficiency was only in their lips, as this verse does not mention any action?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses taking Joseph's bones, contrasting his focused commitment to this mitzvah with the Israelites' preoccupation with material wealth during the exodus. It highlights the tension between divine command and human inclination, suggesting that while the Israelites were compelled to engage in the plunder of Egypt, their distraction from spiritual duties reflects a deeper flaw in their intentions. The reference to "foolish lips" implies that their focus on gold and silver detracted from their spiritual mission, emphasizing the importance of prioritizing divine commandments over material concerns.

passage_content: ואפשרלומר עפ"י מ"ש א"א הגה"ק זלה"ה בקדויו"ט בפ' הנני ממטיר לכם וגו' ויצא העם ולקטו דבר יום ביומו. דתיבת דבר הוא לכאורה מיותר ואין לו הבנה, ופי' הוא ז"ל דהנה ע"י אמונה אמיתית אפשר להמשיך הפרנסה בלי שום השתדלות כמבואר בזוה"ק שטו העם ולקטו דשטות גדול עשו במה שלקטו, כי לבתיהם הי' בא בלי לקיטה,והעיקר הוא לזכות לאמונה אמיתית, ומה שצריך לקיים וברכתיך בכל אשר תעשה יספיק אף במעשה כל דהו, ומצינו בגמ' (ב"מ דף צ' ע"ב) דאף עקימת שפתים הוי מעשה, וא"כ יוצא ידי חובת עשי' אף בדיבור בעלמא, ובלא"ה מצינו שצריך להתפלל על מזונו והוי גם זה מעשה היינו דיבורי התפלה להמשיך הפרנסה, וז"ש הנני ממטיר לכם, ר"ל שאשפיע לכם בלבכם שתדעו שהלחם מן השמים, ואח"כ כשתדעו באמונת אומן שלחם הוא רק מן השמים, אזי ויצא העם ולקטו "דבר" יום ביומו: דבר דייקא שהדיבור בלבד תחשב להם למעשה ולא תצטרכו לעשי' אחרת עכ"ד הקדושים
translation: And it is possible to say according to what the holy Rabbi, may his memory be blessed, wrote in his teachings on the portion "Behold, I will rain down for you" etc., and the people went out and gathered a thing day by day. The word "thing" seems superfluous and lacks understanding, and he explained that through true faith it is possible to draw down sustenance without any effort, as is explained in the Zohar that the people went out and gathered, for it was a great folly what they gathered, because to their homes it came without gathering. The main thing is to merit true faith, and what is necessary to fulfill "And I will bless you in all that you do" is sufficient even with any action at all. And we find in the Gemara (Baba Metzia 60b) that even the bending of the lips is considered an action, and thus one fulfills the obligation of action even with mere speech. Moreover, we find that one must pray for his sustenance, and this too is an action, namely the words of prayer to draw down sustenance. This is what is meant by "Behold, I will rain down for you," meaning that I will inspire in your hearts that the bread is from heaven, and afterwards, when you know with the faith of a craftsman that the bread is only from heaven, then "the people went out and gathered a 'thing' day by day": specifically "thing" that the speech alone will be considered an action for them, and they will not need any other action. Thus concludes the holy teachings.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of true faith as a means to receive sustenance without the need for extensive effort, as illustrated by the Israelites collecting manna. It emphasizes that the term "דבר" (thing) is significant, indicating that even speech and prayer can be considered actions that attract divine provision. The text highlights the importance of recognizing that sustenance comes from Heaven, and through genuine belief, one can fulfill their needs with minimal physical effort. Ultimately, it conveys that faith and prayer are powerful tools in manifesting one's sustenance.

passage_content: והנהבאמת לאו כל אדם זוכה לזה שדיבורו יעשה רושם כעשי' ממש, וכבר פירשו בספה"ק מאמה"כ לא יחל דברו ככל היוצא מפיו יעשה, שאם לא יחל דברו כפירש"י ז"ל לא יעשה דבריו חולין דר"ל שיהי' דיבורו בקדושה ולא יתחלל בשום ענין, אזי ככל היוצא מפיו יעשה שכל דיבוריו שיצאו מפיו יחשבו לעשי', ומי שמקדש דיבורו באמת ואינו מחללו בשום ענין, בוודאי יוכל להמשיך בתפלתו כל השפעות טובות בלי שום עשי' והשתדלות, ותפלתו אינה חוזרת ריקם לעולם, אמנם מי שאינו במדריגה זו לקדש דיבורו בקדושה גמורה, אין דיבורו פועל כ"כ וצריך לאיזה עשי' והשתדלות, אבל מ"מ אין מעצור לה' להושיע ברב או במעט ואף בעשי' כל דהו מקיים וברכתיך בכל אשר תעשה, ואין צריך לבלות ע"ז כל זמניו ח"ו והעיקר הוא האמונה והבטחון.
translation: And behold, in truth, not every person merits that their speech should make an impression as if it were an action itself. It has already been explained in the holy books from our sages that "his word shall not be profaned," meaning that if he does not profane his word, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explained, his words will not become mundane, which means that his speech should be in holiness and not be desecrated in any matter. Then, "as all that comes from his mouth shall be done," meaning that all his words that come from his mouth will be considered as actions. And one who truly sanctifies their speech and does not desecrate it in any way will certainly be able to draw down through their prayer all good influences without any action or effort, and their prayer will never return empty. However, one who is not on this level to sanctify their speech in complete holiness, their speech does not have such an effect and requires some action and effort. Nevertheless, there is no barrier for the Holy One, blessed be He, to save in abundance or in little, and even with any action at all, "I will bless you in all that you do." One does not need to spend all their time on this, heaven forbid; the main thing is faith and trust.
summary: The passage emphasizes that not everyone has the ability for their words to have a direct impact like actions, as highlighted by the teaching that one's speech must be sacred and not profaned. When a person's speech is truly sanctified, their prayers can bring forth blessings without the need for additional actions or efforts, and their prayers are never in vain. However, those who do not reach this level of sanctity in their speech may require some form of action or effort for their words to be effective. Ultimately, the core principle is the importance of faith and trust in God, who can bring salvation regardless of one's actions.

passage_content: ומצינוכשהקב"ה צוה לישראל במצרים שישאלו כלי כסף וכלי זהב למען הרבות הרכוש, והם עשו כך וישאלו, ואח"כ כתיב וישאלום, ופירש"י ז"ל אף מה שלא היו שואלים מהם היו נותנים להם, אתה אומר אחד טול שנים ולך, והנה כיון שבלא"ה היו נותנים להם אף מה שלא שאלו, א"כ למה הוצרך הקב"ה להזהירם כ"כ שישאלו מהם, הלא הי' באפשרי שיתנו להם הכל מבלי שאלה כמו שנתנו מעצמם העודף יותר ממה ששאלו, אמנם הם הוצרכו לעשות איזה השתדלות לקיים וברכתיך בכל אשר תעשה, ואח"כ נפתח להם השפעה להשיג אף מה שלא שאלו, כי אחר שהאדם עושה איזה עשי' כל דהו, הקב"ה בעזרו ומשפיע לו אף מה שלא נכלל כלל בעשי' שלו, ואין מעצור לה' להושיע ברב או במעט, אבל מרע"ה שהי' כל דיבורו בקדושה לא הוצרך לשום עשי' והשתדלות, כי פעל הכל בדיבורו כמאמה"כ ולקטו דבר יום ביומו וגו' ולכן אף שגם עליו חלה חובת המצוה לקיים ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול, מ"מ לא הוצרך להשתדל בזה כלל, כי הי' בכוחו להשיג רכוש גדול בדיבורו בעלמא, ואך ישראל שלא היו במצרים במדריגה זו לפעול הכל בדיבורם, הוצרכו לעשי' והשתדלות.
translation: And when the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded Israel in Egypt to ask for silver and gold vessels in order to increase their wealth, they did so and asked. And afterwards it is written, "And they asked them," and Rashi explains that even what they did not ask for, they gave to them. You might say, "Take one and two for yourself." And behold, since they were giving to them even what they did not ask for, why did the Holy One, blessed be He, need to warn them so much to ask from them? Surely it was possible for them to give everything without asking, just as they gave of their excess beyond what they asked. However, they needed to make some effort to fulfill the verse, "And I will bless you in all that you do." And afterwards, a flow was opened for them to attain even what they did not ask for, because after a person does some action, the Holy One, blessed be He, assists him and grants him even what is not included at all in his action. There is no barrier for the Holy One to save in abundance or in scarcity. But for Moses, who spoke all his words in holiness, he did not need any action or effort, for he accomplished everything with his speech, as it is written, "And gather it, each day, etc." Therefore, even though the obligation of the commandment also applied to him to fulfill, and afterwards they went out with great wealth, he did not need to exert himself in this at all, for he had the power to attain great wealth merely by his speech. But Israel, who were not in Egypt at that level to accomplish everything with their speech, needed to make effort and exertion.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses the commandment given by God to the Israelites in Egypt to ask for silver and gold, emphasizing the necessity of their active participation in the process. Although the Egyptians would have given them these items without being asked, the act of asking was essential for the Israelites to demonstrate their effort and faith, aligning with the principle that divine assistance follows human initiative. The text contrasts this with Moses, who, due to his elevated spiritual status, could achieve results solely through his words without the need for physical action. Ultimately, the passage highlights the relationship between human effort and divine providence, illustrating that while God can provide abundantly, He often requires individuals to take initiative to receive His blessings.

passage_content: ובזהיובן מה שדרשו חכז"ל ע"ז אויל שפתים ילבט מה שנפנו אל כסף וזהב, אף שהי' באמת בציווי הקב"ה לאסוף הרכוש אבל אלמלי הי' דיבורם מקודש בקדושה גמורה הי' בכחם לאסוף הרכוש בדיבור בעלמא כמו מרע"ה, ולא היו מצטרכים להצטוות על עשי' והשתדלות, ואפשר שלכן קראו למרע"ה בזה חכם לב, כי עיקר קדושת הדיבור צ"ל מקושר אל הלב וכל דיבוריו יבואו מעומק פנימית הלב והבן.
translation: And in this is understood what our sages, of blessed memory, taught regarding the verse "The lips of the righteous will speak" about the fact that they turned to silver and gold, even though it was indeed by the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, to gather the wealth. However, had their speech been holy with complete sanctity, they would have had the power to gather the wealth merely through speech, like Moses our teacher, and they would not have needed to be commanded to act and make efforts. And perhaps that is why they referred to Moses our teacher as wise of heart, for the essence of the sanctity of speech must be connected to the heart, and all his words would come from the depth of the inner heart. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of speech in the context of divine command and human action, emphasizing that if the speech of the leaders had been completely holy, they could have gathered wealth effortlessly, akin to Moses. It highlights the connection between the sanctity of speech and the heart, suggesting that true holiness in communication stems from deep inner sincerity. The reference to Moses as "wise of heart" underscores the importance of aligning one's words with profound inner intention and spiritual depth.

passage_content: והנהיוסף הצדיק השפיע לכל העולם בקדושתו, וכנודע מספה"ק שממדת יסוד שהוא קדושת יוסף בא כל שפע הפרנסה, וכמאמה"כ משם רועה אבן ישראל, ולכן בימי הרעב זכה יוסף להיות המשביר לכל עם הארץ, ולזה הראה להם כי פי המדבר אליכם בלה"ק, ר"ל שלא עשה דבריו חולין כפירש"י ז"ל על לא יחל דברו, וכתב רש"י ז"ל שם הראה להם שהוא מהול, כי ברית הלשון וברית המעור מכוונים, והפוגם בבריתו משוך בערלתו, וקדושת היסוד וקדושת הפה כחדא אזלין, ולזה הי' בכחו להשפיע לכל באי עולם אף בלי השתדלות הטבעי, כי בדיבורו הקדוש הי' בכחו לפעול הכל.
translation: And behold, Joseph the righteous influenced the entire world with his holiness, and as is known from the holy books, from the attribute of Yesod, which is the holiness of Joseph, all the flow of sustenance comes. And as it is written, "From there is the shepherd, the stone of Israel." Therefore, in the days of famine, Joseph merited to be the distributor to all the inhabitants of the land. And for this, he showed them that the mouth of the speaker is speaking to you in the holy tongue, meaning that he did not make his words mundane, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explained on "Do not profane his word." And Rashi, of blessed memory, wrote there that he showed them that he is circumcised, for the covenant of the tongue and the covenant of the organ are aligned, and one who damages his covenant is drawn by his foreskin. And the holiness of Yesod and the holiness of the mouth go together, and for this reason, he had the power to influence all the inhabitants of the world even without natural effort, for with his holy speech he had the power to accomplish everything.
summary: יוסף הצדיק השפיע קדושה לכל העולם דרך מידת היסוד, שהיא מקור השפע והפרנסה. הוא זכה להיות המשביר בימי הרעב, והדגיש את קדושת הדיבור והברית, הממחישות את הקשר בין קדושת הלשון לקדושת היסוד. יוסף הראה כי דיבורו הקדוש יכול לפעול ניסים ולהשפיע על כל הבריאה, גם ללא השתדלות טבעית. בכך, הוא מדגיש את הכוח הרוחני של הדיבור והקדושה בחיי האדם.
