passage_content: ומעתהאפשר לומר שלכן לא צוה יוסף שישאוהו מיד ממצרים, שכמו שהוצרך להקדים לבוא לפניהם למצרים, בשביל שיהי' צינור המשפיע בימי הרעב נגד הטבע, כמשה"כ וישלחנו אלקים לפניכם לשום לכם שארית בארץ, כמו כן גם בעת היציאה ממצרים שהוצרכו לרכוש גדול ולהשפעה מרובה, הוצרך גם יוסף הצדיק להיות שם שיומשך להם על ידו כח קדושה זו להמשיך צינור ההשפעה, אמנם כאשר נראה שהוצרכו להשתדלות עבור הרכוש, זה הי' לאות כי לא דבקו בקדושה זו שאמר יוסף כי פי המדבר אליכם בלה"ק שלא עשה דבריו חולין כלל, כי אלו הי' כן הי' בכחם לפעול הכל בדיבור בלי שום השתדלות, ואך במשה מצינו ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו שהשתדל רק בעצמות יוסף ולא הוצרך להשתדל בכסף וזהב.
translation: And from now on, it is possible to say that this is why Joseph did not command that he be carried immediately from Egypt, for just as he needed to come before them in Egypt in order to be a conduit of influence during the years of famine against nature, as it is written, "And God sent him before you to establish for you a remnant in the land," so too, at the time of the exodus from Egypt, when they needed great wealth and abundant influence, it was also necessary for the righteous Joseph to be there, so that this holy power would be drawn to them through him to continue the conduit of influence. However, when it appeared that they needed to exert effort for the wealth, this was a sign that they did not cling to this holiness that Joseph spoke of, for he said, "The mouth of the speaker is speaking to you" in the Holy Tongue, that he did not make his words mundane at all, for if it were so, they would have had the power to accomplish everything through speech without any effort. Only with Moses do we find that "Moses took the bones of Joseph with him," for he only exerted effort for the bones of Joseph and did not need to exert effort for gold and silver.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph's role in the spiritual and material sustenance of the Israelites during their time in Egypt and their subsequent exodus. It emphasizes that Joseph's presence was essential for channeling divine influence and blessings, particularly during times of need, such as famine and the acquisition of wealth. The text suggests that the Israelites' reliance on material efforts indicated a lack of connection to the holiness that Joseph embodied, which could have allowed them to achieve their needs through divine speech alone. Ultimately, it highlights the unique relationship between spiritual leadership and the material world, as exemplified by Moses' act of taking Joseph's bones, symbolizing a focus on spiritual legacy over material wealth.

passage_content: ואפשרלפרש ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו ר"ל עצמותו של יוסף וכח קדושתו לקח עמו ולעצמו, שיהי' לו כח השפעה אף חוץ לדרך הטבע, אמנם עבור מרע"ה א"א לומר שהוצרך יוסף להשאר בשם שיהי' בכחו להשיג קדושה זו ע"י יוסף, כאשר כתב בשו"ת השיב משה (באו"ח סי' ב') שזה וודאי שכל מה שמצינו באחד מבני עלי' וודאי דמשה כללא דכולהו, וא"כ א"א לומר במרע"ה שהוצרך לסיוע מזולתו להשיג איזה קדושה.
translation: And it is possible to explain that Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, meaning the bones of Joseph, and he took with him the power of his holiness, so that he would have the power of influence even outside the natural order. However, regarding Moses our teacher, it cannot be said that Joseph needed to remain in name so that he would have the power to attain this holiness through Joseph, as it is written in the responsa of the Shive Moshe (Orach Chaim, Siman 2) that it is certain that whatever we find in one of the sons of elevation, it is certainly a general principle for all of them, and therefore it cannot be said regarding Moses our teacher that he needed assistance from another to attain any holiness.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses taking the bones of Joseph with him, symbolizing the transmission of Joseph's holiness and spiritual power. It emphasizes that Moses, as a leader and prophet, did not require external assistance from Joseph to attain holiness, as he embodies the collective spiritual potential of all the righteous. The text highlights the unique status of Moses, asserting that he is capable of achieving divine influence independently, without relying on others. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the inherent spiritual strength within the righteous and their ability to connect with the divine.

passage_content: ובזהאפשר לפרש דברי רש"י ז"ל שאצל סיפור השבועה לא קשיא לי' למה לא השביע בניו שישאוהו מיד, שאז הי' אפשר לתרץ אולי הוצרך להיות בשם שלבסוף יזכו ישראל על ידו להשפיע בכח הדיבור חוץ לדרך הטבע, אבל כאשר אמר הכתוב ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו, שמבואר שאך משה לקח עמו עצמותו של יוסף הצדיק ע"ה, ועבורו לא הוצרך להיות בשם, כי בכחו לבוא למדריגה זו בלי שום סיוע כנ"ל, ולזה הקשה למה לא השביען שישאוהו מיד והבן, (ע"כ מכתי"ק).
translation: And with this, it is possible to explain the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, regarding the story of the oath: it is not difficult for him why he did not swear his sons to carry him immediately, for then it could have been explained that perhaps it was necessary to be in the name so that in the end, Israel would merit through him to influence with the power of speech beyond the natural order. But when the verse states, "And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him," it is clear that only Moses took with him the bones of Joseph the righteous, peace be upon him, and for him it was not necessary to be in the name, for he had the power to reach this level without any assistance, as mentioned. Therefore, he questioned why he did not swear them to carry him immediately, and understand. (Thus is written in the manuscript.)
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses taking the bones of Joseph during the Exodus, emphasizing that Moses possessed the spiritual capacity to achieve this without needing a divine name or assistance. It raises the question of why Joseph did not require his sons to swear to carry him immediately, suggesting that Moses's unique spiritual stature allowed him to fulfill this task independently. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the power of righteous individuals to transcend natural limitations through their faith and connection to the divine. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of spiritual leadership and the potential for divine influence through righteous actions.

passage_content: ויקחמשה את עצמות יוסף עמו כי השבע השביע את בנ"י לאמר פקוד יפקוד וגו', פירש"י בשם המכילתא השביעם שישביעו לבניהם, ולמה לא השביע בניו שישאוהו לארץ כנען מיד כמו שהשביע יעקב, אמר יוסף אני שליט הייתי במצרים וכו', אבל בני לא יניחום מצרים לעשות וכו' עכ"ל, והקושיא מפורסמת מדוע לא הקשה רש"י זאת בפ' ויחי אצל סיפור השבועה הזאת, וכן הקשה ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה עיי"ש תירוצו.
translation: And he took the bones of Joseph with him, for he had made the children of Israel swear, saying, "Surely God will visit you," etc. Rashi explains in the name of the Mechilta that he made them swear that they should make their children swear. And why did he not make his sons swear to carry him to the land of Canaan immediately, as Jacob had sworn? Joseph said, "I was a ruler in Egypt," etc., but my sons will not allow them to do so, etc. Thus far the text. And the question is well-known: why did Rashi not raise this issue in Parashat Vayechi regarding the account of this oath? And so asked K"Z the Simchat Moshe, may his merit protect us; see there for his answer.
summary: הפסוק מתאר את לקיחת עצמות יוסף על ידי בני ישראל, בעקבות השבועה שהשביעם יוסף להוציא את עצמותיו ממצרים. רש"י, בשם המכילתא, מסביר כי יוסף השביע את בני ישראל להבטיח שהשבועה תעבור לדורות הבאים, אך לא השביע את בניו לעשות זאת מיד, מתוך הבנה שהמציאות במצרים תעכב את המעשה. השאלה מדוע רש"י לא העלה את הקושיה הזו בפרשת ויחי, מצביעה על עומק ההבנה החסידית של הקשר בין השבועות וההיסטוריה של עם ישראל.

passage_content: ב)סוטה (י"ג ע"א) בא וראה כמה חביבות מצות על משה רבינו, שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק במצות שנאמר חכם לב יקח מצות ובמכילתא הגירסא בא וראה חכמתו של משה וכו', וכבר דקדקו קמאי מה שתיארוהו חז"ל במעשה זו בתואר חכם, ויותר יאות אליו תואר צדיק (עיין בח"א מהרש"א מ"ש בזה), גם מ"ש יקח מצות בלשון רבים, ואין זה אלא מצוה א'.
translation: In Sotah (13a), it says: "Come and see how beloved the commandments are to our teacher Moses, for all of Israel were occupied with the spoils, and he was occupied with the commandments, as it is said, 'A wise heart will acquire commandments.' And in the Mekilta, the version states: 'Come and see the wisdom of Moses,' etc. The earlier ones have already noted what our Sages described him in this act with the title 'wise,' and the title 'righteous' is more fitting for him (see in the Chiddushei Agadot of the Maharsha what is said about this). Also, the phrase 'will acquire commandments' is in the plural, and this is nothing but a single commandment."
summary: The passage highlights the deep affection that Moses had for the commandments, contrasting his focus on fulfilling God's will with the rest of Israel's preoccupation with material gain. It emphasizes the wisdom of Moses, as described by the Sages, and suggests that the title "righteous" (tzaddik) is more fitting for him than "wise." Additionally, the use of the plural form "mitzvot" indicates a broader commitment to the commandments, underscoring the significance of fulfilling God's laws as a primary duty.

passage_content: ויתבארבהקדם מה שפירשתי בטעם שהוצרך משרע"ה לשאול בדבר ה' בפרשת טמאים דכתיב (בפ' בהעלותך) ויאמר אליהם משה עמדו ואשמעה מה יצוה ה' לכם, ובפ' פנחס בענין בנות צלפחד כתיב ויקרב משה את משפטן לפני ה', ורז"ל דרשו ראוי' היתה פרשה זו להאמר ע"י משה כשאר כל התורה כולה, אלא שזכו אלו שתאמר על ידיהן וכו' (הביאו רש"י ז"ל), מ"מ טעמא בעי מדוע נשתנו ב' מצות אלו מכל מצות התורה שהוצרך משרע"ה להימלך בגבורה, והרי כל חלקי התורה נגלו לפניו וקבלם מסיני, ופירשתי עפי"ד ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' שמיני) דנמצא בדברי רז"ל סתירות הרבה בהך הלכתא אי קברי צדיקים מטמאים או לאו, והוא ז"ל הכריע דמעצם הדין ראוי להיות שצדיקים לא יטמאו, כי אין טומאה להם ובמיתתן נקראו חיים אך לא ניתנה לנו להתנהג בדין זה, כי הכרעה זו אין דעתינו דעת האנושי מקפת אותה, כי אני ה' חוקר לב ובוחן כליות כתיב, והאדם יראה לעינים, ולכך אין לנו להתנהג בזה כלל, אף אם נודע לנו שהוא צדיק, כדי שלא לחלק בין צדיק לצדיק דאין כח המבחין בידינו וכו' כנ"ל ברור ואמת בס"ד עכ"ל.
translation: And it will be clarified beforehand what I explained regarding the reason that Moshe Rabbeinu needed to inquire of the word of Hashem in the matter of the impure in the portion of Beha'alotecha, as it is written (in Parshat Beha'alotecha) "And Moshe said to them, 'Stand and I will hear what Hashem commands you.'" And in Parshat Pinchas regarding the daughters of Tzelophehad, it is written, "And Moshe brought their case before Hashem." And our Sages of blessed memory expounded that this section was fitting to be said by Moshe like all of the Torah, but these women merited that it be said through them, etc. (as brought by Rashi, of blessed memory). Nevertheless, a reason is needed as to why these two commandments were different from all the commandments of the Torah, that Moshe Rabbeinu needed to consult with the mighty one. And behold, all parts of the Torah were revealed to him and he received them from Sinai. I explained according to the words of the holy Rabbi (in Parshat Shemini) that there are many contradictions in the words of our Sages regarding this halacha, whether the graves of the righteous render one impure or not. And he, of blessed memory, ruled that by the very law it is fitting that the righteous should not render impure, for they have no impurity, and in their death they are called alive. However, we were not given to conduct ourselves according to this law, for this ruling is beyond human understanding, as it is written, "For I, Hashem, search the heart and examine the kidneys," and man sees only with his eyes. Therefore, we should not conduct ourselves in this matter at all, even if we know that he is a righteous person, so as not to create a distinction between one righteous person and another, for we do not have the power to discern between them, etc. As stated, clear and true, with the help of Hashem.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity for Moses to seek divine guidance regarding specific commandments, highlighting the unique nature of the laws concerning the daughters of Zelophehad and the status of the righteous after death. It emphasizes that while the Torah was fully revealed to Moses, certain matters, such as the purity of the righteous, transcend human understanding and judgment. The text underscores the idea that, despite the inherent purity of the righteous, human perception is limited, and thus one must refrain from making distinctions among them. Ultimately, it reflects a deep theological insight into the relationship between divine wisdom and human limitations in understanding spiritual truths.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר לענינינו דהנה איתא בגמרא (סוכה כ"ה ע"א) ויהי אנשים אשר היו טמאים לנפשאדם, מי היו נושאי ארונו של יוסף היו, נמצא דאם צדיקים אינם מטמאים, היו ראויים אלו להקריב הפסח במועדו ככל ישראל, ולזה באו בטענה לפני משה ואהרן אנחנו טמאים לנפש אדם, היינו לנפש צדיק למה נגרע לבלתי הקריב את קרבן ה' במועדו בתוך בנ"י, והשיב להם משרע"ה עמדו ואשמעה מה יצוה ה' לכם, להורות כי לא ניתן הכרעה זו ביד בי"ד של מטה, ואף אם נודע לנו בבירור שהוא צדיק מטעם שלא לחלק בין צדיק לצדיק דאין כח המבחין בידינו כנ"ל, ובזה א"ש שבתשובתו של הקב"ה למשרע"ה לא נתפרש על פרט הנשאל אם יקריבו הם הפסח במועדו או לאו, רק הודיעו ההלכה בסתם טמאים דעלמא, איש איש כי יהי' טמא לנפש וגו' והטעם כי לא נתנה לנו להתנהג בדין זה כנ"ל, וטמאים דעלמא נדחו לפסח שני והבן. ועד"ז יתבאר בענין בנות צלפחד, דאיתא בספרי לאלה תחלק הארץ צדיקים כמותכם, ואמרז"ל (שבת צ"ו ע"ב) מקושש זה צלפחד ולפי"ז מה מקום לטענתם ליטול חלק בארץ, אמנם כתבו התוס' במס' ב"ב בשם המדרש דמקושש לש"ש נתכוין עיי"ש, ועד"ז הי' טענתם דצדיק גמור הי', וע"כ ויקרב משה את משפטן לפני ה' דלא ניתן לבי"ד של מטה להכריע בזה דרק הבוי"ת חוקר לב ובוחן כליות לידע מחשבה שבלב והבן. (עיין בדברינו במקומו תקחנו משם).
translation:
And in this, it is clarified regarding our matter that it is stated in the Gemara (Sukkah 25a) that there were men who were impure due to a dead body; they were the bearers of Joseph's coffin. It turns out that if the righteous do not render themselves impure, these men were worthy to bring the Passover offering at its appointed time like all of Israel. Therefore, they came with a claim before Moses and Aaron, saying, "We are impure due to a dead body," meaning due to the dead body of a righteous person. "Why should we be diminished from bringing the offering of the Lord at its appointed time among the children of Israel?" And Moses replied to them, "Stand and I will hear what the Lord will command you," to indicate that this decision was not given into the hands of the earthly court. Even if it is known to us clearly that he is a righteous person, for the reason not to differentiate between one righteous person and another, as we do not have the power to discern, as mentioned above. And in this, it is understood that in God's response to Moses, it was not clarified regarding the specific question of whether they would bring the Passover at its appointed time or not, but rather He informed him of the general law concerning the impure of the world, "Any man who is impure due to a dead body," etc., and the reason is that we were not given the authority to act in this matter as mentioned above, and the impure of the world were pushed off to the second Passover, and understand this. 

Similarly, it can be explained regarding the daughters of Zelophehad, as it is stated in the Sifrei, "To these shall the land be divided, righteous ones like you." And our sages said (Shabbat 96b) that the gatherer was Zelophehad. According to this, what was their claim to take a portion in the land? However, the Tosafot wrote in Bava Batra in the name of the Midrash that the gatherer intended for the sake of Heaven, see there. And similarly, their claim was that he was a complete righteous person, and therefore Moses brought their case before the Lord, for it was not given to the earthly court to decide in this matter, as only the Holy One, Blessed be He, searches the heart and examines the innermost thoughts to know the thoughts in the heart, and understand this. (See our words in their place, take it from there).
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual purity and the limitations of human judgment in determining the status of individuals, particularly in the context of the Pesach offering. It highlights the case of the men who were impure due to contact with a dead body, asserting their right to participate in the Paschal sacrifice, as they were righteous individuals. The response from Moses emphasizes that the decision regarding their eligibility is beyond human authority, as only God knows the true intentions of the heart. This reflects a broader theological insight into the nature of divine justice and the recognition that human courts cannot fully discern the spiritual status of individuals.

passage_content: ונקדיםעוד מ"ש האוהחה"ק (פ' חקת) שלא מצינו שהקפיד ה' בפסח מצרים על דין הטומאה, שיהיו טמאי מתים נדחין מלעשות הפסח, וטעם הדבר כי ישראל לא היו טמאי מת, הגם שנגעו והאהילו על המת, אבל לפי שעדיין לא קבלו את התורה, דנו בהם דין גר שנתגייר ביום י"ד ששוחטין עליו ואין חוששין לטומאה שנטמא קודם שנתגייר, ופי' בזה מאמה"כ זאת חקת התורה וגו', פי' חקה זו של הטומאה ותנאי טהרתה תסובב מהתורה, כי ע"י שקבלו התורה נעשו עם בני ישראל דבר שהרוחנים השפלים תאבים להדבק בהם וכו' ובמותם ג"כ תתרבה הטומאה כאמרם ז"ל ישראל מטמאין באהל ואין אומות מטמאין באוהל וכו' ואשר יסובב הכל הוא התורה עייש"ד, ועפי"ז פירשתי דברי המכילתא בפרשת קרבן פסח, וילכו ויעשו בנ"י כאשר צוה ה' את משה ואהרן כן עשו, מה ת"ל כן עשו, אף משה ואהרן כן עשו עכ"ד המכילתא (והובא ברש"י ז"ל) וצ"ב מה צורך להשמיענו שאף משה ואהרן קיימו מצות הפסח ככל ישראל, ולדרכינו נאמר כי הנה בנ"י לא נזהרו מטומאת מת בפסח מצרים, שערם קבלתם התורה לא הי' נוהג לגבייהו דין טומאת מת כדברי האוהחה"ק הנ"ל, אמנם משה ואהרן שקיימו את התורה בעודם במצרים איך הקריבו קרבן פסח, ואפשר מפני דישראל קודם קבלת התורה לא הי' נוהג לגבייהו דין טומאה כלל, וכמו שלא נטמאו במת כך אינם מטמאין אחרים הנוגעים בהם, ולדברי הסובר דעכו"ם מטמא במשא ורק מטומאת אהל נתמעטו אפשר דנזהרו משה ואהרן ממשא וא"ש שהקריבו קרבן פסח. (עיין בדברינו פ' וישלח עמוד קנ"ו עוד בענין זה) אמנם הרי מפורש בפסוק שנשא משה עצמות יוסף עמו, ויוסף הצדיק וודאי הי' לו דין ישראל לחומרא, ואיך הקריב קרבן פסח, אכן כבר ביררנו לעיל דצדיקים אין להם טומאה ובמיתתם נקראו חיים, וא"ש דהוצרך להשמיענו דאף משה ואהרן כן עשו והקריבו את הפסח, ולא נמנעו מדין הטומאה שנהג בהם, ואפשר שלטעם זה לא נכתב בפירוש שאף משה הקריב הפסח, דדין זה שאין צדיקים מטמאים לא ניתן לקבוע הלכה בפירוש, דאין כח המבחין בידינו כמ"ש ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה, וע"כ נכתב רק ברמז במאמר כן עשו, דלפי פשוטו קאי על בני ישראל, אלאשהכריחו רז"ל מיתורא דקרא, שנרמז בו שאף משה ואהרן קיימו מצות הפסח, ולא נמנעו לצד דין הטומאה שנוהגת אצלם.
translation: And we will further precede what the holy author writes (in Parashat Chukat) that we do not find that the Holy One, blessed be He, was particular about the law of impurity during the Passover in Egypt, that the impure from the dead should be pushed away from performing the Passover. The reason for this is that Israel was not impure from the dead, even though they touched and were in a tent over the dead, but since they had not yet received the Torah, they were judged like a convert who converts on the 14th, for whom they slaughter on his behalf and do not concern themselves with the impurity that he had before he converted. And this is explained by the verse: "This is the statute of the Torah," meaning that this statute of impurity and the conditions of its purity are derived from the Torah, for by receiving the Torah, they became part of the people of Israel, a matter that the lowly spirits desire to cling to, etc., and in their death, impurity also increases, as our sages said, "Israel imparts impurity in a tent, but the nations do not impart impurity in a tent," etc. And that which encompasses everything is the Torah, as it is written. And according to this, I explained the words of the Mekilta in the section of the Passover offering, "And the children of Israel went and did as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron; so they did." What does it mean, "so they did"? Even Moses and Aaron did so, thus says the Mekilta (and it is brought in Rashi). And it is necessary to ask what is the need to inform us that even Moses and Aaron fulfilled the commandment of the Passover like all of Israel. According to our approach, we can say that behold, the children of Israel were not careful about the impurity of the dead during the Passover in Egypt, since at the time of their receiving the Torah, the law of impurity from the dead did not apply to them, as the holy author mentioned above. However, Moses and Aaron, who fulfilled the Torah while still in Egypt, how did they offer the Passover sacrifice? It is possible that because Israel, prior to receiving the Torah, did not have the law of impurity apply to them at all, and just as they were not made impure by the dead, so they do not make others impure who touch them. And according to the opinion that a non-Jew imparts impurity through carrying, and only through a tent of impurity were they diminished, it is possible that Moses and Aaron were careful about carrying, and it is understood that they offered the Passover sacrifice. (See our words in Parashat Vayishlach, page 156, further on this matter.) However, it is explicitly stated in the verse that Moses carried the bones of Joseph with him, and Joseph the righteous certainly had the status of Israel stringently. How then did he offer the Passover sacrifice? Indeed, we have already clarified above that the righteous have no impurity, and in their death, they are called alive. And it is understood that it was necessary to inform us that even Moses and Aaron did so and offered the Passover, and they were not prevented by the law of impurity that applied to them. And it is possible that for this reason it was not explicitly written that even Moses offered the Passover, for the law that the righteous do not impart impurity cannot be established as a clear halacha, for we do not have the discerning power, as it is written, "Happy is Moses, may his memory be blessed." And therefore, it was written only in hint in the statement "so they did," that according to its simple meaning refers to the children of Israel, but the sages compelled us from the excess of the verse, that it is hinted that even Moses and Aaron fulfilled the commandment of the Passover and were not prevented by the law of impurity that was applicable to them.
summary: The passage discusses the unique status of the Israelites during the Passover in Egypt, emphasizing that they were not considered ritually impure despite contact with the dead, as they had not yet received the Torah. It highlights the idea that prior to the giving of the Torah, the laws of impurity did not apply to them in the same way. The text also notes that even Moses and Aaron, who were already observing the Torah, were able to partake in the Passover sacrifice without being hindered by the laws of impurity, illustrating the concept that the righteous (tzaddikim) are not subject to the same spiritual limitations as others. Ultimately, the passage underscores the transformative power of the Torah in defining the spiritual identity and status of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ובזהיתבארו דברי המכילתא בא וראה חכמתו של משה שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק במצות שנאמר חכם לב יקח מצות, ולכאורה מדוע יחסוהו אל חכמתו ומה ענין החכמה בזה, ויותר יאות ליחסהו אל צדקותו וחסידותו, גם מ"ש מצות בלשון רבים צ"ב ואינו כ"א מצוה אחת, אמנם הי' לו לחוש שע"י העסק בעצמות יוסף ימנע ממנו הקרבת הפסח, ואולי גם השראת השכינה שהי' תדירה אצלו, אלא שחכמתו עמדה לו והשיג שהעסק בעצמות יוסף לא ימנעהו מן המצות, וזה וזה יתקיימו בידו,והכרעה זו אין דעת אנושי מקפת אותה, אבל משרע"ה נתעלה בחכמת אלקית מבחי' חכמה עליונה, והכריע כן בחכמתו שעי"ז ישיג מצות הרבה, וז"ש בא וראה חכמתו של משה וכו' שנא' חכם לב יקח מצות והבן.
translation: And in this, the words of the Mechilta are clarified: Come and see the wisdom of Moses, for all of Israel were occupied with the spoils, and he was engaged in the commandments, as it is said, "A wise heart will acquire commandments." At first glance, why is this attributed to his wisdom, and what is the connection of wisdom to this? It would be more fitting to attribute it to his righteousness and piety. Also, the phrase "commandments" in the plural is puzzling, as it refers to only one commandment. However, he had to be concerned that by engaging with the bones of Joseph, he would be prevented from offering the Passover sacrifice, and perhaps even the resting of the Shechinah, which was constantly with him. Yet, his wisdom stood by him, and he realized that engaging with the bones of Joseph would not prevent him from the commandments, and both this and that would be fulfilled in his hands. This decision is beyond human understanding, but since Moshe was elevated in divine wisdom from the aspect of supreme wisdom, he decided thus in his wisdom, through which he would attain many commandments. Therefore, it is said, "Come and see the wisdom of Moses," etc., as it is stated, "A wise heart will acquire commandments," and understand.
summary: The passage highlights the unique wisdom of Moses, who prioritized the fulfillment of commandments over the material concerns of the Israelites during the plunder. It emphasizes that his wisdom, described as "divine wisdom," allowed him to engage in the mitzvah of handling Joseph's bones without neglecting the Passover sacrifice. This illustrates the profound connection between wisdom and righteousness in Hasidic thought, suggesting that true understanding enables one to fulfill multiple commandments simultaneously. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that divine wisdom transcends human reasoning, allowing for a deeper engagement with the divine commandments.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד דהנה ישראל נתעסקו בביזה עפ"י מצות השם עליהם, ובוודאי שלא יצוה ה' ליקח ממון של אחרים שלא מן הדין, והרבה תירוצים נאמרו בזה, והאמת שכל רכוש מצרים מגיע לישראל מדינא שזכו בהם מיוסף הצדיק, כדאיתא במדרש ילקוט (פ' ויגש רמז קנ"ח) וילקט יוסף את כל הכסף וגו' א"ר יהודה אמר שמואל כל כסף וזהב שבעולם לקט יוסף והביא למצרים, שנאמר וילקט יוסף את כל הכסף, אין לו אלא בארץ מצרים, שבארץ כנען ובשאר ארצות מנין, תלמוד לומר וכל הארץ באו מצרימה, וכשעלו ישראל ממצרים העלוהו עמהם שנאמר וינצלו את מצרים עכ"ד המדרש, מבואר דעפ"י הדין ה"ה של ישראל שיוסף הצדיק זכה בהם בשבילם, אלא שאחר הסתלקותו נטלוהו המצרים שלא בדין, וכשיצאו ישראל הצילו מידם את שלהם, וע"כ בעת שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה נתעסק משה רבינו בעצמות יוסף להראות שהוא הזוכה ומזכה לישראל בביזה ושלהם נטלו, וז"ש במכילתא בא וראה חכמתו של משה שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק במצות וא"ש הקישור.
translation: And furthermore, behold, Israel engaged in plunder according to the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and certainly, the Lord would not command to take the property of others unjustly. Many explanations have been given regarding this, and the truth is that all the wealth of Egypt rightfully belongs to Israel, as they earned it through Joseph the Righteous, as it is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (Parashat Vayigash, Remez 158): "And Joseph gathered all the money," Rabbi Judah said in the name of Samuel, "All the silver and gold in the world was gathered by Joseph and brought to Egypt," as it is said, "And Joseph gathered all the money." It is only in the land of Egypt; from where do we know about the land of Canaan and other lands? The verse states, "And all the land came to Egypt." And when Israel ascended from Egypt, they took it with them, as it is said, "And they plundered the Egyptians." Thus, it is clear that according to the law, it belongs to Israel, which Joseph the Righteous earned for them. However, after his passing, the Egyptians took it from them unjustly, and when Israel left Egypt, they reclaimed their own from them. Therefore, at the time when all of Israel was engaged in plunder, Moses our Rabbi was occupied with the bones of Joseph to show that he is the one who earned and grants Israel their rightful share in the plunder. And this is what is stated in the Mekilta: "Come and see the wisdom of Moses, for all of Israel was engaged in plunder, and he was occupied with commandments," and this clarifies the connection.
summary: The passage discusses the legitimacy of the Israelites taking wealth from the Egyptians during the Exodus, emphasizing that this act was in accordance with divine command and rooted in justice. It cites the Midrash, explaining that the wealth belonged to the Israelites by right, as it was originally acquired by Joseph for their benefit. Moses' focus on retrieving Joseph's bones amidst the plunder symbolizes the rightful claim of the Israelites to the wealth, reinforcing the idea that their actions were not mere theft but a restoration of what was theirs. This highlights the Hasidic belief in divine providence and the righteousness of the Jewish people's mission.

passage_content: ונבואלתרץ קושית המפורשים על מ"ש רש"י ז"ל בשם המכילתא למה לא השביע יוסף את בניו שישאוהו לא"י מיד כמו שהשביע יעקב וכו', ולכאורה הול"ל קושיא זאת לעיל בפ' ויחי אצל סיפור השבועה זאת, (עיין קושיא א' לעיל), ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק פ' תרומה (דף קמ"א ע"ב) גופיהון דצדיקיא דלא מתענגי בהאי עלמא אלא מתענוגי דמצוה וכו' ההוא רוח מסאבא לא יכיל לשלטאה עלייהו, דהא לא אתענגו מדילי' כלום וכו', מאן דנשמתיה נפקא לבר מארעא קדישא, והאי גופא אסתאב בההוא רוח מסאבו וכו', ואי האי גופא סלקין לי' לאתקברא גו ארעא קדישא, עלי' כתיב (ירמיה ב') ותבואו ותטמאו את ארצי ונחלתי שמתם לתועבה וכו' יוסף לא שליט על גופי' רוח מסאבו לעלמין וכו', ועם כל דא לא בעא דגופי' יסלקון לי' לאתקברא בארעא קדישא, אלא אמר והעליתם את עצמותי ולא גופי', יעקב לא מית וגופי' אתקיים בקיומא תדיר ולא דחיל לסט"א וכו', ועל דא כתיב ושכבתי עם אבותי ונשאתני ממצרים גופא שלים עכ"ד הזוה"ק לענינינו, הרי מבואר הטעם שלא השביע יוסף לבניו שישאוהו לא"י מיד, שלא יהי' בכלל ונחלתי שמתם לתועבה, ואף דלפי מדריגת קדושתו לא שייך לגבי', דלא שליט בי' רוח מסאבא כלל, מ"מ לרוב ענותנותו חשש ונמנע להעלות גופו לטעם זה, ואפשר דע"כ לא הקשו במכילתא התם למה לא השביע יוסף את בניו שישאוהו לא"י מיד, דניחא להו בתירוץ הזוה"ק הנ"ל, אמנם בפסוק זה דכתיב ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו עמו במחיצתו, מבואר מזה דאין בו דין טומאה כלל, דצדיקים אינם מטמאים אף במותם, ומעתה לא יונח עוד בטעמו של הזוה"ק, ע"כ הוקשה להם מ"ט לא השביע לבניו שישאוהו לא"י מיד, ותירצו כי חשש שמא לא יניחום המצרים ולא יוכלו לקיים שבועתו, ואפשר שמקושר טעם זה עם טעם הזוה"ק, דלצד שחשד א"ע שאינו ראוי לכך, ע"כ חש שמא לא יסתייע מילתא ויעכבו המצריים בידם, ולטעם זה השביעם לשיגאלו ויצאו ממצרים יעלו את עצמותיו, (ועיין בדברינו פ' ויחי עמוד תקי"ז מ"ש בזה).
translation: And the question arises regarding the explanation of Rashi, of blessed memory, in the name of the Mechilta, as to why Joseph did not swear his sons to carry him to the Land of Israel immediately, as Jacob had sworn, etc. At first glance, this question should have been raised earlier in Parashat Vayechi, in connection with the story of that oath (see the first question above). It will be clarified by first explaining the words of the Zohar in Parashat Terumah (page 131b), regarding the righteous who do not take pleasure in this world but in the pleasures of the mitzvah, etc. That spirit of impurity cannot dominate them, for they do not take pleasure in anything of theirs, etc. Whoever's soul departs from the Holy Land, that very thing is bound to that spirit of impurity, etc. And if that very thing ascends to be buried in the Holy Land, it is written about it (Jeremiah 2): "And you came and defiled My land, and made My inheritance an abomination," etc. Joseph did not allow the spirit of impurity to rule over him, etc. And despite all this, he did not want his body to be removed to be buried in the Holy Land, but rather said, "And you shall carry my bones up," not my body. Jacob did not die, and his body remains in a constant state of existence and did not fear the Other Side, etc. Therefore, it is written, "And I will lie with my fathers, and you shall carry me out of Egypt," meaning his body is whole. Thus, it is clear why Joseph did not swear his sons to carry him to the Land of Israel immediately, so that he would not be included in "and made My inheritance an abomination." And even though according to his level of holiness it does not apply to him, for the spirit of impurity has no dominion over him at all, nevertheless, out of great humility, he was concerned and refrained from raising his body for this reason. It is possible that this is why they did not ask in the Mechilta why Joseph did not swear his sons to carry him to the Land of Israel immediately, for they were satisfied with the answer of the Zohar mentioned above. However, in the verse that states, "And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him," it is clear from this that there is no law of impurity at all, for the righteous do not defile even in their death. From now on, it will not rest on the reasoning of the Zohar, therefore it was difficult for them why he did not swear his sons to carry him to the Land of Israel immediately. They answered that he was concerned that the Egyptians would not allow them and they would not be able to fulfill his oath. It is possible that this reason is connected to the reason of the Zohar, that on the one hand he suspected himself of being unworthy of this, therefore he was concerned that perhaps the matter would not succeed and the Egyptians would hold them back. For this reason, he swore them to redeem themselves and when they leave Egypt, they should take his bones up (and see our words in Parashat Vayechi, page 117 regarding this).
summary: המעבר עוסק בשאלה מדוע לא השביע יוסף את בניו לשאת את עצמותיו לארץ ישראל מיד, ומבאר זאת על פי דברי הזוה"ק. יוסף, למרות קדושתו, חשש שמא לא יניחו לו המצרים לקיים את שבועתו, ולכן ביקש מהם להעלות את עצמותיו רק לאחר שיגאלו ממצרים. המאמר מדגיש את ענוותנותו של יוסף ואת ההבנה כי צדיקים אינם מטמאים גם במותם, מה שמחזק את הרעיון של קדושת הארץ והקשר בין הגוף לנשמה.

passage_content: ויקחמשה את עצמות יוסף עמו, במס' סוטה (י"ג ע"א) בא וראה כמה חביבות מצות על משה רבינו, שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק במצות שנא' חכם לב יקח מצות וגו' ומנין היה יודע משה רבינו היכן יוסף קבור, אמרו סרח בת אשר נשתיירה מאותו הדור, הלך משה אצלה א"ל כלום את יודעת היכן יוסף קבור, אמרה לו ארון של מתכת עשו לו המצרים וקבעוהו בנילוס וכו', וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל דגם שאר ארונות של השבטים העלו עמהם וכו', אבל היו יודעין קבורתם, משא"כ ביוסף שהעלימו המצרים קבורתו וכו', ולהכי קבעי מנין הי' יודע משה היכן יוסף קבור, דאינו דומה שידע זה בנבואה כיון שלא הוזכר בקרא, אבל ידע ע"י סרח בת אשר שהוא היתה מאותו הדור עכ"ל המהרש"אז"ל, לכאורה תירוצו אינו מספיק דאינו מן הנמנע שהשיג משרע"ה בנבואה מקום קבורתו של יוסף ואף שלא הוזכר בקרא, וכמו שהשיג הרבה דברים נעלמים שאינם מפורשים בפסוקי התורה, ומאי קא קשיא לי' לגמ' מנין היה משה רבינו יודע וכו', גם צ"ב הקישור אל מה שדרשו חכם לב יקח מצות וגו' ומנין הי' יודע משה רבינו וכו', ומדוע ל"ק להו בל"ז, וכן דקדק ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה (בפ' בשלח).
translation: And he took the bones of Joseph with him. In the tractate Sotah (13a), come and see how beloved the commandments are to our teacher Moses, for all of Israel were occupied with the spoils, and he was occupied with the commandments, as it is said, "A wise heart will acquire commandments," etc. And how did our teacher Moses know where Joseph was buried? They said, Sarch bat Asher, who remained from that generation, he went to her and said to her, "Do you know where Joseph is buried?" She said to him, "The Egyptians made for him a metal coffin and placed it in the Nile," etc. And the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, wrote that also the other coffins of the tribes were brought up with them, etc., but they knew their burial places, unlike Joseph, whose burial place the Egyptians concealed, etc. Therefore, the question is, how did Moses know where Joseph was buried? It is not comparable that he knew this through prophecy since it was not mentioned in the verse, but he knew through Sarch bat Asher, who was from that generation, thus said the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed. At first glance, his answer is not sufficient, for it is not impossible that Moshe Rabbeinu received through prophecy the location of Joseph's burial, even though it was not mentioned in the verse, just as he grasped many hidden matters that are not explicitly stated in the verses of the Torah. And what is the Gemara's question, "How did our teacher Moses know?" Also, it is puzzling the connection to what they expounded, "A wise heart will acquire commandments," etc., and why it was not stated to them in a different way. And thus, it was noted by the Yismach Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parshat Beshalach).
summary: הפסוק מתאר את משה רבינו שמקפיד על מצוות, במיוחד בהבאת עצמות יוסף ממצרים, בעוד שיתר ישראל עסוקים בביזה. המהרש"א מסביר שמשה ידע היכן יוסף קבור בזכות סרח בת אשר, שהייתה נותרה מהדור ההוא, מה שמדגיש את חשיבות המסורת והזיכרון ההיסטורי. השאלה מדוע לא ניתן היה לדעת זאת בנבואה מצביעה על הקשר בין חכמה רוחנית לבין ידע מעשי, ומדגישה את הערך של מצוות גם במצבים קשים.

passage_content: ב)הקשה ק"ז זלה"ה דמשמע דדרשו חז"ל רישא דקרא חכם לב יקח מצות, בשבח משרע"ה שהיתה המצוה חביבה עליו, וסיפא דקרא ואויל שפתים ילבט על ישראל שנתעסקו בביזה (עיין בח"א מהרש"א שם) ולכאורה יש להפליא דהרי עסקו בביזה שלא ברצונם, כ"א נצטוו על זה מפי הגבורה וקיימו בזה מצות הבוי"ת, ומה דשבקו העסק בעצמות יוסף למשרע"ה, מבואר שם בגמ' דכוונתם לש"ש היתה ואמרו כבודו בגדולים יותר מבקטנים.
translation: In the difficult passage of K"Z, it is implied that our Sages interpreted the beginning of the verse "A wise heart will acquire commandments" as a praise for Moshe Rabbeinu, that the commandment was dear to him, and the end of the verse "but a fool's lips will bring about strife" refers to Israel who were engaged in plunder (see in Chiddushei Ha'Rashash there). At first glance, it is astonishing, for they were engaged in plunder against their will, as they were commanded to do so from the mouth of the Almighty and fulfilled the commandment of the Blessed One. And regarding their leaving the engagement with the bones of Yosef for Moshe Rabbeinu, it is explained there in the Gemara that their intention was for the sake of Heaven, and they said that his honor is greater among the great than among the small.
summary: The passage discusses the dual interpretation of the verse "A wise heart will acquire commandments," highlighting the praise of Moses for valuing the commandments. It contrasts this with the behavior of the Israelites, who engaged in plunder not out of desire but as a divine command, thus fulfilling God's will. The text emphasizes the intention behind their actions, suggesting that their focus was on serving God rather than personal gain, as illustrated by their prioritization of honoring the deceased Joseph over their own interests. This reflects a deeper Hasidic teaching on the importance of intention and devotion in fulfilling divine commandments.

passage_content: ג)יל"ד דדרשו חכם לב יקח מצות על משרע"ה שנתעסק בעצמות יוסף, ואין זו אלא מצוה א', ומה דדרשו אויל שפתים ילבט על ישראל שעסקו בביזה צ"ב דאין ענין זה לשפתים.
translation: 3) It is said that the wise-hearted will take commandments regarding Moshe Rabbeinu, who was involved with the bones of Yosef, and this is but one commandment. And what is said, "A fool's lips will bring strife" regarding Israel who were engaged in plunder, is a question of why this matter pertains to lips.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of engaging deeply with the mitzvot, particularly in the context of Moses' involvement with the bones of Joseph, which is seen as a singular, profound commandment. It contrasts this with the superficiality of those who merely speak about Israel's plunder, suggesting that true understanding and connection to the divine come from sincere action rather than empty words. This reflects a core Hasidic belief in the importance of heartfelt devotion and the transformative power of mitzvot in one's spiritual journey.

passage_content: ויתבארהענין בהקדם דברי המדרש (ילקוט סו"פ ברכה רמז תתקס"ה) ויקבור אותו בגי, במה זכה משה שהקב"ה נתעסק בו, אלא בשעה שהיו ישראל עסוקין בביזה, הי' מסבב את העיר ג' ימים וג' לילות למצוא ארונו של יוסף ולא מצאו, אחר שנתיגע הרבה פגעה בו סרח בת אשר, אמרה לו רבינו משה למה אתה יגע כל כך אמר לה ג' ימים וג' לילות סבבתי את העיר לבקש ארונו של יוסף ואיני מוצאו, אמרה לו בוא עמי הוליכו לנהר נילוס וכו', א"ל הקב"ה אם בעיניך דבר קטן שעשית חסד, גדול הוא בעיני שלא השגחת בכסף וזהב, ואף אני ארד בכבודי ובעצמי לעשות עמך חסד כשתפטר מן העולם עכ"ד המדרש ולכאורה צ"ב דהרי הג' ימים וג' לילות שהי' משרע"ה מסבב את העיר למצוא ארונו של יוסף, היו בהכרח ג' ימים סמוך ליציאתם, ויתכן שהי' בג' ימי אפילה, דלפי חשבון הרמב"ן ז"ל (בר"פ בא) נמשכו ימי האפילה עד ערב פסח עיי"ש, וישראל עסקו בהשאלת כליהם של מצרים רק אחר מכת בכורות, כמבואר בפסוקים ותחזק מצרים על העם למהר לשלחם וגו' ובנ"י עשו כדבר משה וישאלו ממצרים וגו', ולפי"ז לא היו בזמן א' וביום א', וצ"ב לשון הילקוט הנ"ל בשעה שהיו ישראל עסוקין בביזה, הי' משרע"ה מסבב את העיר ג' ימים וג' לילות, גם דברי הגמ' דסוטה הנ"ל צ"ב, במ"ש שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק בעצמות יוסף, והרי זמנו של זה לא כזמנו של זה. ואיך דרשוהו רז"ל בשבח משה שלא השגיח בכסף וזהב וכו' ובגנותן של ישראל דשבקו העסק בעצמות יוסף ועסקו בביזה ולא קרב זל"ז בזמן וצ"ב.
translation:
And the matter will be clarified by prefacing the words of the Midrash (Yalkut, end of Parashat Berachah, Remez 1065): "And he buried him in the valley." What did Moses do to merit that the Holy One, Blessed be He, engaged with him? Rather, at the time when Israel was occupied with the spoils, he was circling the city for three days and three nights to find the coffin of Joseph, but he did not find it. After he had exerted himself greatly, he encountered Serach bat Asher, who said to him, "Our teacher Moses, why are you toiling so much?" He replied, "For three days and three nights I have been circling the city to seek the coffin of Joseph, and I cannot find it." She said to him, "Come with me, I will lead you to the Nile River," etc. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "If in your eyes it is a small matter that you did kindness, it is great in My eyes that you did not concern yourself with silver and gold. And I too will descend in My glory and personally do kindness with you when you depart from this world." Thus far the Midrash. 

And at first glance, it is difficult to understand, for the three days and three nights that Moshe Rabbeinu was circling the city to find the coffin of Joseph must have necessarily been three days close to their departure. It is possible that it was during the three days of darkness, for according to the calculation of the Ramban (in Parashat Bo), the days of darkness extended until the eve of Passover, as noted there. And Israel was occupied with borrowing the vessels of the Egyptians only after the plague of the firstborn, as is explained in the verses: "And the Egyptians urged the people to hasten to send them away," etc., and the children of Israel did as Moses had spoken and asked of the Egyptians, etc. According to this, they were not at the same time, and it is difficult to understand the language of the aforementioned Yalkut: "At the time when Israel was occupied with the spoils, Moshe Rabbeinu was circling the city for three days and three nights." The words of the Gemara in Sotah are also difficult, in that it states that all of Israel was engaged in the spoils while he was occupied with the bones of Joseph, and the time of this one is not the time of that one. How did our Sages interpret this in praise of Moses, that he did not concern himself with silver and gold, etc., and in condemnation of Israel, that they abandoned the engagement with the bones of Joseph and occupied themselves with the spoils, and they did not draw near to one another in time? This is also difficult to understand.
summary: The passage discusses the merit of Moses in seeking the bones of Joseph while the Israelites were preoccupied with plundering the Egyptians. It highlights the contrast between Moses's selfless act of kindness, which was deemed significant by God, and the Israelites' focus on material wealth. The text raises questions about the timing of these events, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the nature of true devotion and the value of prioritizing spiritual over material pursuits. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of acts of kindness and the divine recognition they receive, even amidst collective distractions.

passage_content: ונל"פדמה שעסקו ישראל בהשאלת כלי המצריים אחר מכת בכורות, יפה עשו וכדין עשו וקיימו מצות הבוי"ת, אבל בג' ימי האפילה שנתעסקו ישראל לחפש בתי המצרים, ובאותו זמן נתייגע משה רבינו למצוא ארונו של יוסף, לזה דרשוהו רז"ל בשבח משה וגנותן של ישראל, דאף שהי' רצון הבוי"ת שיראו ישראל כליהם כמבואר במד"ר דזו א' מהטעמים שהביא הקב"ה חשך על המצריים, אולם להשלים רצון הבוי"ת הי' מספיק בראי' בעלמא ובזמן קצר, ונחשב לחסרון מה שהרבו ההתעסקות בו, כדמשמע מדברי הילקוט הנ"ל שג' ימים וג' לילות שהיה משרע"ה מסבב את העיר לחפש ארונו של יוסף, היו ישראל עסוקין בביזה, ולזה דרשו רז"ל ואויל שפתים ילבט על ישראל, דעצם לקיחת הביזה מצוה הוא, והחסרון הי' מה שהרבו דבר שפתים בענין הביזה, ולא בעסק עצמות יוסף, והגם דלישא ארונו של יוסף כבודו יותר בגדולים ומה"ט הניחוהו למשרע"ה, אבל מה שנתייגע משרע"ה ג' ימים וג' לילות למצוא ארונו של יוסף, הי"ל לישראל להצטרף עמו ולהתעסק במצוה זו והם היו עסוקים בביזה.
translation: And it is explained that the Israelites engaged in borrowing the vessels of the Egyptians after the plague of the firstborn; they did well and acted according to the law, fulfilling the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He. However, during the three days of darkness, the Israelites were occupied with searching the houses of the Egyptians, and at that time, Moshe Rabbeinu was laboring to find the coffin of Yosef. For this, our Sages praised Moshe and criticized the Israelites, for although it was the will of the Holy One, Blessed be He, that the Israelites should see their vessels, as explained in the Midrash that this is one of the reasons the Holy One brought darkness upon the Egyptians, nevertheless, to fulfill the will of the Holy One, it would have sufficed to see them in a brief moment. It was considered a shortcoming that they prolonged their engagement in it, as is implied from the words of the aforementioned Yalkut, that for three days and three nights, Moshe Rabbeinu was circling the city searching for the coffin of Yosef, while the Israelites were occupied with plunder. Therefore, our Sages said, "A fool with lips will argue against Israel," for the very act of taking the plunder is a commandment, and the shortcoming was that they spoke excessively about the plunder and not about the matter of the bones of Yosef. And although carrying the coffin of Yosef is more honorable for the great ones, and for this reason they left it to Moshe Rabbeinu, nonetheless, the fact that Moshe Rabbeinu labored for three days and three nights to find the coffin of Yosef, the Israelites should have joined him and engaged in this commandment, while they were occupied with plunder.
summary: The passage discusses the actions of the Israelites after the plague of the firstborn, highlighting their engagement in taking the Egyptians' possessions as a fulfillment of divine command. However, it contrasts this with Moses' dedication to finding Joseph's coffin, suggesting that while the Israelites' actions were commendable, their excessive focus on material gain was a shortcoming. The text emphasizes the importance of prioritizing spiritual obligations, as Moses' search for Joseph's remains was a significant mitzvah that deserved communal support. Ultimately, it reflects on the tension between physical and spiritual pursuits in the context of divine will.

passage_content: ואפשרשהעלימו מן השמים ממשרע"ה השגת ידיעה זו היכן יוסף קבור, כדי שתהי' פעולת מצותו יתירה, ובכל פסיעה ופסיעה שנתייגע למצוא ארונו של יוסף קיים מצוה וקבל שכר, וע"ד שאמרז"ל (בב"ר פ' ל"ט סימן ט') באברהם שא"ל הקב"ה אלהארץ אשר אראך ולמה לא גילה לו מיד, כדי לחבבה בעיניו וליתן שכר על כל פסיעה ופסיעה, ולזה דרשו רז"ל חכם לב יקח מצות על משרע"ה, שנתייגע למצוא ארונו של יוסף וקיים בזה מצות הרבה בכל פסיעה ופסיעה, וא"ש הקישור ומנין הי' יודע משה רבינו היכן יוסף קבור, דכיון שהעלימו מן השמים ידיעה זו ממנו כדי להרבות שכרו, א"כ מנין הי' יודע, ותירצו דאחר שנתייגע הרבה פגעה בו סרח בת אשר והראה לו מקום קבורתו.
translation: And it is possible that they concealed from the heavens from Moshe Rabbeinu the knowledge of where Yosef is buried, so that the performance of his commandment would be greater, and with every step he took in his effort to find the coffin of Yosef, he would fulfill a commandment and receive reward. This is in accordance with what our sages said (in Bereishit Rabbah, Parashah 39, Section 9) regarding Avraham, to whom the Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "To the land that I will show you," and why He did not reveal it to him immediately, in order to endear it in his eyes and to give reward for every step he took. And for this reason, our sages expounded that a wise heart will acquire commandments on Moshe Rabbeinu, who toiled to find the coffin of Yosef and fulfilled many commandments with every step he took. And it is clear how Moshe Rabbeinu would know where Yosef was buried, for since this knowledge was concealed from him by the heavens in order to increase his reward, how would he know? They answered that after he toiled greatly, he encountered Serach bat Asher, who showed him the place of his burial.
summary: The passage discusses the divine concealment of Joseph's burial place from Moses to enhance the merit of his search for it, emphasizing the Hasidic idea that spiritual rewards are linked to effort and perseverance in fulfilling commandments. It parallels the biblical narrative of Abraham, where God withheld immediate knowledge to increase the value of his journey. Ultimately, after much toil, Moses was guided to the location by the daughter of Asher, illustrating the belief that divine assistance follows sincere effort in seeking truth and fulfilling mitzvot. This reflects a broader theological insight into the relationship between human endeavor and divine reward in the pursuit of holiness.

passage_content: ויגדלמלך מצרים כי ברח העם, פרש"י איקטורין שלח עמהם, וכיון שהגיעו לג' ימים שקבעו לילך ולשוב וראו שאינן חוזרין למצרים, באו והגידו לפרעה ביום ד', ובחמישי ובששי רדפו אחריהם וליל שביעי ירדו לים בשחרית אמרו שירה והוא יום ז' של פסח: לכן אנו קורין השירה ביום השביעי עכ"ל רש"י ז"ל, והקשה הרא"ם ז"ל דמהכא משמע שלא שהו ישראל משיצאו ממצרים עד שאמרו שירה רק ז' ימים, ובסו"פ שלח כתב רשיז"ל מיסודו של ר' משה הדרשן שמנה ימים שהו ישראל משיצאו ממצרים עד שאמרו שירה, ושמא י"ל שר' משה הדרשן חולק עם האגדה האומרה בז' אמרו שירה עכ"ל הרא"ם, ותירוצו קשה דלא יתכן לומר שיחלקו במציאות, ויותר קשה דמפורש בגמ' (סוטה י"ב ע"ב) דבכ"א בניסן אמרו ישראל שירה, ומפורש בפסוק (במדבר ל"ג ג') ויסעו מרעמסס וגו' בחמשה עשר יום לחודש הראשון וגו', נמצא שביום הז' אמרו שירה, ואיך יחלוק ר"מ הדרשן על זה.
translation: And the king of Egypt grew strong because the people had fled. Rashi explains that he sent Ikhtorin with them, and when they reached the three days they had set to go and return, and saw that they were not returning to Egypt, they came and told Pharaoh on the fourth day. On the fifth and sixth, they pursued them, and on the night of the seventh, they descended to the sea at dawn and sang a song, and it is the seventh day of Passover. Therefore, we read the song on the seventh day. Thus far is Rashi's commentary. The Ra'ah questions that from here it seems that Israel did not stay from the time they left Egypt until they sang the song for only seven days, while at the end of Shelach, Rashi wrote based on the foundation of Rabbi Moshe the preacher that Israel stayed for seven days from the time they left Egypt until they sang the song. Perhaps one could say that Rabbi Moshe the preacher disagrees with the legend that states they sang the song on the seventh day. Thus far is the Ra'ah's commentary, and his answer is difficult, for it is not reasonable to say that they would disagree in reality, and it is even more difficult since it is explicitly stated in the Gemara (Sotah 12b) that on the twenty-first of Nisan, Israel sang a song, and it is explicitly stated in the verse (Numbers 33:3) that they departed from Rameses on the fifteenth day of the first month, thus it turns out that on the seventh day they sang a song, and how could Rabbi Moshe the preacher disagree with this.
summary: The passage discusses the timeline of the Israelites' exodus from Egypt and their subsequent song of praise at the Sea of Reeds, emphasizing the significance of the seventh day of Passover when they sang. It highlights a debate among scholars regarding the duration of their journey before singing, with some asserting it was only seven days while others suggest a longer period. This tension reflects deeper theological insights into the nature of redemption and the relationship between divine intervention and human experience. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of song and gratitude in the context of liberation and spiritual awakening.

passage_content: ונקדיםעוד קושית המזרחי (בפ' יתרו) עה"פ ואשא אתכם על כנפי נשרים, פרש"י (מדברי המכילתא) זה יום שבאו ישראל לרעמסס, שהיו ישראל מפוזרין בכל ארץ גושן. ולשעה קלה כשבאו ליסע ולצאת נקבצו כולם לרעמסס, אבל בפ' בא בפסוק ויסעו בנ"י מרעמסס סכותה, אמרו במכילתא והביאו רש"י בפירושו, ק"כ מיל הי' ובאו שם לפי שעה שנאמר ואשא אתכם על כנפי נשרים. (ולפי"ז הנס של כנפי נשרים נעשה להם בנסיעתם מרעמסס לסוכות), ושמאי"ל שקול הוא ויבואו שניהם, דתרווייהו משתמעי מהאי קרא עכ"ל הרא"ם ז"ל, ר"ל דתרווייהו הי' ע"י כנפי נשרים ובשעה קלה שלא כדרך הטבע, אמנם לפי"ז צ"ב מ"ש רשיז"ל כאן (בפ' בשלח) עה"פ ויסעו מסוכות וגו' ביום השני, שהרי בראשון באו מרעמסס לסוכות, ולפי"ד המכילתא ורש"י ז"ל (בפ' בא) שנסיעתם מרעמסס לסוכות על כנפי נשרים ובשעה קלה הי', א"כ אין מוכרח שנסיעתם מסוכות ביום השני הי', והי' אפשר שיהי' הכל ביום א', כיון שלא הי' דרך הטבע כלל.
translation: And we will further advance the question of the Mizrachi (in Parashat Yitro) on the verse "And I bore you on the wings of eagles." Rashi explains (from the words of the Mechilta) that this is the day the Israelites came to Raamses, as the Israelites were scattered throughout the land of Goshen. For a brief moment, when they came to depart and leave, they all gathered in Raamses. However, in Parashat Bo, in the verse "And the children of Israel journeyed from Raamses to Succoth," it is said in the Mechilta, and Rashi brought it in his commentary, that it was 210 mil, and they came there for a moment, as it is said, "And I bore you on the wings of eagles." (According to this, the miracle of the wings of eagles occurred during their journey from Raamses to Succoth.) And it is understood that both are equal, and both came, as both are derived from this verse, thus said the Ra'ah"m, may his memory be blessed, meaning that both were by the wings of eagles and in a brief moment, not in the natural way. However, according to this, it is difficult what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, says here (in Parashat Beshalach) on the verse "And they journeyed from Succoth" etc. on the second day, since on the first they came from Raamses to Succoth, and according to the Mechilta and Rashi, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Bo) that their journey from Raamses to Succoth was on the wings of eagles and in a brief moment, then it is not necessary that their journey from Succoth on the second day was, and it would have been possible for it all to be on the first day, since there was no natural way at all.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous journey of the Israelites from Raamses to Sukkot, emphasizing the concept of divine intervention as expressed in the phrase "I carried you on the wings of eagles." It highlights the idea that this journey occurred in a supernatural manner, transcending natural limitations. The text raises a question regarding the timing of the departure from Sukkot, suggesting that if the initial journey was miraculous, there is no necessity for a subsequent day of travel. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine assistance and the extraordinary experiences of the Jewish people during their exodus.

passage_content: ונקדיםעוד דברי המכילתא (פ' בא) עה"פ ויסעו בנ"י מרעמסס סכתה וגו', ק"כ מיל, כהרף עין נסעו בנ"י מרעמסס לסוכות, לקיים מ"ש ואשא אתכם על כנפי נשרים. סכותה סכות ממש וכו' דברי ר' אליעזר, ר"ע אומר אין סוכות אלא ענני הכבוד וכו' עכ"ד המכילתא, ובמרכבת המשנה הקשה איכא למידק למ"ד סוכות ממש עשו להם, הלא נאסרו במלאכת יו"ט במצרים, וזה הי' ביום ט"ו איך עשו מלאכה ובנו סוכות, אם לא כשיטת הפסיקתא פ' מסעי דביאתם לסוכות הי' ביום ט"ז והוא הנקרא מחרת הפסח, ואף דחוה"מ הי' דאסור ג"כ בעשיית מלאכה. אפשר שעדיין לא הוזהרו אשביתת חוה"מ, כמו שלא נזהרו אחימוץ אלא יום א' עכ"ל המרכבת.
translation: And we will precede with more words from the Mechilta (Parashat Bo) on the verse "And the children of Israel journeyed from Rameses to Succoth," which is 120 mil. In the blink of an eye, the children of Israel journeyed from Rameses to Succoth, to fulfill what is said, "And I bore you on the wings of eagles." Succoth is actual booths, etc., the words of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Akiva says there are no Succoth except the Clouds of Glory, etc. Thus concludes the Mechilta. And in the Merkevet HaMishnah, it is difficult to understand how those who say they made actual booths, for they were prohibited from work on Yom Tov in Egypt, and this was on the 15th day, how could they do work and build booths, unless according to the opinion of the Pesikta in Parashat Masei that their arrival at Succoth was on the 16th, which is called the day after Passover, and even though it was the intermediate days of the festival, which is also prohibited for work. It is possible that they were not yet warned about the cessation of work during the intermediate days, just as they were not careful about the leavening except for one day. Thus concludes the Merkevet.
summary: The passage discusses the journey of the Israelites from Raamses to Sukkot, emphasizing the miraculous nature of their travel, akin to being carried on the wings of eagles. It presents differing interpretations of "Sukkot," with Rabbi Eliezer suggesting they built actual booths, while Rabbi Akiva posits that they were enveloped in divine clouds of glory. The text raises questions about the feasibility of constructing these booths during the holiday, suggesting that the Israelites may not have been fully aware of the prohibitions against work at that time. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine providence and human action during the Exodus.

passage_content: ותירוצוצ"ב דהרי מפורש בתורה (פ' מסעי ל"ג ג') ויסעו מרעמסס בחדש הראשון בחמשה עשר יום וגו' ממחרת הפסח וגו', והתוס' במס' קדושין (ל"ז ע"ב) הביאו ראי' מהאי קרא, דממחרת הפסח משמעותו ממחרת שחיטת הפסח דהיינו יום ט"ו, שבו נסעו ישראל מרעמסס כמפורש בקרא עייש"ד התוס', וכיון שנסיעתם מרעמסס לסוכות כהרף עין ועל כנפי נשרים הי', ויצאו מרעמסס ביום ט"ו איך לא הגיעו לסוכות עד יום ט"ז, אם לא שנדחוק דר"א דס"ל סוכות ממש, והפסיקתא דפ' מסעי דס"ל ביום ט"ז הגיעו לסוכות, חולקים על שיטה זו דנסיעתם מרעמסס לסוכות על כנפי נשרים וכהרף עין הי', אמנם בלא"ה קשה דהרי ק"כ מיל מרעמסס לסוכות, ומהלך אדם בינוני י' פרסה ליום דהיינו ארבעים מיל, נמצא ק"כ מיל הוא מהלך ג' ימים בדרך הטבע, ואף לדברי הפסיקתא שביום ט"ז הגיעו לסוכות עכ"ח בדרך נס הי', וא"כ מ"ט מוכרחלומר שלא הגיעו לסוכות עד יום ט"ז, ושמא ביום ט"ו שנסעו מרעמסס, מיד כהרף עין הגיעו לסוכות.
translation: And the answer is that it is explicitly stated in the Torah (Numbers 33:3) "And they traveled from Rameses in the first month on the fifteenth day," etc., "the day after Passover," etc. The Tosafot in Tractate Kiddushin (37b) bring a proof from this verse, that "the day after Passover" means the day after the slaughtering of the Passover, which is the fifteenth day, on which Israel traveled from Rameses as is explicitly stated in the Tosafot. And since their journey from Rameses to Sukkot was in the blink of an eye and on the wings of eagles, and they left Rameses on the fifteenth day, how could they not have reached Sukkot until the sixteenth day, unless we force the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer who holds that Sukkot is literally, and the Pesikta of Parashat Masei which holds that on the sixteenth day they arrived at Sukkot, disagrees with this view that their journey from Rameses to Sukkot was on the wings of eagles and in the blink of an eye. However, even so, it is difficult, for it is one hundred and twenty mil from Rameses to Sukkot, and an average person walks ten parasangs a day, which is forty mil, thus one hundred and twenty mil is a journey of three days by natural means. And even according to the words of the Pesikta that on the sixteenth day they arrived at Sukkot, it was certainly by a miracle. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that they did not arrive at Sukkot until the sixteenth day, and perhaps on the fifteenth day when they traveled from Rameses, they immediately arrived at Sukkot in the blink of an eye.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous journey of the Israelites from Raamses to Sukkot, emphasizing the concept of divine intervention in their travel. It highlights the tension between the natural understanding of time and distance, suggesting that their swift arrival at Sukkot on the 16th of Nisan, despite the physical distance, was a result of God's miraculous guidance. The text reflects on the Hasidic belief in the power of faith and divine assistance, illustrating how spiritual realities can transcend natural limitations. Ultimately, it underscores the theme of redemption and the transformative nature of divine presence in the lives of the faithful.

passage_content: ואפ"לעפי"ד הגמ' (שבת פ"ז ע"ב) ששי למאי רבא אמר ששי לחנייתן ר' אחא בר יעקב אמר ששי למסען, וקמפלגי בשבת דמרה, מר סבר אשבת איפקוד אתחומין לא איפקוד, (פרש"י הלכך כשנסעו מרפידים נסעו בשבת, שלא הוזהרו שלא לילך יותר מאלפים אמה) ומר סבר אתחומין נמי איפקוד עיי"ש, והנה על שביתת יו"ט של פסח נצטוו ישראל במצרים טרם שנצטוו על השבת, שנאמר מקרא קודש יהי' לכם וכמ"ש במרכבת לעיל, ורוב פוסקים ס"ל דתחומין נאסרו ביו"ט כמו בשבת, ולפי"ז לא יכלו לנסוע מרעמסס לסוכות ק"כ מיל ביו"ט, די"ב מיל מדאורייתא ואף דנסיעתם בדרך נס ועל כנפי נשרים הי', מ"מ גם בדרך זה איכא איסור תחומין, וראי' מדברי הגמ' (ערובין מ"ג ע"ב) דמספקא לי' אי יש תחומין למעלה מי' או לא, ואי יש תחומין לא אתי אלי' בשבת משום תחומין עיי"ש, וביאת אלי' לא בדרך הטבע יהי' ועכ"ח גם בזה איכא תחומין.
translation: And according to the explanation of the Gemara (Shabbat 87b), the sixth (day) for what? Rava said the sixth for their resting, Rabbi Acha bar Yaakov said the sixth for their traveling, and they argue regarding the Sabbath of Mara. One holds that on the Sabbath, the boundaries are not enforced, while the other holds that the boundaries are indeed enforced. (Rashi explains that therefore when they traveled from Refidim, they traveled on the Sabbath, as they were not warned not to go more than two thousand amot.) And one holds that the boundaries are also enforced. See there. And behold, concerning the resting of Yom Tov of Pesach, Israel was commanded in Egypt before they were commanded about the Sabbath, as it is said, "A holy convocation shall be for you," as mentioned in the chariot above. And most poskim hold that boundaries are prohibited on Yom Tov just as on Shabbat. According to this, they could not travel from Raamses to Sukkot, which is 210 mil on Yom Tov, which is 12 mil according to Torah law. And even though their traveling was in a miraculous way, on the wings of eagles, nevertheless, even in this way, there is a prohibition of boundaries. And proof can be brought from the words of the Gemara (Eruvin 43b) that it is uncertain whether there are boundaries above ten (tefachim) or not, and if there are boundaries, it does not come to me on Shabbat because of boundaries. See there. And the coming of Eliyahu will not be in a natural way, and thus, even in this matter, there are boundaries.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of boundaries (techumim) on Shabbat and Yom Tov, highlighting a debate among sages regarding the permissibility of travel beyond these limits. It emphasizes that the Israelites were commanded to observe the sanctity of Yom Tov before Shabbat, indicating a foundational connection between the two. The text illustrates the tension between divine intervention and natural law, suggesting that even miraculous travel is subject to the same restrictions. Ultimately, it reflects on the importance of adhering to spiritual boundaries as a means of maintaining holiness in time.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר לעניננו דלא יכלו לנסוע מרעמסס לסוכות ביום ט"ו משום איסור תחומין די"ב מיל, אמנם לא יכלו להתמהמה במצרים עוד, וכמ"ש האריז"ל דאלמלי נשתהו עוד רגע במצרים, היו משוקעים בשער הנו"ן של טומאה והוכרחו לצאת מיד, לכן יצאו מרעמסס ביום ט"ו א' דפסח, אך לא הרחיקו לילך חוץ לתחום משום יו"ט, ועמדו מחוץ לעיר כדי שלא יתמהמהו במקום טומאה, וביום ט"ז שהוא חוה"מ נסעו משם לסוכות ק"כ מיל בשעה קלה, ובזה יתיישב לשון הכתוב בפ' מסעי ויסעו מרעמסס בחדש הראשון בחמשה עשר יום וגו', ויסעו בני ישראל מרעמסס ויחנו בסוכות, וצ"ב מדוע כפל הכתוב להזכיר נסיעתם מרעמסס ב"פ וסגי בחדא, ולדרכנו נסעו ישראל מרעמסס ב"פ, ביום ט"ו יצאו מן העיר שלא לשהות במקום טומאה עוד רגע, אבל חנו בעיבורה של עיר בתוך התחום כנ"ל, ולענין הרבה דברים נחשב סמוך ונראה כתוך העיר כמבואר בגמ' מגילה עיי"ש, ע"כ כפל הכתוב עוה"פ ויסעו בנ"י מרעמסס ויחנו בסוכות, וזה הי' ביום ט"ז, ויתיישב בזה שיטת הפסיקתא פ' מסעי וגם תי' המרכבת דביאתם לסוכות ביום ט"ז הי', ואף שביום ט"ו נסעו מרעמסס כמפורש בקרא, ונסיעתם הי' על כנפי נשרים וכהרף עין, מ"מ לא הגיעו לסוכות ביום שיצאו לטעם איסור תחומין כנ"ל.
translation: And in this, it is clarified regarding our matter that they could not travel from Raamses to Sukkot on the 15th day due to the prohibition of boundaries of 12 mil. However, they could not delay any longer in Egypt, as the Arizal states that had they lingered even a moment longer in Egypt, they would have been sunk in the gate of the Nun of impurity and were compelled to leave immediately. Therefore, they left Raamses on the 15th day of Passover, but did not venture outside the boundary due to the holiday, and they stood outside the city so that they would not delay in a place of impurity. On the 16th day, which is Chol Hamoed, they traveled from there to Sukkot, 210 mil in a short time. And with this, the wording of the verse in Parshat Masei is settled: "And they traveled from Raamses in the first month on the fifteenth day," etc., "And the children of Israel traveled from Raamses and camped in Sukkot." It is puzzling why the verse repeats their departure from Raamses twice when one mention would suffice. According to our explanation, the Israelites traveled from Raamses twice: on the 15th they left the city so as not to linger in a place of impurity for even a moment, but they camped within the city limits, as mentioned above. And regarding many matters, it is considered close and visible as if within the city, as explained in the Gemara in Megillah, see there. Therefore, the verse repeats, "And the children of Israel traveled from Raamses and camped in Sukkot," and this was on the 16th. This also aligns with the opinion of the Pesikta in Parshat Masei and also the explanation of the Merkevah that their arrival in Sukkot was on the 16th, and even though on the 15th they traveled from Raamses as explicitly stated in the verse, their travel was on the wings of eagles and in the blink of an eye, nevertheless, they did not reach Sukkot on the day they left due to the prohibition of boundaries, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the journey of the Israelites from Raamses to Sukkot, emphasizing the significance of their departure on the 15th of Nisan and the prohibition of traveling beyond a certain distance on holidays. It highlights the urgency of their exit from Egypt to avoid remaining in a place of impurity, as they were on the brink of spiritual danger. The dual mention of their departure and arrival serves to illustrate the profound connection between their physical journey and spiritual redemption, reflecting the Hasidic belief in the importance of timing and divine intervention in the process of liberation. Ultimately, the text underscores the miraculous nature of their exodus, likening it to soaring on the wings of eagles.

passage_content: ולכאורהאפשר לתרץ בזה סתירת דברי רשיז"ל (עיין לעיל קושיא א'), דאם נחשוב מיציאה ראשונה שהי' ביום ט"ו ניסן, שיצאו רק מתוך העיר שלא לשהות במקום טומאה כנ"ל, אפשר ששהו ישראל ח' ימים עד שאמרו שירה, ואם נחשוב מיציאה השני' שנסעו מתחומה של עיר ביום ע"ז, נמצא ששהו רק ז' ימים עד שאמרו שירה על הים, אמנם אין תירוץ זה מספיק שעדיין יקשה מדברי הגמ' (סוטה י"ב ע"ב הנ"ל) דבכ"א בניסן אמרו ישראל שירה, א"כ אינו אלא ז' ימים אף אם נחשוב מהיציאה של יום ט"ו.
translation: And seemingly, it is possible to resolve the contradiction in the words of the Rebbe Shlita (see above question 1), that if we consider the first departure which was on the 15th of Nisan, when they only left the city in order not to remain in a place of impurity as mentioned, it is possible that the Jews stayed for 8 days until they sang the song. However, if we consider the second departure when they traveled beyond the city limits on the 21st, it turns out that they only stayed for 7 days until they sang the song by the sea. Nevertheless, this resolution is not sufficient, as it is still difficult from the words of the Gemara (Sota 12b as mentioned above) that on the 21st of Nisan the Jews sang a song, thus it is only 7 days even if we consider the departure from the 15th.
summary: The passage discusses a theological dilemma regarding the timing of the Israelites' song of praise after their exodus from Egypt, highlighting a potential contradiction in the interpretation of the timeline. It suggests that if the first departure on the 15th of Nissan is considered, the Israelites could have sung after eight days, while a second departure on the 21st would limit it to seven days. However, this reasoning does not fully resolve the issue, as the Talmud states that the song was sung on the 21st of Nissan, indicating a deeper complexity in understanding the nature of divine timing and human experience in the context of redemption. This reflects key Hasidic themes of the interplay between spiritual elevation and the historical journey of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ואפ"לששהו ונתעכבו ישראל על הים גם יום ח', דלא יכלו ליסע משם בז' של פסח משום תחומין כנ"ל, שהרי נצטוו ביום השביעי מקרא קודש, ועוד טעם בדבר דהרי כל כליהם של המצריים של ע"ז הי', והי' צורך לבטל הע"ז טרם שזכו בה ישראל, דאח"כ אין לו ביטול עולמית, וביו"ט א"א לבטלו דהוי כתיקון מנא, דזהו הכשרן וא"א להשתמש בהם זולת זה, ע"כ לא הי' אפשר להם ליטול ביזת הים ביום ז', ונשארו שם ליום ח' ואמרו עוד הפעם שירה, נמצא שאמרו שירה ביום ז' וביום ח', ומ"ש בגמ' בכ"א בניסן אמרו שירה ומ"ש רש"י בשביעי אמרו שירה ובמקו"א כתב שאמרו שירה לח' ימים כולהו איתנייהו וא"ש.
translation: And even though they delayed and the Israelites were held up at the sea until the eighth day, they could not depart from there on the seventh of Passover due to the boundaries, as mentioned above, for they were commanded on the seventh day to have a holy gathering. Furthermore, there is another reason: all the vessels of the Egyptians were idolatrous, and it was necessary to nullify the idolatry before the Israelites could benefit from them, for afterwards there is no eternal nullification. And on a festival, it is impossible to nullify them, as it is considered a rectification of a vessel, for this is their preparation, and it is impossible to use them except for this purpose. Therefore, it was not possible for them to take the spoils of the sea on the seventh day, and they remained there until the eighth day and sang again. Thus, they sang on both the seventh and the eighth days. And what is stated in the Gemara that on the twenty-first of Nisan they sang, and what Rashi writes that on the seventh they sang, and in other places it is written that they sang for eight days, all of them are consistent and understood.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' delay at the sea until the eighth day of Passover, emphasizing the need to nullify the Egyptian idols before benefiting from their spoils. It highlights the theological concept that true redemption requires the removal of idolatry, which cannot occur on a festival day. The Israelites' singing of praise on both the seventh and eighth days reflects their spiritual elevation and connection to divine redemption. This dual expression of gratitude underscores the importance of recognizing and celebrating God's miracles throughout the Passover period.

passage_content: ויגדלמלך מצרים כי ברח העם וגו', פרש"י ז"ל איקטורין שלח עמהם, וכיון שהגיעו לג' ימים וכו' באו והגידו לפרעה ביום ד', ובחמשה ובששי רדפו אחריהם וליל שביעי ירדו לים, בשחרית אמרו שירה והוא יום ז' של פסח וכו' והקשו המפורשים דבסו"פ שלח כתב רש"י ז"ל שמונה חוטים שבציצית כנגד שמונה ימים ששהו ישראל משיצאו ממצרים עד שאמרו שירה על הים, והוא סתירה.
translation: And the king of Egypt grew strong because the people had fled, etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that he sent Ikhtorin with them. And when they reached three days, etc., they came and told Pharaoh on the fourth day, and on the fifth and sixth, they pursued them, and on the night of the seventh, they descended to the sea. In the morning, they sang a song, and it was the seventh day of Passover, etc. And the commentators questioned that at the end of Parashat Shlach, Rashi, of blessed memory, wrote that the eight threads in the tzitzit correspond to the eight days that the Israelites stayed from the time they left Egypt until they sang a song at the sea, and this is a contradiction.
summary: The passage discusses the timeline of the Israelites' exodus from Egypt, highlighting the significance of the seventh day of Passover when they sang a song of praise at the sea. It raises a theological question regarding the apparent contradiction in the interpretation of the eight threads in tzitzit, which are said to correspond to the eight days from their departure until the song was sung. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the connection between physical liberation and spiritual elevation, emphasizing the importance of gratitude and recognition of divine intervention in moments of salvation. The tension between the timeline and the symbolism of the tzitzit serves to illustrate the complexity of divine timing and human experience in the journey of faith.

passage_content: ב)ישיר משה ובנ"י את השירה הזאת לה' ויאמרו לאמר וגו', יש להבין אומרו ישיר בלשון עתיד והול"ל אז שר משה וגו', גם הכפל ויאמרו לאמר צ"ב.
translation: B) "Then Moses and the children of Israel sang this song to the Lord, and they said, saying, etc." It is necessary to understand why it says "sang" in the future tense, and it could have been said "then Moses sang," etc. Also, the repetition "and they said, saying" is puzzling.
summary: In this passage, the use of the future tense "ישיר" (will sing) suggests a prophetic vision of the ongoing relationship between the Jewish people and God, emphasizing the eternal nature of their praise. The repetition of "ויאמרו לאמר" (and they said to say) highlights the importance of vocalizing faith and the communal aspect of worship. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that the act of singing and declaring faith is not just a historical event but a continuous, living expression of devotion that connects past, present, and future. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that the spiritual journey is marked by an ever-deepening engagement with divine praise.
