passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם דברי החת"ס זלה"ה לפרש בנוסח התפלה וזדים טבעת וידידים העברת ויכסו מים צריהם וכו', על זאת שבחו אהובים וכו' על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו וכו', דיל"ד אחר שכבר אמר על זאת שבחו אהובים מה זה שחזר ואמר על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו וכו', ופי' שהיו בישראל שני כתות, האהובים והידידים שבישראל תיכף כשידידים העברת ויכסו מים צריהם, שבחו והודו להקב"ה שהאמינו בו ית"ש שהציל אותם מיד המצריים, אך שאר העם לא שבחו כי אמרו כשם שאנו עולים מצד זה כך מצרים עולים מצד אחר והמרו על ים בים סוף, עד שרמז הקב"ה ופלטם הים לחוץ כדכתיב וירא ישראל את מצרים מת על שפת הים, וז"פ על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו שירת הים אפילו אותם שאינם אהובים ידידים אלא כולם אמרו שירה עכ"ל היוצא לנו מדבריו הקדושים שאמרו ישראל שירה ב"פ משה רבינו ובני העלי' אמרו שירה מיד כשידידים העברת ויכסו מים צריהם, ושאר העם לא אמרו שירה עד שפלט הים את המצריים ואז חזרו ואמרו כל ישראל שירה: האמנם שממשמעות הלשון נראה שגם הידידים והאהובים לא אמרו שירה עד לאחר שיצאו מן הים ויכסו מים צריהם, ולפי"ז אינו מדוייק כ"כ מה שאמר על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו, שהרי גם כשאמרו הידידים כבר היו על שפת הים, אמנם נראה לומר שהידידים והאהובים אמרו שירה מיד כשנכנסו בתוך הים ביבשה, שהאמינו שהקב"ה יעשה להם נס בשלימות להציל אותם מיד המצריים, וממ"ש על זאת שבחו אהובים וכו' אחר וידידים העברת ויכסו מים צריהם אינו מוכרח שאח"כ שבחו אהובים, אולם מאמר על זאת שבחו סובב על תחלת הענין שאמר וים סוף להם בקעת וכו' ומיד התחילו לומר שירה על שם העתיד שהאמינו בהשי"ת שיגמור הנס בשלימות להציל אותם הצלה גמורה.
translation: And it is appropriate to explain, prior to the words of the Chasam Sofer, may his memory be a blessing, regarding the wording of the prayer, "and the waters covered their foes," etc., that concerning this, the beloved ones praised, etc., "by the sea together all gave thanks," etc. The question arises: after it was already stated that the beloved ones praised, what is the reason that it is repeated, "by the sea together all gave thanks," etc.? The explanation is that there were two groups in Israel, the beloved ones and the friends. Immediately when the friends "and the waters covered their foes," they praised and thanked the Holy One, blessed be He, for they believed in Him, may He be blessed, that He saved them from the hands of the Egyptians. However, the rest of the people did not praise, for they said, "Just as we are going up from this side, so the Egyptians are going up from the other side," and they rebelled in the sea at the Sea of Reeds, until the Holy One, blessed be He, hinted and the sea expelled them outside, as it is written, "And Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the seashore." Thus, "by the sea together all gave thanks" refers to the Song of the Sea, even those who are not beloved friends, but all sang a song. From his holy words, it emerges that Israel sang a song twice: Moses our teacher and the sons of the elevation sang a song immediately when the friends "and the waters covered their foes," and the rest of the people did not sing a song until the sea expelled the Egyptians, and then all of Israel returned and sang a song. Indeed, it seems from the meaning of the language that even the friends and the beloved ones did not sing a song until after they came out of the sea and the waters covered their foes. According to this, it is not so precise what was said, "by the sea together all gave thanks," for even when the friends sang, they were already on the seashore. However, it seems to say that the friends and the beloved ones sang a song immediately when they entered the sea on dry land, for they believed that the Holy One, blessed be He, would perform a complete miracle to save them from the hands of the Egyptians. And from what was said, "for this they praised the beloved ones," etc., after "and the waters covered their foes," it is not necessary to conclude that afterwards the beloved ones praised. However, the statement "for this they praised" refers to the beginning of the matter, as it was said, "And the Sea of Reeds was for them a valley," etc., and immediately they began to sing a song in anticipation of the future, for they believed in the Blessed One that He would complete the miracle to save them completely.
summary: The passage discusses the differing responses of two groups within Israel—those referred to as "the beloved" and "the friends"—during the crossing of the Red Sea. While the beloved immediately praised God for their faith in His salvation, the rest of the people hesitated until they witnessed the complete destruction of the Egyptians. Ultimately, the text emphasizes that all of Israel, regardless of their initial faith, joined in song after experiencing God's miraculous deliverance, highlighting the theme of collective gratitude and the transformative power of witnessing divine intervention. The theological insight reflects the belief in God's ultimate redemption and the unity of the Jewish people in recognizing His greatness.

passage_content: והנהכתבו התוס' (ערכין ט"ו ע"א) שישראל לא עברו הים לרחבו מצד זה לזה, רק הלכו כחצי גורן עגולה ועיין בספר ערבי נחל פרשת בשלח שהאריך לבאר דבריהם ז"ל וכתב שי"ב שבילים היו לי"ב שבטים ועיגול החיצונה הי' גדול מאוד להקיף כל העיגולים הפנימיים עיי"ש, ומובן שמשעה שנכנסו לתוך הים עד שעברו כולם נשתהו זמן רב, ואינו מפורש להדיא כמה שהו בעברם את הים, ויתכן לומר מסברא ששהו יום אחד שלם, כי האנשים לבד היו ששים רבוא והנשים וילדיהם ונוסף עליהם הערב רב שהיו הרבה יותר מישראל וע"כ מסתבר שנשתהו בעברם את הים יום אחד שלם, ואף אם נאמר שעברו כולם את הים בליל שביעי של פסח כנראה מפשטות לשון רש"י והמדרשים, אבל מה שפלט הים את המצריים על שפתו זה וודאי אפ"ל שנשתהה עד יום ח' כי אינו מבואר בדבריהם כלל אימת הי' א"כ י"ל שנתעכבו בתוך הים עד שחרית של יום שמיני ואז פלט אותם הים וחזרו כל ישראל לומר שירה יחד כולם, נמצא דביום אחרון של פסח חזרו ואמרו שירה על שפת הים, ומעתה אין עוד סתירה בדברי רש"י ז"ל דתרווייהו אתנהו, ביום שביעי של פסח אמרו שירה האהובים והידידים מיד, ואח"כ ביום שמיני חזרו כולם יחד ואמרו עוה"פ שירה על שפת הים אחר שפלט הים את המצריים.
translation: And behold, the Tosafot (Erchin 15a) write that Israel did not cross the sea from one side to the other, but rather walked as if in a half-circle, and see in the book "Arvei Nachal," Parashat Beshalach, which elaborates on their words and writes that there were twelve paths corresponding to the twelve tribes, and the outer circle was very large to encompass all the inner circles. It is understood that from the moment they entered the sea until they all crossed, they took a long time, and it is not explicitly stated how long they took in crossing the sea. It can be reasoned that they took a full day, for the men alone were six hundred thousand, and the women and children, in addition to the mixed multitude, were much more than Israel. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that they took a full day in crossing the sea. Even if we say that they all crossed the sea on the night of the seventh of Passover, this is evident from the simple wording of Rashi and the Midrashim. However, regarding the fact that the sea expelled the Egyptians on its shore, it can certainly be said that they delayed until the eighth day, for it is not clarified in their words at what time this was. Therefore, it can be said that they were delayed in the sea until the morning of the eighth day, and then the sea expelled them, and all of Israel returned to sing together. Thus, on the last day of Passover, they returned and sang on the shore of the sea. From now on, there is no contradiction in the words of Rashi, for both are true: on the seventh day of Passover, the beloved and dear ones sang immediately, and then on the eighth day, they all returned together and sang a new song on the shore of the sea after the sea expelled the Egyptians.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous crossing of the Red Sea by the Israelites, emphasizing that they traversed it in a circular formation, symbolizing unity among the twelve tribes. It suggests that the crossing took a significant amount of time, possibly a full day, due to the large number of people involved, including the mixed multitude. The text highlights the theological significance of the Israelites singing praises to God both on the seventh day of Passover and again on the eighth day, reinforcing the themes of divine salvation and communal worship. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound connection between the events of the Exodus and the spiritual expressions of gratitude and joy that followed.

passage_content: ובזהמדוייק לשון הפסוק אז ישיר משה וגו' דבשעה שאמרו שירה פעם ראשונה, ראו ברוה"ק שעתידים לומר עוה"פ שירה לכך אמר ישיר בלשון עתיד, וז"פ ויאמרו לאמר שאמרו שירה בידיעה זו שיחזרו עוה"פ לומר כולם יחד על שפת הים, וזה שהסמיכו במדרש לכאן הפסוק פיה פתחה בחכמה וגו' דאיזהו חכם הרואה את הנולד, וגם המה ראו בחכמתם וברוה"ק שעתידים לומר שירה עוה"פ, ומדוייק הלשון "פתחה" שהם עשו פתיחה והתחלה ויחד כולם גמרו ביום המחרת.
translation: And this is precise in the wording of the verse "Then Moses will sing" etc. that at the time they sang the song for the first time, they saw through the Holy Spirit that they would be destined to sing in the future. Therefore, it says "will sing" in the future tense, and similarly "and they said to say" indicates that they sang the song with the knowledge that they would return in the future to sing all together by the shore of the sea. This is why the Midrash connects here the verse "She opens her mouth with wisdom" etc., for who is wise? One who sees the future. And they too saw with their wisdom and through the Holy Spirit that they would be destined to sing in the future, and the wording "opened" is precise, for they made an opening and a beginning, and together they all completed it the next day.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "אז ישיר משה" (Then Moses will sing) in the context of the Israelites' first song of praise after the crossing of the Red Sea. It emphasizes that they were inspired by divine revelation to foresee future generations singing together, highlighting the concept of prophetic insight. The reference to "פיה פתחה בחכמה" (Her mouth opened in wisdom) suggests that true wisdom involves recognizing future events, and the collective singing signifies unity and continuity in worship across time. Ultimately, it illustrates the connection between past, present, and future in the spiritual experience of the Jewish people.

passage_content: אוי"ל עפי"מ שפירשתי בדברי רש"י ז"ל (איכה ב') עה"פ פצו עליך פיהם וגו' מפני מה הקדים פ"א לעי"ן מפני שהיו אומרים בפיהם מה שלא ראו בעיניהם. עפ"י מה שפי' השלה"ק אמרם ז"ל (שמו"רפ' כ"ג) עתידים ישראל לומר שירה לעתיד לבוא, היינו שיאמרו ישראל שירה וישבחו להקב"ה על הנס העתיד לבוא ואף שלא הגיע עליהם מאמינים הם בהקב"ה שבודאי יקיים הבטחתו ואומרים שירה על זה, וז"פ שהיו אומרים בפיהם מה שלא ראו בעיניהם, ר"ל שגם בשעת החורבן שלא ראו בעיניהם שום טובה ונחמה אעפי"כ שבחו והודו להקב"ה ע"ש הישועה העתידה להיות, ועד"ז לענינינו דהאהובים וידידים אמרו שירה תיכף אף שלא ראו עדיין בעיניהם הישועה וההצלה מידי המצריים, אעפי"כ פתחו לומר שירה והקדימו פיהם לעיניהם, וזהו פי' הפסוק פיה פתחה בחכמה שעשו פתיחה והתחלה בפיהם ולא המתינו מלומר שירה עד שיראו הנס בעיניהם, וזהו תורת חסדעל לשונה דהנה אחר שרואין הישועה צריכים לומר שירה מן הדין, אבל טרם שראו הישועה אמרו שירה מצד החסד ולפנים משוה"ד וא"ש קישור פסוק זה לשירת הים.
translation: Woe to me, as I explained in the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed (Lamentations 2:), regarding the verse "They opened their mouths against you" etc. Why did the פ"א (peh) precede the עי"ן (ayin)? Because they were saying with their mouths what they did not see with their eyes. According to what the Shelah HaKadosh explained, our sages, may their memory be blessed (Genesis Rabbah 23), said that Israel is destined to sing a song in the future, meaning that the Jews will sing a song and praise the Holy One, Blessed be He, for the miracle that is to come, and even though it has not yet come upon them, they believe in the Holy One, Blessed be He, that He will surely fulfill His promise and they sing a song about this. This is what is meant by "they were saying with their mouths what they did not see with their eyes," meaning that even at the time of the destruction, when they did not see any good or comfort with their eyes, nevertheless, they praised and thanked the Holy One, Blessed be He, for the future salvation that is to be. Similarly, regarding our matter, the beloved and friends sang a song immediately, even though they had not yet seen the salvation and deliverance from the Egyptians with their eyes; nevertheless, they began to sing and opened their mouths before their eyes. This is the meaning of the verse "Her mouth opened in wisdom," that they made an opening and a beginning with their mouths and did not wait to sing until they saw the miracle with their eyes. This is the Torah of kindness, for after they see the salvation, they are required to sing a song by law, but before they saw the salvation, they sang a song out of kindness and beyond the letter of the law. And it is clear how this verse connects to the Song of the Sea.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of faith and praise in the face of adversity, emphasizing that the Jewish people sang songs of praise to God even before witnessing their redemption. This act of proclaiming faith through song, despite not seeing immediate evidence of salvation, reflects a deep trust in God's promises. It highlights the idea that true devotion and gratitude can manifest through proactive expressions of faith, illustrating a fundamental Hasidic belief in the power of spiritual anticipation and the importance of praising God for future deliverance. The connection to the Song of the Sea further underscores the theme of preemptive gratitude and the nature of divine grace.

passage_content: עודאפ"ל בהקדם דברי המדרש (ילקוט שה"ש ד' רמז תתקפ"ח) כמגדל דוד צוארך כמו שגדלו דוד בספרו לגוזר ים סוף לגזרים וגו' וצ"ב, ונקדים דברי המד"ר (פ' וישב פרשה פ"ד סימן ח') ועשה לו כתונת פסים, כתיב לכו וראו מפעלות אלקים וכתיב בתרי' הפך ים ליבשה, למה וישנאו אותו בשביל שיקרע הים לפניהם וצ"ב, ויתבאר עפי"ד ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה (פ' בשלח) לפרש המדרש פליאה הים ראה וינוס מה ראה ברייתא דרבי ישמעאל ראה, וז"ל דאיתא במדרש כשהעמיד יהושע את החמה אמרה לו אני קשיש ממך, אמר יהושע וכי אומר עבד זקן לאדון קטון אני קשיש ממך כבר נשתעבדת לזקני יוסף שנאמר והנה השמש וגו', ואיתא במדרש (פ' כ"א סי' ו') כי הים טען ג"כ אני קשיש ממך, וז"ש מה ראה לסתור טענתו ראה ארונו של יוסף דנשתעבדו לו כל הנמצאים השמימה, וכ"ת ים מנ"ל, ראה ברייתא דרבי ישמעאל דדריש ק"ו וכו', ומה גרמי השמימיים שהם נמצאים נכבדים נשתעבדו ליוסף, כש"כ הנמצאים בעולם היסודות וע"כ נס מפניו עכ"ל, והנה כתב הרע"ב מברטנורא במשנה (אבות פ"ה מ"ד) עשרה נסים נעשו לאבותינו במצרים ועשרה על הים, דא' מהנסים שנקרע הים לי"ב גזרים כמספר השבטים, וכל שבע עבר בדרך מיוחד וזה שנאמר לגוזר ים סוף לגזרים. והוא מאמר חכז"ל במדרש ולכאורה לפי דברי ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה שדן הים ק"ו מהשתעבדות השמש ליוסף. אין זה רק לשבע יוסף משא"כ בשאר שבטים לא הי' לו ק"ו זה ולמה נקרע לכל שבע ושבט בפ"ע.
translation: It is also said in advance in the words of the Midrash (Yalkut Shimon, Song of Songs, Remez 828) "Like the tower of David is your neck," as David grew in his book to divide the sea of reeds into pieces, etc., and it requires clarification. And we will precede the words of the Midrash (Parashat Vayeshev, Parashah 84, Siman 8) "And he made him a coat of many colors," it is written "Go and see the works of God," and it is written afterwards "He turned the sea into dry land." Why did they hate him? Because he would split the sea before them, and it requires clarification. It will be explained according to the words of the holy Rabbi Yishmael (Parashat Beshalach) to interpret the Midrash: "The sea saw and fled." What did it see? The teaching of Rabbi Yishmael explains: "It saw," as it is written in the Midrash, "When Joshua stood the sun, it said to him, 'I am older than you.' Joshua replied, 'And does a servant say to his master, "I am older than you"? You have already been subjugated to the elder of Joseph, as it is said, "And behold, the sun," etc." And it is written in the Midrash (Parashat Ki Tisa, Siman 6) that the sea also claimed, "I am older than you." Therefore, what did it see to refute its claim? It saw the coffin of Joseph, to which all the beings in the heavens were subjugated. And you might ask, "From where does the sea know this?" It saw the teaching of Rabbi Yishmael, who derives a fortiori, etc. If the celestial bodies, which are esteemed beings, were subjugated to Joseph, how much more so the beings of the world of the elements! Therefore, it fled before him. Thus, the Rabbi of Bartenura wrote in the Mishnah (Ethics of the Fathers, Chapter 5, Mishnah 4) that ten miracles were performed for our ancestors in Egypt and ten at the sea. One of the miracles was that the sea was split into twelve pieces, corresponding to the number of the tribes, and all seven passed through in a special way, and this is what is meant by "to divide the sea of reeds into pieces." And this is the statement of our sages in the Midrash. And at first glance, according to the words of the holy Rabbi Yishmael, who judged the sea a fortiori from the subjugation of the sun to Joseph, this only applies to the tribe of Joseph, whereas for the other tribes, he did not have this fortiori. So why was it split for all seven, each tribe separately?
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous splitting of the Red Sea, emphasizing the theological significance of this event in relation to the Jewish people's connection to Joseph and the twelve tribes. It highlights the idea that even the natural elements, like the sea and the sun, recognize their subservience to the legacy of Joseph, illustrating a cosmic acknowledgment of divine authority. The text also reflects on the unique nature of the miracles performed for the Israelites, suggesting that each tribe experienced a distinct path through the sea, symbolizing their individual spiritual journeys and collective identity. Ultimately, it underscores the profound relationship between divine intervention and the historical narrative of the Jewish people.

passage_content: וביארתיעפימ"ד בזוה"ק (פרשת וישב) שהכרח גדול הי' שישלטו השבטים על יוסף דעי"ז שלטו אח"כ על מצרים כי יוסף הי' השליט במצרים והם שלטו עליו ועי"ז הי' להם הכח להתגבר על טומאת מצרים, ולולא זאת לא היו יכולין לצאת משם ח"ו לעולם עיי"ש, ולפי"ז אם נקרע הים לפני יוסף ק"ו שיש לו להקרע לפני כל השבטים שהם שלטו על יוסף במה שמכרו אותו לעבד, וזהו פי' המדרש למה וישנאו אותו כדי שיקרע הים לפניהם דייקא ולא ליוסף בלבד וזה נסתבב ע"י השנאה שמכרוהו לעבד, מבואר דממה שנקרע הים לי"ב גזרים נתוודע ונתברר שכל הנמצאים בעולם משועבדים לכולם, וזהו פי' המדרש כמגדל דוד צוארך כמו שגדלו דוד בספרו לגוזר ים סוף לגזרים דמפסוק זה נלמד שנקרע הים לי"ב גזרים לכל שבט בפ"ע כנ"ל במדרש ובזה הגדיל דוד את השבטים הק' שהי' להם שליטה על יוסף ועי"ז היו שולטין להתגבר על טומאת מצרים וכל הנמצאים המשועבדים להם.
translation: And you will explain, as it is written in the Zohar (Parashat Vayeshev), that there was a great necessity for the tribes to have dominion over Joseph, for through this they later ruled over Egypt, since Joseph was the ruler in Egypt and they ruled over him. Thus, they had the strength to overcome the impurity of Egypt, and were it not for this, they would not have been able to leave from there, Heaven forbid, forever, as stated there. According to this, if the sea was split before Joseph, how much more so should it be split before all the tribes, who had dominion over Joseph by selling him as a slave. This is the explanation of the Midrash, "And they hated him," so that the sea should specifically split before them and not just for Joseph alone, and this was caused by the hatred that led them to sell him as a slave. It is clear that from the fact that the sea was split into twelve pieces, it became known and clarified that all beings in the world are subservient to them all. This is the explanation of the Midrash, "Like the tower of David is your neck," as David grew in his book to divide the sea of reeds into pieces. From this verse, we learn that the sea was split into twelve pieces for each tribe individually, as mentioned in the Midrash. In this way, David exalted the holy tribes, who had dominion over Joseph, and through this, they were able to overcome the impurity of Egypt and all the beings that were subservient to them.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity for the tribes to dominate Joseph, as this power enabled them to later conquer Egypt, where Joseph was a ruler. The act of selling Joseph into slavery created a dynamic that allowed the tribes to gain strength against the impurity of Egypt. The splitting of the sea into twelve parts symbolizes the collective authority of the tribes, demonstrating that all creations are subservient to them. This theological insight emphasizes the interconnectedness of the tribes' actions and their divine empowerment to overcome spiritual challenges.

passage_content: אמנםיש להבין הלא קוב"ה לא עביד ניסא למגנא ולאיזה צורך נקרע הים לי"ב גזרים דוקא, וכמו"כ היו יכולין לעבור דרך הים כולם בדרך אחד. ויל"פ ע"ד מ"ש האריה"ק בענין נוסח התפלה שאין לשנות מנוסח לנוסח כי כל שבט יש לו שער בפ"ע להכניס התפלה ומי שמשנה לנוסח שבט אחר אין תפלתו מתקבלת, אולם האריז"ל תיקן נוסח כולל ואף אם אין ידוע מאיזה שבט הוא יוכל להתפלל בנוסח זה, ועד"ז אפ"ל לענינינו דע"כ עברו ישראל את הים בי"ב שבילין, כי מיד שנכנסו ישראל בתוך הים ביבשה התחילו לומר שירה כנ"ל וכל שבט ושבט יש לו שער בפ"ע להעלות תפלתו, ובחינת התפלה שונה זה מזה,ולרמז זאת נעשה להם י"ב שבילין לכל א' דרך בפ"ע, ואחר שעלו מן הים עשו רמז ופועל דמיוני על נוסח הכולל כתקנת האריז"ל וחזרו לומר שירה חדשה יחד כולם, ולז"א על זאת שבחו אהובים וכו' ונתנו ידידים זמירות שירות ותשבחות, ר"ל כ"א לפי בחינתו ואח"כ שירה חדשה שבחו גאולים על שפת הים כולם הודו והמליכו ואמרו, שנשתתפו בזה כולם יחד בנוסח הכולל לכל השבעים.
translation: Indeed, one must understand that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not perform miracles for protection, and for what purpose was the sea split into twelve paths specifically? Likewise, they could have crossed the sea all together on one path. It can be explained according to what the holy Ari wrote regarding the wording of prayer, that one should not change from one formulation to another, for each tribe has its own gate to enter their prayer, and one who changes to the formulation of another tribe, their prayer is not accepted. However, the Arizal established a universal formulation, and even if it is not known from which tribe one is, they can pray with this formulation. Similarly, it can be said regarding our matter that Israel crossed the sea in twelve paths, for as soon as Israel entered the sea on dry land, they began to sing a song as mentioned above, and each tribe has its own gate to elevate its prayer, and the aspect of prayer is different from one another. To hint at this, twelve paths were made for them, each one a separate way. And after they ascended from the sea, they made a hint and a symbolic act on the universal formulation as established by the Arizal, and they returned to sing a new song together, and this is what is meant by "On this, the beloved praised," etc., and they gave friends melodies, songs, and praises, meaning each according to their aspect, and afterwards a new song, the redeemed praised together on the shore of the sea, all acknowledged and crowned, and they all participated together in the universal formulation for all seventy.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the twelve paths through the sea that the Israelites took during the Exodus, emphasizing that each tribe has its own unique spiritual gateway for prayer. This reflects the idea that individual expressions of devotion are valid, yet ultimately converge into a collective worship, akin to the unified prayer established by the Arizal. After crossing the sea, the Israelites sang a new song together, symbolizing their shared experience and collective gratitude, while still acknowledging their distinct spiritual identities. This illustrates the balance between individuality and unity in the context of divine worship and connection to God.

passage_content: עודי"ל עפי"ד הנ"ל שתכלית שנאת השבטים ליוסף הי' בשביל שיקרע הים לפניהם. והנה כל זמן שלא נתגלה להם תכלית השנאה שהוא קי"ס, הי' להם להשבטים הק' קצת טינא בלבם על שבע יוסף, וחשבו סיבת השנאה לטעם אחר כמבואר במדרשי חז"ל שראו ברוה"ק ירבעם יוצא ממנו וכדומה, וא"כ לא הי' ביניהם אחדות ושלום כ"כ, משא"כ אחר קרי"ס נתברר להם שהי' זאת סיבה מן השמים כדי שיקרע הים לפניהם אז נעשה שלום ואחדות גמור בין השבטים וחזרו לשבח את הקב"ה כולם יחד, וזהו פי' על שפת הים אחר שעלו מן הים ונתברר להם סיבת שנאתם ליוסף, יחד כולם הודו בשירה חדשה להקב"ה.
translation: According to the above explanation, the ultimate reason for the hatred of the tribes towards Joseph was so that the sea would split before them. Now, as long as the ultimate reason for the hatred, which is the splitting of the sea, was not revealed to them, the holy tribes had some resentment in their hearts against Joseph, and they thought the reason for the hatred was for another cause, as explained in the Midrashim of our Sages, that they saw in the Holy Spirit that Jeroboam would come from him and the like. Therefore, there was not such unity and peace among them. However, after the splitting of the sea, it became clear to them that this was a reason from Heaven so that the sea would split before them. Then, complete peace and unity arose among the tribes, and they all returned to praise the Holy One, Blessed be He, together. This is the explanation of the verse at the sea, after they emerged from the sea and it was clarified to them the reason for their hatred towards Joseph; together they all acknowledged in a new song to the Holy One, Blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the underlying purpose of the brothers' hatred towards Joseph, which was ultimately to facilitate the miraculous splitting of the sea. Prior to this revelation, the brothers harbored resentment, believing their animosity stemmed from different reasons, such as prophetic visions. However, after witnessing the miracle, they understood that their conflict was divinely orchestrated, leading to complete unity and harmony among them. This newfound understanding culminated in a collective praise of God, reflecting a profound theological insight into the relationship between divine providence and human emotions.

passage_content: עודי"ל עפי"מ דאיתא במד"ר פ' זו (פ' כ"ג סי' ז') אז ישיר משה הה"ד קדמו שרים אחר נוגנים וכו' כיון שיצאו ישראל מן הים באו המלאכים להקדים שירה לפני הקב"ה, א"ל הקב"ה יקדמו בני תחלה וכו', ואיתא בדרז"ל שישראל מקדימין לומר שירה להקב"ה ואח"כ המלאכים, ושוב חוזרים ואומרים ישראל והמלאכים שירה ביחד וכמו שאומרים בקדושה כתר יתנו לך ה"א מלאכים המוני מעלה עם עמך ישראל קבוצי מטה יחד כולם קדושה לך ישלשו וכו', וזהו פי' על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו, היינו המלאכים עם ישראל אחר שכבר אמרו בפ"ע חזרו ואמרו עוה"פ שירה חדשה כולם יחד. ועפ"י דרכים הנ"ל יתיישב ג"כ סתירת דברי רש"י ז"ל שהובא לעיל (בדרוש הקדום קושיא א') דבפ' בשלח כתב דבשחרית ז' דפסח אמרו שירה, ובסו"פ שלח כתב שאמרו שירה ביום ח' עיי"ש, אמנם כיון שמוכרח בלא"ה שאמרו שירה שני פעמים כנראה מנוסח לשון התפלה, יתכן לומר שפעם שנית אמרו ביום אחרוןשל פסח, ואין סתירה בדברי רש"י ז"ל ושניהם צדקו יחדיו, השי"ת ירחם עלינו יחיינו ויקרבינו לגאולה האמיתית ונזכה כולנו לישועה שלימה ואמיתית, ישמחו השמים ותגל הארץ, ונזכה לכל מיני ישועות טובות בקדושה ובטהרה בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.

passage_content: ויגדלמלך מצרים כי ברח העם וגו' פירש"י איקטורין שלח עמהם וכיון שהגיעו לשלשת ימים שקבעו לילך ולשוב וראו שאינן חוזרין למצרים באו והגידו לפרעה ביום ד', ובחמישי ובששי רדפו אחריהם וליל שביעי ירדו לים בשחרית אמרו שירה והוא יום שביעי של פסח לכן אנו קורין השירה ביום השביעי ע"כ, כבר הבאנו לעיל קושית המפורשים דזה סותר למש"כ רש"י ז"ל (סו"פ שלח) בשם ר' משה הדרשן דשמונה ימים שהו ישראל משיצאו ממצרים עד שאמרו שירה.
translation: And the king of Egypt grew strong because the people fled, etc. Rashi explains: He sent out Ikhtorin with them, and when they reached the three days that they had set to go and return, and they saw that they were not returning to Egypt, they came and told Pharaoh on the fourth day. And on the fifth and sixth, they pursued them, and on the night of the seventh, they descended to the sea at dawn and sang a song. And it is the seventh day of Passover; therefore, we read the song on the seventh day, etc. We have already brought above the question of the commentators that this contradicts what Rashi, of blessed memory, wrote (in Parashat Shelach) in the name of Rabbi Moshe the preacher, that the Israelites stayed for eight days from the time they left Egypt until they sang the song.
summary: The passage discusses the timeline of the Israelites' exodus from Egypt, highlighting the moment they began to sing praises on the seventh day of Passover after their miraculous crossing of the Red Sea. It emphasizes the significance of this event in the context of divine redemption and the joy of liberation. The reference to differing interpretations regarding the duration of their journey before singing underscores the complexity of understanding divine timing and the unfolding of salvation. This reflects key Hasidic themes of faith, divine intervention, and the transformative power of gratitude in the face of liberation.

passage_content: ב)ילקוט (רמז רנ"ד) ויסע משה את ישראל מהו ויסע שהסיען בעל כרחן. דכתיב ויקח שש מאות רכב עמד פרעה וקשט אותן הסוסים באבנים טובות ומרגליות, וכשנטבעו בים היו צפין על שפת הים והיו ישראל יורדין בכל יום ונוטלין מהן. ולא היו מבקשין לזוז משם כיון שראה משה כך א"ל מה אתם סבורים שבכל יום הים מעלה לכם אבנים טובות ומרגליות, עמד והסיען בעל כרחן ע"כ, וצ"ב מדוע הסיען בעל כרחן הלא הי' רצון השי"ת שיטלו הרכוש דמהאי טעמא הי' הים מעלה להם אבנים טובות ומרגליות וכמ"ש בילקוט (רמז רל"ט) עה"כ וירא ישראל את מצרים מת מפני ארבעה דברים ראו ישראל את מצרים מתים וכו' וכדי שיקחו ישראל את הביזה שהיו טעונין כסף וזהב ואבנים טובות ומרגליות וכו', וירא ישראל את מצרים מתים אינו אומר אלא מת, מתים ולא מתים כענין שנאמר ויהי בצאת נפשה כי מתה, וכי מתה היתה אלא מתה ולא מתה עכ"ד המדרש, גם ראוי להבין מדוע עשה ה' ככה שיהיו המצריים חיים לאחר שפלטם הים.
translation: (b) Yalkut (Remez 754) And Moses led Israel away, what does it mean "and he led them away"? He led them against their will. As it is written, "And Pharaoh took six hundred chariots" and adorned the horses with precious stones and pearls, and when they were drowned in the sea, they were washed up on the shore, and Israel would go down every day and take from them. And they did not wish to move from there. When Moses saw this, he said to them, "What do you think, that every day the sea brings you precious stones and pearls?" He stood up and led them away against their will. Therefore, it is puzzling why he led them away against their will; surely it was the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, that they should take the spoils. For this reason, the sea was bringing them precious stones and pearls, as it is stated in the Yalkut (Remez 739) regarding the verse "And Israel saw the Egyptians dead" because of four things: Israel saw the Egyptians dead, etc., and in order that Israel should take the plunder that they were laden with silver and gold and precious stones and pearls, etc. "And Israel saw the Egyptians dead" does not say "dead" but "dead," dead and not dead, as it is said, "And it came to pass as her soul departed, for she died," and was she really dead? Rather, she died and did not die. Thus concludes the Midrash. It is also appropriate to understand why the Holy One, blessed be He, did this, that the Egyptians should be alive after the sea had released them.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous events during the Exodus, highlighting that Moses had to compel the Israelites to leave the shores of the Red Sea, where they were collecting precious stones and jewels from the drowned Egyptians. It raises questions about God's intentions, as the Israelites were meant to take the Egyptians' wealth, yet they were reluctant to leave the site of their bounty. The text also reflects on the nature of death, suggesting a deeper understanding of life and death, as the Egyptians appeared to be alive even after the sea had engulfed them, prompting contemplation on divine providence and the complexities of redemption.

passage_content: ואפ"לעפי"ד המדרש שהמצריים היו מקשטין סוסיהם באבנים טובות ומרגליות, והנה כל כליהם היו של ע"ז וישראל אי אפשר לבטל ע"ז של עכו"ם וע"כ הי' הכרח שיהיו חיים עדיין והם עצמם יבטלו הע"ז, העולה מדברינו שכן הי' רצון השי"ת שיעלו ישראל רכוש הים, וא"כ קשה מדוע הסיען משרע"ה בעל כרחן.
translation: And according to the Midrash that the Egyptians adorned their horses with precious stones and pearls, behold, all their vessels were for idolatry, and it is impossible for Israel to nullify the idolatry of the nations. Therefore, it was necessary for them to still be alive, and they themselves would nullify the idolatry. This arises from our words that it was indeed the will of the Blessed One that Israel should take the wealth of the sea. And thus, it is difficult to understand why He caused them to be driven away by Moshe against their will.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that the Egyptians adorned their horses with precious stones, symbolizing their idolatry, which was inherently linked to their identity. It suggests that the Jewish people could not eliminate this idolatry on their own, necessitating the continued existence of the Egyptians until the Israelites could fulfill God's will by taking the wealth of the sea. The text raises a theological question about why Moses had to compel the Israelites to leave Egypt against their will, indicating a deeper divine plan at play.

passage_content: אמנםנראה דאף שהי' רצון הבוי"ת שיטלו הרכוש אבל רק במדה ידועה ולא יותר מדאי דאז יותר משהוא מועיל הוא מזיק, וכמ"ש הכתוב ודי זהב שבשביל רוב הזהב שהי' להם עשו את העגל, ועל כן הסיען משה בעל כרחן שלא יקחו יותר מדאי, ומבואר בדברי המדרש הנ"ל שהיו ישראל יורדין בכל יום ונועלין מהם וכו' א"ל משה מה אתם סבורים שבכל יום הים מעלה וכו' ע"כ, ולא מצאתי מבואר בשום מקום כמה ימים נשתהו שם, ועכ"פ משמע מלשון המדרש ששהו אצל עכ"פ שני ימים דהרי מיעוט רבים שנים וע"ז קאמר בכל יום, ואפשר דע"כ נשתהו שני ימים מפני שביום שביעי של פסח הוא יו"ט ולא היו יכולין ללקוט מהביזה דברים המוקצים ביו"ט, ויצאו אל שפת הים גם ביום השני שהוא שמיני ליציאתם, ועל שראו במפלת שונאיהם אמרו שירה עוד פעם, ולפי"ז יתכן שאמרו ישראל שירה בשביעי ובשמיני ליציאתם, ובזה יתורץ דברי רש"י ז"ל, שבפרשה זו כתב דבשביעי אמרו שירה, ובסו"פ שלח כתב בש"ר משה הדרשן בשמיני ליציאתם אמרו שירה, ולדרכינו תרווייהו אתנייהו וא"ש.
translation: Indeed, it seems that although it was the will of the Creator that they should take the possessions, it was only to a certain extent and not excessively, for then it would be more harmful than beneficial, as the verse states, "And the gold was sufficient," for due to the abundance of gold they had, they made the calf. Therefore, Moses forcibly led them away so that they would not take too much. It is explained in the aforementioned Midrash that the Israelites descended every day and locked them out, etc. Moses said to them, "What do you think, that the sea rises every day?" Therefore, I did not find explicitly stated anywhere how many days they lingered there, and nevertheless, it seems from the language of the Midrash that they lingered at least two days, for the minority of the majority is two, and this is stated "every day." It is possible that they lingered two days because on the seventh day of Passover it is a festival, and they could not gather from the spoils items that are set aside on a festival. They also went out to the edge of the sea on the second day, which was the eighth of their departure, and because they saw the downfall of their enemies, they sang a song once again. According to this, it is possible that the Israelites sang a song on the seventh and the eighth of their departure. This clarifies the words of Rashi, who wrote in this section that on the seventh they sang a song, and at the end of the portion of "Shelach," he wrote in the name of Rabbi Moshe the preacher that on the eighth of their departure they sang a song. According to our approach, both statements are valid, and it is understood.
summary: The passage discusses the balance between divine generosity and the potential harm of excess, illustrating that while God intended for the Israelites to take wealth from Egypt, it was limited to prevent negative consequences, as seen in the incident of the Golden Calf. It emphasizes the importance of moderation in receiving blessings, suggesting that too much can lead to spiritual detriment. The text also reflects on the Israelites' experience at the Red Sea, indicating that they sang praises to God on both the seventh and eighth days of their exodus, highlighting their gratitude and recognition of divine intervention. This dual expression of song reinforces the connection between divine salvation and the appropriate response of joy and worship.

passage_content: ויהפךלבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, יל"ד באומרו ויהפך וגו' דהרי מעיקרא בשלחם לא עשו זאת מדעתם ורצונם כ"א אנוס על פי הדיבור שהוכו במכות נמרצות ואיך יצדק לומר ויהפך, גם יל"ד בטעם שינוי הלשונות מתחלה אמר את העם ואח"כ כי שלחנו את ישראל.
translation: And the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was turned against the people, and they said, "What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel away from our service?" It is to be understood regarding the phrase "and it was turned," for initially, when we sent them away, they did not do so of their own will and desire, but rather were compelled by the word, as they were struck with severe plagues. How can it be justified to say "and it was turned"? Additionally, it is to be understood regarding the change in language; at first, it said "the people," and afterwards, "that we have sent Israel."
summary: הפסוק מתאר את שינוי הלב של פרעה ועבדיו לאחר ששלחו את ישראל, ומעלה את השאלה כיצד ניתן לומר "ויהפך" כאשר הם פעלו מתוך כפייה ולא מרצון. יש כאן הבנה עמוקה של חופש הרצון והכוח העליון, כאשר המכות הכבידו עליהם, אך בסופו של דבר, השינוי בלבם מעיד על חזרה לרצון פנימי. השינוי בלשון בין "את העם" ל"שלחנו את ישראל" מדגיש את ההבדל בין התייחסות כללית לעם לבין ההכרה האישית והעמוקה בעם ישראל.

passage_content: ב)(פרשה כ' סימן ה') ויהי בשלח פרעה וגו' הה"ד (שה"ש ד') שלחיך פרדס רמונים: א"ר לוי משל לאחד שהי' לו שדה והי' בה גל של צרורות, עמד ומכרה לאחר, עמד אותו האיש שקנאה והעביר את הגל מתוכה ומצא תחתיו מים חיים, נטעה גפנים וכו' נטע בה כל מיני בשמים וכו', כל מי שהי' עובר עלי' היה משבחה, עבר עליה אותו האיש שמכרה ראה אותה מליאה כל טוב, אמר אוי לי שכך מכרתי אוי לי שכך הוצאתי מידי, כך היו ישראל במצרים גל של צרורות שנאמר (שם) גן נעול אחותי כלה גל נעול מעין חתום, כיון שיצאו נעשו פרדס רמונים וכו', כל הימים שהיו הבריות רואים את ישראל היו משבחין אותן וכו', פרעה ראה אותן שורות שורות כהנים לוים וישראלים דגלים דגלים התחיל צוח ואמר אוי לו לאותו האיש שכך הוציא מתחת ידו לכך נאמר ויהי בשלח פרעה עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב דמיון המשל, ומדוע נמשלו ישראל במצרים לגל של צרורות, גם הראי' שהביא המדרש מפסוק גל נעול מעין חתום אינו מובן דאדרבה ה"ז מורה למעלתן וחשיבותן שלא נטמעו באומות כאמרז"ל, גם סיום דבריהמדרש צ"ב פרעה ראה אותן שורות שורות וכו' דגלים דגלים התחיל צווח ואומר אוי לי וכו' לכך נאמר ויהי בשלח פרעה, לכאורה הלא לא נעשו ישראל לדגלים כ"א במדבר ואחר קרי"ס, ואיך התחרט עכשיו על מה שלא ראה, ואם ראה העתידות באצטגנינות כמ"ש ראו כי רעה נגד פניכם, ובמדרש שאמר מי ומי ההולכים כולם ימותו במדבר ולא יכנסו לארץ כ"א יהושע וכלב, א"כ איך לא ראה כמו"כ בראשונה כששלחם, ומה ניתוסף עכשיו בידיעתו מגדולת חשיבותן של ישראל, שעבור זה התחרט על שליחתם.
translation:
In (Parashat Ki Tisa, Siman 5) it was when Pharaoh sent, etc. as it is said (Song of Songs 4) "Your messengers are a garden of pomegranates": Rabbi Levi said, it is like a man who had a field and there was a heap of stones in it. He stood up and sold it to another. That man who bought it moved the heap and found living waters beneath it. He planted vines, etc., and planted in it all kinds of spices, etc. Anyone who passed by it praised it. The man who sold it passed by and saw it full of goodness. He said, "Woe to me for having sold it, woe to me for having taken it out of my hands." So were the Israelites in Egypt, a heap of stones, as it is said (there) "A locked garden, my sister, my bride, a locked garden, a sealed fountain." When they went out, they became a garden of pomegranates, etc. All the days that people saw the Israelites, they praised them, etc. Pharaoh saw them in rows, rows of priests, Levites, and Israelites, banners upon banners, and he began to scream and said, "Woe to that man for having taken such things from under his hand." Therefore it is said, "And it was when Pharaoh sent." Thus far the Midrash. 

And it is necessary to understand the analogy of the parable, and why the Israelites in Egypt are compared to a heap of stones. Also, the proof that the Midrash brought from the verse "A locked garden, a sealed fountain" is not understood, for on the contrary, this indicates their greatness and importance, that they were not mixed among the nations, as our sages have said. Also, the conclusion of the Midrash is puzzling: Pharaoh saw them in rows, etc., banners upon banners, and he began to scream and say, "Woe to me," etc. Therefore it is said, "And it was when Pharaoh sent." At first glance, it seems that the Israelites were not made into banners until the desert and after the splitting of the sea. How did he regret now what he did not see? And if he saw the future through astrology, as it is said, "See, for evil is before you," and in the Midrash that said, "Who are those going? All will die in the desert and will not enter the land except for Joshua and Caleb," then how did he not see likewise at first when he sent them? And what was added now to his knowledge regarding the greatness and importance of Israel, that for this he regretted sending them?
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel uses a parable to illustrate the transformation of the Israelites from a state of oppression in Egypt, likened to a "heap of stones," to a flourishing nation, symbolized by a "paradise of pomegranates." It emphasizes the inherent value and potential of the Jewish people, which was obscured during their time in Egypt. The text questions Pharaoh's sudden realization of their greatness upon their departure, suggesting a deeper understanding of their significance that he lacked before. This reflects the Hasidic theme of recognizing the hidden potential within individuals and the divine purpose behind their suffering and eventual redemption.

passage_content: והנל"פעפימ"ד בזוה"ק (פ' שמות ט"ו ע"א) כד חמא קוב"ה חדוותא סגיאה דהאי עלמא תתאה וכו'. אמר דלמא ח"ו יתערבון בשאר עממין וישתאר פגימותא בכלהו עלמין, מה עבד קב"ה טלטל לכלהו וכו' עד דנחתו למצרים למידר דיוריהון בעם קשי קדל דמבזין נימוסיהון ומבזין להון לאתחתנא בהון וכו' גוברין געלן בהון נוקבתא געלן בהון. עד דאשתכלל כלא בזרעא קדישא וכו' עכ"ד הזוה"ק, מבואר שהי' סיבה מהבוי"ת שיהיו ישראל נמאסים בעיני המצרים ועי"ז ניצולו מהתחברותם ומלהתחתןעמהם ונשארו זרע קודש, ואילולא כן לא היו ראויים לקבלת התורה כמבואר בזוה"ק פ' יתרו, ומעתה אין זה תימה שלא הכיר פרעה גדולתן של ישראל ולא השיג אף גדולתן העתיד עד לאחר שיצאו מארצו, אף שידע מקצת מן העתידות באצטגנינות, אבל ענין זה העלימו מידיעתו, ונסתבב בגזירת הבוי"ת שיהיו ישראל נמאסין בעיניו כדי שישארו עם קדוש, ולאחר שיצאו מארצו לא הי' צורך לזה, אז השיג גדולתן העתיד בדגלים וכהנים לוים וישראל וצווח ווי וא"ש דברי המדרש.
translation: And this is what is stated in the Zohar (Parashat Shemot 15a) that when the Holy One, blessed be He, saw the great joy of this lower world, etc. He said perhaps, Heaven forbid, they will mix with the other nations and there will remain blemishes in all the worlds. What did the Holy One do? He stirred them all up, etc., until He brought them down to Egypt to dwell among a nation that is hard of neck, who despise their customs and belittle them to marry them, etc. They were strong, they were taken by them, they were taken by them. Until all was included in the holy seed, etc. Thus far the Zohar. It is explained that there was a reason from the Creator that the Israelites should be despised in the eyes of the Egyptians, and thereby they were saved from mingling and marrying with them, and they remained a holy seed. And if not for this, they would not have been worthy of receiving the Torah, as explained in the Zohar, Parashat Yitro. From now on, it is not surprising that Pharaoh did not recognize the greatness of Israel and did not grasp even their future greatness until after they left his land, even though he knew some of the future through astrology. But this matter was hidden from his knowledge, and it was decreed by the Creator that the Israelites should be despised in his eyes so that they would remain a holy people. After they left his land, there was no need for this, then he recognized their future greatness with flags and priests, Levites, and Israelites, and he cried out, "Woe!" And I understand the words of the Midrash.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the divine wisdom behind the Israelites being despised by the Egyptians, which served to prevent intermarriage and preserve their identity as a holy seed. This separation was essential for their worthiness to receive the Torah, as highlighted in the Zohar. Pharaoh's inability to recognize the future greatness of the Israelites was a result of God's decree, ensuring their sanctity until their liberation, after which he acknowledged their significance. Ultimately, this reflects the Hasidic belief in divine providence guiding the fate of the Jewish people for their spiritual elevation.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבאר במאמה"כ ויהפך לבב פרעה וגו' (עיין קושיא א') בהקדם לבאר הכתוב (בפ' בא) ויקם פרעה לילה הוא וכל עבדיו וכל מצרים וגו' כי אין בית אשר אין שם מת, ויקרא למשה ולאהרן לילה ויאמר קומו צאו מתוך עמי וגו', ותחזק מצרים על העם למהר לשלחם מן הארץ כי אמרו כולנו מתים, ויל"ד שהתחיל ויקם פרעה לילה הוא וכל עבדיו וכל מצרים וגו' וסיים ותחזק מצרים על העם והשמיט פרעה ועבדיו, ואפ"ל כי פרעה ועבדיו ידעו שלא יבא עוד מכה עליהם, כי כך התרה משרע"ה בהם שמכת בכורות הוא האחרונה שבכולם וזו כבר עברה, וע"כ הם עצמם לא הסכימו לשלוח את ישראל מארצם, אך מלחץ העם שאמרו כלנו מתים, ובמכילתא שאמרו לא כגזירת משה הוא, שהרי אמר ומת כל בכור, וכאן אף הפשוטים מתים ה' או י' בבית אחד, והטעם מפני שהיו המצריות מזנות וילדות מרווקים פנויים והיו להם בכורות הרבה כפירש"י עה"פ כי אין בית אשר אין שם מת, ואולי פרעה ועבדיו השיגו דבר זה שכל אלו בכורים הם וע"כ לא חששו שיביא עוד מכות עליהם ולא מיראת המות שלחו את ישראל, אלא מפני שכל מצרים החזיקו עליהם למהר לשלחם מן הארץ כי אמרו כולנו מתים, לכן הסכים גם פרעה ואמר קומו צאו מתוך עמי וגו', ועיקר הטעם שנתפתה לדבריהם מפני שלא ידע חשיבותם של ישראל והיו מבוזין בעיניו כי כן סיבב הבוי"ת כנז"ל בדברי הזוה"ק, אמנם לאחר שיצאו ישראל מארצו השיג גדולת מעלתם, וגם זה היתה סיבה מאת ה' כדי שיחזק לבו לרדוף אחריהם, ע"כ עכשיו ויהפך לבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם, כלומר אל המצריים ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, הזכיר ישראל שזה מורה על חשיבות בני ישראל, ומה"ט נתחרטו על ששלח אותם שעכשיו כבר הכירו חשיבותן של ישראל.
translation: And similarly, it is explained in the verse, "And the Lord hardened Pharaoh's heart" (see question A) in advance to explain the written text (in Parashat Bo) "And Pharaoh rose up at night, he and all his servants and all of Egypt..." because there was no house where there was not a dead person, and he called for Moses and Aaron at night and said, "Get up, go out from among my people..." And Egypt was urgent with the people to hasten to send them out of the land, for they said, "We are all dead." It is understood that he began with "And Pharaoh rose up at night, he and all his servants and all of Egypt..." and concluded with "And Egypt was urgent with the people," omitting Pharaoh and his servants. One might say that Pharaoh and his servants knew that no more plague would come upon them, for thus Moses had warned them that the plague of the firstborn was the last of all, and that had already passed. Therefore, they themselves did not agree to send Israel out of their land, but rather due to the pressure of the people who said, "We are all dead." And in the Mekhilta, they said, "It is not like the decree of Moses," for he said, "And every firstborn shall die," and here even the simple ones are dying, five or ten in one house. The reason is that the Egyptian women were committing adultery and giving birth to many firstborns from single men, as Rashi explains on the verse, "For there was no house where there was not a dead person." And perhaps Pharaoh and his servants realized that all these firstborns were theirs, and therefore they did not fear that more plagues would come upon them, nor did they send Israel out of fear of death, but because all of Egypt pressed upon them to hasten to send them out of the land, for they said, "We are all dead." Therefore, Pharaoh also agreed and said, "Get up, go out from among my people..." The main reason that he was persuaded by their words was that he did not recognize the importance of Israel, and they were despised in his eyes, for thus the Blessed One arranged, as mentioned in the words of the Zohar. However, after Israel left his land, he realized their great stature, and this was also a reason from God so that he would strengthen his heart to pursue them. Therefore, now "And the Lord turned the heart of Pharaoh and his servants toward the people," meaning toward the Egyptians, and they said, "What is this we have done that we have sent Israel away from our service?" The mention of Israel indicates the importance of the Children of Israel, and for this reason they regretted sending them away, for now they had already recognized the importance of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Pharaoh's heart and the realization of the significance of the Israelites after their departure from Egypt. Initially, Pharaoh and his servants underestimated the importance of the Israelites, believing that the plagues had ended and that they could safely let them go. However, the overwhelming fear among the Egyptians, who felt they were all doomed, compelled Pharaoh to release the Israelites. After their departure, Pharaoh recognized the value of the Israelites, leading to his regret and the subsequent hardening of his heart to pursue them, illustrating the divine orchestration of events to reveal the true status of the Jewish people.

passage_content: עודי"ל עפי"ד הנועם אלימלך זלה"ה (פ' בשלח) וזל"ק דאיתא בגמרא (עירובין דף נ"ד ע"א) המהלך בדרך ואין עמו לוי' יעסוק בתורה ולכאורה הלא בלאו הכי הוא מחויב תמיד לעסוק בתורה, כמאמר התנא המהלך בדרך ומפנה לבו וכו', ונראה לי ליתן טעם למצות לוי', כשהצדיק מלוה את חבירו הם מתקשרים זה בזה בקדושתם ונעשים כאחד וקדושתו של זה הצדיק העוסק בתורה בביתו הוא משמר את חבירו בדרך, כאילו הוא עצמו עוסק בתורה וכו', זה הוא כשהצדיק הוא המלוה, אבל אם הוא איש נעצב וריקן אין תועלת לזה במה שזה מלווהו, ואדרבה הוא מכניס בו עצבותו וכו', וזהו ויהי בשלח פרעה ר"ל מחמת שפרעה שלח את ישראל וכו' ולכן ולא נחם אלקים וגו' כי קרוב הוא, ר"ל זה קאי אפרעה מחמת שעתה מקרוב הלך מאצלם, והי' עדיין רושם עצבותו בהם ולכן ויסב וגו' עכ"ד, וראוי להבין מה שתיאר לפרעה איש נעצב וריקן ומהו עצבותו, ויותר יאות לו תואר רשע.
translation: According to the words of the pleasant Elimelech, may his memory be blessed (Parshat Beshalach), it is stated in the Gemara (Eruvin 54a) that one who walks on the road and does not have a companion should engage in Torah study. At first glance, it seems that he is always obligated to engage in Torah, as stated by the Tanna, "one who walks on the road and directs his heart," etc. It seems to me to provide a reason for the mitzvah of companionship; when a righteous person accompanies his friend, they connect with each other in their holiness and become as one, and the holiness of the righteous person who engages in Torah at home protects his friend on the way, as if he himself is engaged in Torah, etc. This is when the righteous person is the one accompanying. However, if he is a sad and empty person, there is no benefit to the one he accompanies, and on the contrary, he brings his sadness into him, etc. This is what is meant by "And it was when Pharaoh sent out the people," meaning that because Pharaoh sent out the Israelites, therefore "God did not lead them," etc., for he is close, meaning this refers to Pharaoh because he had just recently departed from them, and the impression of his sadness was still upon them, and therefore "He turned," etc. It is appropriate to understand what he described for Pharaoh as a sad and empty man and what his sadness is; it would be more fitting for him to be described as wicked.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of companionship and spiritual connection, particularly through the lens of a righteous person accompanying another. It emphasizes that when a tzaddik (righteous person) accompanies someone, their shared holiness creates a bond that spiritually uplifts both individuals, akin to studying Torah together. Conversely, if the accompanying person is filled with sadness or emptiness, they may inadvertently transmit their negativity, diminishing the spiritual benefit. The text reflects on Pharaoh's sadness and its lingering impact on the Israelites, illustrating how one's emotional state can affect others' spiritual journeys.

passage_content: ואפ"לעפימ"ש הקדושת לוי זלה"ה (פ' שמות) שע"י הכאת מצרים נתגדל ונתקדש שמו הגדול והקדוש, ולהכי מכת בכורות הי' ע"י הבורא ב"ה בעצמו, כי הוא היתה עיקר הגורם יציאת בנ"י ממצרים, ומחמת יצי"מ נתגדל ונתקדש שמו הגדול וכו' וגם להאומות היתה טובה, שהמצרים נעשים כלים שעל ידם נודע מציאות הבורא וכו' עכ"ד לענינינו, והנה לפי"ז הי' להם זכות שנעשו כלים שנתקדש על ידם ש"ש, אמנם אמרז"ל (קידושין מ' ע"ב) בתוהא על הראשונות ומתחרט על הטוב איבד כל זכותו ונתרוקן מהם עיי"ש, וכמו"כ בפרעה שאמר קומי צאי ושלח את ישראל, וע"י יצי"מ נתקדש שמו ית' בעולם, נמצא הי' כלי להתקדש ש"ש על ידו, אולם אח"כ התחרט ונהפך לבו וצווח ווי על ששלחם, ובזה אבד כל זכותו, ולזה יתואר איש נעצב וריקן,שע"י עצבותו שהתחרט וצווח ווי, נתרוקן ונתערטל מכל זכיותיו.
translation: And according to what the Kedushas Levi, may his memory be a blessing, says (in Parshas Shemos), that through the smiting of Egypt, His great and holy name was magnified and sanctified. Therefore, the plague of the firstborn was by the Creator Himself, blessed be He, for it was the main cause of the Exodus of the Jewish people from Egypt. And because of the Exodus, His great name was magnified and sanctified, etc., and it was also a benefit to the nations, as the Egyptians became vessels through which the existence of the Creator was made known, etc. Thus, according to this, they had the merit of becoming vessels through which His name was sanctified, blessed be He. However, our sages said (Kiddushin 40b) that one who is perplexed about the earlier ones and regrets the good has lost all his merit and has been emptied of it, as stated there. Similarly, with Pharaoh, who said, "Get up, go out, and send the Israelites away," and through the Exodus, His name was sanctified in the world, it turns out that he was a vessel for His name to be sanctified through him. However, afterwards he regretted and his heart turned, and he cried out, "Woe to me for having sent them away," and in this, he lost all his merit. Therefore, it can be described that a man is sad and empty, for through his sadness, having regretted and cried out "woe," he was emptied and stripped of all his merits.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the suffering of Egypt and the subsequent plagues, particularly the plague of the firstborn, served to sanctify God's name and elevate His presence in the world. It emphasizes that the Egyptians, despite their role as instruments of divine will, lost their merit when Pharaoh regretted his decision to release the Israelites, illustrating the idea that remorse can lead to the loss of spiritual merit. This reflects a broader Hasidic teaching on the importance of intention and the consequences of one's choices in relation to divine purpose. Ultimately, the text highlights the transformative power of both suffering and redemption in the context of God's relationship with humanity.

passage_content: ובזהיל"פ ויהפך לבב פרעה וגו', מלת לבב מורה על ב' הלבבות, וע"ד שדרשו רז"ל באברהם שהפכו כולו לטוב מדכתיב ומצאת את לבבו נאמן לפניך ולהיפך בפרעה הפכו כולו לרע, ובחי' קדושה שנקנה אליו ע"י שנתקדש ש"ש על ידו, עכשיו נתרוקן ממנה ונהפך כולו לרע, ויאמרו מה "זאת" עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל, ירמוז עפימ"ש ז"ל (ע"ז ב' ע"ב) אין זאת אלא תורה שנא' וזאת התורה וגו' ע"י יצי"מ זכו ישראל לקבלת התורה, והם התחרטו על שהיו כלים לגרום קדושה גדולה זו, וז"ש מה "זאת" עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל והבן.
translation: And in this context, "And the heart of Pharaoh was hardened," the word "heart" indicates two hearts. This is in accordance with what our Sages have taught regarding Abraham, who turned his heart entirely to good, as it is written, "And you have found his heart faithful before You," while conversely, in the case of Pharaoh, his heart was turned entirely to evil. The aspect of holiness that was acquired by him through being sanctified by the Holy Name, has now been emptied from him and turned entirely to evil. And they will say, "What is this we have done, for we have sent Israel away?" This hints at what our Sages said (Avodah Zarah 2b), "This is nothing but the Torah," as it is stated, "And this is the Torah," etc. Through the Exodus from Egypt, Israel merited the reception of the Torah, and they regretted that they were vessels to bring about this great holiness. Therefore, it is said, "What is this we have done, for we have sent Israel away?" Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the dual nature of the heart, as exemplified by Pharaoh and Abraham. While Abraham's heart was transformed entirely for good, Pharaoh's heart was turned completely to evil, reflecting the consequences of their choices. The text emphasizes that the sanctity acquired through the Exodus allowed the Israelites to receive the Torah, and Pharaoh's regret for sending them away signifies a loss of the opportunity to partake in this divine elevation. Ultimately, the phrase "What have we done?" highlights their realization of the spiritual significance of their actions.

passage_content: ויהפךלבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, צ"ב דהלא מתחילה לא שלחו מדעתם ומרצונם רק אחר שהכה ה' אותם במכות, וא"כ לא שייך הלשון ויהפך דלא הי' באמת שום הפיכה, ועוד צ"ב דבאמת איך לא יראו אחר כל המכות למרות פי ה' ולרדוף אחריהם להחזירם, וברש"י פי' בשביל ממונם שהשאילום, וגם זה צ"ב וכי הי' ממונם חביב עליהם יותר מגופם, ואיך נכנסו בסכנת הגוף בשביל ממונם, גם דמפורש בפסוק טעם אחר על הרדיפה.
translation: And the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was turned against the people, and they said, "What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel away from our service?" It is difficult to understand, for initially they did not send them of their own accord and will, but only after the Lord struck them with plagues. Therefore, the term "and it was turned" does not truly apply, as there was really no turning at all. Furthermore, it is also difficult to understand how, after all the plagues, they did not see the word of the Lord and pursued them to bring them back. Rashi explains that it was for their money that they had lent them, but this is also difficult to comprehend. Did their money mean more to them than their own bodies? How could they put themselves in danger for the sake of their money? Additionally, it is explicitly stated in the verse that there is another reason for the pursuit.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Pharaoh's heart and his servants after the Israelites' departure, questioning the nature of their decision to pursue them. It highlights the paradox of their initial unwillingness to let the Israelites go, suggesting that their change of heart was not genuine but rather a reaction to the plagues inflicted by God. The text also raises the issue of why they prioritized their material possessions over their own lives, indicating a deeper theological insight into the struggle between spiritual and material values. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexity of human motivation in the face of divine intervention.

translation: And it is brought in Yismach Moshe: The sea saw and fled, what did it see? It saw Israel coming with the wealth of Egypt in their hands, and the question remains.
summary: In this passage, the sea's reaction to the approaching Israelites symbolizes the profound spiritual awakening that occurs in the presence of divine redemption. The sea, witnessing the Israelites carrying the spoils of Egypt, represents the natural world responding to the miraculous acts of God. This moment highlights the Hasidic belief in the interconnectedness of all creation and the transformative power of faith, as even the elements of nature recognize and yield to the divine purpose. Ultimately, it emphasizes the theme of liberation and the fulfillment of God's promises to His people.

passage_content: ויתבארהענין בהקדם דברי הגמ' (ב"ב דף י' ע"ב) ואיפסק להלכה בשו"ע יור"ד (סי' רנ"ד) דאסור לקבל צדקה מן הנכרים ולמדו זאת מפסוק (ישעי' כ"ז) ביבש קצירה תשברנה נשים באות מאירות אותה, פירש"י ז"ל כשתכלה זכות שבידן וייבש לחלוחית מעשה צדקה שלהן אז ישברו עכ"ל, ולפי"ז אם מקבלים מהם צדקה נותנים להם חיות וזכות חדש, ועד"ז יסבר טעותו של פרעה כי אף שהוכה במכות נוראים עד שהוכרח לשלחם, דימה בנפשו שנענש משום חוסר זכותו אבל לאחר שהשאילו לישראל כלי כסף ושמלות סבור הי' שמעכשיו ניתוספו זכיותיו ויגינו עליו מעונשים ויסורים, וז"ש ויהפך לבב פרעה וגו' מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, פי' רשיז"ל בשביל ממונם שהשאילום, ר"ל זהו טעם שהפך לבו לרדוף אחריהם כי סמך שבכח הצדקה זו ינצל מן העונשים.
translation: The matter will be clarified by first mentioning the words of the Gemara (Baba Batra 10b) and it is concluded in the Shulchan Aruch, Yoreh De'ah (Siman 294) that it is forbidden to accept charity from non-Jews. This is learned from the verse (Isaiah 27:7) "In the dry season, the women will break it, coming to illuminate it." Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that when the merit in their hands is exhausted and the moisture of their charitable deeds dries up, then they will break. According to this, if we accept charity from them, we give them vitality and a new merit. Thus, Pharaoh's mistake can be understood, for even though he was struck with terrible plagues until he was forced to send them away, he thought in his heart that he was punished due to his lack of merit. However, after he lent the Israelites silver vessels and garments, he believed that now his merits had increased and would protect him from punishments and suffering. This is what is meant by "And the heart of Pharaoh was turned" (Exodus 14:5), "What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel from our service?" Rashi explains that it was because of the money that he had lent them. This means that this was the reason his heart was turned to pursue them, for he relied on the power of this charity to save him from punishment.
summary: The passage discusses the prohibition against accepting charity from non-Jews, based on a Talmudic source and a verse from Isaiah, which suggests that receiving such charity can diminish one's spiritual merit. It highlights the misconception of Pharaoh, who believed that by lending valuables to the Israelites, he could gain new merits to protect himself from punishment, ultimately leading to his decision to pursue them. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of the interplay between merit, divine justice, and the consequences of one's actions in the spiritual realm.

passage_content: אמנםצ"ב למה באמת צוה הקב"ה שיקחו ישראל מהם בדרך שאלה ואיכא חשש שיתרבה זכותם, גם באמת זכותם של המצריים ששאלו לישראל בטובם להיכן אזלא, ואפ"ל דהנה הקשו המפורשים הלא יעקב ועשו חלקו בנחלת שני עולמים, יעקב נטל עוה"ב ועשו עוה"ז ואיך הותר ליעקב ליהנות מעוה"ז והוא חלקו של עשו, ותירצו דאף חלקו של עשו מגיע ליעקב כמ"ש יצחק אבינו הן גביר שמתיו וכו' ומה איפוא אעשה לך דמה שקנה עבד קנה רבו והנה כ"ז ניחא בזמן שעושין רצונו של מקום. אבל אם ח"ו אין עושין נתבטל העבדות כמ"ש והי' כאשר תריד ופרקת עולו, וכמו"כ יש לומר לענינינו דכל זמן שבנ"י היו משועבדים תחת ידם של המצריים לא הי' באפשרות ליטול מהם דבר, דשלא ברשות ה"ה גזל ואם יתנוהו בטובם הרי יתוסף זכותם, אבל אחר שהוציא הקב"ה את בנ"י מתחת ידי המצריים אזי נהפכו המצריים להיות כדין עבדים לישראל, כי יצאו ע"ש זכות העתיד שיקבלו התורה ושוב אמרינן כל מה שקנה עבד קנה רבו והרכוש שלהם הוא ולא ניתוסף למצרים זכות עבור זה, כי החזיקו ישראל בשלהם.
translation: Indeed, it is asked why the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded that Israel take from them in the manner of asking, and there is a concern that their merit would increase. Also, in truth, there is the merit of the Egyptians who asked Israel kindly where they were going. And it can be said that the commentators have asked: Is it not that Jacob and Esau divided the inheritance of the two worlds? Jacob took the World to Come and Esau took this world, and how was it permitted for Jacob to benefit from this world, which is Esau's portion? They answered that even Esau's portion comes to Jacob, as our forefather Isaac said, "Behold, the master of the land is dead," etc. And what then shall I do for you? For what a servant acquires, his master acquires. And all this is acceptable when they are doing the will of the Omnipresent. But if, Heaven forbid, they are not doing so, the servitude is nullified, as it is said, "And it shall be when you let him go, you shall break his yoke." Likewise, it can be said regarding our matter that as long as the Children of Israel were enslaved under the hands of the Egyptians, it was not possible to take anything from them, for without permission it is considered theft, and if they were to give it willingly, their merit would increase. But after the Holy One, blessed be He, took the Children of Israel out from under the hands of the Egyptians, then the Egyptians became like servants to Israel, for they left in the merit of the future that they would receive the Torah. And again we say, "Whatever a servant acquires, his master acquires," and their property belongs to them, and the Egyptians do not gain merit from this, for Israel held onto what is theirs.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the Israelites asking the Egyptians for valuables before their exodus, highlighting the concept of divine justice and ownership. It explains that while the Egyptians initially held rights over their possessions, once the Israelites were freed from bondage, the Egyptians became like servants to them, allowing the Israelites to rightfully claim what was given. This reflects the idea that when fulfilling God's will, the dynamics of ownership and merit shift, emphasizing the importance of divine favor and the transformative power of liberation. Ultimately, the passage illustrates how the Israelites' future merit, particularly through receiving the Torah, legitimizes their claim to the Egyptians' possessions.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דברי המדרש הים ראה וינוס וכו' דהנה הים לא רצה להקרע והי' קטרוג גדול הללו והללו עוע"ז והי' צריכים זכות גדול להנצל, אמנם כאשר ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם ר"ל ברשותם, וע"כ דכל מה שקנה עבד קנה רבו ואין זה רק בעושין רצונו של מקום, א"כ מוכרח שיש להם זכות קבלת התורה ע"ש העתיד וע"כ וינוס מפניהם והבן.
translation: And in this, the words of the Midrash are clarified: "The sea saw and fled," etc. Behold, the sea did not want to split, and there was a great accusation against them, these and those (the idol worshippers), and they needed a great merit to be saved. However, when the sea saw Israel coming with the possessions of Egypt in their hands, meaning under their authority, and therefore, all that a servant acquires belongs to his master, and this is only when they are doing the will of the Omnipresent, it follows that they must have the merit of receiving the Torah for the sake of the future. Therefore, it fled before them, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous splitting of the sea, emphasizing that the sea initially resisted parting due to a significant accusation against the Israelites, who were seen as unworthy. However, when the sea witnessed the Israelites approaching with the wealth of Egypt, it recognized their inherent connection to divine will, as everything an enslaved person acquires belongs to their master. This realization highlighted the Israelites' merit in receiving the Torah in the future, leading the sea to flee before them.

passage_content: באופןאחר יתבארו דקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם להעיר במאמה"כ בפרשת בא, דבר נא באזני העם וישאלו איש מאת רעהו וגו' כלי כסף וכלי זהב פירש"י אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, בבקשה ממך הזהירם על כך שלא יאמר אותו צדיק אברהם ועבדום וענו אותם קיים בהם ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם עכ"ל, כבר דקדקו קמאי דמה צורך לטעם שלא יאמר אותו צדיק הלא חותמו של הקב"ה אמת ונאמן הוא ית' לקיים הבטחתו אף אם לא יאמר אותו צדיק, והפרשת דרכים דייק בלשון קיים "בהם", לא קיים "בהם", שמלת בהם מיותר ומחוסר הבנה ע"כ קושיתו, גם קשה מה צורך הי' להזהירן כ"כ שיקחו כלי כסף וכלי זהב, והם דברים שנפשו של אדם מחמדתן, ומצינו בביזת הים ויסע משה את בנ"י פרש"י הסיעם בע"כ שהי' רצונם להתעכב עוד למלאות ידם מביזת הים, ומדוע בביזת מצרים הי' צורך לאזהרה ולשון בקשה.
translation: In another way, the aforementioned nuances will be clarified in advance to comment on the verse in the Torah in Parashat Bo, "Speak now in the ears of the people, and let them ask each man of his neighbor..." (Exodus 11:2) regarding the silver and gold vessels. Rashi explains that "na" is only a term of request, a plea from you to warn them not to say that the righteous Abraham, 'And they will enslave them and oppress them' was fulfilled in them, and afterwards they went out with great wealth was not fulfilled in them. Thus far his words. The early commentators already questioned what is the need for the reasoning that the righteous one should not say this, for the seal of the Holy One, blessed be He, is truth, and He is faithful to fulfill His promise even if the righteous one does not say it. And the distinction in the wording is precise in "in them," not fulfilled "in them," as the word "in them" is superfluous and lacking in understanding; therefore, this is their question. It is also difficult to understand what the need was to warn them so much to take silver and gold vessels, as these are things that a person's soul covets. And we find in the plunder of the sea that Moses took the Israelites, Rashi explains that he took them against their will because they wanted to delay further to fill their hands with the plunder of the sea. So why, in the plunder of Egypt, was there a need for a warning and a term of request?
summary: The passage discusses the request made by Moses to the Israelites to ask their neighbors for silver and gold, emphasizing the importance of this request as a means to prevent the righteous Abraham from claiming that God's promise was fulfilled without their active participation. It highlights the notion that God's truth and faithfulness to His promises do not depend on human actions, yet the specific wording "in them" suggests a deeper understanding of the relationship between divine promise and human agency. Additionally, it questions why such a request was necessary in Egypt, unlike the situation at the Red Sea, where the Israelites were eager to take spoils without prompting. This reflects a Hasidic emphasis on the interplay between divine providence and human initiative in the fulfillment of God's promises.

passage_content: ב)הקשה האוהחה"ק בפ' שמות דמה צורך הי' ליטול בשאלה שאינו מהמוסר לגנוב דעתם של המצרים, ובימי אלכסנדר מוקדן הי' להם טענה על ישראל שנטלן ממונם, הלא הקב"ה כל יכול, וכמו שנתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים להשאיל להם, כמו"כ ביכולתו ית' ליתן בדעתם שיתנו במתנה לצמיתות ולא יהי' להם עוד טענה עליהם.
translation: In the difficult question of the Holy Torah in Parashat Shemot, what need was there to take in a manner that does not align with the ethics of deceiving the Egyptians? And in the days of Alexander the Great, they had a claim against Israel that they took their possessions. Surely, the Holy One, blessed be He, is all-powerful, and just as He granted favor to the people in the eyes of the Egyptians to borrow from them, so too, it is within His ability to instill in their minds that they should give as a gift permanently, and they would no longer have a claim against them.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of the Israelites asking the Egyptians for their possessions, despite the potential for misunderstanding or resentment. It highlights the omnipotence of God, who could have instilled in the Egyptians a willingness to give freely, thus eliminating any grounds for complaint. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of divine providence and the complexities of human interactions, emphasizing that even seemingly difficult situations serve a greater purpose in the divine plan. Ultimately, it illustrates the balance between human agency and divine intervention in the unfolding of events.

passage_content: ג)ברכות (דף ט' ע"ב) כשאמר משה לישראל וישאלו איש מאת רעהו וגו' אמרו לו ולואי שנצא בעצמנו, משל לאדם שהי' חבוש בבית האסורין והיו אומרים לו מוציאין אותך למחר וכו' ונותנין לך ממון הרבה, ואומר להם בבקשה מכם הוציאוני עכשיו ואיני מבקש ממון עכ"ד הגמ', לכאורה אין המשל דומה לנמשל, דבהמשל אמרו לו שלמחר מוציאין אותך ונותנין לך ממון הרבה, ע"כ וויתר על הרווחת הממון שלא יתארך מאסרו ויצא מיד, אבל במצרים הכי הי' ס"ד שע"י שישאלו ממצרים יתארך גלותם, ומה טעם שימאנו בדבר ומה צורך להזהירם ואינו דומה להמשל כלל.
translation: 3) Blessings (page 9b) When Moses said to Israel, "And they shall ask each man of his neighbor, etc.," they said to him, "Would that we could go out by ourselves!" This is comparable to a person who was imprisoned and they were saying to him, "Tomorrow they will take you out, etc., and they will give you a lot of money." And he says to them, "Please, take me out now, and I do not ask for money." Thus far the Gemara. At first glance, the parable does not resemble the lesson, for in the parable they told him that tomorrow they would take him out and give him a lot of money; therefore, he relinquished the benefit of the money so that his imprisonment would not be prolonged and he would go out immediately. But in Egypt, the thought was that by asking to leave Egypt, their exile would be prolonged. What reason would they have to refuse this matter, and what need is there to warn them? It is not at all similar to the parable.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the moment when Moses instructs the Israelites to ask their neighbors for valuables before leaving Egypt. The comparison made to a prisoner longing for immediate freedom rather than wealth highlights the tension between spiritual liberation and material gain. The theological insight emphasizes the importance of prioritizing freedom from spiritual bondage over temporary material benefits, suggesting that the Israelites' reluctance to ask for riches stems from a deeper desire for immediate redemption rather than prolonging their suffering. This illustrates a key Hasidic concept of valuing spiritual liberation above worldly possessions.

passage_content: ויתבארבהקדם דברי הזוה"ק פ' שמות (דף ג' ע"א) ואלה שמות בנ"י וגו' ר' חייא פתח (משלי כ"ג) אל תלחם את לחם רע עין ואל תתאו למטעמותיו וכו', דאי כד נחתו ישראל למצרים לא יטעמון נהמא דמצראי, לא אשתבקו בגלותא ולא יעיקון לון מצראי א"ל ר' יצחק והא גזירה אתגזר א"ל הא לא אתגזר במצרים דוקא אלא בארץ לא להם ואפילו בארעא אחרא עכ"ד הזוה"ק, מבואר דבשביל שנהנו ישראל מן המצריים ע"כ יכלו להם לשעבדם ולצערם, ובעה"ת הביאו מדרש (בפ' שמות) שפרעה נתן להם שכר בתחלה, ודחקו עצמן מפני חימוד השכר, ואח"כ גזר עליהם בכפי' להשלים חקם כאשר עשו בהיות השכר נתן להם, אבל שבט לוי לא קבלו עליהם לעבוד בשכר וע"כ לא הי' לו פתחון פה לשעבד בהם גם בכפי' עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה הרי השעבוד הי' בגזירת מלכות ובעכ"ח ומי מעכב בידם ואף שלא עבדו בשכר הי' בידו להכריחם אח"כ בכפי' ומדוע בשביל טעם זה מאנו מלשעבדם, אמנם יבואר הענין עפי"ד הזוה"ק הנ"ל שישראל על ידי שנהנו מהם מתחלה הי' להם שליטה עליהם, אבל שבט לוי לא נהנו מהם לא הי' היכולת בידם להשתעבד בהם.
translation: And it is explained in advance in the words of the Zohar, Parashat Shemot (page 3, column 1), "And these are the names of the children of Israel," etc. Rabbi Chiya opened (Proverbs 23), "Do not eat the bread of a man with an evil eye, and do not crave his delicacies," etc. For when the Israelites descended to Egypt, they would not taste the bread of the Egyptians; they did not mix in the exile, and the Egyptians would not oppress them. Rabbi Yitzchak said to him, "But it is a decree!" He replied, "That decree was not decreed specifically in Egypt, but in a land not belonging to them, and even in another land." Thus far the Zohar. It is explained that because the Israelites benefited from the Egyptians, therefore they were able to enslave them and afflict them. In the Holy Torah, it brings a Midrash (in Parashat Shemot) that Pharaoh initially gave them wages, and they pressed themselves because of the desire for the wages. Afterwards, he decreed upon them to complete their work as they had done when the wages were given to them. However, the tribe of Levi did not accept upon themselves to work for wages, and therefore he had no opening to enslave them even with a decree. Thus far the Midrash. And seemingly, the enslavement was by royal decree, and who could prevent them? Even though they did not work for wages, he could have compelled them afterwards with a decree. And why, for this reason, did they refuse to enslave them? However, the matter can be explained according to the aforementioned Zohar, that the Israelites, by having benefited from them initially, had control over them. But since the tribe of Levi did not benefit from them, they did not have the ability to be enslaved by them.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the Zohar's interpretation of the Israelites' experience in Egypt, emphasizing that their initial enjoyment of the Egyptians' provisions gave the Egyptians power over them, leading to their eventual enslavement. In contrast, the tribe of Levi refrained from benefiting from the Egyptians, which rendered them immune to subjugation. This highlights a key Hasidic concept that spiritual integrity and detachment from material gain can protect one from external oppression. Ultimately, the text illustrates the theological insight that reliance on divine sustenance rather than worldly rewards fosters true freedom.
