passage_content: והנהבנ"י יוצאי מצרים השיגו שע"י שנהנו דור הראשון מממון של מצרים נגרם השעבוד להם, ואפשר שלטעם זה לא רצו ליקח כסף וזהב של המצריים בצאתם שהיו יראים לנפשם פן יגרום זה להם אריכת הגלות, ע"כ הי' צורך לבקשם ולהזהירם על כך שישאלו, וא"ש דמיון המשל להנמשל, דגם כאן הי' טעם סירובם מלקבל מחשש שלא יתארך גלותם בסיבת הממון, ולזה אמרו הלואי שנצא בעצמינו בלא ממון אבל יהי' היציאה מיד, משיתאחר יציאתינו ויתנו לנו ממון הרבה והוא המבואר בהמשל ג"כ.
translation: And behold, the Jewish people who left Egypt understood that the suffering they experienced was caused by the enjoyment of the first generation from the wealth of Egypt. It is possible that for this reason they did not want to take the gold and silver of the Egyptians when they left, fearing for their souls that this would cause their exile to be prolonged. Therefore, it was necessary to ask and warn them to request it. And it is clear that the analogy of the parable relates to the subject, for here too, the reason for their refusal to accept was out of fear that their exile would be extended because of the wealth. For this reason, they said, "Would that we could leave on our own without wealth, but let the departure be immediate." For if our departure is delayed and they give us much wealth, this is also explained in the parable.
summary: The passage discusses the reluctance of the Israelites to take wealth from Egypt during their exodus, fearing that it might prolong their exile. This hesitation reflects a deeper theological insight that material possessions can lead to spiritual bondage. The text emphasizes the desire for immediate redemption over the allure of riches, suggesting that true freedom comes from a detachment from materialism. Ultimately, it highlights the tension between physical wealth and spiritual liberation in the context of the Jewish experience of exile and redemption.

passage_content: אמנםהך חששא הי' להם רק כ"ז שלא יצאו ממצרים עדיין אבל בקריעת ים סוף שראו המצריים פגרים מתים כמ"ש וירא ישראל את מצרים מת על שפת הים לא היו מתייראים עוד ליהנות מממונם, כי אין בידם להרע להם עוד, ע"כ עסקו ישראל בביזת הים ברצון נפשם אבל בביזת מצרים מיאנו לטעם יראה זו פן יתארך גלותם ויוסיפו לשעבדם, וע"כ היו הצורך לבקשם ולהזהירם. אכן לפי האמת לא הי' מקום לחששא זו כלל מאחרשהקב"ה צוה להם שישאלו, שומר מצוה לא ידע דבר רע, והקב"ה ידע שכבר סר צלם ולא יוכלו עוד לשעבד בישראל, רק שחששו ישראל שעד שיגיע זמן איבודם יגרמו עוד צרות לישראל אם יהנו מממונם, ע"כ להרגיע רוחם צוה הקב"ה שיקחו מהם בדרך שאלה לזמן ולא נהנו ממנה כ"א לאחר איבודם בים.
translation: Indeed, this concern was only present as long as they had not yet left Egypt. However, at the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, when the Egyptians saw dead corpses, as it is written, "And Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the seashore," they were no longer afraid to enjoy their possessions, for they could no longer harm them. Therefore, the Israelites engaged in the plunder of the sea with all their hearts, but regarding the plunder of Egypt, they were hesitant due to this fear, lest their exile be prolonged and they be further enslaved. Thus, there was a need to seek and warn them. In truth, there was no basis for this concern at all, since the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded them to ask. A guardian of the commandment knows no evil, and the Holy One, blessed be He, knew that the image of the Egyptians had already departed, and they would no longer be able to enslave Israel. However, the Israelites were concerned that until the time of their destruction, the Egyptians might cause further troubles for Israel if they enjoyed their possessions. Therefore, to calm their spirits, the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded them to take from them in the manner of asking, and they did not enjoy it except after their destruction in the sea.
summary: The passage discusses the initial fear of the Israelites regarding taking possessions from the Egyptians before the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, stemming from a concern that it might prolong their enslavement. However, after witnessing the destruction of the Egyptians, their fear dissipated, allowing them to willingly engage in the spoils of the sea. The text emphasizes that God's command to ask for these possessions was a reassurance, as He knew the Egyptians could no longer harm them. Ultimately, the Israelites' hesitation was rooted in a deeper concern for their future suffering, highlighting the tension between divine assurance and human apprehension.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר מאמר רז"ל שלא יאמר אותו צדיק וכו' דהנה הך חששא שאם יהנו מן המצריים יגרום להם אריכת הגלות אינו רק אם ישראל אינם ראויים להיגאל וקטרוג עונותיהם יוכל לגרום אריכת הגלות, משא"כ אם ראויים א"א לדחות ולאחרו ע"י הקטרוג, ואפשר שזהו הכוונה שלא יאמר אותו צדיק וכו' ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם, דבאמת הי' מספיק לקיים הבטחתו ית' בביזת הים שהיתה גדולה מביזת מצרים הרבה, אלא משום שלא יצטער אותו צדיק אברהם, שלטעם שלא היו ישראל ראויים לא נתקיים בהם ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לצד יראת הקטרוג, ע"כ צוה הקב"ה שיקחו גם מרכוש מצרים, ולזה דייק מלת בהם ר"ל בהם הדבר תלוי וקטרוג עונותיהם גרמו, ובוודאי שלא יתרעם אאע"ה על מדותיו ית', אבל יצטער על מדריגתן של ישראל, וז"ש ועבדום וענו אותם קיים "בהם" שע"י קטרוג עונותיהם הוכבד עליהם העבדות ועינוי, ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא נתקיים בהם לצד עצמותם שלא היו ראויים להיגאל, ואיכא חששא שע"י הרכוש יתעורר הקטרוג ויתארכו ימי שעבודם, וע"כ צוה הקב"ה שיקחו גם רכוש מצרים נוסף על ביזת הים, ובזה אפ"ל דברי המדרש הים ראה וינוס ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם, דהנה שר של מצרים קטרג עליהם מה בין אלו לאלו הללו עוע"ז והללו וכו' אך כיון שראה רכוש מצרים בידם מזה ראי' כי ראויים הם דאל"ה לא הי' מצוה ה' ליקח ממונם כלל אף בדרך שאלה וע"כ נקרע לפניהם.
translation: And in this, it is explained the saying of our Sages that the righteous should not say, etc. Behold, this concern that if they benefit from the Egyptians it will cause them a prolongation of the exile is only if Israel is not worthy of redemption, and the accusation of their sins can cause the prolongation of the exile. However, if they are worthy, it is impossible to delay or postpone it due to the accusation. And perhaps this is the intention that the righteous should not say, etc., and afterwards they will go out with great wealth, which was not fulfilled in them. For in truth, it would have been sufficient for the Holy One, blessed be He, to fulfill His promise with the plunder of the sea, which was much greater than the plunder of Egypt. However, because that righteous one, Abraham, would not want to suffer, for the reason that Israel was not worthy, it was not fulfilled in them, and afterwards they went out with great wealth due to the fear of the accusation. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded that they also take from the wealth of Egypt, and thus the word "in them" is precise, meaning that the matter depends on them, and the accusation of their sins caused it. And certainly, our father Abraham would not be angry at His attributes, but he would be pained by the level of Israel. And this is what is meant by "and they will serve them and they will oppress them," which is fulfilled "in them," that due to the accusation of their sins, the servitude and oppression were made heavier upon them. And afterwards, they went out with great wealth, which was not fulfilled in them due to their essence, as they were not worthy of redemption. And there is a concern that through the wealth, the accusation will be aroused and their days of servitude will be prolonged. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded that they also take the wealth of Egypt in addition to the plunder of the sea. And in this, one can explain the words of the Midrash: "The sea saw and fled," when Israel came and the wealth of Egypt was in their hands. Behold, the minister of Egypt accused them, saying, "What is the difference between these and those? These are idol worshippers and those are..." But since he saw the wealth of Egypt in their hands, this was proof that they were worthy, for otherwise, the Lord would not have commanded to take their possessions at all, even in a manner of borrowing, and therefore it was torn before them.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the Israelites' redemption from Egypt, emphasizing that their worthiness to be redeemed is crucial in determining the length of their exile. It suggests that the presence of wealth from Egypt could provoke accusations against them, potentially prolonging their servitude. However, God commanded them to take this wealth to demonstrate their deserving status, as the act of taking it signifies divine approval. Ultimately, the narrative illustrates the interplay between divine justice, human merit, and the complexities of redemption.

passage_content: ובזהא"ש מה שפירש"י בשביל ממונם שהשאילום, דהנה פרעה חשב ג"כ שע"י שנהנו מרכושם יהי' לו שליטה עליהם לשעבדם עוד ומה ששלח אותם הי' מוכרח מפני המכות, אמנם כל זה הי' טרם שנטלו ממונם, אבל אחר שנטלו את ממונם חשב שע"י גרמת הקטרוג יוכל לשעבד בהם עוד ולא יענש, וזהו פירוש ויהפך לבב פרעה וגו' ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, שהתחרט על ששלחם ושחררם משעבודו, אלא שרש"י ז"ל בא לתרץ איך יתכן לומר ויהפך הלא לא שלחם מרצונו כ"א מהכרח המכות כקושית האוהחה"ק, ולזה מתרץ בשביל ממונם שהשאילום כי על ידי זה השיאו לבו להתחרט ונהפך לבו גם על מה ששלחם מהכרח המכות, כי חשב כי מעתה הי' יכול להחזיק בהם ולא יענש עוד, וזה הי' סיבת טעותו, ועיקר חרטתו וטעם רדיפתו אחריהםהוא המפורש בפסוק כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, ומ"ש רש"י ז"ל בשביל ממונם שהשאילום אין זה טעם חדש, רק לבאר סיבת ההשתנות ואיך פג יראתו מעונש המכות אשר עברו עליו, לז"א מפני ממונם שהשאילום והבן.
translation: In this context, what Rashi explains is that it was because of their wealth that they lent it to him. Behold, Pharaoh also thought that by having benefited from their possessions, he would have control over them to enslave them further, and what caused him to send them away was the necessity due to the plagues. However, all this was before they took away their wealth. But after they took their possessions, he thought that through causing the accusation, he could enslave them again and would not be punished. This is the meaning of "And the heart of Pharaoh was changed," etc., and they said, "What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel from our service?" He regretted having sent them and freed them from his servitude. However, Rashi, blessed be his memory, comes to explain how it is possible to say that his heart was changed, for he did not send them willingly but rather out of the necessity of the plagues, as the question of the holy ones is. Therefore, he explains it was because of their wealth that they lent it to him, for through this, he incited his heart to regret, and his heart was also turned regarding what he sent them due to the necessity of the plagues, for he thought that from now on he could hold onto them and would not be punished anymore. This was the cause of his error, and the essence of his regret and the reason for his pursuit after them is explicitly stated in the verse, "For we have sent Israel from our service." And what Rashi, blessed be his memory, says about their wealth that they lent him is not a new reason, but rather to explain the cause of the change and how his fear of the punishment of the plagues that had come upon him diminished. Therefore, he said, "Because of their wealth that they lent it to him," and understand.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's change of heart after releasing the Israelites, attributing it to his desire to regain control over them through their possessions, which he believed would allow him to enslave them again without punishment. Rashi's interpretation highlights that Pharaoh's regret stemmed from a misunderstanding of the consequences of his actions, as he thought he could escape divine retribution after the plagues. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of free will and the illusion of control, emphasizing how material concerns can cloud one's judgment and lead to spiritual downfall. Ultimately, Pharaoh's fixation on wealth and power reveals the folly of prioritizing earthly possessions over moral and spiritual obligations.

passage_content: באופןאחר אפ"ל דברי המדרשים הנ"ל: בהקדם להעיר עוד במאמה"כ ויהפך לבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, וצ"ב דלא הי' התהפכות ברצון לבם כלל ומעיקרא לא שלחום ברצונם אלא הוכרחו לכך מכובד המכות, ורצונם עכשיו כרצונם אז, ואיך יאמר הכתוב ויהפך לבב פרעה, גם צ"ב שינוי וכפל הלשונות מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו וגו', ולא הי' כאן עשי' אחרת זולתי השליחות, והול"ל מה זאת שלחנו.
translation: In another way, one might say the words of the aforementioned Midrashim: It is appropriate to point out further regarding the verse, "And He hardened the heart of Pharaoh and his servants against the people, and they said, 'What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel away from our service?'" It is puzzling that there was no turning of their hearts at all, and initially, they did not send them willingly but were compelled to do so due to the severity of the plagues. Their will now is as their will then, and how can the verse say, "And He hardened the heart of Pharaoh"? It is also puzzling why there is a change and repetition in the wording, "What is this we have done, that we have sent them away?" There was no other action here besides the sending away, and it should have said, "What is this we have sent?"
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Pharaoh's heart as described in the Torah, questioning how such a change could occur if Pharaoh and his servants were initially compelled to release the Israelites due to the plagues. It highlights the idea that their desire to return to slavery was not a genuine change of heart but rather a reflection of their original intentions. The repetition in the text emphasizes the internal conflict and the illusion of free will in the face of divine intervention, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the nature of human agency and divine influence.

passage_content: ולבארהענין נקדים דברי המכילתא וה' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים וישאילום, ר"א רוח הקודש שרתה עליהן. והי' אומר לו השאילני כליך המונח במקום פלוני, והלה מוציא ונותן לו ואין חן אלא רוה"ק וכו' עכ"ד המכילתא, וראוי להבין מה צורך הי' להשתמש ברוה"ק הלא מבואר במדרש ילקוט (רמז קפ"ו) דבג' ימי אפילה היו ישראל נכנסין לבתיהן של המצריים ורואין כל מה שיש להם ובשעה שאמר להן הקב"ה ושאלה אשה משכנתה היו ישראל נכנסין אצלם ואומרים להם השאילני אותו הכלי שיש לך, והוא אומר אין לי ואומר לו אני יודע שיש לך וכו' ראיתי אותו בידך והי' משאילו אותו הכלי,ומהיכן היו ישראל יודעים אלא באותן ימי החושך ע"כ, וא"כ מדוע הי' צורך להם להשתמש ברוה"ק לענין זה, ואפ"ל ביאור הענין עפ"י מש"כ האריז"ל (בשער המצות פרשת ראה) במצות זכירת יצי"מ החילוק שבין גאולת מצרים לשאר הגאולות בבל ומדי וכו' שבמצרים נתבררו בגאולתם כל הנשמות כמש"ה וינצלו את מצרים לכן לא הי' צורך לחזור עוד שם, אבל בשאר הגאולות נשארו שם נשמות שלא נתבררו לגמרי וכו', גם כתב שהבטחת הקב"ה ואחרי כן יצאו ברכוש גדול, הכוונה על ניצוצי הקדושה והנשמות שיוציאו ממצרים עמהם שהוא הרכוש הגדול של ישראל.
translation:
To clarify the matter, we will begin with the words of the Mechilta: "And the Lord gave the people favor in the eyes of the Egyptians, and they borrowed from them." Rabbi Eliezer states that the Holy Spirit rested upon them. He would say to them, "Lend me the vessel that is in such-and-such a place," and the other would take it out and give it to him. And there is no favor except for the Holy Spirit, etc. Thus far from the Mechilta. It is appropriate to understand why there was a need to use the Holy Spirit, for it is explained in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 156) that during the three days of darkness, the Israelites would enter the houses of the Egyptians and see all that they had. And when the Holy One, blessed be He, said to them, "And a woman shall borrow from her neighbor," the Israelites would go to them and say, "Lend me that vessel you have," and he would say, "I have none," and he would say to him, "I know you have one," etc. "I saw it in your hand," and he would lend him that vessel. And from where did the Israelites know this, except during those days of darkness? Therefore, why was there a need for them to use the Holy Spirit in this matter? 

One could explain the matter according to what the Arizal wrote (in Sha'ar HaMitzvot, Parashat Re'eh) regarding the mitzvah of remembering the Exodus from Egypt, the distinction between the redemption from Egypt and other redemptions such as Babylon and Media, etc. In Egypt, all the souls were clarified in their redemption, as it is written, "And they plundered the Egyptians." Therefore, there was no need to return there again. However, in other redemptions, there remained souls that were not completely clarified, etc. He also wrote that the promise of the Holy One, blessed be He, was that afterwards they would leave with great wealth, referring to the sparks of holiness and the souls that they would take out of Egypt with them, which is the great wealth of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the divine favor granted to the Israelites in Egypt, as highlighted by the use of the Holy Spirit (Ruach HaKodesh) during their request for items from the Egyptians. It emphasizes that during the three days of darkness, the Israelites were able to see the possessions of the Egyptians, which facilitated their borrowing. The text contrasts the redemption from Egypt, where all souls were purified, with future exiles where some souls remain unrefined. Ultimately, it underscores that the true wealth of the Israelites lies in the holy sparks and souls they would take with them from Egypt, representing their spiritual inheritance.

passage_content: ולכאורההלא אין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו ונצטוו ישראל להשאיל ממצרים כלי כסף וכלי זהב ושמלות כדי לקיים הבטחת הרכוש ואיך יתפרש כוונת הפסוק על הניצה"ק והנשמות, אמנם אליבא דאמת הא בהא תליא עפי"מ שכתב ק"ז הייטב לב זלה"ה בפרשת בהר עה"פ וכי תמכרו ממכר לעמיתך או קנה מיד עמיתך וגו' שכל חפץ וכלי שהאדם קונה הוא מקושר ושייך לשורש נשמתו לתקן הניצה"ק שיש בחפץ ההוא עיי"ש, והבעש"ט הק' זי"ע פי' עה"פ רעבים גם צמאים נפשם בהם תתעטף וזל"ק, פי' בכאן סוד גדול ונורא והוא למה ברא הקב"ה עניני מאכל ומשתה שאדם תאב להם לאכול ולשתות, והטעם שהם ממש ניצוצי אדה"ר שהם מתלבשים בדומם צומח חי מדבר ויש להם חשק לדבק בקדושה וכו', וז"ש רעבים גם צמאים כשאדם רעב וצמא להם למה זה, וז"ש נפשם בהם תתעטף עכל"ק, וכמו כן באותן הכלים שהוציאו ישראל ממצרים הי' בהם ניצוצי הקדושה משורש נשמתם וע"כ אסרה תורה לחזור למצרים לעולם כי כבר נתבררו ונגאלו משם כל נשמות ישראל, משא"כ אלמלי נשארו שם ניצוה"ק שהיו בחפצים ובכלים ההם לא היו נגאלין גאולה גמורה ועדיין היו צריכין לחזור להוציא ולברר הכל, וזה שאמר הקב"ה למשה בבקשה ממך הזהירם על כך שלא יאמר אותו צדיק וכו' ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם ויצטרכו לחזור שוב למצרים ומזה יהי' לו צער גדול לאאע"ה, ע"כ תזהיר את ישראל שישאלו ויטלו כל החפצים השייכים לשורש נשמותיהם לברר כל ניצה"ק ממצרים ולעשותה כמצולה שאין בה דגים ולא יצטרכו לחזור עוה"פ למצרים.
translation: And seemingly, the verse does not depart from its simple meaning, and Israel was commanded to borrow from Egypt silver vessels, gold vessels, and garments in order to fulfill the promise of wealth. How then can the intention of the verse be interpreted regarding the sparks of holiness and the souls? However, according to the truth, this is dependent on what was written by the holy Rabbi Yoel in the portion of Behar on the verse "And if you sell a sale to your fellow or buy from the hand of your fellow," that every object and vessel that a person acquires is connected and belongs to the root of his soul to rectify the sparks of holiness that are in that object, as explained there. And the Baal Shem Tov, may his memory be blessed, explained on the verse "Hungry and thirsty, their soul is in them," that here is a great and awesome secret, which is why the Holy One, blessed be He, created matters of food and drink that a person craves to eat and drink. The reason is that they are truly sparks of Adam HaRishon, which are clothed in inanimate, plant, animal, and speaking beings, and they have a desire to cling to holiness, etc. Therefore, it is said "Hungry and thirsty," when a person is hungry and thirsty for them, why is that? And it is said "Their soul is in them," meaning all of this. Likewise, in those vessels that Israel took out of Egypt, there were sparks of holiness from the root of their souls, and therefore the Torah forbade returning to Egypt forever, for all the souls of Israel were already clarified and redeemed from there. However, had the sparks of holiness remained there in those objects and vessels, they would not have been redeemed completely and would still need to return to extract and clarify everything. This is what the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: "Please warn them not to say that righteous one, etc.," and afterwards they went out with great wealth, which was not fulfilled in them, and they would need to return again to Egypt, and from this there would be great sorrow for him, may his memory be blessed. Therefore, you should warn Israel to ask and take all the objects that are connected to the root of their souls to clarify all the sparks of holiness from Egypt and to make it like a net that has no fish, and they will not need to return to Egypt in the future.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual significance of the Israelites' request for gold, silver, and garments from Egypt, emphasizing that these items contained holy sparks connected to their souls. It highlights the idea that food and drink are also composed of divine sparks from Adam HaRishon, which humans are drawn to in order to connect with holiness. The text warns that if the Israelites did not gather these holy sparks, they would not achieve complete redemption and might have to return to Egypt. Ultimately, the passage underscores the importance of reclaiming these sparks to ensure a full spiritual liberation.

passage_content: ובזהיובן מה שהוצרכו להשתמש ברוח הקודש בהשאלת הכלים דאף שראו כל הכלים והחפצים בשלשת ימי האפילה, מכל מקום הי' צורך להם לידע איזה חפץ יש בו ניצוץ הקדוש השייך לשורש נשמתו, דאין אדם נוגע במה שמוכן לחבירו, כי כל אחד צריך לתקן מה ששייך לשורש נשמתו, וע"כ הוצרכו להשתמש ברוה"ק שידעו ליטול רק מה ששייך לו ולהניח מה ששייך לחבירו ומה שאין בו ניצה"ק כלל
translation: And with this it is understood why they needed to use the Holy Spirit in the borrowing of the vessels, for even though they saw all the vessels and items during the three days of darkness, nonetheless, they needed to know which item contained the holy spark that belongs to the root of their soul, for a person does not touch what is prepared for another, as each one must rectify what is related to the root of their soul. Therefore, they needed to use the Holy Spirit to know to take only what belongs to them and to leave what belongs to others and what does not contain a holy spark at all.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of using divine inspiration (Ruach HaKodesh) to discern which objects possess a holy spark (nitzotz kadosh) that corresponds to an individual's soul root. Despite the visibility of all items during the three days of darkness, each person must only take what is relevant to their own spiritual rectification, as one cannot interfere with what is designated for another. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the personal connection between the soul and its unique mission, emphasizing the importance of individual spiritual responsibility.

passage_content: והנההים הי' לו טענה שעדיין לא הגיע זמנו להקרע לפני ישראל אעפ"י שתנאי התנה הקב"ה עמו בשעת הבריאה שיקרע לפני ישראל, אבל התנאי הי' רק אחרי כלות זמן שעבודם שנגזר עליהם ד' מאות שנה ועדיין לא שלמו ולכן לא רצה לקרוע לפניהם, אבל כשראה רכוש מצרים בידם שכבר הוציאו משם הניצה"ק ונתבררו ונגאלו כל נשמות ישראל, מזה השיג שכבר הגיע זמנם להגאל ולא יחזרו למצרים עוד לעולם וע"כ וינוס, וזהו פי' המדרש הים ראה וינוס מה ראה, ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם ומזה שפט שכבר הגיע עת הגאולה, ויובן בזה אידך דברי המדרש ברייתא דרבי ישמעאל ראה, כי סתם מכילתא הוא מכילתא דרבי ישמעאל, ומבואר בדברי המכילתא הנ"ל בפסוק וה' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים שהי"ל לישראל רוה"ק ועי"ז הוציאו בלעם מפיהם כל ניצוצי הקדושה ומזה השיג שהגיע זמן גאולתם ונקרע מפניהם.
translation: And behold, he had a claim that the time had not yet come for him to split before Israel, even though the Holy One, Blessed be He, had stipulated with him at the time of creation that he would split before Israel. But the condition was only after the completion of the time of their servitude, which was decreed upon them for four hundred years, and they had not yet completed it; therefore, he did not want to split before them. However, when he saw the wealth of Egypt in their hands, that they had already taken it out from there, and all the souls of Israel had been clarified and redeemed, from this he understood that their time for redemption had indeed arrived and they would not return to Egypt ever again. And therefore, he fled. This is the explanation of the Midrash: "The sea saw and fled." What did it see? It saw Israel coming with the wealth of Egypt in their hands, and from this, it judged that the time of redemption had arrived. And this can be understood in light of the other words of the Midrash: "The Beraita of Rabbi Yishmael saw," for it is a general Mechilta, the Mechilta of Rabbi Yishmael. And it is explained in the words of the aforementioned Mechilta on the verse, "And the Lord gave the people favor in the eyes of Egypt," that Israel had the Holy Spirit, and through this, they extracted from Bilam's mouth all the sparks of holiness, and from this, he understood that the time of their redemption had arrived, and he split before them.
summary: The passage discusses the timing of the splitting of the sea, emphasizing that it was contingent upon the fulfillment of Israel's suffering in Egypt, which had not yet been completed. However, upon witnessing the Israelites carrying the wealth of Egypt, the sea recognized that the time for their redemption had arrived, as all the holy sparks had been redeemed. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of divine timing and the interconnectedness of Israel's spiritual state with their physical redemption. Ultimately, the sea's reaction signifies the culmination of Israel's suffering and the onset of their liberation.

passage_content: והנהפרעה וחרטומי מצרים היו חכמים ובקיאים בכוחות הטומאה והשיגו ג"כ שמה שזכו ישראל לצאת משם יציאה גמורה בלי לחזור שמה הוא ע"י שלקחו עמהם כל הכלים וכסף וזהב שבזה נתבררו כל נשמות ישראל, וזולת זה היו מוכרחים לחזור עוה"פ למצרים כדי לברר מה שנשאר שמה, ואיתא בגמרא (יבמות קי"ג ע"ב) נשתטית לאיוציא תנא דבי ר"י ושלחה מביתו מי שמשלחה ואינה חוזרת יצתה זו שמשלחה וחוזרת, הרי דמשמעות שלוח היא שליחות גמורה בלי חזרה, ובזה יובן מאמה"כ ויהפך לבבפרעה ועבדיו אל העם ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו: כלומר ששלחנו אותם שליחות גמורה שאינם חוזרים עוד, והנה מה שהשאילום כל הכלים והחפצים עשו מרצונם הטוב ולא היו מוכרחים ואנוסים לכך כפירש"י דאף מה שלא היו שואלין מהם היו נותנין להם אתה אומר אחד טול שנים ולך, אמנם עכשיו התחרטו על כך שברצונם גרמו זאת שיהי' שילוחין גמורים בלי חזרה, וזה שאמרו מה זאת עשינו הכוונה על השאלת כליהם מרצונם הטוב ובזה גרמנו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדינו, ולא על עצם השילוחין נתחרטו כי לזה היו מוכרחין מחמת המכות, רק נתחרטו על השאלת הכלים שבזה גרמו שיהי' שליחות גמורה, דאל"ה היו מוכרחין לחזור והיו יכולים לשעבד בהם עוה"פ. וזה שכתב רש"י ז"ל נהפך לבם לרדוף אחריהם בשביל ממונם שהשאילום, שע"י הממון שהשאילום גרמו שלא יחזרו אצלם עוד, ואינו סותר למה שאמר הפסוק כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו כי הא בהא תליא דאם לא הממון שהשאילום היו מוכרחין לחזור אצלם עוה"פ והיו משעבדין עמהם עוד.
translation: And behold, Pharaoh and the magicians of Egypt were wise and knowledgeable in the forces of impurity, and they also understood that the reason the Israelites were able to leave there completely without returning was because they took with them all the vessels, silver, and gold, through which all the souls of Israel were clarified. Otherwise, they would have been compelled to return in the afterlife to Egypt to clarify what remained there. And it is stated in the Gemara (Yevamot 113b) that if a person sends away a messenger and she does not return, this is a complete sending away. Thus, it is understood from the verse, "And the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was turned against the people, and they said, 'What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel away from our service?'" This means that they sent them away as a complete sending, that they would not return anymore. And behold, the fact that they borrowed all the vessels and items was done of their own good will, and they were not compelled or forced to do so, as Rashi explains that even what they did not ask from them, they would give to them, saying, "You take one, and take two for yourself." However, now they regretted that by their own will they caused that there would be a complete sending away without return. And this is what they said, "What is this we have done?" The intention was regarding the borrowing of their vessels out of their good will, and by this, we caused that we sent Israel away from our service, and not because they regretted the very act of sending them away, for they were compelled to do so because of the plagues. They only regretted the borrowing of the vessels, for by this they caused that it would be a complete sending away, for otherwise they would have been compelled to return and could have enslaved them in the afterlife. And this is what Rashi wrote, "Their hearts were turned to pursue them because of the money they borrowed," for through the money they borrowed, they caused that they would not return to them anymore. And this does not contradict what the verse says, "For we have sent Israel away from our service," for this is dependent on that; if not for the money they borrowed, they would have been compelled to return to them in the afterlife and would have enslaved them again.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' departure from Egypt, emphasizing that their complete liberation was facilitated by taking gold and silver, which purified their souls. It highlights that the Egyptians, despite being wise in the forces of impurity, inadvertently contributed to a genuine and irreversible sending away of the Israelites by willingly giving them their possessions. The regret expressed by Pharaoh and his servants stemmed not from the act of sending the Israelites away, which was necessitated by the plagues, but from the realization that their generosity in lending valuables ensured that the Israelites would not return. This illustrates a profound theological insight into the interplay of free will, divine providence, and the transformative power of material possessions in the context of spiritual liberation.

passage_content: ויהפךלבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, ראוי להבין איך יצדק ענין התהפכות וחרטה בדבר שלא עשו ברצונם מעיקרא, כ"א מחמת ההכרח ובכפי' כמשה"כ ותחזק מצרים על העם למהר לשלחם וגו' כי אמרו כולנו מתים, גם צריך להבין השתנות דעתם וסברתם, כי מעיקרא יראו לנפשם פן ימותו כולם, ואיך עכשיו הפקירו חיותם מנגד לרדוף אחרי ישראל.
translation: And the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was turned against the people, and they said, "What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel away from our service?" It is fitting to understand how the matter of reversal and regret can be justified regarding something they did not do willingly from the outset, but rather out of necessity, as it is written, "And Egypt was strengthened against the people to hasten to send them away," for they said, "We are all dying." It is also necessary to understand the change in their opinion and reasoning, for initially they feared for their lives lest they all die, and how now they have abandoned their lives in order to pursue Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Pharaoh and his servants' hearts as they reconsider their decision to release the Israelites from slavery. It raises questions about the nature of this change, given that their initial choice was driven by fear of death rather than free will. The text highlights the complexity of human emotions and decisions, suggesting that even in moments of desperation, individuals can shift from self-preservation to a willingness to pursue what they once deemed a threat. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the interplay of divine influence and human agency in the unfolding of events.

passage_content: ואפ"לדלכאורה קשה מה שהגזימו המצריים פחדתם לומר כולנו מתים, ובמכילתא איתא שאמרו לא כגזירת משה, שהרי אמר ומת כל בכור, וכאן אף הפשוטים מתים ה' או י' בבית אחד, ולכאורה הלא ראו שנתקיימו כל דברי משה א' מהם לא נעדר ולא נשתנה אף כמלא נימא, ובודאי גם בזה יתקיים כדבריו ורק הבכורים ימותו, ורש"י פי' שהמצריות מזנות תחת בעליהן וכו' והיו להם בכורות הרבה, פעמים הם חמשה לאשה אחת, כ"א בכור לאביו, אמנם גם לטעם זה לא יצדק לומר כולנו מתים, גם כי בודאי לא הי' נעדר מהם ידיעת אפשרות זה ואפשר כי סיבת יראתם הי', דכיון שניתן רשות למשחית ליכנס לבתי המצרים ולהרוג כל הבכורים שוב לא יבחין, כי ידעו שכולם חייבים מיתה לצד הפלגת רשעתם, ובאמת הי' ראוי להם ככה, אלא שניצולו מן המשחית כדי שיתקדש ש"ש על ידם בקרי"ס, וכמ"ש הכתוב בהתראת הברד ואולם בעבור זאת העמדתיך בעבור הראותך את כחי ולמען ספר שמי בכל הארץ, אמנם המצריים כאשר ראו שנעשה להם נס וניצולו ממיתה ודאית, לא שמו אל לבם שזהו אך לרעתם, אבל תלו סיבת הצלתם בע"ז שלהם, והי' זה סיבה מהבוית"ש לחזק את לבם לרדוף אחר ישראל, ולזה ויהפך לבב פרעה ועבדיו וגו' ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל כי עכשיו פג פחד המיתה מהם, שראו שאף שניתן רשות למשחית לא קרב אליהם, אין זה כ"א יראתם קשה, והבוי"ת סיכל את דעתם וחיזק את לבבם כדי שיאבדו ויתקדש ש"ש בקרי"ס.
translation: And although it seems difficult at first glance what the Egyptians exaggerated in their fear to say, "We are all dead," in the Mekhilta it is stated that they said, "Not like the decree of Moshe," for he said, "And every firstborn shall die," and here even the simple ones die, five or ten in one house. And at first glance, did they not see that all the words of Moshe were fulfilled, not one of them was missing or changed, not even as a hair's breadth? Certainly, in this matter too, it would be fulfilled as his words, and only the firstborn would die. And Rashi explained that the Egyptian women were committing adultery under their husbands, etc., and they had many firstborns, sometimes five for one woman, each one a firstborn to his father. However, even for this reason, it would not be correct to say, "We are all dead," for certainly they were not unaware of this possibility, and perhaps the reason for their fear was that since permission was given to the destroyer to enter the houses of the Egyptians and kill all the firstborns, he would no longer distinguish, for they knew that all were deserving of death due to the extreme wickedness. And indeed, it was fitting for them this way, except that they were saved from the destroyer so that the Holy Name would be sanctified through them in the plague of the firstborn. As the verse states regarding the warning of the hail, "And for this reason I have raised you up, to show you My power and to declare My name throughout the earth." However, when the Egyptians saw that a miracle was done for them and they were saved from certain death, they did not take to heart that this was only to their detriment, but attributed the reason for their salvation to their idols. And this was a reason from the Blessed One to strengthen their hearts to pursue Israel. And therefore, "And the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was hardened," and they said, "What is this we have done that we have sent Israel away? For now the fear of death has departed from them," for they saw that even though permission was given to the destroyer, he did not come near them. This was only their severe fear, and the Blessed One thwarted their thoughts and strengthened their hearts so that they would perish and the Holy Name would be sanctified through them in the plague of the firstborn.
summary: The passage discusses the Egyptians' exaggerated fear of death during the plagues, particularly their belief that all would die despite the specific prophecy of the death of the firstborn. It highlights the theological insight that their lack of faith in God's word led them to misinterpret their temporary escape from death as a sign of their gods' power, rather than recognizing it as a divine mercy. This misjudgment ultimately hardened Pharaoh's heart, allowing for the fulfillment of God's plan to sanctify His name through the redemption of Israel. The text emphasizes the interplay between divine sovereignty and human agency in the context of faith and judgment.

passage_content: ויאמרמשה אל העם אל תיראו התיצבו וראו את ישועת ה' אשר יעשה לכם היום וגו', יש להבין מה צורך להקדמה זו התיצבו וראו וגו' הול"ל בקיצור כי אשר ראיתם את מצרים לא תוסיפו לראותם עוד עד עולם, ודרשת חכז"ל ידועים.
translation: And Moses said to the people, "Do not be afraid; stand firm and see the salvation of the Lord which He will perform for you today," etc. It is necessary to understand what the need is for this introduction, "stand firm and see," etc. It could have been stated more succinctly: "For the Egyptians whom you see today, you shall never see again forever." And the teachings of our Sages are well known.
summary: משה רבנו אומר לעם ישראל לא לפחד, אלא להתייצב ולראות את ישועת ה' שתתרחש. יש להבין שההקדמה "התיצבו וראו" מדגישה את הצורך בהכנה רוחנית כדי לחוות את הנס. במקום לקצר ולומר שלא יראו את מצרים שוב, הוא מדגיש את החשיבות של התבוננות והבנה עמוקה של הנס, כפי שמבואר בדרשות חז"ל. זה מלמד על האמונה בכוחו של ה' ועל הצורך בהכנה נפשית כדי לקבל את ישועתו.

passage_content: ב)סוף רות (פ"ז סי' י') וזאת לפנים בישראל על הגאולה ועל התמורה לקיים כל דבר, ר"ח פתר קרא בגו אפיא דישראל, לשעבר היו מקלסין על הגאולה שנאמר זה אלי ואנוהו, ועכשיו על התמורה שנאמר וימירו את כבודם בתבנית שור אוכל עשב וצ"ב, גם ראוי להבין קישור דרשא זו אל פשוטו של מקרא דמיירי בעניני קנין וחליפין.
translation: At the end of Ruth (Chapter 7, Section 10), it is stated: "And this was previously in Israel regarding redemption and transformation to fulfill all matters." R' Chaim interpreted the verse in the context of Israel. In the past, they would praise the redemption, as it is said, "This is my God, and I will glorify Him," and now regarding the transformation, as it is said, "And they exchanged their glory for the likeness of an ox that eats grass," and there is much to ponder. It is also fitting to understand the connection of this interpretation to the simple meaning of the text, which deals with matters of acquisition and exchange.
summary: The passage discusses the themes of redemption and transformation in the context of Israel's spiritual journey. It contrasts the past, where the focus was on praising God for redemption, with the present, where there is a shift towards a more materialistic understanding, symbolized by the exchange of divine glory for a mere image of a calf. This transformation highlights the need to comprehend the deeper connections between the scriptural interpretation and the practical aspects of acquisition and exchange, emphasizing the importance of maintaining spiritual integrity amidst worldly distractions.

passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם דברי הגמ' (ברכות ל"ח ע"א) ת"ר מה הוא אומר המוציא לחם מן הארץ ר"נ אומר מוציא לחם מן הארץ, אמר רבא במוציא כ"ע לאפליגי דאפיק משמע וכו', כי פליגי בהמוציא רבנן סברי המוציא דאפיק משמע וכו', ור"נ סבר המוציא דמפיק משמע שנאמר המוציא אתכם מתחת סבלות מצרים, ורבנן ההוא הכי קאמר להו קב"ה לישראל, כד מפיקנא לכו עבידנא לכו מילתא, כי היכי דידעיתו דאנא הוא דאפיקית יתכון ממצרים עכ"ד הגמ' וצ"ב דמשמע מכאן דבשעת יציאת מצרים עדיין לא ידעו אם הקב"ה הוא המוציא אותם ואיך יתכן זאת הלא ראו בעיניהם הנסים והנפלאות שעשה הקב"ה עמהם בשעת יציאתם ממצרים ואיך יסתפקו ח"ו שלא הקב"ה הוציא אותם, אמנם ענין זה מבואר בדבריהרמב"ם ז"ל (ה' יסוה"ת פ"ח ה"א) וז"ל משה רבינו לא האמינו בו ישראל מפני האותות שעשה, שהמאמין ע"פ האותות יש בלבו דופי, שאפשר שיעשה האות בלט וכשוף, אלא כל האותות שעשה משה במדבר לפי הצורך עשאם וכו', ובמה האמינו בו במעמד הר סיני, שעינינו ראו ולא זר ואזנינו שמעו ולא אחר וכו' עכ"ל הרי דבשעת יציאת מצרים עדיין לא נתברר בידם שכל האותות והמופתים הם מצד הקדושה.
translation: And we will explain before the words of the Gemara (Berakhot 38a): Our Rabbis taught: What does he say? "He who brings forth bread from the earth." Rabbi Natan says: "He brings forth bread from the earth." Rava said: In the case of "he who brings forth," all agree that it means "to bring forth," etc. When they argue about "he who brings forth," the Rabbis hold that "he brings forth" means "to bring forth," etc. And Rabbi Natan holds that "he brings forth" means "to take out," as it is said, "He who brought you out from under the burdens of Egypt." And the Rabbis say that this is what the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel: "When I bring you out, I will do something for you," so that you will know that I am the one who brought you out of Egypt. Thus far the Gemara. And it is difficult to understand from here that at the time of the Exodus from Egypt, they still did not know if the Holy One, blessed be He, was the one who brought them out. How could this be? They saw with their own eyes the miracles and wonders that the Holy One, blessed be He, performed for them at the time of their Exodus from Egypt, and how could they possibly doubt that the Holy One, blessed be He, had brought them out? However, this matter is clarified in the words of the Rambam, may his memory be blessed (Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah, Chapter 8, Halacha 1): "Moses our teacher was not believed by Israel because of the signs he performed, for one who believes based on signs has doubt in his heart, as it is possible that the sign was done through sorcery. Rather, all the signs that Moses did in the desert were done according to necessity, etc. And in what did they believe in him? At the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai, for 'Our eyes saw and not a stranger, our ears heard and not another,' etc." Thus, it is clear that at the time of the Exodus from Egypt, it was not yet clarified to them that all the signs and wonders were from the aspect of holiness.
summary: The passage discusses the uncertainty of the Israelites during the Exodus regarding the divine origin of their liberation, despite witnessing miraculous signs. It references the Talmudic debate on the interpretation of "the one who brings forth bread from the earth," highlighting differing views on the nature of divine intervention. The Rambam's insights emphasize that true faith was only established at Mount Sinai, where the Israelites directly experienced God's presence, contrasting with their earlier doubts rooted in the possibility of deception through signs. This reflects a deeper theological understanding of faith that transcends mere miracles, requiring a direct encounter with the divine.

passage_content: ונראהמדברי הרמב"ם ז"ל שמפרש מ"ש בגמרא כד אפיקנא יתכון עבידנא לכו מילתא דתדעו דאנא הוא דאפיקית יתכון הכוונה על מ"ת שנתברר להם בראי' ושמיעה שכל הנסים והאותות נעשה להם מהקב"ה, ואפ"ל עוד לעניננו שהכוונה גם על קרי"ס שגם אז נתברר לישראל שהכל מהקב"ה עפימ"ד במדרש רבה (פרשה כ"ג סימן ח') ר' יהודה אומר מי אמר קילוס להקב"ה התינוקות, אותן שהי' פרעה מבקש להשליך ליאור שהם מכירים להקב"ה, כיצד כשהיו ישראל במצרים, והיתה אשה מבנות ישראל מבקשת לילד, היתה יוצאת לשדה ויולדת שם, וכיון שהיתה יולדת עוזבת הנער ומוסרת אותו להקב"ה ואומרת, רבש"ע אני עשיתי את שלי ואתה עשה את שלך, א"ר יוחנן מיד הי' יורד הקב"ה בכבודו כביכול וחותך עיבורן ומרחיצן וסכן וכו', והיה נותן ב' טנרין בידו אחד מניקו שמן ואחד מניקו דבש וכו' וכיון שבאו ישראל לים, היו אותן התינוקות שם, והם ראו להקב"ה בים, התחילו אומרים לאבותיהם, זה אותו שהי' עושה לנו כל אותן הדברים כשהיינו במצרים שנאמר זה קלי ואנוהו עכ"ד המדרש. ולכאורה אינו מובן דהלא כל תואר גופני רחוק הוא מאתו ית', ומהו ענין ההכרה שהכירוהו אותן התינוקות ואמרו זה אלי וגו', ומ"ע הכירו יותר מאבותיהם.
translation: And it seems from the words of the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, that he explains what is said in the Gemara: "When I bring you out, you will do something that you will know that I am the one who brought you out." The intention is regarding the Torah that was clarified to them through seeing and hearing that all the miracles and signs were done for them by the Holy One, blessed be He. And it can also be said regarding our matter that the intention is also about the children’s recognition, for then it was also clarified to Israel that everything is from the Holy One, blessed be He. According to the Midrash Rabbah (Parashah 23, Siman 8), Rabbi Yehuda says: Who praised the Holy One, blessed be He? The infants, those whom Pharaoh sought to throw into the Nile because they recognized the Holy One, blessed be He. How so? When Israel was in Egypt, and a woman from the daughters of Israel sought to give birth, she would go out to the field and give birth there. And when she gave birth, she would leave the child and dedicate him to the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: "Master of the Universe, I have done my part, and You do Your part." Rabbi Yochanan said: Immediately the Holy One, blessed be He, would descend in His glory, as it were, and would cut the umbilical cord and wash them and wrap them, etc. And He would give two little cakes into their hands, one filled with oil and one filled with honey, etc. And when Israel came to the sea, those infants were there, and they saw the Holy One, blessed be He, at the sea. They began to say to their fathers: "This is the one who did all those things for us when we were in Egypt," as it is said: "This is my God, and I will glorify Him." Thus far the Midrash. And at first glance, it is not understood, for all physical attributes are distant from Him, and what is the matter of the recognition that those infants recognized Him and said: "This is my God," etc., and how did they recognize more than their fathers?
summary: The passage discusses the recognition of God's presence and miracles by the children of Israel, particularly the infants who were saved from Pharaoh's decree. It highlights that these children, even in their innocence, had a profound awareness of God's actions during their time in Egypt and at the Red Sea. The text emphasizes the idea that divine revelation and understanding can transcend intellectual comprehension, suggesting that the purity of the children's hearts allowed them to perceive God's greatness more clearly than their parents. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the innate connection between the soul and the Divine, emphasizing the importance of faith and spiritual awareness.

passage_content: אמנםידוע מספה"ק דזה לעומת זה עשה אלקים וכל מה שמתרחקין מצד הסט"א מתקרבין יותר אל צד הקדושה לזכות להשפעה אלקית ולהשיג את האמת, וישראל בגלות מצרים אע"פ שהיו מובדלים ומופרשים מתועבת מצרים מ"מ נכנס בהם קצת השפעה מטומאת מצרים מאכילת פירותי' כמ"ש הב"ח (או"ח סי' ר"ח) וגם מהשפעת שרו של מצרים וכדומה, שכ"ז השפיע במקצת עליהם ועי"ז לא הי' מאיר להם כ"כ השפעה אלקית, אמנם אותן התינוקות שניזונו ממזון שמים רוחני, נשפע עליהם הארה קדושה נפלאה ע"י קדושת המאכל וע"ד שכתב בספה"ק אגרא דכלה בשם הרה"ק הר"ר מענדלי מרימנוב זי"ע לפרש הפסוק ויראו בנ"י ויאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא כי לא ידעו מה הוא. שהי' המן דק ובהיר כ"כ ברוחניות, עד שע"י אכילתו נזדכך הגוף והי' ניכר לכ"א פנימיות חבירו ומחשבתו, והנה איש אשר הי' מכיר את חבירו ביום אתמול בלא הודע פנימיותיו, וחשבו לצדיק או בהיפוך, וביום שאכלו את המן נתוודע לו פנימיותו ולא הכירו כי נדמה בעיניו כאיש אחר, וזה ויאמרו איש אל אחיו מן הוא ר"ל מי הוא זה, כי נהפך לאיש אחר עכל"ק, ועד"ז אותן תינוקות שאכלו לחם מן השמים וניזונו מן הקדושה ונבנו על יסודי הקדושה בלא תערובת מאכל גשמי ובהבדלה גמורה מכוחות הטומאה, ע"כ הכירו הם הבוי"ת על הים והשיגו שכל הנסים שנעשו לישראל עד עכשיו ביצי"מ וקריעת ים סוף הם מסטרא דקדושה ע"י הקב"ה ואין בו תערובות מכוחות הטומאה ולפיכך אמרו זה אלי ואנוהו: דהנה כלל גדול הוא בכ"מ דתיבת זה בא למעט זה ולא אחר, ורמזו באמרם זה אלי ואנוהו למעט כל תערובת מצד הסט"א והם העידו על הגאולה שהיא מאת הקב"ה לבדו.
translation: It is known from the holy books that "this is opposite that" which God has made, and all that distance themselves from the side of the Other Side draw closer to the side of holiness to merit divine influence and to attain the truth. And Israel in the exile of Egypt, although they were separated and distinct from the abomination of Egypt, nevertheless, a bit of influence from the impurity of Egypt entered into them from eating its fruits, as mentioned by the Bach (Orach Chaim, Siman 238), and also from the influence of the angel of Egypt and the like, which all influenced them somewhat, and as a result, the divine influence did not shine upon them so much. However, those infants who were nourished by spiritual heavenly food received a wondrous holy illumination through the sanctity of the food, in accordance with what is written in the holy books Agra D'Kallah in the name of the holy Rabbi Mendel of Rimnov, may his merit protect us, to explain the verse "And the children of Israel saw and said to one another, 'What is it?' for they did not know what it was." The manna was so fine and clear in its spirituality that by eating it, the body was refined, and it was evident to everyone the inner thoughts of their friends. Behold, a person who recognized his friend yesterday without knowing his inner self, and thought him to be righteous or the opposite, on the day they ate the manna, his inner self was revealed to him, and he did not recognize him because he appeared to him as another person. This is what they meant when they said, "What is it?" meaning who is this, for he had transformed into another person, as explained. Similarly, those infants who ate the bread from heaven and were nourished by holiness and were built on the foundations of holiness without any mixture of physical food and with complete separation from the forces of impurity, therefore they recognized the Creator at the sea and understood that all the miracles that were done for Israel until now in Egypt and the splitting of the sea were from the side of holiness by the Holy One, blessed be He, and there was no mixture with the forces of impurity. Therefore, they said, "This is my God, and I will glorify Him": for behold, it is a great principle everywhere that the word "this" comes to exclude "that" and not another, and they hinted by saying "This is my God, and I will glorify Him" to exclude all mixture from the side of the Other Side, and they testified about the redemption that it is solely from the Holy One, blessed be He.
summary: The passage emphasizes the Hasidic concept that everything in creation exists in a balance between holiness and impurity, with the Jewish people in Egypt experiencing a dilution of divine influence due to their surroundings. However, those who consumed the heavenly manna were spiritually elevated, allowing them to perceive the true essence of one another and recognize the divine nature of their redemption. This recognition culminated in their declaration, "This is my God," signifying a pure connection to the divine, free from any contamination of the forces of impurity. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of divine influence and the distinction between holiness and impurity in the process of redemption.

passage_content: וזהוכוונת המדרש וזאת לפנים בישראל וגו' לשעבר היו מקלסין על הגאולה פי' שהיו יודעין ומבחיניםבגאולה שהוא מהקב"ה שנאמר זה אלי ואנוהו, שאותן התינוקות העידו עלי' באומרם זה אלי, אבל עכשיו על התמורה מחליפין כבוד השי"ת בכבוד הסט"א שחולקין כבוד למינות ולע"ז ולהירוס הדת ולזה נותנים שם של גאולה, ואין לך תמורה גדולה מזו, ורמז הפסוק כאן מה שיהי' בדורות האחרונים, דהנה איתא בזוה"ק פ' חקת (דף ק"פ ע"א) בענין קנין נעל שזה הי' רק לפנים בישראל כד הוו צנועין קדישין וכו' וכיון דאסגיאו חייבין כסיאו מלה בגוונא אחרא וכו', א"כ הפסוק הזה של וזאת לפנים בישראל מדבר מהירידה שיהי' בדורות האחרונים: וע"כ מצאו חז"ל מקום לרמז כאן חילוק זה שבין דורות הראשונים לדורות אלו בעיקבא דמשיחא שאז הללו ושבחו על הגאולה, ועכשיו בעוה"ר הילולא וחינגא על התמורה, גם שאז התחיל השתלשלות מלכות בית דוד שנתגלה ההלכה עמוני ולא עמונית מואבי ולא מואבית שהי' עד אותו זמן בהסתר מחמת הקטרוג, ואז נתגלה שורש מלכות בית דוד ע"י רות, לכן מצאו לנכון לרמוז כאן ענין השתלשלות הגאולה והתמורה שיהי' בדורות האחרונים קודם ביאת המשיח.
translation: And this is the intention of the Midrash, and this was previously in Israel, etc. In the past, they would praise the redemption, meaning they knew and distinguished that the redemption is from the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is said, "This is my God, and I will glorify Him," for those children testified about it by saying, "This is my God." But now, regarding the change, they exchange the honor of the Holy One, Blessed be He, for the honor of the other side, giving honor to heresy and idolatry and the destruction of the faith, and for this, they give it the name of redemption. There is no greater change than this, and the verse here hints at what will be in the last generations. Behold, it is stated in the Zohar, Parashat Chukat (page 120a), regarding the acquisition of the shoe, that this was only previously in Israel when they were modest and holy, etc. And since they have become obligated to their seat in another color, etc., therefore, this verse of "and this was previously in Israel" speaks of the descent that will be in the last generations. And thus, the Sages found a place to hint here at the distinction between the earlier generations and these generations in the footsteps of the Messiah, for then they would praise and glorify the redemption, and now, woe to us, they celebrate and rejoice over the change. Also, then the unfolding of the kingdom of the House of David began, when the law was revealed that an Ammonite may not enter the congregation, nor a Moabite, which until that time was hidden due to the accusation. Then the root of the kingdom of the House of David was revealed through Ruth. Therefore, they found it appropriate to hint here at the unfolding of the redemption and the change that will be in the last generations before the coming of the Messiah.
summary: הקטע מדגיש את השינוי בתודעה ובכבוד המיוחס לגאולה בין הדורות. בעבר, היה ברור שהגאולה היא מהקב"ה, אך כיום יש נטייה להחליף את כבוד ה' בכבוד של רעיונות זרים ומינות. המדרש רומז על הירידה הרוחנית שתחול בעיקבא דמשיחא, כאשר במקום לשבח את הגאולה, יהללו את התמורה. כמו כן, הוא מציין את חשיבות גילוי מלכות בית דוד דרך רות, כסימן להשתלשלות הגאולה והאתגרים שיבואו לפני ביאת המשיח.

passage_content: ובזהיובן מאמה"כ התיצבו וראו את ישועת ה' אשר יעשה לכם היום, דהנה חוץ ממה שהובטחו בנ"י מהבוכ"ע שיוושעו, צריכין עוד לישועה גדולה להיותם מבחינים ויודעים איזהו ישועת ה' דישועת ה' הוא רק מה שבא מהקב"ה שיכולין לומר עליו זה קלי ואנוהו ומביא קדושה וטהרה לסייע לעבודת השי"ת, וכל מי שיזכה לראות הגאולה שלימה יראה גודל השפעת אלקי שיורד על בנ"י מישועה אמיתית ואיך שנתקרבין להקב"ה, ואם יזכה יבחין ויראה עד כמה שנתרחקו ישראל ע"י הגאולה המרה, ולא רק אלו שנשקעו לגמרי בהטומאה, ואין יכולין לצאת רק ברחמי שמים כשהבוכ"ע יעזור ויהי' קיבוץ נידחים, רק גם כל יהודי אף מי שאינו עמהם נתרחק מיהדות ע"י גודל כח השפעתם, וצריכין לרחמי שמים והתחזקות שנוכל לעבוד השי"ת בזה השפלות.
translation: And in this is understood from our holy Torah, "Stand firm and see the salvation of the Lord which He will do for you today," for behold, aside from the promise given to the Jewish people from the Holy One, Blessed be He, that they will be saved, there is a need for a great salvation in order to discern and know what is the salvation of the Lord. The salvation of the Lord is only that which comes from the Holy One, Blessed be He, of which one can say, "This is my God, and I will glorify Him," and it brings holiness and purity to assist in the service of the Blessed Creator. And anyone who merits to see the complete redemption will witness the great divine influence descending upon the Jewish people from true salvation and how we draw closer to the Holy One, Blessed be He. And if one merits, they will discern and see how far Israel has distanced itself due to the bitter redemption, and not only those who have completely sunk into impurity, who can only emerge through heavenly mercy when the Holy One, Blessed be He, will help and there will be a gathering of the dispersed, but also every Jew, even one who is not with them, has distanced himself from Judaism due to the great power of their influence, and we need heavenly mercy and strengthening so that we can serve the Blessed Creator in this lowliness.
summary: המאמר מדגיש את הצורך בישועה גדולה לעם ישראל, מעבר להבטחות שניתנו להם, ומבאר כי ישועה זו נובעת מהקב"ה בלבד. יש להבין כי ישועת ה' מביאה קדושה וטהרה, ומי שיזכה לראות את הגאולה ירגיש את השפעת האלוקית המתרקמת בקרב העם. המאמר מציין גם את הריחוק שחשו ישראל מהיהדות בעקבות הגאולה המרה, ומדגיש את הצורך ברחמי שמים ובחיזוק רוחני כדי לשוב לעבודת ה' בשפלות זו.

passage_content: ולז"אמרע"ה לבנ"י הבטחה, דחוץ מהישועה יהי' להם עוד ישועה גדולה שיראו ויבינו מהו ישועת השי"ת, וז"ש התיצבו וראו את ישועת ה' מלשון (כתובות דף ק"ח ע"ב) רואה אנו את דברי אדמון, שיחשב בעיניכם רק ישועה הבאה מהשי"ת, דאותן שהן רחוקין מן האמת ר"ל רואין ישועה בדרכי המינות והסט"א, אבל הדבוק בבוכ"ע ועובד ה' באמת אינו רואה רק ישועת ה' ורק זה נראה בעיניו ולא זולת, ואמר "התיצבו" "וראו" את ישועת ה' אשר יעשה לכם היום, ע"ד הכתוב אשר יאמר היום בהר ה' יראה, פירש"י ז"ל היום הימים העתידין כמו עד היום הזה שבכלהמקרא, שכל הדורות הבאים הקוראים את המקרא הזה אומרים עד היום הזה על היום שעומדים בו יעיי"ש, ועד"ז כוונת הפסוק אשר יעשה לכם היום, שיהי' להבטחה זו קיום נצחי להשיג הבחנה אמיתית איזהו ישועת ה' וכנ"ל.
translation: And to say to Moshe Rabbeinu, a promise to the Children of Israel, that besides the salvation, there will be another great salvation, that they will see and understand what the salvation of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is. And this is what is meant by "stand firm and see the salvation of the Lord," from the language (Kethubot 108b) we see the words of Admon, that it should be considered in your eyes only as salvation that comes from the Holy One, Blessed be He. For those who are far from the truth, God forbid, see salvation through the ways of heresy and the Other Side, but one who is attached to the Blessed Creator and serves the Holy One, Blessed be He, truly sees only the salvation of the Lord, and this is what appears in his eyes and nothing else. And it says, "Stand firm" and "see" the salvation of the Lord which He will do for you today, in accordance with the verse "which will be said today on the mountain of the Lord, it will be seen," as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains that "today" refers to the days of the future, like "until this day" in the entire scripture, that all the future generations who read this scripture say "until this day" about the day they are standing in, as you can see there. And similarly, the intention of the verse "which He will do for you today" is that this promise will have an eternal fulfillment to achieve a true distinction of what is the salvation of the Lord, as mentioned above.
summary: המעבר מדבריו של משה רבנו לבני ישראל מדגיש את ההבטחה לישועה גדולה, שהיא הבנה עמוקה של ישועת ה' עצמה. יש המבחינים בין ישועות אמיתיות, המגיעות מהשי"ת, לבין ישועות שקריות הנובעות ממינות והסט"א. הדבקות בה' והעבודה האמיתית מאפשרות לראות רק את ישועת ה' ולא דבר אחר. ההבטחה היא שישועה זו תישאר נצחית ותאפשר לדורות הבאים להבין את מהות ישועת ה' בכל עת.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד בכוונת המאמר התיצבו וראו את ישועת ה' וגו', דהניצול בזכות עצמו זוכה לראות במפלתן של רשעים, משא"כ הניצול בזכות אחרים, ומה"ט נאמר ללוט אל תבט אחריך, מפני שלא ניצול אלא בזכות אברהם, וז"ש להם משרע"ה התיצבו ולא תעשו שום פעולה רק לבטוח בישועת ה', ועי"ז וראו את ישועת ה' אשר יעשה לכם היום, שתוושעו בזכות עצמכם ותוכלו לראות הישועה במו עיניכם.
translation: And furthermore, regarding the intention of the statement "Stand firm and see the salvation of the Lord," it is that one who is saved by his own merit is privileged to witness the downfall of the wicked, whereas one who is saved by the merit of others does not have this privilege. For this reason, it was said to Lot, "Do not look behind you," because he was saved only by the merit of Abraham. Therefore, Moshe said to them, "Stand firm and do not take any action, only trust in the salvation of the Lord," and through this, "and see the salvation of the Lord which He will perform for you today," that you will be saved by your own merit and will be able to see the salvation with your own eyes.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of personal merit in achieving salvation, contrasting those who are saved through their own righteousness with those who rely on the merits of others. It cites the example of Lot, who was saved due to Abraham's righteousness, highlighting that true salvation allows one to witness the downfall of the wicked. The instruction to stand firm and trust in God's salvation reflects a call to self-reliance in faith, leading to a direct experience of divine deliverance. Ultimately, the text underscores the value of individual spiritual effort in attaining a personal connection to God's redemptive power.

passage_content: ויאמרמשה אל העם התיצבו וראו את ישועת ה' וגו', איתא במכילתא ובתרגום יוב"ע וירושלמי ד' כתין נעשו ישראל על הים, אחת אומרת ליפול אל הים, ואחת אומרת לשוב למצרים, ואחת אומרת לעשות מלחמה כנגדן, ואחת אומרת נצווח כנגדן, זו שאומרת נפול לים, נאמר להם התיצבו וראו את ישועת ה', זו שאמרה נשוב למצרים נאמר להם כי כאשר ראיתם את מצרים וגו', זו שאמרה נעשה מלחמה כנגדן נאמר להם ה' ילחם לכם, זו שאמרה נצווח כנגדן נאמר להם ואתם תחרישון עכ"ד המכילתא, ראוי להבין סברת הכת שאמרה נפול לים ומה ירויחו בזה, וכמו"כ אינו מובן דעת הכת שאמרה נשוב למצרים, ואותן שאמרו נצווח כנגדן. מה יועיל הצעקה והם מחושקים בכלי קרב.
translation: And Moses said to the people, "Stand firm and see the salvation of the Lord," etc. It is stated in the Mechilta and in the Targum Yonatan and in the Jerusalem Talmud that four factions arose among Israel at the sea: one said to fall into the sea, another said to return to Egypt, another said to wage war against them, and another said to cry out against them. To the one who said to fall into the sea, it was said to them, "Stand firm and see the salvation of the Lord." To the one who said to return to Egypt, it was said to them, "For as you have seen the Egyptians," etc. To the one who said to wage war against them, it was said to them, "The Lord will fight for you." To the one who said to cry out against them, it was said to them, "And you shall be silent." Thus far from the Mechilta. It is fitting to understand the reasoning of the faction that said to fall into the sea and what they would gain from this. Likewise, it is not clear the opinion of the faction that said to return to Egypt, and those who said to cry out against them. What benefit is there in the cry when they are armed with weapons?
summary: In this passage, the various responses of the Israelites at the Red Sea illustrate the diverse human reactions to crisis and fear. Each perspective reflects a different theological insight: the call to stand firm and witness God's salvation emphasizes faith and trust in divine intervention, while the suggestions to flee, fight, or cry out reveal the struggle between despair and hope. The text highlights the importance of recognizing God's power and the futility of relying solely on human strategies in the face of overwhelming challenges. Ultimately, it underscores the central Hasidic belief in surrendering to God's will and the transformative nature of faith in moments of adversity.

passage_content: ב)(פ' כ"ד ס"ב) ויסע משה את ישראל, ר"י אומר אמרו ישראל באותה שעה, כלום הוציאנו הקב"ה ממצרים אלא בשביל ה' דברים. א' לתת לנו ביזת מצרים, ב' להרכיבנו על ענני כבוד, ג' לקרוע לנו את הים, ד' להפרע לנו מן המצרים, ה' לומר לפניו שירה, עכשיו כבר נתן לנו ביזת מצרים והרכיבנו על ענני כבוד, וקרע לנו את הים ופרע מן המצרים ואמרנו שירה לפניו נחזור למצרים, א"ל משה כך אמר לי המקום כי כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום וגו', אמרו לו כבר מתו כולן נחזור למצרים, א"ל באו ופרעו את השטר, שכך אמר לי הקב"ה בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב מה היתה סברתם שלא הוציאם הקב"ה אלא בשביל ה' דברים אלו בלבד, והלא היתה מוכרח היציאה משם דאלמלי התמהמהו היו משוקעים במ"ע שערי טומאה ומהו הנתינת טעם הזה דאחרי כל הנסים שעשה הקב"ה עמהם בטלה הכרח היציאה ושוב יוכלו לחזור למצרים.
translation: (Exodus 24:2) And Moses led Israel, Rabbi Yochanan says that Israel said at that time, "Did the Holy One, Blessed be He, take us out of Egypt for only five things? First, to give us the spoils of Egypt; second, to carry us on clouds of glory; third, to split the sea for us; fourth, to take vengeance on the Egyptians; fifth, to have us sing before Him." Now, He has already given us the spoils of Egypt, carried us on clouds of glory, split the sea for us, avenged us against the Egyptians, and we sang before Him. "Shall we return to Egypt?" Moses said to them, "Thus said the Holy One, Blessed be He, 'As you have seen the Egyptians today...'" They replied, "All of them have already died; let us return to Egypt." He said to them, "Come and pay the debt, for thus said the Holy One, Blessed be He, 'When you take the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain.'" Thus ends the Midrash. It is to be questioned what their reasoning was that the Holy One, Blessed be He, took them out only for these five things, when the exodus was necessary, for if they had delayed, they would have been sunk in the forty-nine gates of impurity. What is the reasoning behind this, that after all the miracles the Holy One, Blessed be He, performed for them, the necessity of the exodus was nullified, and they could return to Egypt?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the Jewish people express their belief that God redeemed them from Egypt for five specific purposes, including receiving the spoils of Egypt and experiencing divine miracles. However, after witnessing these miracles, they contemplate returning to Egypt, prompting Moses to remind them of God's command to serve Him at Mount Sinai. The text raises questions about their understanding of redemption, suggesting that their focus on these five reasons overlooks the necessity of their liberation from the spiritual depths of Egypt. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of recognizing the broader purpose of their exodus beyond immediate benefits.

passage_content: ואפ"לדכוונתם הי' לש"ש, וסברת הכתה שאמרה נפול לים וסבר עפי"ד הזוה"ק (פ' וישב קפ"ה ע"א) אמאי כתיב בראובן למען הציל אותו מידם להשיבו אל אביו, וכי לא חייש ראובן דאינון נחשין ועקרבין ינזקון לי' וכו', אמר ראובן טב למנפל לי' לגוי גובא דנחשין ועקרבין, ולא יתמסר בידא דשנאוי וכו', דזעירין אינון דיכלי לאשתזבא מידי בעלי בחירה וכו', דהכא אתר דנחשים ועקרבים אי איהו צדיקא קוב"ה ירחיש לי' ניסא, ולזמנין דזכו אבהן מסייעין לי' לבר נש וישתזיב מנייהו, אבל כיון דיתמסר בידא דשנאוי, זעירין אינון דיכלין לאשתזבא, ובג"כ אמר למען הציל אותו מידם, מידם דייקא וכו' עכ"ד הזוה"ק.
translation: And even though their intention was for the sake of Heaven, and the reasoning of the verse that says "fall into the sea" is according to the words of the Zohar (Parashat Vayeshev 85a), why is it written about Reuven "to save him from their hands to return him to his father"? And did Reuven not consider that there are snakes and scorpions that would harm him, etc.? Reuven said it is better for him to fall into the hands of a nation full of snakes and scorpions, and he would not be delivered into the hands of the hated one, etc. For they are small and are able to be saved from those with free will, etc. Here, in a place of snakes and scorpions, if he is a righteous person, the Holy One, blessed be He, will perform a miracle for him. And at times, if his fathers merit, they will assist him to be saved from them. But since he is delivered into the hands of the hated one, they are small and are able to be saved. And also, it says "to save him from their hands," specifically from their hands, etc. Thus concludes the Zohar.
summary: The passage discusses the intentions behind Reuven's actions to save Yosef from his brothers, referencing the Zohar's insights on divine protection. It emphasizes that while Reuven was aware of the dangers posed by "snakes and scorpions," he believed it was better for Yosef to fall into the hands of a foreign nation than to be delivered to his hostile brothers. The text highlights the concept of divine intervention, suggesting that a righteous person can invoke miracles, and that the protection from harm is contingent upon the nature of one's captors. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of divine assistance in overcoming perilous situations.

passage_content: ועד"זאפ"ל לענינינו כי בטחו ישראל בישועתו ית' שינצלו מיד המצריים, כי ידעו שמוכנים לקבלת התורה וע"ד כן הוציאם הקב"ה ממצרים, אמנם כוונתם הי' למעט בחי' הנס עד כמה שאפשר כי אם יתמסרו בידי שונאיהם יצטרכו לזכות גדול להנצל מידי בעלי בחירה כמבואר בזוה"ק, ע"כ להנצל מסכנה זו בחרו יותר ליפול לים, והקב"ה ירחיש להם ניסא להעלותם ממצולות ים. כאשר כבר אירע להם ככה כאמרז"ל (ב"ר פרשה צ"ז סימן ג') ס' רבוא ילדים הושלכו ליאור ביום א' ועלו כולם, גם אמרו חכז"ל (יבמות דף קכ"א ע"א) מים שאין להם סוף אשתו אסורה, א"ר גמליאל פעם א' הייתי מהלך בספינה וראיתי ספינה א' שנשברה והייתי מצטער על ת"ח שבה ומנו ר' עקיבא, וכשעליתי ביבשה בא וישב ודן לפני בהלכה וכו', אמרתי באותה שעה כמה גדולים דברי חכמים שאמרו וכו' מים שאין להם סוף אשתו אסורה עכ"ד הגמ' ופי' דיש כח לחז"ל לשנות הטבע, כמו שדרשו ז"ל לק"ל גומר עלי, וע"י כח תורתן שקבעו הלכה דמים שאין להם סוף אשתו אסורה, ניתנה כח הצלה גם בדרך הטבע ממים שאין להם סוף, וז"ש באותה שעה (שעלה ר"ע) אמרתי כמה גדולים דברי חכמים שאמרו מים שאין להם סוף אסורה, ואפשר דמה"ט אמרו נפול לים למעט בניסא, ושלא יצטרכו להנצל מידי בעלי בחירה שצריך זכות גדול לזה, והשיב משרע"ה להם אל תיראו התיצבו וראו את ישועת ה' אשר יעשה לכם היום וגו', כי כך הי' רצון הבוי"ת להגדיל בחינת הנס ועי"ז נתפרסם קדושת שמו ית' בעולם.
translation: And similarly, regarding our matter, that the Jews trusted in His salvation, blessed be He, that they would be saved from the hands of the Egyptians, for they knew they were prepared to receive the Torah, and thus the Holy One, blessed be He, took them out of Egypt. However, their intention was to minimize the aspect of the miracle as much as possible, for if they were to surrender into the hands of their enemies, they would need a great merit to be saved from those with free will, as explained in the Zohar. Therefore, to be saved from this danger, they chose rather to fall into the sea, and the Holy One, blessed be He, would perform a miracle for them to raise them from the depths of the sea. As it had already happened to them, as our sages of blessed memory said (Bereishit Rabbah, Parashah 97, Siman 3), six hundred thousand children were thrown into the river on the first day, and they all rose. They also said (Yevamot 121a), "Water that has no end, his wife is forbidden." Rabbi Gamliel said, "Once I was walking on a ship and I saw a ship that had broken, and I was distressed about the Torah scholar on it, and he was Rabbi Akiva. And when I ascended to dry land, he came and sat and judged before me in halacha," etc. I said at that time, "How great are the words of the sages who said, etc., 'Water that has no end, his wife is forbidden.'" Thus said the Gemara, and it explains that the sages have the power to change nature, as they have interpreted, "The law is concluded upon me." And through the power of their Torah, which established the law that "water that has no end, his wife is forbidden," the power of salvation was also granted in a natural way from water that has no end. And this is what I said at that time (when Rabbi Akiva ascended), "How great are the words of the sages who said, 'Water that has no end is forbidden.'" And it is possible that for this reason they said to fall into the sea to minimize the miracle, and so that they would not need to be saved from the hands of those with free will, which requires a great merit for that. And Moshe Rabbeinu responded to them, "Do not be afraid; stand firm and see the salvation of the Lord which He will perform for you today," etc., for thus was the will of the Creator to magnify the aspect of the miracle, and through this, His holy name would be proclaimed in the world.
summary: The passage discusses the faith of the Israelites in God's salvation from the Egyptians, emphasizing their readiness to receive the Torah. It highlights their choice to face the sea rather than fall into the hands of their enemies, reflecting a desire to minimize reliance on miracles. The text illustrates the power of the sages to alter natural laws through their teachings, suggesting that their wisdom provides a means of salvation even in dire circumstances. Ultimately, it conveys that God's intention was to magnify the miracle and sanctify His name in the world.

passage_content: וכמו"כהכת שאמרה נחזור למצרים אפשר שהי' ג"כ כוונתם לש"ש רק שטעו, ויתבאר עפי"מ שפירשתי מה שסרב מרע"ה כ"כ לילך בשליחות הקב"ה לגאול את ישראל יען שראה כי אין זה גאולה שלימה ויצטרכו בנ"י לסבול עוד גלות, וע"כ חשב שמוטב שיתעכבו עוד זמן מה עד שתהי' הגאולה שלימה ולא יסבלו גלות עוד ומה"ט סירב ולא רצה לילך, ועד"ז אמרו ישראל לאחר שיצאו מן הים, הרי הכרח היציאה הי' בשביל שלא נשקע ח"ו בנו"ן שערי טומאה, אבל אחרי יצאנו משם והרכיבנו על ענני כבוד ונתן לנו ביזת מצרים וקרע לנו את הים ופרע מן המצריםואמרנו שירה לפניו נחזור למצרים דמעתה יהי' לנו כח התגברות נגד כוחות הטומאה ומוטב יותר להמתין שם עד הגאולה הנצחית שאין אחרי' גלות ושעבוד, ועד"ז טענה גם אותה הכת שאמרו לשוב למצרים, אבל האמת שכבר עברה השעה וא"א לשנות, ואם יהי' להם זכותים גדולים יזכו שלא יהי' חורבן אלא שלא זכו לזה.
translation: And similarly, the sect that said we should return to Egypt may have also intended for the sake of Heaven, but they were mistaken. It will be explained according to what I have interpreted regarding why Moshe Rabbeinu so strongly refused to go on the mission of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to redeem Israel, because he saw that this was not a complete redemption and that the Jewish people would still have to endure further exile. Therefore, he thought it would be better to delay a little longer until the redemption would be complete and they would not suffer exile anymore. For this reason, he refused and did not want to go. Likewise, the Israelites said after they left the sea, the necessity of the exodus was so that we would not be submerged, Heaven forbid, in the fifty gates of impurity. But after we left there, He lifted us on clouds of glory, gave us the spoils of Egypt, split the sea for us, and exacted retribution from the Egyptians, and we sang a song before Him, saying we should return to Egypt, for from now on we would have the strength to overcome the forces of impurity, and it would be better to wait there until the eternal redemption, which has no subsequent exile or servitude. Similarly, that sect also argued to return to Egypt, but the truth is that the time has already passed, and it is impossible to change. If they have great merits, they will be granted that there will be no destruction, but they did not merit this.
summary: The passage discusses the mistaken desire of the Israelites to return to Egypt after their miraculous exodus, reflecting a misunderstanding of true redemption. It emphasizes that Moses refused God's mission to redeem the people because he foresaw that it would not lead to a complete salvation, resulting in further suffering. The text highlights the importance of waiting for a perfect redemption, free from subsequent exile and oppression, and suggests that the desire to return stemmed from a misguided belief that they could gain strength against the forces of impurity. Ultimately, it asserts that the time for such a return has passed, and true redemption cannot be altered by human desires.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד דהכת שאמרה נפול לים, השיגו שע"י כח המסנ"פ הזה שיפילו עצמם לים יזכו לנס קרי"ס, וכמ"ש רז"ל (סוטה דף ל"ז ע"א) שקפץ נחשון בן עמינדב לגלי הים באותה שעה אמר הקב"ה למשה ידידי משוקעים במים וכו' ואתה עומד ומרבה בתפלה וכו', ועד"ז הי' סברת הכת שאמרה נפול לים לעורר עי"ז כח הנס מיד, והשיב להם משרע"ה התיצבו וראו את ישועת ה' וגו', שימתינו עד שיצוה ה' כמ"ש דבר אל בנ"י ויסעו, ועד שתראו שהישועה מאת ה' אין לעשות דבר ע"ד עצמו, והכת שאמרה נלחום כנגדן השיב להם משה ה' ילחם לכם שאסור ללחום באומות על דעת עצמינו, ובענין הגאולה אסור לעשות שום פעולה אנושי, רק הבוי"ת ילחום מלחמתינו, ואפשר דהכת שאמרה נצווח כנגדן, יודעים היו להשתמש בשמות הקדושים, ועד"ז רצו לצווח כנגדן ולעשות בהם כלה בכח השמות הק', ואמר להם משה רבינו ואתם תחרישון, שכל פעולה אף בתפלה יותר מדאי אסורה בענין הגאולה.
translation: And furthermore, the sect that said to fall into the sea understood that through the power of this messianic force, by throwing themselves into the sea, they would merit the miracle of the splitting of the sea, as our sages of blessed memory said (Sotah 37a) that Nachshon ben Amminadav jumped into the waves of the sea, at that moment the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moshe, "My friend, they are submerged in the water," etc., and you stand and increase in prayer, etc. Similarly, the reasoning of the sect that said to fall into the sea was to evoke the power of the miracle immediately. And Moshe Rabbeinu responded to them, "Stand firm and see the salvation of the Lord," etc., that they should wait until the Lord commands, as it is said, "Speak to the Children of Israel and let them journey," and until you see that the salvation is from the Lord, one should not take any action on their own accord. And the sect that said to fight against them, Moshe replied to them, "The Lord will fight for you," for it is forbidden to fight against the nations on our own authority. And regarding the redemption, it is forbidden to take any human action; only the Blessed One will wage our war. And it is possible that the sect that said to cry out against them knew how to use the holy names, and thus they wanted to cry out against them and destroy them with the power of the holy names. And Moshe Rabbeinu said to them, "And you shall be silent," for any action, even in prayer, more than necessary, is forbidden regarding the redemption.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of relying solely on divine intervention for salvation, as exemplified by the Israelites at the Red Sea. It emphasizes that human actions, even in prayer or invoking sacred names, should not precede God's command, as true redemption comes from the Almighty alone. Moses instructs the people to remain silent and wait for God's guidance, highlighting the importance of faith and trust in divine will over personal initiative in matters of redemption. This reflects a core Hasidic belief in surrendering to God's plan and recognizing His sovereignty in the process of salvation.
