passage_content: ואיתאבמדרש שמואל (אבות סו"פ ששי משנה י"א) כל מה שברא הקב"ה בעולמו לא ברא אלא לכבודו שנאמר כל הנקרא בשמי ולכבודי בראתיו יצרתיו אף עשיתיו, ואומר ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, ופי' המדרש שמואל אמר עוד ואומר ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, הנראה שאין לו קשר כלל עם האמור, ואפשר שהכוונה וכו' דתינח בשאר העולמות שלא בראם אלא לכבודו לפי שכולם מעריצין ומקדישין את שם הא' המלך הגדול הגבור והנורא, אמנם עולם העשי' אשר ראה ראינו כי גברה יד סט"א ויצר לב האדם רע מנעוריו להכעיס את בוראו, א"כ אין בריאת עוה"ז לכבודו ית' וטוב לו שלא נברא, לזה תירץ כי אף אם עתה רבו כמו רבו עבדים המתפרצים למרות עיני כבודו, עכ"ז לעתיד לבוא יהיה ה' אחד ושמו אחד, ולז"א ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד ואז יהי' כל העולם לאחד לקרוא בשם ה' וכו', נמצא שאף עולםהעשיה לא בראו אלא לכבודו עכ"ל, וידוע שגאולה העתידה תלוי בתשובה, וכמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל (ה' תשובה פ"ז ה"ה) אין ישראל נגאלין אלא בתשובה וכבר הבטיחה תורה שסוף ישראל לעשות תשובה בסוף גלותן ומיד הן נגאלין, ובזה יובן סיום דברי המדרש כששאל משה מהקב"ה ומה עלי לעשות והשיב לו הבורא יתברך שמו ואתה הרם את מטך ונטה את ידך ורמז לו שאין הדבר תלוי אלא בתשובה כנ"ל, באותה שעה אמרו ישראל ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד כי השיגו ישראל שגם גאולה העתידה תליא בתשובה ובזכות התשובה נזכה לבחי' ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד שיהי' מלא כל הארץ כבודו ואף עולם העשי' כנ"ל.
translation: And it is taught in the Midrash Shmuel (Ethics of the Fathers, Chapter 6, Mishnah 11) that everything the Holy One, Blessed be He, created in His world, He created only for His honor, as it is said, "Everyone who is called by My name, and for My glory I have created him, I have formed him, yes, I have made him." And it says, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever." The Midrash Shmuel further explains and says, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," which seems to have no connection at all to what was said. It is possible that the intention is that this applies to the other worlds, which He did not create except for His honor, since all of them glorify and sanctify the name of the Almighty, the great, mighty, and awesome King. However, in the world of action, we have seen that the hand of the Other Side has prevailed, and the inclination of man's heart is evil from his youth, to provoke his Creator. Therefore, the creation of this world is not for His honor, and it would have been better for him not to have been created. To this, it is answered that even if now there are many like the many rebellious servants who defy the honor of His presence, nevertheless, in the future, the Lord will be one and His name one. This is to say, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," and then the whole world will be united to call upon the name of the Lord, etc. Thus, even the world of action was created only for His honor. It is known that the future redemption depends on repentance, as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote (Laws of Repentance, Chapter 7, Halacha 5) that Israel will not be redeemed except through repentance, and the Torah has already promised that in the end, Israel will repent at the end of their exile, and immediately they will be redeemed. In this, the conclusion of the Midrash's words is understood when Moses asked the Holy One, Blessed be He, "What shall I do?" and the Creator, blessed be His name, answered him, "And you lift up your staff and stretch out your hand," hinting to him that the matter depends only on repentance, as mentioned. At that time, Israel said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," for they understood that the future redemption is dependent on repentance, and by virtue of repentance, we will merit the aspect of "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," that the whole earth will be filled with His glory, even the world of action, as mentioned.
summary: The passage emphasizes that everything created by God is for His honor, as stated in the verse "For My glory I have created, formed, and made." It acknowledges the struggle of the physical world, where human inclination often leads to sin, yet it affirms that ultimately, God's sovereignty will prevail, and all will recognize His oneness. The text connects the future redemption of Israel to the concept of repentance, highlighting that true salvation is contingent upon returning to God. Thus, the future acknowledgment of God's kingship will encompass all creation, including the physical world, through the power of repentance.

passage_content: ויבואובני ישראל בתוך הים ביבשה, במד"ר (פרשה כ"א סי' י') אם בים למה ביבשה ואם ביבשה למה בתוך הים אלא מכאן אתה למד שלא נקרע להם הים עד שבאו לתוכו עד חוטמן ואח"כ נעשה להם יבשה, ובמקו"א איתא בדרז"ל שלא נקרע הים עד שקפץ נחשון בן עמינדב לתוך הים, ואפ"ל דאין בזה סתירה, דנחשון הי' הראשון שהראה להם הדרך אולם לא נתייבשו המים עד שכל ישראל קפצו לתוך הים.
translation: And the children of Israel came into the sea on dry land, as it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat 21, Siman 10): If they were in the sea, why on dry land? And if on dry land, why in the sea? Rather, from here you learn that the sea was not split for them until they came into it up to their ankles, and then dry land was made for them. And in another place, it is stated in the Sages that the sea was not split until Nachshon ben Amminadav jumped into the sea. And it can be said that there is no contradiction in this, for Nachshon was the first to show them the way; however, the waters did not become dry until all of Israel jumped into the sea.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous crossing of the Red Sea by the Israelites, emphasizing that the sea did not part until they demonstrated faith by entering it. It highlights the role of Nachshon ben Aminadav, who was the first to leap into the water, symbolizing the importance of taking initiative in faith. The text conveys a key Hasidic concept that divine intervention often requires human action and trust, illustrating the relationship between faith and redemption. Ultimately, it teaches that true miracles occur when individuals commit themselves fully to their beliefs.

passage_content: ולבארהענין מדוע לא נקרע הים עד שקפצו לתוכו ובאו במים עד חוטמן, אפ"ל עפימ"ש בספה"ק דברי חיים (פ' נח) עה"כ קץ כל בשר בא לפני, דאיתא בזוה"ק דעל כל החטאים מהני תשובה, לבר מההוא חטא הידוע פגם הברית מדת היסוד דלא מהני כ"א בתיובתא סגי, וטעם הדבר מבואר בספרים דהחטא פוגם האדם במדותיו, ובמדה שחוטא מסיר עצמו משרשי הקדושה וכו' ובעשותו תשובה מביא חיות חדש משורשו אל האבר והצנור שנחלש וכו', אך בחטא החמור הנ"ל ר"ל הוא כמסיר שרשו לגמרי כמבואר בספה"ק, ולכן כמעט אין לו תרופה, ואך בקושי תשובה מעורר אדם הנהגה רצונית למעלה מהטבע יחון ונעתר לה' גם בשובו מחטא זה. ולעיל מזה כתב עיקר הדבר למסור נפשו להקב"ה בהשתוקקות רב עד דכדוכה של נפש, ומתוקן בזה מה שחרבו העולמות ובא עד הקץ יעייש"ד.
translation: To explain the matter of why the sea did not split until they jumped into it and came into the water up to their necks, one can say according to what is written in the holy book Divrei Chaim (Parashat Noach) regarding the verse "The end of all flesh has come before Me," that it is stated in the Zohar that for all sins, repentance is effective, except for that known sin of the breach of the covenant, the attribute of the foundation, which only has a remedy through a significant repentance. The reason for this is explained in the books that the sin damages a person in their attributes, and in the attribute in which one sins, they remove themselves from the roots of holiness, etc. And by doing repentance, they bring new vitality from their root to the limb and the channel that has weakened, etc. However, in the aforementioned grave sin, it is as if one completely removes their root, as explained in the holy books, and therefore there is almost no remedy for it. Only with difficulty does repentance awaken a person to a voluntary conduct above nature, and they will be graciously answered by the Holy One, blessed be He, even when returning from this sin. Furthermore, it is written above that the main thing is to give one's soul to the Holy One, blessed be He, with great longing until the very essence of the soul, and in this, what has been destroyed in the worlds is rectified, and it reaches the end, as it is written.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of deep commitment and self-sacrifice in the process of repentance, particularly in relation to the severe sin of violating the covenant (P'gam HaBrit). It emphasizes that while most sins can be rectified through repentance, this specific sin severely damages one's spiritual roots, making true atonement exceedingly difficult. The text highlights that genuine repentance requires a profound yearning for God, which can invoke divine mercy and restoration, even in the face of such grave transgressions. Ultimately, it underscores the transformative power of sincere devotion and the potential for renewal despite the destruction caused by sin.

passage_content: והנהאמרז"ל במדרש (ילקוט ראובני) שהי' קטרוג גדול על ישראל בעמדם על הים והשר של מצרים והס"מ קטרגו הללו עובדי ע"ז והללו עובדי ע"ז הללו מג"ע והללו מג"ע, ובאמת היו ישראל גדורים מעריות במצרים כאמרז"ל במד"ר (ויק"ר פ' ל"ב סי' ה') אחת היתה ופירסמה הכתוב, ואיתא בזוה"ק שאף מאיסור נדה הוזהרו ואף שלא היו מצווין עדיין ומכ"ש מעריות בפועל, אמנם אם מידי עבירה נשמרו מידי הרהור לא ניצולו. וטומאת המקום גרם, שהיובמצרים ערות הארץ במ"ט שערי טומאה ובלי תורה לא היו יכולין להטהר ממחשבות והרהורים רעים, והרבינו יונה כתב דבעבר ושנה גם מחשבה רעה הקב"ה מצרפה למעשה, וכמו"כ נכשלו בע"ז לצד גודל טומאת הארץ, לכן על מה שנכשלו בע"ז הי' התיקון מ"ש בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה שקבלו אח"כ את התוה"ק וע"ש זכות העתיד נתלה להם, ועל הקטרוג הללו מג"ע הי' תיקונם ע"י מסירת נפש, לכן הוצרכו למסור נפשם ולקפוץ בתוך הים, ובזה עזרם הבוכ"ע וניצולו מהקטרוג ועברו הים בחרבה.
translation: And behold, our sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash (Yalkut Reuveni) that there was a great accusation against Israel as they stood by the sea, and the minister of Egypt and the accuser (Satan) accused them, saying: "These are idol worshippers, and those are idol worshippers; these are from forbidden relations, and those are from forbidden relations." In truth, Israel was guarded from forbidden relations in Egypt, as our sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashah 32, Section 5): "There was one [forbidden relation], and the verse made it known." And it is stated in the Zohar that they were even warned against the prohibition of nida, even though they were not yet commanded, and certainly they were guarded from forbidden relations in practice. However, if they were protected from sin, they were not saved from improper thoughts. The impurity of the place caused it, for the land of Egypt was filled with the impurity of the forty-nine gates of impurity, and without the Torah, they could not purify themselves from evil thoughts and reflections. Rabbi Yonah wrote that in the past and in the future, even a bad thought is considered as an action by the Holy One, Blessed be He. Likewise, they stumbled in idol worship due to the great impurity of the land. Therefore, regarding their stumbling in idol worship, the rectification was what was said: "When you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain," where they later received the Torah and the merit of the future was dependent upon them. And for the accusation of these forbidden relations, their rectification was through self-sacrifice; therefore, they needed to sacrifice themselves and jump into the sea. In this, the Blessed One helped them, and they were saved from the accusation and crossed the sea on dry land.
summary: The passage discusses the significant spiritual challenges faced by the Israelites at the Red Sea, where they were accused by the Egyptian minister and the Satan of idolatry. Despite their physical abstention from immoral acts in Egypt, they struggled with negative thoughts due to the impurity of the land. Their eventual redemption came through their willingness to sacrifice themselves by jumping into the sea, which allowed them to overcome these accusations and ultimately receive the Torah. This act of self-sacrifice was crucial for their spiritual elevation and liberation from the spiritual defilement of Egypt.

passage_content: ובמד"ר(פרשה כ"א סי' ה') וישאו בני ישראל את עיניהם והנה מצרים נוסע אחריהם ראו שרן של מצרים פורח באויר, כיון שראו אותו נתייראו הרבה שנא' ויראו מאוד, לכאורה מדוע נתייראו כ"כ הלא בכל מלחמה כן הוא שהשרים של מעלה באים לעזרת אומתם, ואפ"ל בכוונת הענין דהנה שורש החטאים ומדות רעות שנכשלים בה בנ"א בא מכח שר של האומה שדרים בה, דכ"א י"ל מדה רעה אחרת וכמו שכתב בספה"ק מאור ושמש (הו"ד לעיל פ' וארא), וכשיצאו בנ"י ממצרים השיגו עד היכן משוקעים בטומאת מצרים, ולצד זה הי' יראתם משר של מצרים נוסע אחריהם, דמפני שראו וימרו על ים בים סוף. שמקצתם לא אבו שמוע בקול ה', הבינו שזהו מהשפעה רע של שר מצרים ועדיין לא יצאו ממנו לגמרי, וז"ש שרן של מצרים נוסע אחריהם שהשפעתו הרע עדיין נדבק בהם ונוסע אחריהם וע"כ נתייראו הרבה מאוד, ובזה פי' הכתוב הושיעני אלקים כי באו מים עד נפש, דהנה מים ירמוז על אומה"ע, וכמ"ש המפורשים הפסוק מקולות מים רבים אדירים משברי ים, דהכוונה על האומה"ע, והשפעתם הרעה הגיע עד הנפש של כ"א מישראל וגם להגדולים שהם נפש העם, השי"ת ירחם עלינו ויצילנו מהם כי כבר באו מים עד נפש.וכתב במסילת ישרים ע"ד הגמרא (ב"ב דף ע"ח ע"ב) על כן יאמרו המושלים, אלו המושלים ביצרם, באו חשבון בואו ונחשוב חשבונו של עולם הפסד מצוה כנגד שכרה ושכר עבירה כנגד עבירה, דלכאורה כל אחד צריך לחשוב חשבון הזה ומדוע אמר המושלים ביצרם דייקא, ופירש הוא ז"ל דהמקושר ודבוק בהבלי עוה"ז אין במציאות שיעשה חשבון אמיתי וצודק מפני שמשוחד אל תאוותיו ורצוניותיו, וז"ש ע"כ יאמרו המושלים ביצרם דייקא, שהם יכולים לחשוב חשבונו של עולם, ומי שאינו בגדר זה אינו יכול לעשות חשבון אמיתי עכ"ד, ובעוה"ר בזמנינו אלה מי יאמר זכיתי לבי טהרתי מחטאי, ומי יוכל להתפאר שהוא מהמושלים ביצרם, ואין בידינו לחדש עצות ודרכים חדשים בשמירת התוה"ק ובעבדות הבוב"ה וכדומה, דחשבונו של עולם יכולים לחשוב רק המושלים ביצרם דייקא, ואנו אין לנו אלא דרכי אבותינו ורבותינו הקדושים שהנחילו לנו דרך האמת ומפיהם אנו חיים שהם היו המושלים ביצרםבאמת ובעוה"ר המה הלכו למנוחות ואותנו עזבו לאנחות, ואין לנו רק לילך בעקבי הצאן שהפסיעות והעקביים ניכרים.
translation:
In the Midrash (Parashat 21, Siman 5), it is written: "And the children of Israel lifted their eyes, and behold, Egypt was traveling after them; they saw the minister of Egypt flying in the air. When they saw him, they were very afraid, as it is said, 'and they were very afraid.' At first glance, why were they so afraid? Is it not the case that in every war, the ministers from above come to assist their nation? It could be understood in the context that the root of sins and bad traits that people stumble upon comes from the power of the minister of the nation that dwells within them. Each one has a different bad trait, as it is written in the holy books, Maor v'Shemesh (quoted above, Parashat Va'era). When the children of Israel left Egypt, they realized how deeply they were immersed in the impurity of Egypt. Alongside this, they were afraid of the minister of Egypt traveling after them, for they saw that they rebelled against the voice of God at the Sea of Reeds. Some of them did not want to listen to the voice of God; they understood that this was due to the evil influence of the minister of Egypt, and they had not yet completely departed from him. Therefore, it is said, 'the minister of Egypt is traveling after them,' meaning that his evil influence was still clinging to them and traveling after them, and thus they were very afraid. In this, the verse is explained: 'Save me, O God, for the waters have come up to my soul,' for the waters hint at the nations of the world, as the commentators explain the verse, 'From the voices of many waters, mighty are the breakers of the sea,' referring to the nations of the world. Their evil influence reached the very soul of each one of Israel, including the great ones who are the soul of the people. May the Holy One, blessed be He, have mercy on us and save us from them, for the waters have already come up to my soul.

And it is written in Mesilat Yesharim regarding the Gemara (Baba Batra 78b): 'Therefore, the rulers will say, those who rule over their desires, come let us calculate the account of the world, the loss of a mitzvah against its reward and the reward of a transgression against the transgression.' At first glance, everyone should think about this account, and why is it specifically said 'the rulers over their desires'? He explained that one who is connected and attached to the vanities of this world cannot truly and justly make an account because he is biased towards his desires and inclinations. Therefore, it is said, 'the rulers over their desires,' specifically they can think about the account of the world, and one who is not within this category cannot make a true account. In our times, who can say, 'I have merited to purify my heart from my sins,' and who can boast that he is among those who rule over their desires? We have no ability to innovate new advice and new ways in the observance of the Torah and in the service of the Blessed One, and so on, for the account of the world can only be thought of by those who rule over their desires specifically. We have nothing but the ways of our forefathers and our holy teachers who bequeathed to us the path of truth, and from their words we live, for they were truly the rulers over their desires, and in our times they have gone to rest and left us to sigh. We have no choice but to walk in the footsteps of the flock, where the steps and the footprints are evident."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the fear of the Israelites upon seeing the Egyptian forces pursuing them, emphasizing that their fear stemmed from the lingering influence of the Egyptian spiritual forces, which represented their unresolved sins and negative traits. The text highlights the importance of self-awareness and the struggle against one's inner impulses, suggesting that true understanding of divine justice and accountability is only accessible to those who have mastered their desires. The author laments the current state of spiritual decline, asserting that only the teachings of the righteous ancestors can guide the faithful in navigating their spiritual challenges. Ultimately, the passage calls for reliance on the paths laid out by previous generations to achieve true connection with God amidst the trials of life.

passage_content: ויסראת אופן מרכבותיו וינהגהו בכבדות, במדרש ילקוט (הובא ברש"י ז"ל) מחמת האש שלמעלן נשרפו גלגלין שלמטן והיו מוטות, ומרכבות רצות ונכנסות על כרחן וכו', דרך ארץ המרכבות נמשכות אחר הפרדים, עכשיו מרכבות מושכות את הפרדים עכ"ד המדרש, ראוי להבין למה עשה ה' נס זה לשנות מדרך הרגיל שהמרכבות נמשכות אחר הפרדים ועכשיו מרכבות מושכות את הפרדים ומה צורך בנס הזה.
translation: And He made the chariots heavy and drove them heavily. In the Midrash Yalkut (brought in Rashi, may his memory be blessed), it is explained that because of the fire from above, the wheels below were burned and were bent, and the chariots ran and entered against their will, etc. Normally, the chariots are drawn after the mules, but now the chariots are pulling the mules, thus concludes the Midrash. It is fitting to understand why the Holy One, blessed be He, performed this miracle to change the usual way that the chariots are drawn after the mules, and now the chariots are pulling the mules, and what is the need for this miracle.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on a miraculous event where the chariots, typically drawn by horses, are instead pulling the horses due to a divine intervention. This reversal of the natural order serves to illustrate God's sovereignty over creation and the transformative power of faith. The text invites contemplation on the reasons behind such miracles, emphasizing the importance of understanding divine will and the lessons it imparts about reliance on God. Ultimately, it highlights the dynamic relationship between the spiritual and physical realms, showcasing how divine influence can alter the course of nature.

passage_content: ב)ילקוט (רמז רמ"א) בשעה שבקש הקב"ה להטביע את מצרים, עמד עוזא שר של מצרים לפני הקב"ה ואמר לפניו רבש"ע נקראת צדיק וישר וכו' למה אתה רוצה להטביע מצרים כלום הטביעו בני מבניך או הרגו מהם וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, והיא פליאה נשגבה איך יתכן לטעון שיקרא קמי שמיא הלא גזרו בגלוי כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכוהו ואמרו רז"ל (ב"ר פ' צ"ז ס"ה) ששים רבוא ילדי ישראל הושלכו ליאור גם הרגו הרבה ורמסו בטיט כמבואר בדברי חז"ל, ואיך יטעון שקר לפני הקב"ה.
translation: In the Yalkut (Remez Rema), it is stated that when the Holy One, blessed be He, sought to drown Egypt, Uzza, the minister of Egypt, stood before the Holy One and said, "Master of the Universe, You are called righteous and upright, etc. Why do You want to drown Egypt? Did they drown any of Your children or kill any of them?" Thus concludes the Midrash. It is a wondrous astonishment how it is possible to argue before Heaven, for it was openly decreed, "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river," and our Sages have said (Bereishit Rabbah, chapter 67, section 5) that six hundred thousand Israelite children were cast into the river, and many were killed and trampled in the mud, as explained in the words of our Sages. How can he lie before the Holy One, blessed be He?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on a midrashic account where the angel Uzza, representing Egypt, challenges God’s intention to drown the Egyptians during the Exodus. Uzza questions why God would punish Egypt when they had not killed any of His children, despite the historical reality of the mass slaughter of Israelite infants. This highlights a profound theological tension between divine justice and mercy, illustrating the complexities of accountability and the moral implications of divine judgment in the face of human suffering. The passage invites contemplation on the nature of righteousness and the challenges of understanding divine actions in the context of human history.

passage_content: ג)במדרש ילקוט (רמז רל"ד) והמים להם חומה מלמד שירד ס"מ, ואמר רבש"ע לא עבדו ישראלע"ז במצרים ואתה עושה להם נסים, מה הללו עובדי ע"ז אף הללו עובדי ע"ז, אמר לו הקב"ה שוטה שבעולם והלא לא עבדו אלא מתוך שעבוד ומתוך טירוף דעת ואתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצון, וקשה מדוע תלה זה בזה דכמו שהם עוע"ז גם ישראל כן, ואם יש בטענה זו ממש יספיק אם יאמר הללו עוע"ז ומ"ט הוצרך לתלותו במה שהמצריים עוע"ז, גם יש להבין התירוץ שישראל לא עבדו אלא מתוך שעבוד והיו אנוסים הלא ע"ז ביהרג ואל יעבור וליתא לטענת אונס.
translation: In the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 274), it is taught that the waters were a wall for them, which indicates that a certain measure (S"M) descended. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: "The Israelites did not serve idols in Egypt, and yet You perform miracles for them. Just as these (the Egyptians) are idol worshippers, so too are these (the Israelites) idol worshippers." The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied: "Fool of the world! They did not serve out of free will, but rather out of servitude and madness. And you judge the unwitting as if they were deliberate, and the coerced as if they were willing." It is difficult to understand why He connected this to that, as if they are idol worshippers like the Egyptians. If there is substance to this claim, it would suffice to say that these are idol worshippers. And why was it necessary to connect it to the fact that the Egyptians are idol worshippers? Additionally, one must understand the response that the Israelites did not serve except out of servitude and were coerced, for idol worship is a matter of "be killed and do not transgress," and the claim of coercion does not apply.
summary: The passage discusses a Midrashic interpretation regarding the Israelites' worship of idols in Egypt, emphasizing that their actions were not genuine but rather a result of oppression and mental turmoil. It highlights the distinction between intentional sin and actions performed under duress, suggesting that God recognizes the context of their suffering. The text critiques the notion that the Israelites could be judged as idolaters like the Egyptians, asserting that their circumstances mitigate their culpability. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexities of divine judgment and the nature of sin in relation to human suffering.

passage_content: ונראהליישב בהקדם דברי רש"י ז"ל עה"כ ויקח שש מאות רכב בחור וגו', ומהיכן היו הבהמות הללו, אם תאמר משל מצרי הרי נאמר וימת כל מקנה מצרים, וא"ת משל ישראל והלא נאמר וגם מקנינו ילך עמנו, משל מי היו, מהירא את דבר ה' ע"כ, רואים מזה כמה גדולה התקלה לישראל אם היראים את דבר ה' הם עבדי פרעה, שאילולא הם לא הי' לו לפרעה במה להלחם עם ישראל, ועל כרחן צריכין למימר שהיו יראים את דבר ה' עכ"פ מיראת העונש שהרי הכתוב מעיד עליהם ככה, ואפשר שהם לא הטביעו ילדי ישראל וגם לא עבדו ע"ז, ועפי"ז שפיר טען עוזא שר של מצרים כלום הטביעו בני מבניך או הרגו מהם ורצה עכ"פ להציל היראי ה' כי אלו היראים את דבר ה' באמת לא היו מהטובעים וגם לא הרגו ילדי ישראל, אמנם מפני שהיו מעבדי פרעה ונכנעים אליו נחשבו גם הם כמוהו וכמאמר הכתוב מושל מקשיב על דבר שקר כל משרתיו רשעים, ואפשר שעד"ז הי' הס"מ מקטרג על ישראל, דבאמת בעת שעמדו ישראל על הים כבר נפרשו מע"ז, אמנם טענתו הו' עד"ז, דכמו הירא את דבר ה' מעבדי פרעה, נדונים אף על הרע שלא עשו בעצמם, אלא מפני שהם עבדי פרעה נחשבים כמוהו מטעם דמושל מקשיב על דבר שקר כל משרתיו רשעים, ולפי"ז הרי גם ישראל היו עבדים לפרעה ומה הללו עובדי ע"ז אף הללו עובדי ע"ז שצ"ל נחשבים כמוהו כמוהם, והשיב לו הקב"ה שוטה שבעולם והלא לא עבדו אלא מתוך שעבוד ומתוך טירוף הדעת ואתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצון. דהרי מה שעבדו את פרעה לא מרצונם עשו זאת אלא שהיו אנוסים, אבל אלו היראים את דבר ה' מעצמם נעשו עבדים לפרעה ומרצונם הטוב השתתפו אליו לכך נחשבים כמוהו להיות נענשים על כל רעתו.
translation: And it is appropriate to address promptly the words of Rashi, of blessed memory, on the verse "And he took six hundred chosen chariots," and from where were these beasts? If you say they were from the Egyptians, it is stated, "And all the livestock of Egypt died." And if you say they were from Israel, behold, it is said, "And also our livestock will go with us." Whose were they? Those who feared the word of God, therefore we see how great the calamity is for Israel if those who fear the word of God are the servants of Pharaoh. For had it not been for them, Pharaoh would not have had anything to fight against Israel. Necessarily, we must say that they feared the word of God, at least out of fear of punishment, as the scripture testifies about them thus. And it is possible that they did not drown the children of Israel and did not serve idols. Based on this, it is reasonable that Oza, the minister of Egypt, argued, "Did your children drown any of my children or kill any of them?" He wanted, at least, to save those who fear God, for those who truly fear the word of God were not among the drowned and did not kill the children of Israel. However, because they were servants of Pharaoh and submitted to him, they were also considered like him, as the scripture says, "A ruler who listens to falsehood, all his servants are wicked." And it is possible that similarly, the accuser was slandering Israel, for at the time when Israel stood by the sea, they had already distanced themselves from idolatry. However, his claim was similar, that just as those who fear the word of God are servants of Pharaoh, they are judged even for the evil they did not do themselves, but because they are servants of Pharaoh, they are considered like him, due to the principle that "A ruler who listens to falsehood, all his servants are wicked." According to this, Israel were also servants of Pharaoh, and if these were idol worshippers, then these are also idol worshippers, and they must be considered like him and like them. And the Holy One, blessed be He, replied to him, "Fool of the world! They did not serve except out of servitude and out of madness, and you judge the unwitting as if they were deliberate and the coerced as if they were willing." For what they served Pharaoh, they did not do of their own will, but rather they were coerced. But those who fear the word of God became servants of Pharaoh of their own accord and willingly participated with him; therefore, they are considered like him to be punished for all his evil.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the Israelites' servitude to Pharaoh, emphasizing that even those who feared God were considered complicit due to their status as Pharaoh's servants. It highlights the severity of their situation, suggesting that their fear of divine punishment did not absolve them from the consequences of their association with evil. The text argues that while the Israelites may not have actively participated in idolatry or the oppression of their own children, their voluntary servitude to Pharaoh rendered them guilty by association. Ultimately, it conveys the idea that true fear of God should lead to a rejection of all forms of idolatry and oppression, and that divine judgment takes into account the intentions and circumstances of individuals.

passage_content: ונקדיםלפרש הכתוב (בשה"ש) לסוסתי ברכבי פרעה דמיתיך רעיתי, וראוי להבין ענין המשל גם הקישור אל הפסוק שלמעלה צאי לך בעקבי הצאן וגו', ובספה"ק נועם אלימלך בליקוטים פי' הכתוב לסוסתי ברכבי פרעה דמיתיך רעיתי, היות גבי פרעה שינה ב"ה את הסדר, דרך הסוסים מושכין וכו' וכאן הקרון מושך וכו' וזהו לסוסתי כמו הסוסים ברכבי פרעה היו בהיפך הטבע, כן דמיתיך רעיתי, זאת אומרת כנ"י להשי"ת כן דמיתיך כי הצדיקים עושין כן, שהקב"ה גוזר גזירה והצדיק מבטל, והצדיק גוזר והשי"ת מקיים נמצא העולם מתנהג לפי רצון הצדיק עכל"ק, והנה ידוע מש"כ בסה"ק דגל מחנה אפרים פרשת וארא דפשט הפסוק משתנה לפי בחי' הדור עיי"ש (כוונתו בדבר שאינו נוגע להלכה כמובן), ובדורינו השפל אפ"ל כוונת הכתוב עפ"י מה שאמרו רז"ל בגמרא (ביצה דף ל"ז ע"א) בהמה וכלים כרגלי הבעלים, והנה הסוסים היו של יראי ה' והרכב של פרעה ולפי דרך הטבע מהראוי שהסוסים יוליכו את הרכב, אבל לא כן עשה ה' כי אם הרכב משך הסוסים ואף בעליהם נמשכו עמהם [ולקושטא דמילתא תמיד כן הוא שאם יראי ה' מתחברים עם רשעים אז מתהפך הגלגל והרשעים הם מנהיגים את היראי ה', אבל דא עקא שלא תמיד אפשר לראות זאת באתגליא] אולם אז בקרי"ס הי' התגלות גדול וראו במו עיניהם הנס הזה ועי"ז ידעו ישראל להתרחק גם מחבורתם ויש בו גם הוראה לדורות.
translation: And we will precede to explain the verse (in Song of Songs) "As the chariots of Pharaoh, so have I compared you, my beloved." It is fitting to understand the matter of the parable and also the connection to the verse above, "Go forth in the footsteps of the flock," etc. In the holy book Noam Elimelech in the Likutim, the verse "As the chariots of Pharaoh, so have I compared you, my beloved" is explained, that regarding Pharaoh, the Holy One, blessed be He, changed the order; through the horses they pull, etc., and here the chariot pulls, etc. This is like "as the horses of Pharaoh," which were contrary to nature. So too, "I have compared you, my beloved," meaning the Jewish people to the Holy One, blessed be He, so have I compared you, for the righteous act in this way, that the Holy One, blessed be He, decrees a decree and the righteous nullify it, and the righteous decree and the Holy One, blessed be He, fulfills it. Thus, the world is conducted according to the will of the righteous, as explained. And it is known from what is written in the holy book Degel Machaneh Ephraim, Parashat Va'era, that the simple meaning of the verse changes according to the level of the generation, as mentioned there (his intention is in matters that do not pertain to halacha, of course). In our lowly generation, one might say the intention of the verse according to what our sages, of blessed memory, said in the Gemara (Beitzah 37a), "Animals and vessels are according to the feet of their owners." And behold, the horses were of the God-fearing, and the chariot of Pharaoh, and according to the way of nature, it would be fitting for the horses to lead the chariot. But the Holy One, blessed be He, did not do so; rather, the chariot pulled the horses, and even their owners were drawn along with them. [And to clarify the matter, it is always the case that if the God-fearing connect with the wicked, then the wheel turns, and the wicked lead the God-fearing. However, it is unfortunate that this is not always possible to see openly.] Yet then, in the time of the miracles, there was a great revelation, and they saw this miracle with their own eyes, and through this, Israel knew to distance themselves even from their association, and it also serves as a lesson for generations.
summary: The passage discusses the metaphor of "my horse is like the chariots of Pharaoh" from the Song of Songs, emphasizing the reversal of natural order by God, where the chariots pull the horses instead of the other way around. This reflects the idea that the righteous can influence divine decrees, demonstrating that the world operates according to the will of the tzaddikim (righteous ones). It highlights the importance of separating from the wicked, as the righteous can become subservient to them if they associate closely. Ultimately, the text serves as a reminder of the divine intervention and the need for vigilance in maintaining one's spiritual integrity.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבאר קישור הכתוב, דלעיל מיני' כתיב אם לא תדעי לך היפה בנשים צאי לך בעקבי הצאן, פרש"י אם לא תדעי לך להיכן תלכי וכו' שחדל הרועה מלהנהיג אותך וכו' צאי לך בעקבי הצאן, הסתכלי בפסיעות דרך שהלכו הצאן וכו' התבונני בדרכי אבותיך הראשונים וכו', נראה שרש"י ז"ל דייק בלשונו הקדוש שחדל הרועה מלהנהיגאותך, משמע שלא יחסר להם מנהיג, אלא שחדל מלהנהיג, כי אם מתחברים עם רשעים אז הרשעים מנהיגים את המנהיגולכן הסמיכו אח"כ הפסוק לסוסתי ברכבי פרעה שנמשלו ברכבי פרעה שהרכב נעשה המושך וכמו"כ הרשעים נעשו המנהיגים ע"י שמתחברים אליהם והבן.
translation: And similarly, it explains the connection of the verse, as above it is written, "If you do not know, O fairest among women, go forth in the footsteps of the flock." Rashi explains, "If you do not know where to go, etc., since the shepherd has ceased to lead you, etc., go forth in the footsteps of the flock, look at the steps of the way the flock has gone, etc., contemplate the ways of your forefathers." It seems that Rashi, blessed be his memory, was precise in his holy language that the shepherd has ceased to lead you, implying that they do not lack a leader, but rather that he has ceased to lead. For if they connect with the wicked, then the wicked become the leaders of the leader. Therefore, the verse is later connected to "My mare among the chariots of Pharaoh," which are likened to the chariots of Pharaoh, where the chariot becomes the one that pulls, and likewise, the wicked become the leaders by connecting to them. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that when a righteous leader (the shepherd) ceases to guide the people, it does not mean they lack leadership altogether; rather, they may be influenced by the wicked if they associate with them. The reference to "following the footsteps of the sheep" emphasizes the importance of looking to the paths of the righteous ancestors for guidance. The connection to "the chariots of Pharaoh" illustrates how the wicked can become leaders when people align themselves with them, highlighting the need for discernment in choosing one's associations.

passage_content: ויאמרה' אל משה נטה את ידך על הים וישובו המים וגו' וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו וגו', וישובו המים ויכסו את הרכב וגו' יל"ד על שינוי הלשון, דתחלה אמר וישב הים ואח"כ וישובו המים בלשון רבים, משמע שהוא ענין נפרד וב' שיבות היו שם וצ"ב.
translation: And Hashem said to Moshe, "Stretch out your hand over the sea," and the waters returned, etc. And the sea returned to its strength at dawn, etc. And the waters returned and covered the chariots, etc. There is a question on the change of language, for initially it says, "And the sea returned," and afterwards, "And the waters returned" in the plural form, which implies that it is a separate matter and that there were two returns there, and this requires clarification.
summary: In Sefer Divrey Yoel, the passage discusses the divine command to Moses to stretch out his hand over the sea, highlighting the distinction between the singular "the sea returned" and the plural "the waters returned." This duality suggests a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine intervention, indicating that there were two separate acts of return: one for the sea itself and another for the waters. This reflects the Hasidic concept of the interconnectedness of divine actions and the multifaceted nature of God's miracles, emphasizing the complexity of divine will in the world.

passage_content: ב)ילקוט (רמז רל"ו) וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו, א"ר יונתן התנה הקב"ה תנאים עם הים שיהא נקרע לפני ישראל, הה"ד וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו, לתנאו שהתנה הקב"ה עמו עכ"ד המדרש, והקשו המפורשים דרמז התנאי היל"ל לעיל אצל ויבקעו המים, דהרי התנאי הי' על הבקיעה, ומדוע רמז עלי' הכתוב במאמר וישב הים.
translation: In the Yalkut (Remez 246), it is stated that the sea returned to its strength at dawn. Rabbi Yonatan said that the Holy One, blessed be He, made conditions with the sea that it should be split before Israel, as it is written, "And the sea returned to its strength at dawn," according to the condition that the Holy One, blessed be He, made with it. Thus concludes the Midrash. The commentators have questioned why the condition was mentioned in relation to "And the sea returned" when the condition was regarding the splitting, and why the verse refers to it in the statement "And the sea returned."
summary: The passage discusses a midrashic interpretation of the splitting of the sea, highlighting that God made a condition with the sea to part before the Israelites. This reflects the Hasidic concept of divine partnership in the unfolding of miracles, emphasizing that the natural world responds to God's will. The text raises a question about the phrasing used in the scripture, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine promises and the fulfillment of conditions in the relationship between God and creation. Ultimately, it illustrates the interplay between divine authority and the responsiveness of the natural order.

passage_content: ואפשרלתרץ קושית המפרשים הנ"ל, בהקדם דברי המד"ר (פ' כ"ב סי' ב') וישובו המים אמר ר' יוחנן כיון שעלה אחרון שבישראל מן הים ירד לתוכו אחרון של מצרים, ורשב"ל אומר על אלו ועל אלו ננעל הים מד' רוחותיו, אמר משה לפני הקב"ה מה יעשו ישראל, אמר לו אי אתה זקוק, למה שאני עושה להם נס, באותה שעה שלח הקב"ה את ידו והעלן מן הים שנאמר (תהלים י"ח) ישלח ממרום יקחני ימשני ממים רבים עכ"ד המדרש, נמצא לדברי רשב"ל הי' נס הבקיעה כפול, שמתחלה נבקעו המים וישם הקב"ה את הים לחרבה ויבואו בנ"י בתוך הים ביבשה, ואחר ששב הים לאיתנו, עמדו כנד נוזלים ולא נגעו בישראל, עד ששלח הקב"ה את ידו והעלה את ישראל מן הים, ואח"כ שבו גם אלו המים ויכסו את הרכב וכל חיל פרעה, וא"ש שינוי וכפל הלשון וישב הים וגו' וישובו המים ויכסו את הרכב וגו', דב' שיבות היו כנ"ל, וע"כ רמז הכתוב על התנאי שהותנה הקב"ה עם הים במאמר וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו, כי אחר ששבו המים הי' עוד צורך לתנאי שיעמדו מלפני ישראל, והנס השני הי' גדול מן הראשון, כי הבוי"ת קצב גבול לים כדכתיב חול גבול שמת האומר לים עד פה תבוא, וזהו תנאי בריאתו מששת ימי בראשית, ועד"ז בנס הבקיעה גזר על הים עד פה תבוא ועמדו במקומם, אבל גדול הי' הנס השני שאחר ששבו המים וננעלו ישראל בתוכו אעפ"כ עמדו מפניהם ולא נגעו בהם, ולזה רמז הכתוב על התנאי במאמר וישב הים וגו', וכ"ז לשיטת רשב"ל.
translation: And it is possible to resolve the difficulty of the aforementioned commentators by prefacing the words of the Midrash (Parashat Beshalach, Section 2): "And the waters returned," Rabbi Yochanan said, "Once the last of Israel ascended from the sea, the last of Egypt descended into it." And Resh Lakish says, "The sea was locked on all four sides." Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "What will Israel do?" He said to him, "You do not need to worry, for I will perform a miracle for them." At that moment, the Holy One, Blessed be He, sent His hand and raised them from the sea, as it is said (Psalms 18), "He sent from on high, He took me; He drew me out of many waters." Thus far the Midrash. According to Resh Lakish, the miracle of the splitting was twofold: Initially, the waters were split, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, made the sea dry land, and the Children of Israel came into the sea on dry ground. And after the sea returned to its strength, it stood like a wall of water and did not touch Israel, until the Holy One, Blessed be He, sent His hand and raised Israel from the sea. Afterwards, the waters returned and covered the chariots and all the host of Pharaoh. This explains the change and repetition in the language, "And the sea returned" and "And the waters returned and covered the chariots," for there were two returns as mentioned. Therefore, the verse hints at the condition that the Holy One, Blessed be He, made with the sea in the statement, "And the sea returned to its strength in the morning," for after the waters returned, there was still a need for a condition that they should stand before Israel. The second miracle was greater than the first, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, set a boundary for the sea, as it is written, "Thus far shall you come, but no farther," and this is the condition of its creation from the six days of creation. Similarly, in the miracle of the splitting, He decreed upon the sea, "Thus far shall you come," and they stood in their place. But the second miracle was greater, for after the waters returned and Israel was locked within it, nevertheless, they stood before them and did not touch them. And this is what the verse hints at regarding the condition in the statement, "And the sea returned," etc. And all this is according to the opinion of Resh Lakish.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous splitting of the sea during the Exodus, emphasizing the dual nature of the miracle as described by Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish (Rashbi'l). It highlights that after the waters were split and the Israelites crossed on dry land, the sea returned to its state but remained still before the Israelites, showcasing a second, greater miracle. This reflects the divine control over nature, as God established conditions for the sea to part and later to not harm the Israelites, illustrating the profound relationship between divine will and the natural world. The text underscores the significance of God's promises and the unique nature of the miracles performed for the Israelites.

passage_content: ואפ"לגם אליבא דר' יוחנן, עפימ"ד במכילתא ומצרים נסים לקראתו ללמדך שכל מקום ומקום שהיו מצרים נסים, הי' הים רץ כנגדו, ופי' במרכבת המשנה דלזה הוצרך השי"ת תנאי על השבת הים חוץ לגבולו, דחול גבולו שמת, אמנם קשה ממה דאיתא בש"ס (סוטה דף י"א ע"א) דהיתר שבועת המבול, שע"ז לא נשבע הקב"ה שהם באים ונופלים בתוך הים, ולפי"ז לא יצדק, להיות הים רץ לקראתם חוץ לגבולו והציף אותם ע"כ קושיתו, ואפשר לתרץ קושיתו עפ"י גירסת המד"ר שגררן הקב"ה לחרבו של ים, ולפי"ז לא הציף אותם הים חוץ לגבולו, ויתכן שכאשר נסו המים אחריהם, המה בעצמם הטעו וחזרו לחרבו של ים שינצלו בחרבה, ואז צפו מים על ראשם ונטבעו, ואין זה בכלל השבועה כמ"ש במדרש אמר הקב"ה כבר נשבעתי שאיני מביא מבול לעולם. אבל מה אעשה לכם, אני מביא אתכם למבול, וא"ש אף לשיטת ר' יוחנן מה שרמז הקב"ה על התנאי במאמר וישב הים לאיתנו, כי אחר ששבו המים על מצרים היו המצרים נסים מן הים, והוצרך הים לנוס אחריהם מחוץ גבולו ולהחזירם לתוך הים ולזה הי' צורך לתנאי דחול גבולו שמת, ולזה רמז הכתוב על התנאי במאמר וישב הים וגו'.
translation: And even according to Rabbi Yochanan, as stated in the Mechilta, when the Egyptians were fleeing, the sea ran against them, teaching you that wherever the Egyptians fled, the sea rushed against them. The explanation in the Merkevet HaMishnah is that for this, the Holy One, Blessed be He, required a condition regarding the sea's return to its boundary, that outside its boundary it would die. However, it is difficult regarding what is stated in the Talmud (Sotah 11a) about the allowance of the flood's oath, for which the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not swear that they would come and fall into the sea. According to this, it would not be correct for the sea to rush against them outside its boundary and drown them; therefore, this is their difficulty. It is possible to answer their difficulty according to the version in the Midrash that the Holy One, Blessed be He, drew them to the sword of the sea, and according to this, the sea did not drown them outside its boundary. It is possible that when the waters fled after them, they themselves were misled and returned to the sword of the sea to be saved by the sword, and then the waters rose over their heads and they drowned, and this is not included in the oath, as it is said in the Midrash: the Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "I have already sworn that I will not bring a flood upon the world." But what shall I do to you? I will bring you to the flood. And this is also understood according to the opinion of Rabbi Yochanan regarding what the Holy One, Blessed be He, hinted at concerning the condition in the statement, "And the sea returned to its strength," for after the waters returned upon the Egyptians, the Egyptians were fleeing from the sea, and the sea needed to flee after them outside its boundary and bring them back into the sea, and for this, there was a need for the condition that outside its boundary it would die, and for this, the verse hinted at the condition in the statement, "And the sea returned, etc."
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous events surrounding the parting of the Red Sea and the subsequent drowning of the Egyptians, emphasizing the divine conditions set by God regarding the sea's boundaries. It explores the tension between God's oath not to bring a flood and the necessity for the sea to pursue the Egyptians beyond its limits. The text suggests that the Egyptians, in their own confusion, inadvertently led themselves back to the sea's depths, thus fulfilling God's plan without violating His oath. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the interplay of divine justice and mercy in the context of redemption and punishment.

passage_content: אזישיר משה ובני ישראל את השירה הזאת לה' ויאמרו לאמר אשירה לה' כי גאה גאה וגו', זה קלי ואנוהו אלקי אבי וארוממנהו, פירש"י ז"ל זה קלי, בכבודו נגלה עליהן והיו מראין אותו באצבע ראתה שפחה על הים מה שלא ראו נביאים וכו'אלקי אבי לא אני תחלת הקדושה אלא מוחזקת ועומדת לי הקדושה, ואלקותו עלי מימי אבותי, ובמד"ר (פרשה כ"ג סי' ט"ו) כמה גדולים יורדי הים, כמה נתחבט והתחנן מרע"ה הראיני נא את כבודך, ולבסוף לא ראה הדמות בעצם רק בסימן, ועולי הים כ"א מראה בהדמות זה קלי, א"ל הקב"ה לישראל, בעוה"ז אמרתם לפני פעם אחת זה קלי, אבל לע"ל אתם אומרים אותו דבר ב"פ, שנאמר (ישעי' כ"ה) ואמר ביום ההוא הנה אלקינו זה קוינו לו ויושיענו זהה' קוינו לו וגו' עכ"ד המדרש, ראוי להבין מהו היתרון שיאמרו אותו ישראל לע"ל שתי פעמים, העיקר ה"ה שיזכו להתגלות אלקית בבחי' גדולה כזו ומאי נפק"מ כמה פעמים יאמרו מלת "זה" פעם אחת או ב' פעמים.
translation: Then Moses and the children of Israel sang this song to the Lord, and they said, saying, "I will sing to the Lord, for He has triumphed gloriously," etc. "This is my God, and I will glorify Him; the God of my father, and I will exalt Him." Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains: "This is my God," His glory was revealed to them, and they pointed to Him with their fingers. A maidservant saw at the sea what the prophets did not see, etc. "The God of my father," I am not the beginning of holiness, but holiness is firmly established for me, and His divinity has been upon me since the days of my ancestors. And in the Midrash (Parashat 23, Section 15), how great are those who descend to the sea, how much Moses pleaded and entreated, "Show me, please, Your glory," and in the end, he did not see the essence of the form, only a sign. And those who ascend from the sea each see the form, "This is my God." The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel, "In this world, you said before Me once, 'This is my God,' but in the World to Come, you will say the same thing twice," as it is said (Isaiah 25), "And it will be said in that day, 'Behold, our God, this is what we hoped for, and He will save us; this is the Lord, we hoped for Him,' etc." Thus concludes the Midrash. It is fitting to understand what the advantage is that Israel will say it twice in the future. The essence is that they will merit a divine revelation in such a great aspect, and what difference does it make how many times they say the word "this," once or twice.
summary: The passage discusses the profound revelation of God's presence experienced by the Israelites at the Red Sea, where they proclaimed "This is my God" with a clarity that surpassed even the prophets. It emphasizes the continuity of divine connection from the patriarchs to the present, highlighting that the holiness and relationship with God are deeply rooted in tradition. The text suggests that in the future, the Israelites will express their faith in God with even greater intensity, reflecting a more profound revelation of the divine. This dual expression of "This is my God" signifies an elevated spiritual state and a deeper understanding of God's essence.

passage_content: ב)(רות רבתי פ' ז' סי' י"א) איתא דרש פלא עה"כ וזאת לפנים בישראל על הגאולה ועל התמורה, ר' חנינא פתר קרא בגו אפי' דישראל, לשעבר היו מקלסין על הגאולה שנאמר זה קלי ואנוהו, ועכשיו על התמורה שנאמר (תהלים ק"ו) וימירו את כבודם בתבנית שור אוכל עשב, אין לך מנוול ומשוקץ ומשונה כשור בשעה שאוכל עשב וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, ופי' במתנת כהונה בגו אפייא וכו', במנהגם ועניינם של ישראל כדאמר אופיי' של אלהיה, והיפה ענף מביא גירסא שנו אפייא, פי' ששינו פניהם ממה שהיו בתחלה, שלפנים פנו לה' ועתה לעבודת כוכבים, וגם י"ל דדריש וזאת לפנים בישראל, שנשתנו פנים בישראל יעיי"ש, והרד"ל פי' בגו אפייא דישראל וי"ל ביני אפייא דישראל, בין החשובים ופני עדת ישראל הי' מנהג זה, וכמ"ש בזוה"ק פ' חקת דף ק"פ עיי"ש, אמנם יש להבין מ"ש ועכשיו על התמורה שנא' וימירו את כבודם בתבנית שור אוכל עשב, הרי זה כבר הי' ומדוע אמר ועכשיו, גם אינו מובן קישור דרשתם ז"ל לפשטות הכתובים, דמיירי בקנין חליפין שלף איש נעלו ונתן לרעהו, ומה ענין לזה דלשעבר היו ישראל מקלסין על הגאולה ועכשיו על התמורה, שפגמו בחטא העגל ועשו תמורה בתבנית שור אוכל עשב, גם מ"ש בגו אפייא דישראל לכל הפירושים צ"ב הקישור למעשה בועז ורות דעסיק בי' קרא, גם צ"ב מ"ש לשעבר היו מקלסין על הגאולה שנאמר זה קלי ואנוהו, לכאורה לא מצינו שאמרו קילוס זה על הגאולה, ומבואר בדברי רז"ל שאמרו כן על התגלות אלקית שזכו כ"א להראות באצבע כנ"ל, ועל הגאולה אמרו לשונות אחרים של קילוס אשירה לה' כי גאה גאה וגו', ועוד הרבה פסוקים, ומדוע נקטו רז"ל הך קרא דייקא שלא אמרו על הגאולה בעצם.
translation: In (Ruth Rabbah, Parashat 7, Section 11) it is stated that the wonder is on the verse, "And this was before in Israel regarding the redemption and the transformation." Rabbi Chanina explained the verse in the context of "even of Israel." Previously, they would praise the redemption, as it is said, "This is my God, and I will glorify Him," and now they praise the transformation, as it is said (Psalms 106), "And they exchanged their glory for the likeness of an ox that eats grass." There is no more disgraceful, abominable, and strange thing than an ox while it eats grass, etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. And it explains in the context of the gift of the priesthood, in the context of "even of Israel," etc., in the customs and matters of Israel, as it is said, "the appearance of their God." And the beautiful branch brings a version that says "they changed their appearance," meaning that they changed their faces from what they were at first, for previously they turned to the Lord, and now to the worship of idols. It can also be said that it is interpreted "and this was before in Israel," that the faces of Israel have changed, see there. And the Radal explained "in the appearance of Israel," and it can be said "between the appearances of Israel," between the important ones, and the faces of the congregation of Israel had this custom, as it is written in the Zohar, Parashat Chukat, page 120, see there. However, one must understand what is meant by "and now on the transformation," as it is said, "And they exchanged their glory for the likeness of an ox that eats grass," for this had already been, and why does it say "and now"? It is also not understood how their interpretation connects to the simple meaning of the verses, which deals with the acquisition of exchange, where a man took off his shoe and gave it to his friend. What is the connection to the fact that previously Israel would praise the redemption and now the transformation, that they blemished with the sin of the golden calf and made a transformation in the likeness of an ox that eats grass? Also, what is meant by "in the appearance of Israel" for all interpretations, the connection to the act of Boaz and Ruth, which deals with this verse? It is also unclear what is meant by "previously they would praise the redemption, as it is said, 'This is my God, and I will glorify Him,'" for seemingly we do not find that they said this praise regarding the redemption. It is explained in the words of our sages that they said this regarding the divine revelation that each one merited to point at, as mentioned above, and regarding the redemption, they said other expressions of praise, "I will sing to the Lord, for He has triumphed gloriously," etc., and many other verses. Why did our sages specifically choose this verse, which they did not say regarding the redemption itself?
summary: The passage discusses the transformation in the spiritual state of Israel, contrasting their past praise for redemption with their current state of idolatry, symbolized by the verse "they exchanged their glory for the likeness of an ox that eats grass." It highlights the shift in Israel's focus from divine worship to the worship of false idols, reflecting a deeper theological insight into the consequences of sin, particularly the sin of the Golden Calf. The text also raises questions about the nature of their previous praises and the specific verses cited, suggesting a need for a deeper understanding of the relationship between Israel's actions and their spiritual identity.

passage_content: ג)בפרשה ויבוא עמלק וילחם עם ישראל ברפידים, דקדק המהר"ל מפראג ז"ל בגור ארי' דהול"ל ויצא עמלק וילחם עם ישראל, דבמלחמה שייך לשון יציאה וכמ"ש ויצא סיחון לקראתינו, ובאמת ויבוא עמלק מיותר דהי' מספיק שיאמר וילחם עמלק עם ישראל ברפידים, ואם לחם עמם ידוע נדע שבא אליהם.
translation: In the section "And Amalek came and fought with Israel at Rephidim," the Maharal of Prague, may his merit protect us, is precise in his interpretation that it should have said "And Amalek went out and fought with Israel," for in warfare, the term "going out" is appropriate, as it is stated, "And Sichon went out to meet us." In truth, the phrase "And Amalek came" is superfluous, as it would have been sufficient to say "And Amalek fought with Israel at Rephidim," and if he fought with them, it is known that he came to them.
summary: המהר"ל מפראג מדגיש את השפה שבה מתוארת מלחמת עמלק עם ישראל, ומצביע על כך שהמילה "ויבוא" מיותרת, שכן מלחמה מחייבת את המושג "יציאה". הוא מציע שהשימוש במילה "ויבוא" מעיד על עומק רוחני, שבו עמלק לא רק יוצא למלחמה, אלא גם נכנס לתוך המאבק הרוחני עם ישראל. זה מצביע על הקשר בין המלחמה הפיזית למאבק הרוחני, שבו עמלק מייצג את הכוחות המנוגדים לאור ולתכלית של עם ישראל.

passage_content: ד)פירש"י ז"ל מאי רפידים, שרפו ידיהן מן התורה, לכאורה תורה לא נרמז בכתוב ובמלת רפידים יש רמז שרפו ידיהן, ועדיין לא ידענא ממה רפו ידיהן.
translation: Translation: "Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains what Raphidim means: they burned their hands from the Torah. At first glance, the Torah is not hinted at in the text, but in the word Raphidim there is a hint that they burned their hands. Yet, we still do not know from what they burned their hands."
summary: The passage discusses the term "Rafidim," interpreting it as a reference to the people's weakening commitment to the Torah, as indicated by the phrase "they burned their hands from the Torah." This suggests a spiritual decline or disengagement from divine teachings. The inquiry into the source of their weakening highlights the importance of understanding the roots of spiritual apathy and the need for a deeper connection to the Torah in Hasidic thought. Ultimately, it emphasizes the significance of maintaining one's dedication to spiritual practices and the teachings of the Torah.

passage_content: ה)(פ' כ"ו סי' א') ויבוא עמלק הה"ד (איוב ג') לא שלותי ולא שקטתי ולא נחתי ויבוא רוגז וכו', לא שלותי מגזירה ראשונה שגזר פרעה עלי שנאמר (שמות א') וימררו את חייהם, והעמיד לו הקב"ה גואל זה מרים ע"ש המירור, ולא שקטתי מגזירה שני' (שם) אם בן הוא והמתן אותו, והעמיד הקב"ה גואל זה אהרן ע"ש ההריון, ולא נחתי מגזירה שלישית שגזר ואמר (שם) כל הבן הילוד תשליכוהו. והעמיד הקב"ה גואל ע"ש המים זה משה שנאמר (שם ב') כי מן המים משיתוהו, ויבוא רוגז זה עמלק עכ"ד המדרש, ראוי להבין דדריש לא שלותי ולא שקטתי ולא נחתי וכו' והעמיד להן גואל וכו'. והרי ע"י שהעמיד להן גואל, הרי נחו מהגזירה ומהו לא נחתי, גם היכן מצינו באהרן ומרים שהיו גואלים, גם צ"ב מ"ש ויבוא רוגז זה עמלק איך נרמז עמלק בלשון רוגז, וכי הצרות והגזירות של פרעה לא היו רוגז, ולמה דוקא הצרות של עמלק נרמז בלשון רוגז, גם הלשון ויבוא רוגז צ"ב דבאחריני לא אמר לשון ויבא כ"א בזה דייקא וטעמא בעי.
translation: (Section 26, Chapter 1) And Amalek came, as it is written (Job 3): "I was not at ease, nor was I quiet, nor did I rest, yet trouble came." I was not at ease from the first decree that Pharaoh decreed against me, as it is written (Exodus 1): "They made their lives bitter." And the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them a redeemer, this is Miriam, in the merit of the bitterness. And I was not quiet from the second decree (Exodus 1): "If it is a son, you shall kill him." And the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them a redeemer, this is Aaron, in the merit of the pregnancy. And I did not rest from the third decree that he decreed and said (Exodus 1): "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river." And the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them a redeemer in the merit of the waters, this is Moses, as it is said (Exodus 2): "For from the waters I drew him." And trouble came, this is Amalek. Thus far the Midrash. It is fitting to understand why it is stated "I was not at ease, nor was I quiet, nor did I rest," and yet the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them a redeemer, etc. And behold, by establishing for them a redeemer, they rested from the decree, so what does it mean "I did not rest"? Also, where do we find that Aaron and Miriam were redeemers? It is also necessary to clarify what is meant by "trouble came, this is Amalek," how is Amalek hinted at in the language of trouble? And were not the troubles and decrees of Pharaoh also trouble? And why specifically are the troubles of Amalek hinted at in the language of trouble? Additionally, the phrase "and trouble came" is puzzling, for in other instances it does not say "and came," but specifically here it is precise, and the reason needs to be examined.
summary: The passage discusses the suffering of the Israelites under Pharaoh's decrees and the subsequent divine interventions through the figures of Miriam, Aaron, and Moses as their redeemers. It emphasizes the continuous state of unrest ("לא שלותי ולא שקטתי ולא נחתי") experienced by the Israelites despite the arrival of their saviors, highlighting the persistent nature of their struggles. The mention of Amalek as a source of "רוגז" (anger) suggests that the challenges posed by Amalek are particularly significant, representing a deeper spiritual conflict. This underscores the idea that even with redemption, the struggle against evil and turmoil remains a central theme in the Jewish experience.

passage_content: ו)ר' יהושע אומר כשבא עמלק להזיק את ישראל מתחת כנפי אביהם שבשמים אמר משה לפני הקב"ה, רבש"ע רשע זה בא לאבד בניך מתחת כנפיך, ס"ת שנתת להם בהר סיני מי יקרא בו, ר"א המודעי אומר כשבא עמלק להזיק את ישראל וכו' אמר משה לפני הקב"ה רבש"ע בניך שאתה עתיד לפזרן תחת ארבע רוחות השמים וכו', רשע זה בא לכלם מתחת כנפיך ס"ת שנתת להם מי יקרא בו עכ"ד המכילתא, וצ"ב מה שאמר תורה שנתת להם מי יקרא בו, הרי הי' עדיין לפני מתן תורה ואם יכלה ח"ו זרע ישראל, א"כ לא יהי' מי שיקבל התורה, והול"ל מי יקבל את התורה, גם בדברי ר"א המודעי צ"ב ענין הטענה מ"ש בניך שאתה עתיד לפזרן וכו', וכי זכות הוא להם, הרי מפני חטאינו גלינו מארצנו, ומה ענינו להמליץ זכות בזה.
translation: And Rabbi Yehoshua says, when Amalek came to harm Israel from under the wings of their Father in Heaven, Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Master of the Universe, this wicked one has come to destroy Your children from under Your wings. The Torah that You gave them at Mount Sinai, who will read it?" Rabbi Eliezer the Modai says, when Amalek came to harm Israel, etc., Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Master of the Universe, Your children whom You are destined to scatter under the four corners of the heavens, etc., this wicked one has come to all of them from under Your wings. The Torah that You gave them, who will read it?" Thus far the Mechilta. And it is difficult to understand what it means when it says, "the Torah that You gave them, who will read it," for it was still before the giving of the Torah, and if, Heaven forbid, the seed of Israel were to be destroyed, then there would be no one to receive the Torah. It should have said, "who will receive the Torah." Also, in the words of Rabbi Eliezer the Modai, it is difficult to understand the claim, "Your children whom You are destined to scatter," etc. Is it a merit for them? After all, because of our sins we were exiled from our land, and what is our connection to advocate for merit in this?
summary: In this passage, Rabbi Yehoshua and Rabbi Elazar HaModai discuss the threat posed by Amalek to the Jewish people, emphasizing the protective role of God as a father. Moses appeals to God, highlighting the potential loss of the Torah and the future dispersion of the Jewish people, questioning who would uphold the Torah if Israel were to be destroyed. The text raises profound theological questions about the continuity of the Jewish people and the significance of the Torah, even in the face of sin and exile, suggesting that the very existence of the Jewish people is intertwined with their divine mission to receive and uphold the Torah.

passage_content: ז)דרשו במכילתא ויבא עמלק שבא בגילוי פנים לפי שכל הביאות שבא לא בא אלא במטמוניות שנאמר אשר קרך בדרך וגו', אבל ביאה זו לא בא אלא בגילוי פנים לכך נאמר ויבוא עמלק עכ"ד המכילתא, וצ"ב דלא מצינו בשום מקום שבא במטמוניות, גם איך נשמע מאשר קרך בדרך שבא במטמוניות, ובמדרש יש הרבה דרשות במאמה"כ אשר קרך בדרך ולכולהו קאי על מלחמה זו ואיך נשמע מכאן על מלחמות הקודמים שהיו במטמוניות, גם איך הי' יכול ללחום במטמוניות וישראל היו מוקפים בעננים ולא הי' בידו לגשת אליהן.
translation: 7) It is expounded in the Mechilta that Amalek came with revealed intentions, for all the other arrivals were only in hidden ways, as it is said, "that encountered you on the way," etc. However, this arrival came only with revealed intentions; therefore, it is said, "And Amalek came." Thus far is the Mechilta. And it is puzzling, for we do not find anywhere that he came in hidden ways, and how can we understand from "that encountered you on the way" that he came in hidden ways? Moreover, in the Midrash, there are many interpretations on the verse "that encountered you on the way," and all of them refer to this war. How can we derive from here about the previous wars that were in hidden ways? Additionally, how could he wage war in hidden ways when Israel was surrounded by clouds, and he had no ability to approach them?
summary: The passage discusses the unique nature of Amalek's attack on Israel, emphasizing that it was a direct confrontation ("בגילוי פנים") rather than a covert one, as seen in previous encounters. The reference to "אשר קרך בדרך" suggests that Amalek's approach was brazen and open, contrasting with the hidden nature of past battles. The text raises questions about the interpretation of previous conflicts and the implications of Amalek's boldness, highlighting the theological significance of facing evil openly rather than through subterfuge. This reflects a deeper understanding of the struggle between good and evil in the context of divine providence and human agency.

passage_content: ח)כאשר ירים משה ידו וגבר ישראל וכאשר יניח ידו וגבר עמלק במתני' (ר"ה דף כ"ט ע"א) הקשו וכי ידיו של משה עושות מלחמה או שוברות מלחמה, אלא לומר לך כל זמן שישראל מסתכלין כלפי מעלה ומשעבדין את לבם לאביהם שבשמים היו מתגברים וכו', וצ"ב מהו הקושיא וכי ידיו של משה עושות מלחמה, דבוודאי כן הוא שהי' בכח ידיו של משרע"ה להכריע נצחון המלחמה לטובה, גם התירוץ צ"ב דמ"ט הניח משרע"ה את ידו, אם בזה הי' תליא נצחונם והצלתם של ישראל, גם על ישראל קשה מ"ט כשהניח משרע"ה את ידו לא היו מסתכלים כלפי מעלה ומשעבדין את לבם לאביהם שבשמים.
translation: When Moses raised his hands, Israel prevailed, and when he lowered his hands, Amalek prevailed, as stated in the Mishnah (Rosh Hashanah 29a). They asked, do the hands of Moses wage war or break the war? Rather, it is to tell you that as long as Israel looks upward and subjugates their hearts to their Father in Heaven, they would prevail, etc. However, it is difficult to understand what the question is: do the hands of Moses wage war? Certainly, it is true that it was through the power of the hands of Moshe Rabbeinu that the victory of the war was determined for the good. Also, the answer is difficult: why did Moshe Rabbeinu lower his hands? If their victory and salvation depended on this, it is also difficult regarding Israel: why, when Moshe Rabbeinu lowered his hands, did they not look upward and subjugate their hearts to their Father in Heaven?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses raising and lowering his hands during the battle against Amalek, emphasizing that Israel's victory is contingent upon their spiritual focus and connection to God. It highlights the Hasidic concept that divine assistance is linked to the people's devotion and mindfulness towards their Creator. The text questions the mechanics of this relationship, pondering why Israel faltered when Moses lowered his hands, suggesting that their spiritual state directly influences their success in battle. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of faith and divine reliance in overcoming challenges.

passage_content: ט)יל"ד בלשון הכתוב והי' כאשר ירים משה וגו', הרי מלחמה זו כבר הי', ומדוע הזכירו בלשון עתיד והי' הול"ל וכאשר ירים וגו'
translation: 9) It is written in the language of the text, "And it shall be when Moses lifts up," indicating that this war has already occurred. Why is it mentioned in the future tense? It should have said, "And when he lifts up," etc.
summary: הפסוק מתאר את המלחמה כמציאות שכבר התרחשה, אך הוא משתמש בלשון עתיד כדי להדגיש את הקשר בין מעשה האדם לבין ההשגחה העליונה. השימוש בלשון עתיד מצביע על הכוח של תפילה ומעשים טובים לשנות את המציאות, ומדגיש את האמונה בכוחו של משה כמנהיג רוחני. בכך, יש כאן ביטוי לתפיסה החסידית של השפעת האדם על הגורל וההיסטוריה, והיכולת להעלות את המציאות הרוחנית דרך מעשיו.

passage_content: י)ה' אל משה כתוב זאת זכרון בספר ושים באזני יהושע כי מחה אמחה את זכר עמלק מתחת השמים, נחלקו המפורשים בפי' הכתוב, הראב"ע ז"ל פי' כתוב זאת זכרון בספר, כי הוא ספר מלחמות ה', ואיננו אתנו שנאבד כאשר אין לנו דברי הימים למלכי ישראל וכו' עיי"ש, והרמב"ן ז"ל דחה פירושו עיי"ש וכתב הנכון בעיני כי בספר ירמוז לספר התורה שיזכרו בנ"י מה שעשה עמלק, וכ"כ הספורנו כתוב זאת זכרון בספר פרשת זכור, והפי' הוא שהבוכ"ע צווהו לכתוב בס"ת המצוה זאת של זכור את אשר עשה לך עמלק וכו', אמנם גם זה צ"ב דלא נזכר כן בשאר המצות שהקב"ה צוה לו עליהן לכותבם בספר התורה, וכל המצות כתבם משרע"ה בס"ת עפ"י ציווי השי"ת, ומי שאומר אפי' על אות א' שבתורה שמשה מפי עצמו כתבה, ה"ה בכלל האומר תורה לא מן השמים הוא וכופר בתורה, ועל כולם נצטוה מפי הקב"ה לכתוב, ואעפי"כ לא מצינו בפרטיות כל מצוה ומצוה שיאמר לו הקב"ה במיוחד כתוב זאת זכרון בספר, ומדוע במצוה זו דייקא הזכיר הכתוב שהקב"ה צווהו לכתבה זכרון בספר, גם דאין כאן מקומו דפ' זכור נאמרה במשנה תורה בפ' תצא, ומדוע הקדימו הכתוב לצוותו על ככה עכשיו.
translation: 10) The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Write this as a remembrance in a book and place it in the ears of Joshua, for I will utterly blot out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven." The commentators have disagreed on the interpretation of this verse. The Ra'avad, may his memory be blessed, explained that "write this as a remembrance in a book" refers to the Book of the Wars of the Lord, and it is not with us, as we have lost the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, etc. See there. However, the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, rejected his interpretation and wrote what seems correct to me, that the "book" alludes to the Torah, so that the Children of Israel will remember what Amalek did. So too, the Sforno wrote that "write this as a remembrance in a book" refers to the portion of Zachor, and the explanation is that the Blessed One commanded him to write in the Torah this commandment of remembering what Amalek did to you, etc. However, this too is questionable, for it is not mentioned in other commandments that the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded him to write them in the Torah. All the commandments were written by Moses in the Torah according to the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and anyone who says that even one letter in the Torah was written by Moses from his own mouth is included among those who say that the Torah is not from heaven and denies the Torah. And all of them were commanded by the Holy One, Blessed be He, to write, and yet we do not find specifically for each commandment that the Holy One, Blessed be He, told him particularly to "write this as a remembrance in a book." Why, specifically in this commandment, does the verse emphasize that the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded him to write it as a remembrance in a book? Furthermore, it is not the place for it, as the portion of Zachor was said in the Deuteronomy in the portion of Ki Teitzei. Why then did the verse precede to command him about this now?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the commandment given to Moses to write a remembrance of Amalek in a book, highlighting the significance of this directive compared to other commandments. The debate among commentators, such as the Ra'avad and Ramban, centers on the unique emphasis placed on recording Amalek's actions, suggesting a deeper theological importance in remembering this enmity. The text raises questions about why this particular commandment is singled out for written remembrance, indicating a profound connection between memory, identity, and divine command in the Jewish tradition. Ultimately, it underscores the necessity of preserving historical memory as a means of spiritual and communal continuity.

passage_content: יא)באזני יהושע, צ"ב מהו באזני יהושע, והרי נצטווה לכתבו בתוה"ק ונתפרסם לכ"א מישראל ולא רק ליהושע, ואמרז"ל (סנהדרין דף כ' ע"ב) שלש מצות נצטוו ישראל בכניסתן לארץ וא' מהם מחיית עמלק, הרי לא נמסרה ליהושע בלחישה ומהו באזני יהושע.
translation: 11) "In the ears of Joshua," what does it mean "in the ears of Joshua"? After all, he was commanded to write it in the Torah and it was made known to all of Israel, not just to Joshua. And our Sages of blessed memory said (Sanhedrin 20b) that three commandments were given to Israel upon their entering the land, and one of them is the annihilation of Amalek; this was not given to Joshua in a whisper, so what does it mean "in the ears of Joshua"?
summary: The passage discusses the phrase "in the ears of Joshua," questioning its significance since the command was meant for all of Israel and not just for Joshua. It highlights the idea that certain divine instructions, such as the command to eradicate Amalek, were not given in a whisper but were public and collective. This raises a theological insight about the unique role of leadership and the transmission of divine will, emphasizing the importance of personal connection and responsibility in fulfilling God's commandments. Ultimately, it reflects on the deeper relationship between God, the leader, and the community in the context of divine commandments.

passage_content: יב)ז"ל פירש דע"כ נצטו' למסרו ליהושע מפני שהוא עתיד להכניס את ישראל לארץוכן הוא במד"ר (פ' כ"ו סי' ג') אמנם לכאורה לא מצינו שיהושע נלחם בעמלק אחר כניסת הארץ חוץ מפעם הזה עכשיו, ולא הגיע זמנה עד מלוך שאול והוא לחם עם עמלק, ולמה נאמר ושים באזני יהושע, גם צ"ב הלשון "ושים" דהול"ל אמר אל יהושע, ולא מצינו כזאת במקום אחר כמ"ש אמור אל אהרן ולא כתיב ושים באזניו ומה נשתנה כאן דכתיב לשון שימה.
translation: 11) It is said that it was necessary to give it to Joshua because he was destined to bring Israel into the land. And so it is in the Midrash (Parashat Ki Tisa, section 3). However, seemingly we do not find that Joshua fought against Amalek after entering the land, except for this instance now, and its time did not come until the reign of Saul, when he fought with Amalek. And why is it said, "and place in the ears of Joshua"? It is also puzzling the wording "and place," as it could have said "say to Joshua," and we do not find such a thing elsewhere, as it says "say to Aaron," and it is not written "and place in his ears." What is different here that it is written in the language of placing?
summary: The passage discusses the command to Moses to convey the message of fighting Amalek to Joshua, emphasizing Joshua's future role in leading Israel into the Promised Land. It raises questions about the timing of the battle against Amalek, noting that Joshua did not engage in this fight until the reign of Saul. The use of the phrase "put in the ears of Joshua" instead of simply saying "tell Joshua" is highlighted, suggesting a deeper, more profound transmission of wisdom and responsibility that transcends mere instruction, reflecting the Hasidic emphasis on the inner spiritual significance of leadership and divine mission.

passage_content: והנהבגמרא מגילה (דף ז' ע"א) דרשו רז"ל הכתוב כתוב זאת זכרון בספר על כתיבת המגילה, כתוב זאת מ"ש כאן ובמשנה תורה, זכרון מה שכתוב בנביאים, בספר מה שכתוב במגילה, ואיתא בירושלמי מגילה פ"א ה"ה) דקריאת המגילה ניתנה למשרע"ה בהר סיני, ופי' היפה מראה דע"כ נאמר ושים באזני יהושע דמורה שילחוש לו באזניו דרך סוד נסתר מהמון, דבימי מרדכי ואסתר היו צריכים ישראל לתשובה גדולה כמבואר בדרז"ל, ואלמלי הי' נגלה ונתפרסם מקודם נפילת המן וכו' ותשועתם של ישראל, בוודאי מורא לא הי' עולה על ראשם מגזירת המן, וממילא לא הי' סיבה המביאם לעשות תשובה, לזה נסתר מהמון מצות קריאת המגילה בשעת מ"ת, ולא נמסר רק למשה לבדו והוא מסרה ליהושע, וכן כל ראש הדור מסר זה בדרך סוד לראש הדור שלאחריו עד מרדכי, והיינו שים באזני יהושע דייקא עכת"ד ז"ל, ועפי"ד יתיישב הלשון שימה שאמר הכתוב ושים באזני יהושע, עפימ"ד בירושלמי (ע"ז) ואלה המשפטים אשר תשים לפניהם, דד"ת הם כאוצר שהוא מכוסה, ודריש תשים לשון סימא שהוא מכוסה כאוצר, ואין לגלותם לבנ"א שאינם מהוגנים. וכ"ש מצות קריאת המגילה שהיתה צריכה להיות נסתר מהמון כנ"ל, לז"א "ושים'' "באזני" יהושע שיהי' מכוסה כאוצר ורק לאזני יהושע נאמרה בלחישה.
translation: And behold, in the Gemara Megillah (7a), our Sages expounded the verse "Write this as a memorial in a book" regarding the writing of the Megillah. "Write this" refers to what is stated here and in the Mishneh Torah, "memorial" refers to what is written in the Prophets, and "in a book" refers to what is written in the Megillah. And it is stated in the Jerusalem Talmud Megillah (1:5) that the reading of the Megillah was given to Moshe Rabbeinu at Mount Sinai. The beautiful explanation is that therefore it is said "and place in the ears of Yehoshua," which indicates that he should whisper to him in his ears through a hidden secret from the multitude. For in the days of Mordechai and Esther, Israel needed a great repentance, as explained by our Sages. Had it been revealed and publicized beforehand, before the downfall of Haman, etc., and the salvation of Israel, certainly the fear would not have risen upon them from the decree of Haman, and consequently, there would have been no reason to bring them to repentance. Therefore, the commandment of reading the Megillah was concealed from the multitude at the time of the giving of the Torah, and it was not entrusted except to Moshe alone, and he passed it on to Yehoshua. Likewise, every head of the generation passed this down in a secret manner to the head of the subsequent generation until Mordechai. This is what is meant by "place in the ears of Yehoshua" specifically, as stated by him. According to this, the wording of "place" that the verse says "and place in the ears of Yehoshua" is clarified, as stated in the Jerusalem Talmud (Avodah Zarah) that "these are the judgments which you shall place before them," for the Torah is like a treasure that is covered, and the term "place" implies a hidden treasure that is covered, and it should not be revealed to people who are not worthy. How much more so the commandment of reading the Megillah, which needed to be concealed from the multitude as mentioned above, hence it says "and place" "in the ears" of Yehoshua, that it should be covered like a treasure, and only to the ears of Yehoshua was it said in a whisper.
summary: The passage discusses the hidden nature of the commandment to read the Megillah, which was given to Moses at Sinai and passed down through generations in secrecy. It emphasizes that the reading was intended to be concealed from the masses, as it was crucial for the Jewish people to engage in deep repentance during the time of Mordechai and Esther. The reference to "putting in the ears of Joshua" signifies that this knowledge was reserved for the leaders, akin to a hidden treasure, to ensure that the true significance of the commandment remained protected from those unworthy of its depth. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the importance of inner spiritual truths and the necessity of guidance from righteous leaders.
