passage_content: וכמו"כלענינינו דהנה דורות הראשונים נעשו להם נסים בזכותם כי הי' להם מע"ט, וע"כ לא היו אומרים שירה, כי בתורת נדבה לא רצו לומר, דלמא לא יאמרו כיאות לכבוד המלך ונמצא שאינו מודה רק ח"ו להיפך, אבל בקריעתים סוף שקיטרג עליהם שר של ים הללו עוע"ז והללו עוע"ז, א"כ מה שנעשה להם נס ונבקע הים לא הי' בזכותם, כ"א שהקב"ה ברוב רחמיו ריחם עליהם ועשה להם נס ע"כ היו מחוייבים לומר שירה מצד הדין ואין למנוע מחשש דילמא לא יאמרו כהוגן דהרי הוא מחוייב לומר כפי השגתו, וא"ש דברי המדרש שמעולם לא אמר אדם שירה להקב"ה, ר"ל מחמת היראה כי מי יאמר זכיתי לבי כיאות לפני מלך הכבוד, עד שבאו אלו ואמרו שירה על שהיו מחוייבים מן הדין והבן.
translation: And like "in our matters, behold, the earlier generations had miracles done for them because they had merit, and therefore they did not say song, because they did not want to say it as a freewill offering, lest they not say it properly for the honor of the King and it would appear that they are not acknowledging, G-d forbid, the opposite. But in the splitting of the sea, after the accuser of the sea had brought accusations against them, these idols and those idols, therefore the miracle that was done for them and the sea was split was not due to their merit, but rather that the Holy One, blessed be He, in His abundant mercy had compassion on them and performed a miracle for them. Therefore, they were obligated to say song by law, and one should not refrain out of fear that they might not say it properly, for he is obligated to say according to his understanding. And this explains the words of the Midrash that no person ever said song to the Holy One, blessed be He, meaning out of fear, for who would say that he is worthy to speak properly before the King of Glory, until these came and said song because they were obligated by law, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of miracles experienced by the earlier generations, emphasizing that their merits (ma'alot) were the reason for these miracles, yet they refrained from singing praises out of fear of inadequacy in honoring God. It highlights that the splitting of the sea was not due to their righteousness but rather God's mercy, which obligated them to sing. The text reflects on the tension between human humility and the obligation to express gratitude, suggesting that true praise arises from a recognition of divine grace despite one's shortcomings. Ultimately, it conveys that genuine worship stems from a sense of duty and acknowledgment of God's compassion.

passage_content: באופןאחר אפ"ל דברי המדרש הנ"ל, בהקדם דברי הגמ' (מגילה י"ד ע"א) אין אומרים הלל על נס שבחו"ל, והקשו בגמ' יציאת מצרים דנס שבחו"ל היכי אמרינן שירה, כדתניא עד שלא נכנסו ישראל הוכשרו כל ארצות לומר שירה, משנכנסו ישראל לארץ לא הוכשרו כל הארצות לומר שירה עכ"ד הגמ', וק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' בשלח) הביא בשם ס' ברית שלו' בתוס' נופך מדילי', דע"כ לא אמרו ישראל שירה על נס דיציאת מצרים גופא, כי על נס שבחו"ל אין אומרים שירה, אבל על נס שנעשה במים דהוא כארץ ישראל אומרים, והיינו הלכו ביבשה בתוך הים, וא"כ נעשה נס בים דהוא כא"י לכך אז ישיר עכ"ל עוד כתב שם נ"ל ליתן טעם להא דכל הארצות לא הוכשרו לומר שירה רק א"י, עפימ"ד במד"ר (בראשית פ' ל"ב סי' ג') ואף שבחו של הקב"ה אומרים כן מקצתו בפניו וכו', וידוע מה שכתבו דבפניו שרי לשבוחי דלא שייך לומר סיימתינהו וכו' משא"כ שלא בפניו, והנה ארץ ישראל עיני ד' אלקיך בה וכו', והיינו טעמא דברייתא דעד שלא נכנסו ישראל הוכשרו כל הארצות וכו', דהי' יכול להיות התגלות השראת שכינה בכל מקום לכך הוכשרו, משא"כ אחר כך וכו', וז"ש אשירה לד' כי גאה גאה. כפרש"י גאה גאה על כל השירות וא"כ כל מה שאקלס יש בו תוספת, וא"כ אין לשיר רק בא"י דהוי בפניו ולא שייך לומר סיימתינהו וכו', מ"מ אשירה דהרי סוס ורוכבו רמה בים והוי כארץ ישראל ע"כ מקצת לה"ק.
translation: In another way, one could say the words of the aforementioned Midrash, by prefacing the words of the Gemara (Megillah 14a) that we do not say Hallel for a miracle that occurred outside of the Land of Israel. The Gemara questions how we can say song for the Exodus from Egypt, as it is taught that before Israel entered, all lands were fit to sing, but once Israel entered the land, not all lands were fit to sing, thus concludes the Gemara. And so, Moshe, peace be upon him (in Parashat Beshalach), brought in the name of his book "Brit Shalom" a nuance from my own, that indeed Israel did not sing a song for the miracle of the Exodus itself, for a miracle that occurred outside of the Land of Israel does not warrant a song, but for a miracle that occurred in the waters, which is like the Land of Israel, they do sing, as they walked on dry land in the sea. Therefore, a miracle occurred in the sea, which is like the Land of Israel, and thus they sang. Furthermore, he wrote there that it seems to me to give a reason for why not all lands were fit to sing, only the Land of Israel, according to what is said in the Midrash (Genesis 32:3), and even though the praise of the Holy One, blessed be He, is said in part before Him, etc., it is known what they wrote that before Him it is permitted to praise, for it is not appropriate to say "you have completed them," etc., unlike when not before Him. And behold, in the Land of Israel, the eyes of the Lord your God are upon it, etc. This is the reason for the teaching that before Israel entered, all lands were fit to sing, for there could have been a revelation of the Divine Presence everywhere, therefore they were fit, unlike afterwards, etc. And this is what is meant by "I will sing to the Lord, for He has triumphed gloriously." As Rashi explains, "gloriously" refers to all the songs, and thus everything that is sung has an addition. Therefore, one should only sing in the Land of Israel, which is before Him, and it is not appropriate to say "you have completed them," etc. Nevertheless, "I will sing," for behold, the horse and its rider He has thrown into the sea, and this is like the Land of Israel, thus partially to the Holy One, blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between singing praises for miracles in the Land of Israel versus outside of it, emphasizing that only in Israel is there a full capacity to express gratitude and song to God. It references the Talmud's teaching that prior to Israel's entry, all lands were deemed worthy of singing, but this changed once they entered the land. The text highlights that the miracle of the splitting of the sea, akin to an event in Israel, allows for the expression of song, as it represents a divine revelation. Ultimately, it underscores the unique spiritual significance of the Land of Israel as a place where God's presence is fully manifest, enabling a deeper form of worship and praise.

passage_content: ולכאורהדבה"ק צ"ב דהרי מפורש בגמ' דעד שלא נכנסו ישראל לארץ הוכשרו כל הארצות לומר שירה, וא"כ מ"ט צריכנא לטעמא דנס שנעשה במים הוי כא"י, ובלא"ה הוכשרו כל הארצות אז, ואפ"לעפימ"ש ק"ז בייט"פ (מאמר שפת הים סי' י') לפרש דברי המדרש (פ' כ"ג סי' ו') אז ישיר משה ובנ"י וגו' הה"ד (תהלים נ"ט) ואני אשיר עזיך אימתי בשעה שעמדו על הים ואמרו שירה, ומה אמרו עזי וזמרת י"ה, וארנן לבקר חסדך זה בוקר של מתן תורה, כי ידוע שכל הנביאים בעת שתבוא אליו הנבואה אע"פ שהוא במראה וע"י מלאך יחלשו כחותיו ויתקלקל בנינו כמעט שתצא רוחו ממנו, כמ"ש בדניאל כשדיבר עמו גבריאל במראה, אמר לא נשאר בי כח והודי נהפך עלי וגו', ואני הייתי נרדם ע"פ ארצה וגו', מלבד משרע"ה לא הי' כן, וז"ש ודבר ד' אל משה פא"פ כאשר ידבר איש אל רעהו וכו' וא"כ לכאורה יקשה להבין לפי משאמרז"ל (מכילתא) ראתה שפחה על הים מה שלא ראה יחזקאל, שנא' זה אל"י שכל או"א מראה באצבעו וכו', והי' מהראוי לישראל ליפול ע"פ ארצה, נבהל ונרדם עד כמעט שתצא רוחם, ואיך קמו על רגלם ופתחו פיהם ואמרו שירה, אע"כ אין זה מכוחם כ"א ברוך הנותן ליעף כח ולאין אונים עצמה ירבה, להעצים כוחן של ישראל לקום ולומר שירה וכו', וז"ש אשירה לד' וגו', לא מכחי כ"א עזי וזמרת י"ה ויהי לו לישועה, שיד ה' הושיעה לי להתחזק בכח ולזמר לשמו ית' וכו' ולא נתבטלו במציאות וכן הי' במ"ת, וכן לעתיד שנא' כי עין בעין יראו וגו' עיי"ש ביאור הענין.
translation: And seemingly, the question arises, for it is explicitly stated in the Gemara that before Israel entered the land, all the lands were prepared to sing a song. Therefore, what is the reason we need the explanation that the miracle that occurred in the waters is considered like the land of Israel? And if so, all the lands were prepared then. Nevertheless, according to what is stated in Kitzur Shulchan Aruch (the section on the Song of the Sea), to explain the words of the Midrash (Parashat Beshalach, section 6), "Then Moses and the children of Israel sang," as it is written (Psalms 59), "And I will sing of Your strength," when did they sing? At the time they stood by the sea and sang a song. And what did they say? "My strength and the song of the Lord," and I will sing in the morning of Your kindness, this morning being the morning of the giving of the Torah. For it is known that all the prophets, when the prophecy comes to them, even if it is in a vision and through an angel, their powers weaken, and their being is almost disrupted to the point that their spirit is about to leave them, as it is written about Daniel when Gabriel spoke to him in a vision, he said, "No strength remained in me, and my appearance was altered," etc. And I was asleep on my face, etc. Except for Moshe Rabbeinu, it was not so, and therefore it is said, "And the Lord spoke to Moses face to face as a man speaks to his friend," etc. And thus, it is seemingly difficult to understand according to what our sages said (Mechilta), that a maidservant saw at the sea what Ezekiel did not see, as it is stated, "This is my God," for every man sees with his finger, etc. It would have been appropriate for Israel to fall on their faces, terrified and asleep until their spirit almost left them. How then did they rise on their feet and open their mouths and sing? Therefore, it is not from their own strength, but rather from the Blessed One who gives strength to the weary and increases the power of the powerless, to empower the strength of Israel to rise and sing, etc. And thus it is said, "I will sing to the Lord," etc., not from my own strength, but rather "My strength and the song of the Lord, and He became my salvation," for the hand of the Lord saved me to strengthen me with power and to sing to His name, etc., and they did not become nullified in existence, and so it was at the giving of the Torah, and so it will be in the future, as it is said, "For eye to eye they will see," etc. There, the explanation of the matter is found.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous nature of the Israelites' song at the Sea of Reeds, emphasizing that their ability to sing was not from their own strength but a divine gift that empowered them. It contrasts the experience of Moses, who spoke to God directly without losing strength, with that of other prophets who weakened in the presence of divine revelation. The text highlights that the song of praise was a result of God's intervention, allowing the Israelites to express their gratitude and recognition of His salvation. This theme of divine empowerment is linked to the future revelation of God, where all will witness His glory directly.

passage_content: ומעתהאפ"ל דאה"נ דעד שלא נכנסו ישראל לארץ הוכשרו כל הארצות לומר שירה, אמנם לבחי' זו שיהיו למעלה ממדריגת הנביאים א"א לזכות בחו"ל, אלא לפי שהי' הנס במים שהוא מקום טהרה, גם שכבר השפיל הקב"ה הסט"א ושר של מצרים הוסר ממשלתו, כמ"ש (רז"ל במד"ר דברים פי"א י"ט) סוס ורוכבו רמה בים סוסיהם ורוכביהם אין כתיב כאן, אלא סוס ורוכבו זה השר שלהן, ע"כ מאז נתעלו ישראל לבחי' א"י שהוא תחת יד הקב"ה לבדו ויכלו לומר שירה בבחי' גבוה כזו שלא זכו אלי' כל הנביאים, ואפשר דלבחי' כזו לא זכו אף האבוה"ק מטעם דאין אומרים שירה בחו"ל, ואף דעד שלא נכנסו ישראל לארץ הוכשרו כל הארצות, מ"מ לצד היותן תחת ממשלת שרים החיצונים לא זכו לזה, וישראל על הים זכו לזה מטעם הנ"ל וכן יהי' לע"ל.
translation: And from now on, it can be said that indeed, until Israel entered the land, all the lands were prepared to sing a song. However, for the level that they would be above the rank of the prophets, it is impossible to merit this outside of the land. This is because the miracle occurred in the waters, which is a place of purity, and also because the Holy One, blessed be He, had already humbled the Other Side, and the minister of Egypt was removed from his dominion, as it is said (our sages in Midrash Devarim 11:19) "A horse and its rider He threw into the sea," but it does not say "their horses and their riders," rather "a horse and its rider," referring to their minister. Therefore, from that time, Israel ascended to the level of the Land of Israel, which is solely under the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, and they were able to sing a song at such a high level that all the prophets did not merit. It is possible that even the forefathers did not merit this level because one does not sing a song outside of the land. And although until Israel entered the land, all the lands were prepared, nevertheless, due to being under the dominion of external ministers, they did not merit this. And Israel at the sea merited this for the reasons mentioned, and so it will be in the future.
summary: The passage discusses the unique spiritual elevation of the Jewish people upon entering the Land of Israel, emphasizing that they achieved a level of divine connection and the ability to sing praises to God that even the prophets did not attain. It highlights that prior to their entry into the land, while all nations were prepared to sing, they were still under the influence of external spiritual forces. The text underscores the significance of the miraculous events at the sea, which purified the Israelites and allowed them to rise above the limitations imposed by foreign powers. Ultimately, it suggests that this elevated state of spiritual expression will also be realized in the future.

passage_content: וז"שבמדרש אז ישיר משה וגו' הה"ד פיה פתחה בחכמה ותורת חסד על לשונה, שהי' מחסדו ית' להעצים כחן של ישראל שיכלו לפתוח פיהן ולסדר דבריהם בחכמה, ולא נבהלו ולא נרדמו, ולז"א מיום שברא הקב"ה את העולם ועד שעמדו ישראל על הים, לא מצינו אדם שאמר שירה ר"ל בבחי' זו, ואף הנביאים לא זכו אלי', ואין אז אלא שמחה שנא' אז ימלא שחוק פינו, דלע"ל יזכו ישראל ג"כ אל הבחי' ההוא.
translation: And this is what is meant in the Midrash, "Then Moses sang," etc. This is the meaning of "She opened her mouth with wisdom, and the Torah of kindness is on her tongue," that it was by His kindness, blessed be He, to empower the strength of Israel so that they could open their mouths and arrange their words with wisdom, and they were not frightened nor did they fall asleep. And therefore it is said that from the day the Holy One, blessed be He, created the world until Israel stood by the sea, we do not find anyone who sang a song, meaning in this manner, and even the prophets did not merit to it. And "then" is only joy, as it is said, "Then our mouth will be filled with laughter," for in the future Israel will also merit to that aspect.
summary: The passage emphasizes the unique moment when the Israelites sang at the sea, highlighting that this expression of song and praise was a divine gift, enabling them to articulate their joy and wisdom. It notes that from the creation of the world until that point, no one had sung in such a manner, not even the prophets, indicating the extraordinary nature of this event. The reference to "then our mouths will be filled with laughter" suggests a future hope for Israel to experience similar joy and spiritual elevation. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of divine grace empowering the faithful to connect deeply with their spiritual heritage.

passage_content: אזישיר משה ובנ"י וגו', פרש"י ז"ל עלה בלבו שישיר וכו', ראוי להבין מה צורך להשמיעינו זה, ובודאי שעלה בלבו לפני העשי', דסוף מעשה מחשבה בתחלה.
translation: Then Moses and the Children of Israel sang, etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that it arose in his heart to sing, etc. It is fitting to understand what is the need to inform us of this, and certainly it arose in his heart before the action, for the end of the deed is in the thought at the beginning.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the moment when Moses and the Israelites sang after the crossing of the Red Sea, emphasizing that this song was premeditated in Moses' heart even before the miraculous event occurred. This highlights the Hasidic concept that thoughts and intentions precede actions, suggesting that the ultimate purpose of creation and divine intervention is rooted in the inner spiritual aspirations of individuals. The idea that "the end of an action is found in its thought" underscores the importance of intention in one's relationship with God and the unfolding of divine plans.

passage_content: ב)(פ' כ"ג סי' ד') אז ישיר משה וגו' הה"ד (משלי ל"א) פיה פתחה בחכמה ותורת חסד על לשונה, מיום שברא הקב"ה את העולם וכו', לא מצינו אדם שאמר שירה להקב"ה אלא ישראל וכו' ראוי להבין מ"ט לא אמרו אבות העולם שירה על הנסים שנעשו להם, ומדוע דייקא ישראל אמרו שירה, גם צ"ב הקישור אל הפסוק פיה פתחה בחכמה.
translation: (2) (In Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 4) Then Moses sang, etc. This is as it is written (Proverbs 31:26) "She opens her mouth with wisdom, and the teaching of kindness is on her tongue." From the day that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created the world, etc., we do not find anyone who sang a song to the Holy One, Blessed be He, except for Israel, etc. It is fitting to understand why the patriarchs of the world did not sing a song for the miracles that were done for them, and why specifically Israel sang a song. It is also necessary to clarify the connection to the verse "She opens her mouth with wisdom."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the unique role of the Jewish people in singing praise to God, emphasizing that throughout history, only Israel has offered such songs of gratitude for divine miracles. The text questions why the patriarchs did not sing praises for the miracles they experienced, suggesting a deeper understanding of the relationship between Israel and God. The connection to the verse "She opens her mouth with wisdom, and the law of kindness is on her tongue" highlights the wisdom inherent in Israel's expression of gratitude, suggesting that their song is rooted in a profound understanding of divine kindness and the covenantal relationship with God.

passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם מ"ד בספה"ק ייטב לב בשם א"ז הגה"ק מו"ה אלעזר ניסן זלה"ה עה"פ וירא פנחס ויקח רומח בידו, עפ"י מאמחז"ל (קידושין דף מ' ע"א) מחשבה טובה הקב"ה מצרפה למעשה, הענין כי אמרת אלקי צרופה היינו צירופי אותיות, ותיכף כשעלה במחשבת אדם לטוב, נעשה מזה צירוף אותיות ונכתב בפועל לפניו ית' וכו', ע"כ תיכף כשראה פנחס ועלה בלבו שיקח רומח בידו, ויגל ד' את עיני פנחס וראה אלו האותיות וכו', וכיון שראה מעשה זו בצירופי אותיות נזכר הלכה עיי"ש, ופי' בזה ק"ז הייטב זלה"ה דכמו"כ באברהם הי' מסופק אם הוא מחוייב להטריח עצמו באורחים מחמת שהי' חולה מאוד, אך השי"ת הוא חוקר לב וכו' ומחשבה טובה הקב"ה מצרפה למעשה, ונעשה מזה צירוףאותיות וירץ לקראתם פתח האוהל, וכשראה אברהם צירוף האותיות וירץ לקראתם, הבין שזאת הוא רצון הבוי"ת וכו' עיי"ש.
translation: And it is explained in advance in the holy book Yitav Lev in the name of the holy Rabbi, our teacher Elazar Nisan, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "And Pinchas saw, and he took a spear in his hand," according to our sages (Kiddushin 40a) that a good thought is considered by the Holy One, blessed be He, as an action. The matter is that the phrase "Elokai Tzrufah" refers to the combinations of letters, and immediately when a good thought arises in a person's mind, it becomes a combination of letters and is written in action before Him, blessed be He, etc. Therefore, as soon as Pinchas saw and it arose in his heart to take a spear in his hand, the Holy One, blessed be He, opened Pinchas's eyes and he saw these letters, etc. And when he saw this action in the combinations of letters, he remembered the law, as mentioned there. And the explanation of this is that just as Abraham was in doubt whether he was obligated to trouble himself for guests because he was very ill, the Holy One, blessed be He, searches the heart, etc., and a good thought is considered by the Holy One, blessed be He, as an action, and from this a combination of letters was made, and he ran to greet them at the entrance of the tent. And when Abraham saw the combination of letters and ran to greet them, he understood that this was the will of the Creator, etc., as mentioned there.
summary: The passage discusses the Hasidic concept that good intentions are recognized and actualized by God, as illustrated through the actions of Pinchas and Abraham. When Pinchas resolved to take a spear, God revealed to him the letters that represented his good thought, signifying divine approval. Similarly, Abraham, despite his illness, was inspired to welcome guests upon perceiving the letters of his good intentions, demonstrating that God actively connects thoughts of goodness to tangible actions. This highlights the belief in the transformative power of intention and divine guidance in fulfilling one's purpose.

passage_content: ועד"זאפ"ל לענינינו כי משה ובנ"י היו מסופקים אם יאמרו שירה או לאו כי ראו שכל הדורות שלפניהם לא אמרו שירה, אולם מיד שעלה בלבם לומר שירה, מחשבה טובה הקב"ה מצרפה למעשה, ונעשה מזה צירופי אותיות אלו אז ישיר משה ובנ"י את השירה הזאת, ובראותם צירופי אותיות אלו, מיד אמרו שירה, ולזה פרש"י ז"ל עלה בלבם לומר שירה, ר"ל כי מחשבה הטובה הביאם לידי מעשה, וע"י צירופי האותיות שנעשה ממחשבתם הכריעו לומר שירה, והנה ידוע דכוונת הלב הוא העיקר, והבוית"ש יודע מחשבתו של אדם והי' מספיק זה בלבד, אלא שאעפ"כ יש יתרון במוצא שפתים, שלפעמים המחשבה בלבד אינה זכה וברורה לש"ש, וסגולת הקול מעורר הכוונה כאמרז"ל, ומה"ט האבוה"ק לא הוצרכו לומר שירה בפה, כי הי' סגי במחשבה בלב, כי היו דבוקים ואדוקים במחשבתם בו ית"ש תמיד בלי הפסק בכוונה לש"ש בכל תנועה והרהור, וישראל אצל קרי"ס הגם שהיו ג"כ במדריגה מאוד נעלה כאמרז"ל ראתה שפחה על הים מה שלא ראה יחזקאל וכו', מ"מ מורא עלה על ראשם, פן לא יעמדו במדריגה זו ולא יהיו כל מחשבותם זכה לש"ש, ע"כ פתחו לומר שירה כדי להגיע ע"י התעוררות הקול לכוונה אמיתית לש"ש.
translation: And similarly, regarding our matter, that Moses and the Children of Israel were in doubt whether to sing a song or not, for they saw that all the generations before them did not sing a song. However, as soon as the thought arose in their hearts to sing a song, the Holy One, blessed be He, combines a good thought with an action, and from this, these combinations of letters were made, then Moses and the Children of Israel sang this song. And upon seeing these combinations of letters, they immediately sang a song. This is what Rashi, of blessed memory, explains: the thought arose in their hearts to sing a song, meaning that the good thought brought them to action, and through the combinations of letters that were made from their thought, they were prompted to sing a song. And it is known that the intention of the heart is the main thing, and the Holy One, blessed be He, knows a person's thoughts, and this alone would have been sufficient. However, nevertheless, there is an advantage in the utterance of the lips, for sometimes the thought alone is not pure and clear for the sake of Heaven, and the power of the voice arouses the intention, as our sages have said. For this reason, the holy ancestors did not need to sing a song with their mouths, as it was sufficient with the thought in their hearts, for they were always attached and bound in their thoughts to Him, blessed be He, without interruption, with intention for the sake of Heaven in every movement and contemplation. And Israel, at the crossing of the sea, although they were also at a very high level, as our sages have said, a maidservant saw at the sea what Ezekiel did not see, nevertheless, fear fell upon them, lest they not maintain this level and that all their thoughts would not be pure for the sake of Heaven. Therefore, they began to sing a song in order to reach true intention for the sake of Heaven through the arousal of the voice.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses the internal struggle of Moses and the Israelites regarding whether to sing a song of praise after the crossing of the Red Sea, noting their hesitation due to the absence of such expressions in previous generations. However, once the thought of singing arose in their hearts, God combined this good intention with action, leading to the creation of the song. The text emphasizes the importance of heartfelt intention, while also recognizing the value of vocal expression to elevate one's thoughts and intentions towards God, especially in moments of fear and uncertainty. Ultimately, the act of singing serves to solidify their connection to the Divine and ensure their intentions are pure.

passage_content: ובזהיבואר קישור דרשת המדרש לסמיכת הפסוק פיה פתחה בחכמה וכו', עפימ"ש רז"ל (סוכה מ"ט ע"ב) מ"ד פיה פתחה בחכמה ותורת חסד על לשונה, וכי יש תורה של חסד ויש תורה שאינה של חסד, אלא תורה לשמה זו היא תורה של חסד, תורה שלא לשמה זו הוא תורה שאינה של חסד, עכ"ד הגמ', והרי"ף בעין יעקב שם פי' בזה מאמה"כ פיה פתחה בחכמה, שכך היא דרכה של תורה ללמוד בתחלה שלא לשמה כדי שיקראוהו חכם, ואח"כ מביאתו ללמוד לשמה ותורתו תורת חסד עייש"ד, וי"ל עוד דתכלית ההתחלה שלא לשמה, כדי שאח"כ יביאהו ללימוד לשמה, וז"פ פיה פתחה בחכמה, ע"ד שאמרז"ל (תמיד ל"ב ע"א) איזהו חכם הרואה את הנולד, וע"כ התחלה זו שלא לשמה, בחי' חכמה יקרא, כדי שיזכה אח"כ לתורת חסד על לשונה, ועד"ז בישראל בשעת קרי"ס שעלה בלבם לומר שירה, אלא שחששו פן לא יהי' מחשבתם זכה וברורה לש"ש, וע"כ אמרו שירה בפה כנ"ל, וז"פ קישור דברי המדרש הה"ד פיה פתחה בחכמה ע"ד איזהו חכם הרואה את הנולד, ועי"ז ותורת חסד על לשונה, שזכו להגיע למדריגת לשמה.
translation: And it is explained the connection of the Midrash's interpretation to the verse "Her mouth opens with wisdom," etc., according to what our Sages of blessed memory said (Sukkah 49b) "Her mouth opens with wisdom and the Torah of kindness is on her tongue." And is there a Torah of kindness and a Torah that is not of kindness? Rather, the Torah for its own sake is the Torah of kindness, and the Torah not for its own sake is the Torah that is not of kindness, thus concludes the Gemara. And the Rif in Ein Yaakov there explains this from the verse "Her mouth opens with wisdom," that this is the way of the Torah to learn initially not for its own sake so that one may be called wise, and afterwards it brings him to learn for its own sake, and his Torah is a Torah of kindness, as is known. And it can also be said that the purpose of the initial learning not for its own sake is so that afterwards it will bring him to learn for its own sake, and this is the meaning of "Her mouth opens with wisdom," in the manner that our Sages said (Tamid 32a) "Who is wise? One who sees the outcome." Therefore, this initial stage not for its own sake, in the aspect of wisdom, is called so that he may merit afterwards to the Torah of kindness on her tongue. And similarly with Israel at the time of the reading of the Shema, when it arose in their hearts to sing a song, but they were concerned that their thoughts might not be pure and clear for the sake of Heaven, and therefore they sang with their mouths as mentioned above. And this is the connection of the words of the Midrash, as it is said "Her mouth opens with wisdom" in the manner of "Who is wise? One who sees the outcome," and through this, "and the Torah of kindness is on her tongue," that they merited to reach the level of learning for its own sake.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between learning Torah for its own sake (lishma) and the initial stage of learning for ulterior motives (shelo lishma). It emphasizes that the beginning of learning, even if not purely for its own sake, serves as a necessary step towards achieving a deeper understanding and embodying the essence of Torah, which is characterized as a "Torah of kindness." The reference to "Pehah Pat'cha BeChochmah" highlights that true wisdom leads to a life of kindness, illustrating the transformative journey from superficial learning to genuine spiritual insight and practice.

summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a Midrash that explains why the sea fled before the Israelites during the Exodus. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the transformative power of faith and the inherent dignity of the Jewish people, as well as the idea that the natural world responds to the spiritual realities of God's chosen ones. The fleeing of the sea serves as a testament to the profound connection between divine providence and the unfolding of Israel's destiny.

passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם דברי הראב"ע ז"ל עה"פ התיצבו וראו את ישועת ד' וגו', יש לתמוה איך יירא מחנה גדולה של שש מאות אלף איש מהרודפים אחריהם, ולמה לא ילחמו על נפשם ועל בניהם, התשובה כי המצרים היו אדונים לישראל וזה הדור היוצא ממצרים למד מנעוריו לסבול עול מצרים ונפשו שפלה וכו' ואינם מלומדים למלחמה עכ"ד, אמנם סותר ד"ע שפי' לעיל עה"פ וחמשים עלו בנ"י, וחמשים מזויינים חגורי חומש למלחמה וכו', כי ביד רמה יצאו בכלי מלחמה, ולא כמו עבדים בורחים עכ"ל, ומה שהקשה למה לא ילחמו על נפשם אין זה קושיא, דמפני שא"ל משרע"ה מפי הגבורה התייצבו וראו את ישועת ד' וגו' ד' ילחם לכם ואתם תחרישון, ע"כ אף שהיו בסכנה גדולה, עמדו בנסיון ולא נלחמו עם המצריים, אף שהיו מזויינים וגבורי חיל, אבל כן הי' רצון הבוי"ת שלא ילחמו והשלימו רצון הבוי"ת, וראי' לדבר שנמנעו רק לטעם זה, שהרי בג' ימי אפילה היו המצרים כולם ככפותים, העומד אינו יכול לישב וכו', וישראל נכנסו לבתיהם והיו מחפשים במטמוניותם, והי' בידם להרגם כולם וליקח כל כלי חמדתם ולצאת מארצם באין מפריע, ומדוע לא קשיא להראב"ע שם איך לא לחמו על נפשם ונפש בניהם, ולא הי' צורך לגבורה ולאלכלי זיין, אע"כ שנמנעו רק להשלים רצון הבוי"ת, ונצטוו על ככה שלא לצאת בזרוע ולא יקחו הרכוש בזרוע כ"א בדרך שאלה.
translation: And it is explained before the words of the Ra'avad, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "Stand still and see the salvation of the Lord," etc. It is puzzling how a great camp of six hundred thousand people would fear the pursuers after them, and why they would not fight for their lives and for their children. The answer is that the Egyptians were masters over Israel, and this generation that was leaving Egypt had learned from their youth to endure the yoke of Egypt, and their souls were lowly, etc., and they were not trained for battle. However, this contradicts the words stated earlier on the verse "And fifty ascended with the children of Israel," and "fifty armed, girded with weapons for battle," etc., for they went out with a high hand and with weapons of war, and not like fleeing slaves. As for the question of why they did not fight for their lives, this is not a difficulty, for since Moses told them, by divine command, "Stand still and see the salvation of the Lord," "The Lord will fight for you, and you shall hold your peace," therefore, even though they were in great danger, they stood firm in the test and did not fight with the Egyptians, even though they were armed and mighty warriors. But indeed, it was the will of the Blessed One that they should not fight, and they fulfilled the will of the Blessed One. The proof of this is that they refrained only for this reason, for during the three days of darkness, all the Egyptians were like bound, unable to sit, etc., and Israel entered their homes and were searching in their treasures, and they had the ability to kill them all and take all their precious belongings and leave their land without interference. And why was it not a question to the Ra'avad there how they did not fight for their lives and the lives of their children? And there was no need for bravery or weapons, rather it must be that they refrained only to fulfill the will of the Blessed One, and they were commanded not to go out with force and not to take the possessions by force, but rather in a manner of asking.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of the Israelites' fear in the face of the Egyptian army, despite being armed and capable of fighting. It emphasizes that their reluctance to engage in battle stemmed from their obedience to God's command, as conveyed by Moses, to stand firm and witness God's salvation. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of surrendering to divine will, illustrating that true strength lies in faith and trust in God rather than in physical might. The Israelites' choice to refrain from fighting, even when they had the means to do so, underscores their commitment to fulfilling God's desire and the belief that divine intervention would secure their deliverance.

passage_content: ועד"זאפ"ל דברי המדרש הנ"ל הים ראה וינס מה ראה רכוש מצרים בידם, דאמרו רז"ל (במד"ר פ' י"ד סי' ג') כששאלו ישראל מהמצריים להשאיל להם כלי כסף וכלי זהב וכו', היו אומרים אין בידינו כלום אומר לו ישראל אני ראיתיו בביתך ובמקום פלוני הוא, נמצא מהרכוש הי' ראי' שעמדו ישראל בנסיונם וציפו לישועת ד', ולא בטחו בזרוע בשר ובדרך מלחמה, וע"כ היו ראויים לנס שלא כדרך הטבע בקרי"ס, ולא הוצרכו לפעולה טבעיות בדרך מלחמה, וז"ש מה ראה רכוש מצרים בידם וע"כ וינוס.
translation: And similarly, the words of the aforementioned Midrash state that the sea saw and fled because it saw the wealth of Egypt in their hands. As our Sages said (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Yitro, Section 3), when the Israelites asked the Egyptians to lend them silver and gold vessels, they would say, "We have nothing." The Israelites would respond, "I saw it in your house and in such and such a place." Thus, the wealth was a testimony that the Israelites stood firm in their trial and awaited the salvation of G-d, and did not rely on the arm of flesh or the ways of war. Therefore, they were worthy of a miracle that was not according to the natural order at the splitting of the sea, and they did not need natural actions in the way of war. This is what it means that the sea saw the wealth of Egypt in their hands, and therefore it fled.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous nature of the Israelites' escape from Egypt, emphasizing their faith in God's salvation rather than reliance on military might. It highlights that when the Israelites asked the Egyptians for gold and silver, they demonstrated their trust in divine intervention, as they knew the wealth was available despite the Egyptians' denial. This unwavering faith made them deserving of a supernatural miracle, leading to their successful exodus. The reference to the Egyptians fleeing signifies the power of faith and divine assistance in overcoming natural obstacles.

passage_content: והנהאיתא במדרש ילקוט (רמז רנ"ד) ויסע משה את ישראל מים סוף הסיען בעל כרחם, שעטרו מצרים סוסיהם בתכשיטי זהב וכסף ואבנים טובות וכו' לפיכך הוצרך להסיען בעל כרחם, ולכאורה צ"ב דהרי בהשאלת כליהם כתיב דבר נא באזני העם וגו' ודרשו רז"ל (ברכות דף ט' ע"א) אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, א"ל הקב"ה למשה לך אמור לישראל בבקשה מכם שאלו מן המצרים וכו', הרי דלא הי' רצונם להרבות מרכוש מצרים, והי' צורך לבקשם על ככה, ומדוע נשתנה דעתם אח"כ והוצרך להסיעם בע"כ, ואפ"ל בפשטות דמפני שבמצרים היתה ציווי הבוי"ת על כך שישאלו, ולזה הי' התגברות ונסיון בדבר, ולזה הי' צורך להזהירם ולבקשם על כך, משא"כ אחר ביזת הים שכבר נצטוו ליסע משם הי' ההתגברות והנסיון על ההיפך וע"כ הי' צורך להסיעם בע"כ ולסייע בידם והבן.
translation: And behold, it is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 274) that Moses led the Israelites from the Sea of Reeds against their will, for the Egyptians adorned their horses with gold and silver jewelry and precious stones, etc. Therefore, it was necessary to lead them against their will. At first glance, this is puzzling, for regarding the borrowing of their possessions, it is written, "Speak please in the ears of the people," and our Sages expounded (Berakhot 9a) that "please" is only a term of request. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Go and tell the Israelites, 'Please, ask the Egyptians for their possessions,'" etc. Thus, it was not their desire to increase the wealth of Egypt, and there was a need to request this from them. Why then did their minds change afterward, necessitating their being led against their will? It can be simply explained that in Egypt there was a command from the Creator to ask for this, and therefore there was a strengthening and trial in this matter, and thus there was a need to warn and request them about it. However, after the plundering of the sea, when they were already commanded to leave from there, the strengthening and trial was in the opposite direction, and therefore it was necessary to lead them against their will and to assist them. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of the Israelites' reluctance to ask for the Egyptians' wealth before leaving Egypt, despite being commanded to do so. Initially, God instructed Moses to request the Israelites to ask for valuables, indicating a divine necessity for their participation. However, after the miraculous events at the Red Sea, their mindset shifted, necessitating divine intervention to compel them to leave, highlighting the struggle between divine command and human will. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of free will and divine assistance in fulfilling God's plans.

passage_content: במדרשהים ראה וינס מה ראה, ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם, וצ"ב, ונל"פ בהקדם לבאר הכתוב ויהפך לבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, פרש"י ז"ל ויהפך בשביל ממונם שהשאילום, וצ"ב דאין זה טעם המפורש בכתוב כי שלחנו את ישראל וגו', הרי שהתחרטו על עצם השליחות ולא על חסרון הממון.
translation: In the Midrash, he saw and wondered what he saw: he saw Israel coming with the possessions of Egypt in their hands, and it is a question. It is necessary to explain the verse "And the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was turned against the people, and they said, 'What is this we have done that we have sent Israel away from our service?'" Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that it was turned because of their money that they had lent them. And it is a question, for this is not the reason explicitly stated in the verse, "that we have sent Israel away," for they regretted the very act of sending them away, not due to a lack of money.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the transformation of Pharaoh's heart, emphasizing that his regret stemmed not merely from the loss of material wealth but from the deeper realization of the consequences of releasing the Israelites from bondage. The text suggests that the true motivation behind Pharaoh's change of heart was a recognition of the spiritual and moral implications of his actions, highlighting a key Hasidic concept that material concerns often mask deeper existential dilemmas. This insight invites contemplation on the nature of freedom and the responsibilities that accompany it, as well as the struggle between spiritual liberation and material attachment.

passage_content: ואפ"לבהקדם דברי הפר"ד שכתב דישראל זכו בהרכוש מדין הענקה, עפימ"ד במדרש שפרעה שיחרר את ישראל וא"ל הרי אתם ברשותכם הרי אתם בני חורין ועבד עברי יש לו הענקה עכ"ד ז"ל, וק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה כתב דהטעם שהי' צורך לשיחרורו, מפני שעדיין לא נשלם זמנם של ישראל לצאת, אלא שדילג הקב"ה על הקץ ויצאו לסוף רד"ו כי לא יכלו להתמהמה עוד, אמנם קשה ע"ז דהרי פרעה הי' מוכרח לשחררם מחמת שנלאה לסבול כובד המכות, א"כ השחרור לאו כלום הוא, דאונסא כמאן דלא עביד, ותירץ דקיי"ל (במס' ב"ב מ"ח) תלוהו וזבין זביני' זבינא, דאגב אונסא וזוזי גמר ומקנה, אבל תלוהו ויהיב במתנה לא מהני, וכאן הוי תלוהו וזבין, דאם בזמן ההוא שיצאו כתיב וינצלו את מצרים בשכר העבודה, א"כ אלמלי נשארו שם עד השלים הזמן גם ארצם לא הי' מספיק, והרכוש שנטלו הוי כמו פשרה דדינו כמכר עכ"ד ק"ז זלה"ה, נמצא דמרכוש מצרים יש הוכחה שיצאו ברשות ופרעה שיחררם כדין, ולפי"ד הפר"ד שזכו ברכוש מדין הענקה, בעכ"ח שהי' שחרור גמור וכדין, דבורח אין לו הענקה, וז"ש רש"י ז"ל בשביל ממונם שהשאילום דעי"ז נעשו משוחררים ואין לומר אונסא כמאן דלא עביד, והיינו טעם הכתוב כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו.
translation: And even though the words of the Pardes are prior, that Israel merited the possessions by the law of gift, as it is stated in the Midrash that Pharaoh freed Israel and said to them, "Here you are in your own authority, here you are free men," and a Hebrew slave has a gift, thus far his words. And so too, the joyous Moshe, peace be upon him, wrote that the reason there was a need for their liberation was because the time for Israel to leave had not yet been completed, but that the Holy One, blessed be He, skipped the end and they left at the end of 210 years because they could no longer delay. However, this is difficult, for Pharaoh was compelled to free them because he could no longer bear the weight of the plagues; thus, the liberation is of no consequence, for coercion is as if one did not act. And he answered that we hold (in Bava Batra 48) that if one lends and sells, the sale is valid, because due to coercion, the money is completed and acquired. But if one lends and gives as a gift, it is not effective. And here it is as if he lent and sold, for at the time they left it is written, "And they plundered Egypt in return for the work," thus if they had remained there until the time was completed, even their land would not have sufficed, and the possessions they took are like a settlement, and its law is like a sale. Thus, it is found that from the possessions of Egypt there is proof that they left with permission and Pharaoh freed them lawfully. And according to the words of the Pardes, they merited the possessions by the law of gift, with the understanding that it was a complete and lawful liberation, for a fugitive has no gift. And this is what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, said, "Because of their possessions that they lent them, thereby they became free, and one cannot say coercion is as if one did not act," and this is the reason for the verse, "For we have sent away Israel from our service."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of Israel's liberation from Egypt, emphasizing that their release was not merely a result of Pharaoh's coercion but rather a divine act that allowed them to leave with wealth, akin to a legal transfer of ownership. It highlights the idea that their departure was sanctioned by God, who bypassed the predetermined time for their exodus due to their suffering. The text also underscores that the wealth acquired from the Egyptians was a legitimate form of compensation, reinforcing the notion that their freedom was complete and lawful, thus validating their status as free individuals. Ultimately, it illustrates the theological principle that divine intervention can alter the course of events for the sake of the oppressed.

passage_content: והנהאיתא במדרש (ילקוט ראובני) שקטרג שר של ים ואמר מה נשתנו אלו מאלו הללו עובדי ע"ז והללו עוע"ז וכו', ולכאורה מה טענה הוא זו הלא המצריים היו רודפים אחר ישראל להורגם, וקיי"ל דרוצח ניתן להצילו בנפשו אף אם הנרדף אינו צדיק יותר ממנו, אלא צ"ל שהשר של ים סבור ששחרורם של ישראל הי' שלא כדין וה"ה בורחים ואין דינם של מצריים כרודפים, אולם מרכוש מצרים ראה והשיג דשחרורם הי' כדין, ולז"א הים ראה וינס ראה רכוש מצרים בידם והבן.
translation: And behold, it is stated in the Midrash (Yalkut Reuveni) that the prince of the sea accused and said, "What distinguishes these from those? These are idol worshippers and these are idol worshippers," etc. At first glance, what kind of accusation is this? After all, the Egyptians were pursuing Israel to kill them, and we hold that a murderer can be saved by his own life even if the pursued is not more righteous than him. Rather, it must be that the prince of the sea believes that the liberation of Israel was not just, and thus the Egyptians fleeing are not considered pursuers. However, he saw and understood from the wealth of Egypt that their liberation was indeed just. Therefore, it is said, "The sea saw and fled," for it saw the wealth of Egypt in their hands. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses a midrashic interpretation where the sea's angel accuses the Israelites of being no different from the Egyptians, who worship idols. The argument hinges on the belief that the Israelites' escape was unjust, as the Egyptians were pursuing them. However, the sea recognizes that the Israelites' liberation was indeed justified when it sees the wealth of Egypt in their possession, highlighting a deeper theological insight into divine justice and the righteousness of the Israelites' cause. This reflects the Hasidic concept of understanding the divine plan and the moral complexities of redemption.

passage_content: ה'איש מלחמה ה' שמו, פירש"י ז"ל אף בשעה שהוא נלחם ונוקם מאויביו אוחז הוא במדתו לרחם על ברואיו וכו' עיי"ש, ונל"פ עוד מאמר הכתוב בסוף הפרשה ויאמר כי יד על כס י"ה מלחמה לה' בעמלק מדור דור, פירש"י ידו של הקב"ה הורמהלישבע בכסאו להיות לו מלחמה ואיבה בעמלק עולמית, ומהו כס ולא נאמר כסא ואף השם נחלק לחציו, נשבע הקב"ה שאין שמו שלם ואין כסאו שלם עד שימחה שמו של עמלק כולו, וכשימחה שמו יהי' השם שלם והכסא שלם וכו', ובספה"ק פי' הפסוק (תהלים כ') ימלא ה' כל משאלותיך, שזה יהי' כל משאלותיך שיתמלא השם ויהי' שמו שלם, והאלשיך הק' האריך לבאר שעיקר מלחמת עמלק היינו מלחמת היצה"ר כי עונותינו מוסיפים כח בשרו שלעמלק הוא ס"מ הוא השטן וכ"א מישראל צריך ללחום מלחמה זו עכת"ד, והנה זה א"א רק בעזר השי"ת, דאלמלא הקב"ה עוזרו אינו יכול לו כמו שאמרו חכז"ל, נמצא הקב"ה הוא הלוחם מלחמת עמלק בכל דור ודור, והתכלית מזה שיהי' שמו שלם כשימחה שמו של עמלק כולו.
translation: "The 'man of war' is His name, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that even at the time He is fighting and avenging against His enemies, He still holds to His attribute of mercy towards His creations, etc. See there. And it seems to me that the verse at the end of the section, 'For the hand is on the throne of YHWH; there will be a war for YHWH against Amalek from generation to generation,' means that the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, is raised to swear by His throne to have a perpetual war and enmity against Amalek. And what is 'throne' and not 'throne'? And even the name is divided in half. The Holy One, blessed be He, swore that His name is not complete and His throne is not complete until the name of Amalek is completely erased. And when the name is erased, then the name will be complete and the throne will be complete, etc. And in the holy books, the verse (Psalms 20) 'May the Lord fulfill all your requests' is explained to mean that this will be all your requests, that the name will be fulfilled and His name will be complete. And the Kli Yakar elaborated that the essence of the war against Amalek is the war against the evil inclination, for our sins give strength to the flesh of Amalek, who is the Satan. And every Jew must wage this war. Thus, it is only possible with the help of the Holy One, blessed be He, for if the Holy One, blessed be He, does not assist him, he cannot prevail, as our sages of blessed memory said. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, is the one fighting the war against Amalek in every generation, and the ultimate goal of this is that His name will be complete when the name of Amalek is completely erased."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of God's eternal struggle against Amalek, symbolizing the evil inclination (yetzer hara) within humanity. It emphasizes that God's name and throne are incomplete until Amalek is eradicated, reflecting a profound connection between divine justice and the moral state of the world. The text highlights that every individual must engage in this spiritual battle, relying on God's assistance, as the ultimate goal is to achieve the completeness of God's name through the defeat of evil.

passage_content: וז"פהכתוב ה' איש מלחמה שהקב"ה הוא בעל מלחמה כמ"ש מלחמה לה' בעמלק מדור דור, ותכלית מלחמה זו ה' שמו, שיהי' השם שלם. שאין השם שלם עד שימחה שמו של עמלק כולו, ולזה הקב"ה מסייע לכל איש מישראל ללחום עם שרו של עמלק הוא הס"מ הוא היצה"ר כדי שנזכה לבחי' ה' שמו, והשי"ת יעזור שבימינו נזכה לזה להיות שמו וכסאו ית' שלם.
translation: And here it is written: "The Lord is a man of war," for the Holy One, blessed be He, is the Master of war, as it is said, "War to the Lord against Amalek from generation to generation." The purpose of this war is the name of the Lord, that His name should be complete. The name is not complete until the name of Amalek is entirely erased. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, assists every man of Israel to fight against his minister, which is the Sitra Achra, the evil inclination, so that we may merit the aspect of the name of the Lord. May the Blessed One help that in our days we merit this, that His name and His throne should be complete.
summary: The passage emphasizes that God is portrayed as a warrior, engaged in an ongoing battle against Amalek, symbolizing the forces of evil and the evil inclination (yetzer hara). The ultimate goal of this struggle is to achieve the completeness of God's name, which can only be realized when Amalek is entirely eradicated. It highlights that God assists every Jew in this spiritual warfare, aiming for the fulfillment of His name and throne in the world. The text expresses a hope for divine assistance in achieving this completeness in our times.

passage_content: ויאמרה' אל משה הנני ממטיר לכם לחם מן השמים ויצא העם ולקטו דבר יום ביומו, לכאורה תיבת לכם כמיותר, גם מה שאמר ולקטו דבר יום ביומו תיבת דבר מיותר וצ"ב, ובמדרש (הובא בישמח משה) הים ראה וינוס מה ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם וצ"ב.
translation: And Hashem said to Moshe, "Behold, I am raining down for you bread from the heavens," and the people went out and gathered a thing day by day. At first glance, the word "for you" seems superfluous, and also what it says, "and they gathered a thing day by day," the word "thing" is unnecessary, and it requires explanation. And in the Midrash (brought in Yismach Moshe), "The sea saw and fled" — what did it see? Israel coming with the possessions of Egypt in their hands, and it requires explanation.
summary: In this passage, the Divine promise to Moses about providing manna from heaven highlights the concept of daily sustenance and reliance on God. The seemingly superfluous words "לכם" and "דבר" suggest a deeper significance, emphasizing the personal and specific nature of God's provision for the Israelites. Additionally, the reference to the sea fleeing upon seeing the Israelites with the spoils of Egypt illustrates the power of faith and the miraculous nature of divine intervention in the face of adversity. This reflects key Hasidic themes of trust in God's providence and the transformative journey of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ונקדיםלבאר מאמה"כ (בפ' בא) דבר נא באזני העם וישאלו וגו' פי' רשיז"ל אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, בבקשה ממך הזהירם על כך. שלא יאמר אותו צדיק אברהם ועבדום ועינו אותם קיים בהם, ואחרי כן יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם ודקדקו המפורשים דתיבת בהם שהוכפל שני פעמים מיותרים, עוד הקשו בקשה זו למה כיון דכל אדם להוט אחר ממון ונפשו של אדם מחמדתן, גם מה צורך לטעם זה כדי שלא יאמר אותו צדיק, וגם בלא זה יקיים השי"ת הבטחתו.
translation: And we will precede to explain from the verse (in Parashat Bo) "Speak now in the ears of the people, and they shall ask..." The explanation of Rashi is that "now" is only a term of request, a plea from you to warn them about this. So that the righteous one, Abraham, should not say, "And they will serve them, and they will oppress them" is fulfilled in them, and afterwards they will go out with great wealth, which is not fulfilled in them. And the commentators have noted that the word "in them" is repeated unnecessarily twice. Furthermore, they questioned this request, why, since every person is eager for money and the soul of a person covets it, what need is there for this reason so that the righteous one should not say this? And even without this, the Holy One, blessed be He, will fulfill His promise.
summary: The passage discusses the request made by God to Moses to warn the Israelites to ask their Egyptian neighbors for valuables before leaving Egypt. It emphasizes the importance of this request as a means to prevent the righteous Abraham from claiming that God's promise of wealth was unfulfilled, highlighting the theological concept that divine promises must be upheld in a way that aligns with human understanding. The repetition of the word "בهم" (in them) suggests a deeper significance, indicating that God's actions are meticulously planned to ensure that His covenant with Abraham is honored. Ultimately, it reflects the Hasidic belief in the interplay between divine providence and human agency in the fulfillment of God's promises.

passage_content: וכלאלה באחת יתבארו בהקדם מה שהקשה התבו"ש על מ"ש הרמ"א ז"ל (סי' תרפ"ב ס"א) דאם שכח לומר על הנסים בבהמ"ז, כשמגיע להרחמן יאמר הרחמן הוא יעשה לנו נסים וכו', והתבו"ש דחה דין זה וטעמו דאין להתפלל שיעשה לו נס, והביא ראי' מהא דאמרינן בגמרא (ברכות ס' ע"א) היתה אשתו מעוברת ואמר יה"ר שתלד אשתי זכר הרי זה תפילת שוא, ופריך מהא דכתיב ואחר ילדה בת שדנה לאה דין בעצמה וכו' מיד נהפכה לבת, ומשני אין מזכירין מעשה נסים, ואי נימא דמותר להתפלל שיעשה לו נס, עדיין תקשה דאמאי הוי תפלת שוא הרי יכול להתפלל שתלד זכר בדרך נס, אלא וודאי שאין להתפלל על נס.
translation: And all of these will be clarified in advance regarding what the Tzavah Shalom questioned on what the Rama, of blessed memory, wrote (Orach Chaim 582:1) that if one forgot to say "Al Hanisim" in the Grace After Meals, when he reaches "HaRachaman," he should say, "The Merciful One should perform miracles for us," etc. The Tzavah Shalom rejected this ruling and his reason is that one should not pray for a miracle to be done for him. He brought a proof from what we say in the Gemara (Berachot 60a) that if his wife is pregnant and he says, "May it be Your will that my wife gives birth to a male," this is a prayer in vain. And it is questioned from the fact that it is written, "And afterward she gave birth to a daughter," as Leah herself said, etc., immediately she was turned into a daughter. And the answer is that we do not mention miraculous deeds. And if we say that it is permitted to pray for a miracle to be done for him, it would still be difficult why it is considered a prayer in vain, since he could pray for her to give birth to a male in a miraculous way. Rather, it is certainly not appropriate to pray for a miracle.
summary: The passage discusses the debate regarding the permissibility of praying for miracles, specifically in the context of the blessing after meals (Birkat Hamazon). It references the Rema's ruling that one can invoke God's ability to perform miracles if one forgets to mention "on the miracles." However, the Tzafnat Paneach argues against this, citing that praying for a miracle is considered futile, as demonstrated by the Talmudic example of a man praying for a son when his wife is pregnant, which is deemed a prayer without purpose. The underlying theological insight emphasizes the importance of recognizing the natural order and the limitations of human prayer in relation to divine intervention.

passage_content: והישועותיעקב מתרץ שיטת הרמ"א ז"ל עפי"ד המדרש בפסוק אל תירא אברם אנכי מגן לך שכרך הרבה מאוד, הכל יודעין שאנכי מגן לך, והכוונה בזה דהנה אמרו רז"ל (שבת דף ל"ב ע"א) שאם עושין לאדם נס מנכין לו מזכיותיו. אמנם כשהנס מפורסם ועי"ז נתקדש ש"ש הנה ניתוסף לו זכות חדש בשביל קידוש השם, וז"ש אל תירא אברם מכח נכיון הזכות ע"י הנסים, כי אנכי מגן לך והכל יודעין שאנכי מגן לך, וע"כ שכרך הרבה מאוד וכו' וע"כ על נס מפורסם לרבים ראוי להתפלל כדי שיתקדש שמו ית' עכ"ד, והנה במסכת תענית (דף כ"ד ע"א) מבואר דאסור להנות ממעשה נסים גבי מעשה דאלעזר איש בירתא שנתמלא אוצרו חטים בדרך נס ואמר לבתו הרי הן הקדש עליך ואין לך בהן אלא כאחד מעניי ישראל, וכתב רש"י ז"ל משום דמעשה נסים הוא ואסור לאדם להנות ממעשה נסים כדאמר לעיל (דף כ' ע"ב) ואם עושין לו נס מנכין לו מזכיותיו
translation: And the salvation of Jacob explains the opinion of the Rema, may his memory be blessed, according to the interpretation of the Midrash on the verse "Do not fear, Abram, I am your shield; your reward is very great." Everyone knows that I am your shield, and the intention here is that our Sages have said (Shabbat 32a) that if a miracle is performed for a person, his merits are diminished. However, when the miracle is publicized and thereby the Name of Heaven is sanctified, a new merit is added to him because of the sanctification of the Name. Therefore, it is said, "Do not fear, Abram," regarding the diminishing of merit through miracles, for I am your shield, and everyone knows that I am your shield; therefore, your reward is very great, etc. And thus, for a public miracle, it is appropriate to pray so that His Name, blessed be He, is sanctified. Thus it is explained in Tractate Ta'anit (24a) that it is forbidden to benefit from miraculous acts, as in the case of Eliezer of Birtah, who had his storehouse filled with wheat through a miracle and said to his daughter, "Here they are consecrated to you, and you have no more than one of the poor of Israel." And Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote that it is because it is a miraculous act, and it is forbidden for a person to benefit from miraculous acts, as stated above (20b), and if a miracle is performed for him, his merits are diminished.
summary: הישועות יעקב מסביר את שיטת הרמ"א על פי המדרש, שמדגיש את חשיבות קידוש השם כאשר מתרחש נס. הוא מציין כי כאשר הנס מפורסם, האדם מקבל זכות חדשה, ולכן אין לחשוש מהפחתת זכויות בעקבות הנסים. בנוסף, הוא מתייחס לאיסור להנות ממעשי נסים, כמו במקרה של אלעזר איש בירתא, כדי להדגיש את הצורך לשמור על ענווה ולזכור שהנס אינו נועד להנאה אישית.

passage_content: אמנםעפ"י המבואר בדברי הישועות יעקב דאם הוא נס מפורסם ונתקדש ש"ש על ידו אין מנכין לו מזכיותיו, אפשר דבכה"ג מותר להנות ממעשה נסים והנה בענין הרכוש שהוציאו ממצרים הי' ג"כמעשה נסים, כפי' רש"י וישאלום אף מה שלא שאלו מהם היו נותנים להם, ואמרז"ל במס' בכורות (דף ה' ע"ב) אין לך כל אחד ואחד מישראל שלא היו עמו תשעים חמורים טעונים מכספם וזהבם של מצרים, וא"כ א"א להנות ממנה ומחויבים להקדישו ומה ירויחו עם הרכוש, אמנם באם לקחו הרכוש רק להשלים רצון הבוי"ת א"כ אדרבה יתוסף זכותם ושפיר הותר להם להנות ממנה, וע"כ אמר השי"ת שענין השאלת כליהם לא יהי' לכוונת תועלתם כי אז יאסר להנות מהם. רק כוונת השאילה יהי' למען יקוים מאמר השי"ת אל אברהם, וע"ז בוודאי צריך אזהרה רבא שלא יכוונו להנאת עצמם וישליכו תאות נפשם מנגד, רק יכוונו למלאות רצון השי"ת שיקוים הבטחתו אל אברהם, וז"ש דבר נא באזני העם אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, בבקשה ממך הזהירם על כך. היינו שלכוונה זו יהי' השאלה כדי שלא יאמר אותו צדיק וכו', וממילא יהי' מותר ליהנות מהם אף כי הוא מעשה נסים ולא יהיו מחויבים להקדישו, וזהו אמרו כדי שלא יאמר אותו צדיק, ועבדום ועינו אותם קיים בהם דייקא, ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם, כי אינו שלהם ומחויבים להקדישו, ולזה יבקש מהם שיהי' כוונת השאלה רק לעשות רצונו ית' ולהרבות כבוד שמים ולא בשביל תאות וחמדת הממון. ועפי"ז יתבאר המדרש דהנה ידוע דעל הים הי' קטרוג גדול מה נשתנו אלו מאלו, אולם כאשר ראה שר של ים ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם דייקא, דהיינו שהוא שלהם ואינם מחוייבים להקדישו, ומזה מוכח אשר כל כוונתם הי' למען יתקדש ש"ש, ע"כ וינוס כי עי"ז נסתמו פיות המקטריגים.
translation: Indeed, according to what is explained in the words of Yeshuos Yaakov, if it is a public miracle and sanctified by the Holy Name through it, one does not diminish from his merits. It is possible that in such a case it is permitted to benefit from acts of miracles. And behold, regarding the property that was taken out of Egypt, it was also an act of miracles, as Rashi explains, "And they will ask of them," even for what they did not ask, they would give to them. And our sages said in Tractate Bekhorot (5b) that there is not one of Israel who did not have ninety donkeys loaded with the silver and gold of Egypt. Therefore, it is impossible to benefit from it, and they are obligated to sanctify it. What will they gain with the property? However, if they took the property only to fulfill the will of the Blessed One, then on the contrary, their merit will increase, and it is permitted for them to benefit from it. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said that the matter of asking for their vessels should not be for their own benefit, for then it would be forbidden to benefit from them. Rather, the intention of the asking should be so that the word of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to Abraham will be fulfilled. And for this, there certainly needs to be a great warning not to intend for their own enjoyment and to cast aside the desires of their souls, but rather to intend to fulfill the will of the Holy One, Blessed be He, so that His promise to Abraham will be fulfilled. This is what is meant by "Speak now in the ears of the people," for "now" is only a term of request, a request from you to warn them about this. This means that the intention of the asking should be so that the righteous one will not say, etc., and consequently, it will be permitted to benefit from them even though it is an act of miracles, and they will not be obligated to sanctify it. And this is what he said, "So that the righteous one will not say," and "And they will serve them and oppress them" is fulfilled in them precisely, and afterwards they went out with great wealth is not fulfilled in them, for it is not theirs and they are obligated to sanctify it. And for this, he will ask of them that the intention of the asking should only be to do His will and to increase the honor of Heaven, and not for the desire and greed for money. And according to this, the Midrash will be explained, for it is known that at the sea there was a great accusation, "What distinguishes these from those?" However, when the minister of the sea saw that Israel was coming with the property of Egypt in their hands precisely, meaning that it is theirs and they are not obligated to sanctify it, from this it is proven that all their intention was for the sake of sanctifying the Holy Name. Therefore, he fled, for through this the mouths of the accusers were sealed.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine providence and the permissibility of enjoying the spoils taken from Egypt, emphasizing that if the Israelites' intention in asking for these items was to fulfill God's will and honor His name, they would not be obligated to dedicate them. It highlights the importance of pure intentions in fulfilling God's commandments, suggesting that their actions should not stem from personal desire but rather from a desire to glorify God. The text also addresses the spiritual implications of their actions, indicating that their sincere intentions would protect them from accusations and affirm their righteousness in the eyes of God. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that true fulfillment of divine will leads to blessings and the sanctification of God's name.

passage_content: והנהאמרו חכז"ל (יומא דף ל"ח ע"א) כל מה שברא הקב"ה לא ברא אלא לכבודו, כי מכל הנבראים שבעולם יש ללמוד מציאות השי"ת וגדולתו, כי חכמת הפעולה תעיד על פועלה כמבואר בחובת הלבבות שער הבחינה, וכמ"ש השמים מספרים כבוד א"ל ומעשה ידיו מגיד הרקיע יום ליום יביע אומר וכו', כי בהתבונן האדם מעשה השי"תוברואיו הנפלאות חדשים לבקרים, יגיע אליו היראה וההכנעה, וכמו שמצינו באברהם אבינו ע"ה שמזה הפליא עצה והגדיל תושי' להאמין במציאות השי"ת ואחדותו והשגחתו, אמנם כ"ז יועיל לבני עלי' אשר המה מועטים, כי לאשר הוטבע כן בטבע לא יתפעל האדם מחמתם, ולזה צריך התבוננות גדול ועמקות נפלא, לאשר הוא רגיל בתמידות אינו מתפעל ממנו כאשר ביאר זאת בחובת הלבבות בטוב טעם באריכות, אולם כאשר יקרה איזה דבר ניסיי חדש מה שחוץ לטבע, הנה זאת תפעול התעוררות גדול בלב הרואים לידע כי לה' הארץ והטבע וכל אשר בה.
translation: And behold, it is said by our sages (Yoma 38a) that everything the Holy One, blessed be He, created, He created only for His honor, for from all the creations in the world one can learn about the existence of the Blessed One and His greatness. For the wisdom of the action testifies to the One who performed it, as explained in the Duties of the Heart, Gate of Reflection. As it is written, "The heavens declare the glory of God, and the firmament shows His handiwork; day unto day utters speech" (Psalms 19:1-2), for when a person contemplates the works of the Holy One, blessed be He, and His wondrous creations, new every morning, he will come to fear and humility. And as we find with our forefather Abraham, may peace be upon him, from this he was amazed and greatly strengthened in his belief in the existence of the Blessed One, His oneness, and His providence. However, all this will benefit the righteous, who are few, for those who are naturally inclined will not be affected by it. Therefore, great contemplation and profound depth are needed, for one who is accustomed to it continuously will not be moved by it, as explained in the Duties of the Heart with good reason and at length. However, when a miraculous event occurs, something beyond nature, this will greatly awaken the hearts of those who see it to know that to the Lord belongs the earth and the nature and all that is in it.
summary: הקטע מדגיש כי כל מה שברא הקב"ה נברא לכבודו, וכי כל נברא מעיד על מציאותו וגדולתו של השי"ת. חכמת הבריאה מעידה על הפועל, והאדם, בהתבוננותו במעשי ה' ובנפלאות הבריאה, יכול להגיע ליראה והכנעה. עם זאת, יש צורך בהתבוננות עמוקה כדי להרגיש את השפעת הבריאה, ובמיוחד כאשר מתרחשים ניסים חורגים מהטבע, דבר שמעורר את הלב להבין שהכל שייך לה' והטבע הוא חלק מהבריאה שלו.

passage_content: והנההמן שהמטיר השי"ת לישראל מן השמים הי' דבר ניסיי היפך הטבע, כי הטבע מחייב להצמיח לחם מן הארץ ולא מן השמים, ולפי"מ דקיי"ל אסור להנות ממעשה נסים איך אכלו ישראל את המן, אמנם לפי האמור דכאשר יצמח קידוש השם ע"י הנס אז מותר להנות ממנה א"ש, כי באמת אין לך קידוש השם גדול מזה שהוא לגמרי היפך הטבע עד קצה האחרון ועי"ז יכירו וידעו כל באי עולם כי ה' הוא אלקים משדד הטבע, וזהו אומרו הנני ממטיר לכם שיהי' לעצמכם ותוכלו להנות ממנו, הגם כי הוא לחם מן השמים והוא דבר ניסיי ואסור להנות ממעשה נסים, ע"ז אמר ויצא העם ולקטו דבר יום ביומו דייקא, כי מן המן ידעו לספר כבוד השי"ת, ודברי נפלאותיו ישיחו בכל יום ויום, כענין אמרו יום ליום יביע אומר, אשר מזה יהי' קידוש השם גדול מאוד, ועי"ז מותר להנות ממנו כדברי הישועות יעקב והבן.
translation: And behold, the manna that the Holy One, blessed be He, rained down for Israel from the heavens was a miraculous thing, contrary to nature, for nature requires that bread be produced from the earth and not from the heavens. According to our understanding, it is forbidden to derive benefit from acts of miracles; however, as stated, when the sanctification of the Name arises through the miracle, then it is permitted to derive benefit from it. Indeed, there is no greater sanctification of the Name than that which is completely contrary to nature to the utmost extent, and through this, all the inhabitants of the world will recognize and know that the Lord is God, who overturns nature. And this is what He says: "Behold, I am raining down for you," that it should be for yourselves and you will be able to benefit from it, even though it is bread from the heavens and it is a miraculous thing, and it is forbidden to derive benefit from acts of miracles. To this, it is said, "And the people went out and gathered, each day according to its day," precisely, for from the manna they knew to proclaim the glory of the Holy One, blessed be He, and His wondrous deeds they would speak of every day, as it is said, "Day to day utters speech," which will lead to a great sanctification of the Name, and through this, it is permitted to derive benefit from it, as stated by the Yeshuos Yaakov and his son.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous nature of the manna provided by God to the Israelites, emphasizing that it defies natural laws, as bread typically comes from the earth rather than the heavens. It asserts that enjoying the manna is permissible because it serves to sanctify God's name, demonstrating His power over nature. The act of collecting the manna daily allows the Israelites to recognize and proclaim God's glory, leading to a significant sanctification of His name. Thus, the miraculous sustenance becomes a means for spiritual elevation and public acknowledgment of God's sovereignty.

passage_content: ויאמרה' אל משה הנני ממטיר לכם לחם מן השמים וגו' למען אנסנו הילך בתורתי אם לא, פירש"י ז"ל הילך בתורתי, אם ישמרו מצות התליות בו שלא יותירו ממנו ולא יצאו בשבת ללקוט עכ"ל והרמב"ן ז"ל העתיק דברי רש"י ז"ל וכתב עליו ואיננו נכון אבל הוא כמו שאמר המאכילך מן במדבר וגו' ולמען נסותך להיטיבך באחריתך כי נסיון הוא להם, שלא יהי' לאדם מזון ולא יראו להם עצה במדבר, רק המן שלא ידעו מתחלה ולא שמעו מאבותם, ויורד להם דבר יום ביומו וירעיבו אליו, ועם כל זה שמעו ללכת אחרי השם לא מקום לחם, וככה אמר להםעוד וזכרת את כל הדרך וגו' ולמען נסותך לדעת וגו' התשמור מצותיו אם לא וכו', והוליכם במדבר וכו' ושלא יהי' להם לחם רק מן השמים דבר יום ביומו לנסותם ולהטיב להם באחרונה שיאמינו בו לעולם עכ"ל הרמב"ן ז"ל, ולשני הפירושים צ"ב בלשון הפסוק הילך בתורתי, דלפירש"י הי' לו לומר הישמרו מצותי, גם לדעת הרמב"ן שהנסיון בענין האמונה קשה ג"כ הלשון הילך והול"ל למען אנסנו אם יאמינו לדברי, עוד יל"ד למה הוצרך הכתוב להזכיר דבר והפיכו הילך בתורתי אם לא, ומובן מאליו שהמציאות הוא דבר והפיכו דאל"כ אינו בגדר נסיון כלל, ומלות אם לא המה מיותרים.
translation: And Hashem said to Moshe, "Behold, I am raining down for you bread from the heavens," etc. "In order to test them whether they will walk in My Torah or not." Rashi, of blessed memory, explained: "Whether they will keep the commandments that are dependent upon it, that they should not leave over from it and that they should not go out on Shabbat to gather." Thus far the words of Rashi. And Ramban, of blessed memory, copied Rashi's words and wrote upon them: "And this is not correct, but it is as the one who feeds you in the wilderness," etc. "And in order to test you to do good for you in your end," for it is a test for them, that a person should have no food and they should not see any counsel in the wilderness, only the manna, which they did not know at first and did not hear from their forefathers, and it descends to them a thing day by day and they are hungry for it. And with all this, they listened to go after Hashem, not for the sake of bread. And thus He said to them again: "And you shall remember all the way," etc. "And in order to test you to know," etc. "Whether you will keep His commandments or not," etc. "And He led them in the wilderness," etc. "And that they should have no bread except from the heavens, a thing day by day, to test them and to do good for them in the end, that they should believe in Him forever." Thus far the words of Ramban. And on both interpretations, it is difficult regarding the language of the verse: "Whether they will walk in My Torah," for according to Rashi, it should have said: "Whether they will keep My commandments." Also, according to Ramban, since the test is regarding faith, the language "whether they will walk" is also difficult, and it should have said: "In order to test us if they will believe in My words." Furthermore, it is necessary to understand why the verse needed to mention "a thing" and "whether they will walk in My Torah or not," when it is self-evident that "a thing" is a test, for otherwise it is not considered a test at all, and the words "if not" are superfluous.
summary: The passage discusses God's provision of manna in the desert as a test of faith and adherence to His commandments. It highlights the dual purpose of this divine sustenance: to ensure reliance on God rather than earthly provisions and to instill a deeper understanding of His laws. The text raises questions about the phrasing "if not," suggesting a deeper exploration of the nature of faith and obedience. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of trusting in God's guidance and the spiritual lessons derived from reliance on heavenly sustenance.

passage_content: ב)ביום הששי לקטו לחם משנה וגו' ויבאו כל נשיאי העדה ויגידו למשה ויאמר אליהם הוא אשר דבר ה' שבתון שבת קודש וגו' פירש"י מכאן יש ללמוד שעדיין לא הגיד להם משה פרשת שבת שנצטווה לומר להם והי' ביום הששי והכינו וגו', עד ששאלו את זאת, אמר להם הוא אשר דבר ה' שנצטויתי לומר לכם, ולכן ענשו הכתוב שאמר לו עד אנא מאנתם ולא הוציאו מן הכלל, ובמד"ר (פר' כ"ה סימן י') ויותירו אנשים ממנו וכו' מיד ויקצוף עליהם משה, כיון שכעס שכח לומר להם שילקטו ביום הששי שני עומרים לאחד, כיון שהלכו ולקטו ביום הששי ומצאו כפלים, באו הנשיאים ואמרו למשה וכו', וע"ז נאמר עד אנה מאנתם שהוא מכניס משה בכללם עכ"ד המדרש, והקשו המפורשים מדוע לא אמר להם מצות השבת מיד ביום הראשון, שהרי ירד להם המן בראשון בשבת תחלה כדאי' בגמ', ואז היה עדיין לפני הקצף שהותירו ביום הב'.
translation: On the sixth day, they gathered a double portion of bread, and all the leaders of the congregation came and told Moses. He said to them, "This is what the Lord has said: a day of rest, a holy Sabbath," etc. Rashi explains that from here we learn that Moses had not yet told them the section of the Sabbath that he was commanded to say to them, "And it shall be on the sixth day, and you shall prepare," etc., until they asked about this. He said to them, "This is what the Lord has commanded me to tell you." Therefore, the text punishes him by saying, "Until when will you refuse?" and he did not exclude himself from the group. And in the Midrash (Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 10), it states, "And some men left over from it," etc., immediately Moses became angry with them. Since he was angry, he forgot to tell them to gather on the sixth day two omers for each person. When they went and gathered on the sixth day and found double, the leaders came and said to Moses, etc. For this, it is said, "Until when will you refuse?" which includes Moses among them. Thus far the Midrash. The commentators questioned why he did not tell them the commandment of the Sabbath immediately on the first day, since the manna descended for them on the first Sabbath, as stated in the Gemara, and then he would have still been before the anger regarding what they left over on the second day.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the discussion revolves around the Israelites' collection of manna on the sixth day and their subsequent inquiry about the Sabbath. The text highlights the importance of divine instruction regarding the Sabbath, emphasizing that Moses had not yet communicated this commandment until prompted by the leaders. The anger of Moses reflects a deeper theological insight into the necessity of obedience to God's commandments and the consequences of doubt among the people. This narrative illustrates the tension between divine revelation and human understanding, underscoring the significance of faith and adherence to God's will.

passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם קושית המפורשים ז"ל מדוע לא ירד המן בשבת, כמו שהקב"ה מוריד גשמים וטללים בשבת, ואמרז"ל במד"ר (בראשית פי"א ס"ה) טורנוסרופוס הרשע שאל את ר"ע אם כדבריך שהקב"ה מכבד את השבת אל ישב בה רוחות, אל יוריד בה גשמים, א"ל אמשול לך משל לשנים שהיו דרין בחצר א', אם אין זה נותן עירוב וזה נותן עירוב שמא מותרין לטלטל בחצר, אבל אם הי' אחד דר בחצר הרי הוא מותר בכל החצר, אף הקב"ה לפי שאין רשות אחרת עמו, וכל העולם כולו שלו מותר בכל העולם כולו, וה"ה כרה"י עיי"ש במד"ר, וכמו"כ מה"ט הי' יכול הקב"ה להוריד המן בשבת, וי"ל שנשבת המן בשביל ישראל, דנאסר להם לקיטתו משום תחומין והוצאה, כדרשתם ז"ל (עירובין י"ז ע"ב) אל יצא איש ממקומו, אל יצא עם הכלי ללקוט המן, ועיין בתוס' שם דתרווייהו משתמעי מיני' הוצאה ותחומין.
translation: And it is possible to answer the question of the commentators, why the manna did not fall on Shabbat, just as the Holy One, blessed be He, brings down rain and dew on Shabbat. And our sages of blessed memory said in Midrash Rabbah (Genesis 11:65) that the wicked Turnus Rufus asked Rabbi Akiva if, as you say, the Holy One, blessed be He, honors Shabbat, should not winds blow on it, and should not rain fall on it? He replied, I will give you a parable of two people who lived in one courtyard; if one does not provide an eruv and the other does provide an eruv, perhaps they are permitted to carry in the courtyard. But if one person lived in the courtyard, he is permitted throughout the entire courtyard. So too, the Holy One, blessed be He, since there is no other authority with Him, and the entire world belongs to Him, is permitted throughout the entire world. And the same applies to a private domain, as stated there in Midrash Rabbah. Likewise, for this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, could have brought down the manna on Shabbat, and it can be said that the manna ceased for the sake of Israel, for it was forbidden for them to gather it due to the laws of boundaries and carrying, as our sages of blessed memory expounded (Eruvin 17b), "Let no man go out from his place," let him not go out with a vessel to gather the manna. And see in the Tosafot there that both aspects of carrying and boundaries are implied.
summary: The passage discusses the reason why manna was not provided on Shabbat, contrasting it with God's provision of rain on that day. It emphasizes that while God could technically provide manna, He chose not to in order to honor the sanctity of Shabbat and to prevent the Israelites from violating the laws of carrying and boundaries. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine providence and the observance of Shabbat, highlighting the importance of rest and spiritual elevation on this holy day. Ultimately, it illustrates the concept that God's authority and the sanctity of Shabbat take precedence over the need for physical sustenance.

passage_content: והנהאמרז"ל יומא (ע"ה ע"א) כתיב ירד המן עליו, וכתיב ויצא העם ולקטו וכתיב שטו העם ולקטו, (פירש"י ירד המן עליו אלמא בתוך המחנה הי' יורד, וכתיב ויצא העם ולקטו יציאה מחוץ למחנה משמע, וכתיב שטו משמע למקום רחוק) הא כיצד צדיקים יורד על פתח בתיהם, בינונים יצאו ולקטו, רשעים שטו ולקטו עכ"ד הגמ', ולפי"ז הי' אפשר שירד המן לצדיקים, דליכא לגבייהו איסור תחומין והוצאה, שירד על פתח בתיהם, ואפשר דמפני שלא הי' רוב הדור במדריגה זו, ע"כ לא ירד אף לצדיקים משום לא פלוג, אמנם אלמלי הי' כל ישראל במדריגה זו שירד להם המן על פתח אהליהם, הי' יורד המן גם בשבת.
translation: And behold, our Sages of blessed memory said in Yoma (38a) that it is written, "The manna descended upon him," and it is written, "And the people went out and gathered," and it is written, "The people strayed and gathered." (Rashi explains that "the manna descended upon him" implies that it fell within the camp, and "the people went out and gathered" implies going outside the camp, while "the people strayed" implies going to a distant place.) How so? The righteous had it descend at the entrance of their homes, the average ones went out and gathered, and the wicked strayed and gathered. Thus far the Gemara. According to this, it was possible for the manna to descend for the righteous, as there was no prohibition of boundaries and carrying for them, since it descended at the entrance of their homes. It is possible that because the majority of the generation was not on this level, therefore it did not descend even for the righteous, due to the principle of "not distinguishing." However, had all of Israel been on this level, that the manna would descend at the entrance of their tents, it would have descended even on Shabbat.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of the manna that fell for the Israelites in the desert, highlighting the different experiences of the righteous, the average, and the wicked. It suggests that the manna could have descended directly to the homes of the righteous, as they were not bound by the prohibitions of carrying on Shabbat. However, since the majority of the generation did not reach such a spiritual level, the manna was not provided in this manner, emphasizing the principle of "no distinction" among the people. The text implies that had all of Israel attained a higher spiritual state, the manna would have fallen at their doorsteps even on Shabbat.
